GTX 660 Ti is basically a handicapped GTX 670, with fewer ROP's and smaller memory bus of the GTX 660. I decided to get GTX 600 series card rather than a Radeon 7000 series because Nvidia has a more stable average FPS. Even with higher FPS on AMD, Nvidia may look smoother because the average FPS is more consistent. Maybe AMD will fix that in the future. GTX 660 is a better value because for $100 less you get 10%-15% less performance. Many have OC GTX 660 Ti to 670 performance.

The card is very quiet especially compared to the Radeon HD 4870 I replaced. I won't compare the cards any further because they are generations apart. You may not get to go with ultra settings at high resolutions in today's most demanding games, but graphics look very good at the high setting.

This product is what i've looking for years. I have several print servers in my closet because no one worked well with my printers. Finally this product solves the problem with the bi-directional protocol you need with modern printers. It is like a USB port sharing throught the network, so the devices connect to your computer like there are connected to your USB local port. The sharing is not at the same time, you have to connect and disconnect your devices so other users can use them. It has two features that helps you sharing among other users: one feature is for printers, that connects and disconnets the printer on demand, so other users don't have to request it, and the second is for other device types, you can request the other user to disconnect the device if you need it.     This product is for home networks, or very small offices.    The only thing that prevented me to put 5 stars is the speed, of course it is not like the native USB port, because you use IP protocol and then a wireless adapter, that's far from 400 Mbps.    One last thing: the hub itself is not wireless, like it says at the box, and many other reviwers noted, but at least you can connect it to your Access Point independently of the Wireless technology. If you migrate from your old b or g to the new N, you don't loose your HUB.

I'm a trackball fan. In my tech cupboard you'll find two prized Microsoft Intellimouse Trackballs -- and I mean the really stodgy, ovoid 1990s model issued in sexy beige and grey. While they may have looked like artificial kneecaps, they sure worked! These old, well-used gadgets serve less today as go-to gear than reminders of being spared in an early brush with carpal tunnel. I've never since found a design as comfortable. They saw me through the composition of a 12-volume reference set and, more happily, countless games of Quake II.

The Orbit under review here is a pretty good replacement. I'll start with what I can praise: fit. Over time in my average-sized hand, I've stopped noticing it. That for me is a baseline measure of any I/O device's success. It becomes invisible, as it should. I've never noticed any soreness or irritation, whether sitting or standing. Well done, Kensington, on this score.

Next, I have to take points off for both the cheaply-made buttons and the lame ring-based scrolling mechanism. The buttons misfire occasionally due to their clunky construction. And compared to another more successful ring-shaped scroller -- the touchpad on my elegant Logitech diNovo Edge keyboard -- this implementation's way too fussy. Far too often you track, but it doesn't.

A warning about the included USB dongle. If you break or lose this tiny fingernail-sized receiver, your $50 trackball is toast. So I learned tonight when inquiring if I could buy a spare so I wouldn't have to constantly relocate mine between systems. While this may be understandable (the pairing is done uniquely at the factory) it also reveals the manufacturer simply doesn't care about longevity. Bluetooth would have been a far better idea for extending the life of what will, in too many cases, become a disposable product.

So there you have it: a comfortable shape with moderate-to-iffy construction featuring a partly-workable scrollingmechanism, all of it tied for its survival to a 25-cent irreplaceable dongle by a manufacturer that will throw its hands up if something happens to yours. I don't need to add that I doubt this trackball will be around nearly as long as its predecessors.
output: Good enough, but beware irreplaceable dongle

[[ASIN:B000PEF254 Lexar Professional UDMA - Flash memory card - 8 GB - 300x - CompactFlash]]  I use a a Canon 5D and love Lexar cards. From the first digital camera I had many years ago, I always got better response from the Lexar one as compared with other brands. First it was 4X, then, 8X then 16X, then 40X, then 80X, then 133X, now 300X. My cameras went from 3.3 MP then several 8 MP, now 12.8 MP so there was a need for faster and larger cards. Well Lexar has kept up. I now have 5 of the 8GB 300X. I still use the 8 GB 133X as well as some 40 and 80X cards. The difference I notice is down loading my images to my computer, the 300X is way faster with a proper card reader. Even with the express card reader on my laptop in the field the 300X card downloads the 8 GB faster. Also when shooting a burst of pictures, whether its getting the right image at sporting events or a bird in flight, with either my Canon 20D or now the Canon 5D, I never have to wait for the files to write to the cards.    I like the peace of mind that comes from the quality of Lexar products. I spend a lot of time, effort, and money getting the images and the thought of loosing them due to card problems is unimaginable. I also no doubt will be getting the Canon 1DS Mark IIII  in the near future, and like the idea than the cards I am now using will be fast enough to keep up with the 21 MP camera. So no regrets.    Well off to Alaska with my Lexar cards,    Albert Mach Fine Art & Custom Framing

I just got these glasses this morning and I've been using them for about five hours. I debated whether to give these four or five stars, in large part because I don't have anything to compare these against (other than my naked eye).    The first thing you will notice is the way they warm up the screen. I use a 24\\" LCD that has a fluorescent backlight ([[ASIN:B000QEITJE Samsung SyncMaster 245T 24\\" LCD Monitor]]) and the difference is best described as going from a fluorescent light to an incandescent.     The glasses have a yellow tint, but once I wore them for a few minutes and compared the glasses/no-glasses view, the no-glasses view felt cold and harsh.    Second, they are light. As a non-glasses-wearing type, I worried a bit about how they would feel, but they are fine.    Third, they fit snugly, but not tightly. This is a total bonus, since your face is probably different than mine.    Finally, a comment about the price. I paid $99 through Amazon. It felt a bit expensive, but I rationalized it as such: I stare at a computer about 12 hours a day during the week and about 5 hours a day during the weekend. This is about 3600 hours a year staring at a screen. If they last me a year, I will have paid 2.75 cents per hour of use.
output: Very comfortable and eases long stretches of computer use

My EZDigimagic DM220P08 is awesome.  I have had my SD burner for over two years and commend the Digimagic people for making it easier to store my photos, and not clog up my hardrive.    When I first got it, I had to have the technician walk me through the steps of inserting the SD card and what button to push, as I have a disability that makes reading the computer jargon instructions difficult.  The EZ PnP Tech. people are very accomodating, and helpful!    After I placed the SD chip in the front slot, and placed the CD in the carrier, which looks just like the CD player carrier on your PC or Laptop, and when the DM220P08  had formatted and booted up and was convinced that the CD was ready it went to town, it copied all 150 photos in just about 4-5 minutes, it then initialized the disc, beeps, and spits out a completed CD.      For general shooting, I just use a CD, and it can accomodate four burns on a one gig SD chip before telling you to switch out the CD for a new one when full, and completes the burn.  It automatically picks up at the end of the last burn, and starts the next installment, and makes a new folder that shows up on your computer's hard drive area as a EZPnp disc icon.  So when you click on the icon, it shows how many burns you have on that CD/DVD.    So all you DSLR users with monster 24mp cameras out there with your 16 gig chips in your cameras, you will just have to use DVD's for your massive storage needs.     DVD's are incredible though, I have only filled one so far, and that was when I shot tons of photos while in Salt Lake City last Thanksgiving.  I was doing a Missionary a good deed and taking some shots of his home and family for a Christmas present to him.  I shot over 300 6mp full res shots, and it barely even bothered the CD, I could have placed two hundred more shots on that one.    I take it everywhere I go for photo shoots!  And with just four DVD's I can down load a ton of shots that would otherwise have crashed my hard drive, and by formatting the chips, can take another ton of shots.  I have a cheapy plastic CD file box with all my photo Disc's, and there are over two thousand shots with the name of the shoot written with a sharpie on the CD/DVD's for simple identification .    There is only one drawback that kept me from giving it a five star rating, and that is you can't play the CD or DVD's on the home TV in your DVD player, so without owning the DM220P08 and having the patch cords, you will have to view them on your gift CD/DVD's on your PC or Laptop.     By the way! It is as small as a portable CD player and fits anywhere for trips and photo shoots.    So until EZ PnP people get permission to be able to make a burner that is CD/DVD to TV DVD player compatible, you will just have to view the shots on your PC or Laptop.

Instances.input: I work from home, and I use this computer for everything. I wanted to find a computer that I could travel with, and to replace my old Gateway notebook. I was leaning towards Toshiba throughout my online research, but when I saw this in the store, I was intrigued. It is a beautiful design (resembling a Mac), the screen is the perfect size, and it is light-weight. I drive around a lot for my job, and carry this computer around with me comfortably. I was amazed at how fast it starts up, granted I removed some bloat-ware. I recommend removing the pre-installed anti-virus software from any new computer. I also use this computer for basic internet functions (Facebook, e-mails, browsing), but I also watch a lot of movies and TV shows, too. I bought a VGA cable to connect to the plasma TV, and the picture looks great (compared to my boyfriend's older laptop). The video card is just amazing. I think watching a movie through my computer on the TV actually looks better than watching a DVD.    The only complaint I have about this notebook, which is true for all newer HP notebooks, is the touchpad. It's not easy to scroll webpages sometimes, and the sensitivity varies. Sometimes it is hard to select by tapping, and other times, I accidentally click on something because it is too sensitive. I would recommend getting a wireless mouse, and disabling the touchpad. Overall, I am very impressed with HP's effort. I bought the computer for $600 at Best Buy, which I thought was a pretty good deal. It's super fast, has great picture quality, and serves all of my needs. I definitely recommend this computer.

Only downside is that the "briefcase" strap is on one side which makes it feel awkward when carrying it.  However this is only an aesthetics issue as the bag allows for much versatility.  A second "briefcase" strap on the opposite side would fix this.  There is room for papers if you don't mind folding them or creating bends on one side, not suitable for folders.  Actually, this mini-messenger bag is the MODERN FANNY-PACK; perfect for the on-the-go traveler who needs to carry cash/cards, phone, iPad, chargers, passport, etc.

Instances.input: Very happy with the product.     I've bought two of these devices to build a wireless bridge to the media room to feed TCP/IP to DirecTV DVR and Popcorn Hour NMT. The bridge works flawlessly, and is very fast at ~200Mbit/sec. I also run a  MacBook Pro off the access point part of the bridge over 5GHz wireless-N with stable connection and no issues whatsoever.    The device is well designed, with nice touches abound. It looks stylish with piano black finish on the sides and clear lucite panel in front, and fits nicely on a typical book shelf. There are two Ethernet ports in the back so if you have only two devices, you won't even need a switch on the bridge end. The genius touch is that you can turn off all LEDs on the box, including both front panel power/traffic and rear panel port status LEDs, so there is no annoying blinking in a darkened room!    I understand that the lack of wireless-G and 2.4GHz range may be limiting for some people but I don't have this problem.
Great clarity and easy to use.

[[ASIN:B0018O9JIG IOGear USB 2.1 Bluetooth Micro Adapter GBU421]]    I paid $12.83 for this adapter and am now able to play games with a Wii remote on my PC. I was able to set it up very quickly, the drivers were a smooth install, and it gets the job done with no noticable lag. Certainly worth the price, I highly recommend this thing.    Just remember to press Alt+S to skip the password page if the thing you're trying to connect to your PC doesn't have a password(like a Wiimote). I had to Google around for that bit of information, couldn't find it in the manual or anything. I also have to reconnect the Wii remote every time I wanna use it, but that's really just a software issue.

This is exceptionally easy to use. No installation required. It comes with a CD with the user's manual on it, but, unless you are a caveman, there's no need to use that. Just plug it in (required 2 USB ports) and press burn, and your DVD is on its way. Easy. Made great DVDs.

First off, this is a great keyboard. Nice and large, big keys, and plenty of space between keys. It was easy to connect with Bluetooth to my Nexus 7. If you're looking for a keyboard, Logitech is a great choice.

I was looking something to match the incredible [[ASIN:B007PRHNHO Logitech Keyboard Cover for iPad]], which is pretty much a perfect device. I wanted a similar keyboard scaled to a Nexus 7. I tried out the [[ASIN:B008QJXPGS Keyboard Case For Nexus 7]], but the leather case part adds hugely to the thickness, and it did not have Logitech quality.

I *expected* this keyboard to be about as wide as the Nexus 7 is long. I should have looked at the measurements. This keyboard is almost twice as long as the Nexus 7. This is a huge, full-sized keyboard. It is in no way, shape or form compact. It's large enough that two of them could serve and a jumping ramp for a Mini Cooper. If you're looking for a nice compact keyboard, learn from me mistake.

The carrying case is well made. This is a great, fully functional keyboard. If you're looking for something big, this is a five star product. If you're looking for something you can carry in your jeans pocket, this is a three star product.

Logitech -- copy your own design for the iPad case and scale it down.
output: Huge.  Not Compact.  Bigger than I expected.

2) The flakey connectivity that other reviewers have mentioned has now affected my cable as well. Given that this cable is 10ft long it is going to bend and flex a lot over time. As have many, over the years, I have purchased several inexpensive protectors for different phones and, like many, I have never received defective products or experienced any difficulties in their application.       Given its positive reviews, and guarantee, I purchased this moderately costly protector with high expectations. I followed the application directions to a \\"T\\"; the protector fit perfectly but suffered two bubbles about the size of a pencil eraser, about one-half inch from the edge - bubbles that cannot be squeegeed off and seem to be permanent. As they are at the edge of the viewing area they pose no visual problem; their presence nags, nevertheless.    What does present as a problem, however, is that the film has stippling defects (looks like an orange peel) within the visible screen area. The defects are annoying because they reflect light from the screen as does a gem stone, i.e., they sparkle as the device is moved. I should think that the manufacturer ought to be able to produce sheets without such defects, especially given their cost.    In its enclosed literature, the manufacturer entreats customers to contact them before writing a negative review on Amazon, assuring customers that they will \\"promptly rectify the issue and do what we can do to earn a positive review.\\" While a laudable and reasonable request, it is not worth it to me to expend my resources (time, energy, and money) to seek to rectify the issue.    Over the years, I have purchased a few two- or three-protector packs for different phones for a couple for bucks each. None of them had visible defects, they all applied easily without serious bubbles, and never suffered from excess scratching; and I have the remaining protectors as replacements if/when needed. When needed, I will do the same for the Fire HD and get a two- or three-protector pack at a cheaper cost than this Skinomi - and - apart from saving money, I probably will not be able to tell the difference. My advice, purchase theinexpensive two- or three-protector packs here at Amazon as this Skinomi is no better than the inexpensive ones, came defective whereas the inexpensive ones were not, and the inexpensive ones do the same job.    Ed
output: Defective and did not perform as advertised.

This product works as expected. If there were any faults with this product, they were due to my own, amateur skills at applying a laptop screen protector for the first time. Other than that, the touch screen ability on my laptop did not suffer, even with the few dust particles that managed to make their way into the screen protector. It is still touch sensitive, with little to no inaccuracies when it came to where I touched the screen. There is hardly any resistance when it came to dragging my finger along the surface of the screen protector, especially while playing the Windows tablet games. Overall, it is a satisfactory product that has met my expectations.

One thing to note to anyone who also plans on getting this screen protector: it's going to take some patience in order to get the screen protector as perfectly aligned with as few air bubbles and dust particles coming in as possible. Before buying this product, I suggest looking up a YouTube video on how to apply screen protectors to laptops in order to get a solid technique. If possible, the better option would be to ask a professional to apply the screen protector for you.

Instances.input: great product to use.

This hub is admittedly expensive. Its price of $55 (at Amazon.com as of February 29, 2012) is about 45% more than the price of a competitor's USB 3.0 4-port hub, which Amazon.com also sells (for $38.88 as of February 29, 2012). If you don't plan to connect printers and scanners or other power-hungry devices through the hub, the competitor's hub will probably satisfy your needs. However, if you plan to connect power-hungry devices, I highly recommend this hub, despite its substantially higher price, or any competitor's hub with similar specifications. I believe that with this hub, you can rest assured that whatever USB 3.0 or USB 2.0 device you connect to the hub, the device will work.

Before buying the U.S. Robotics hub, I contacted the manufacturer to inquire whether the hub would support power-hungry USB 2.0 devices. The manufacturer's representative assured me that the hub would do so. The representative stated that the manufacturer had tested the hub on a broad range of USB devices varying in power requirements. Furthermore, the representative stated that if the hub did not support a USB 2.0 device, I could return the hub to the manufacturer (during the warranty period) for a refund of my purchase price if the retailer (Amazon.com in this case) would not refund the price for any reason.

Previously, I purchased and used another manufacturer's USB 3.0 4-port hub. The hub's adapter has an output rating of 2A. Unfortunately, the hub would not support certain power-hungry USB 2.0 devices that I used. Thus, I had to continue to use my USB 2.0 hubs for those devices and to carry a USB 2.0 hub with me along with the USB 3.0 hub when on the road to be certain that whatever USB 2.0 device I might want to connect through a hub would work.

On February 23, I purchased the U.S. Robotics hub in the hope that it would support all my USB 2.0 devices. It has proved itself in every way. With the U.S. Robotics hub, I can retire my USB 2.0 hubs and carry only one hub with me on the road. The U.S. Robotic hub's adapter has an output rating of 4A, twice the other hub's output. U.S. Robotics states that the output at each port is 900mA for USB 3.0 devices, the maximum allowed for such devices. Presumably, the hub's output is 500 mA for USB 2.0 devices, for which the maximum allowed is 500 mA.

My USB 2.0 devices that work on the U.S. Robotics hub and did not work on the other manufacturer's hub are: (1) Canon PIXMA Pro9000 Mark II color-photo printer, (2) Epson Perfection V750-M Pro scanner, (3) HP Color LaserJet CP3525dn printer (643 w. max), and (4) Kodak i1220 scanner. A USB 2.0 HP LaserJet P2055dn (570 w. max) works on both hubs. My Western Digital USB 2.0 and 3.0 hard drives also work on both hubs.

I prefer the U.S. Robotics hub not only because it supports all my current USB 3.0 and 2.0 devices, but because U.S. Robotics has thoroughly tested its hub to support many USB 2.0 devices and has assured me (with an oral money-back guarantee, as noted above) that the hub will work with any USB 3.0 or 2.0 device. The adapter's output rating of 4A and 900mA at each port for USB 3.0 devices gives me the confidence that enough power will be available at each port to support any USB 3.0 and 2.0 device I may use in the future.

If you can find another hub whose adapter has an output rating of 4A, that provides 900 mA of power to each port for USB 3.0 devices when all four ports are in use, that has been similarly tested, for which the manufacturer provides a similar assurance, and at a lower price, by all means, purchase that hub. I would so so, too. While the U.S. Robotics hub meets my needs now, if a competitor makes available a similar hub at a lower price, even if the U.S. Robotics hub's price may decline over time, I would not hesitate to purchase the competitor's hub. Until such time comes, I recommend the U.S. Robotics hub so you won't have to be concerned that some devices may not be supported by the hub.
output: Adequate power for power-hungry USB 2.0 devices

If you are a mobile technology warrier, this product is for you! First off, do not mess around with the i5 versions, and invest the extra money on this solid platform based on the latest i7 technology. Though I was initially disappointed that the memory was soldered to the motherboard and not field upgradeable, there were so many other things I just loved about this product.

First, it is less than 2 ounces heavier than the Macbook Air, so this is not really a major factor. The graphics are wonderful, and one of the best aspects is how Asus is willing to standard behind their product with a 1-year Accidental Damage Protection (ADP) policy FREE (!!!) that covers your investment in the event of an unforeseen accident. I am sure the Best Buy sales folks don't explain this one when they push their warranty!!!

Next, the box is loaded with everything you need to make the most of this product ... unlike the Macbook Air where you have another $100-150 of investment. Items that were absent from the \\"What's in the box\\" include a VGA Adapter and a USB-to-Ethernet Adapter. The computer also has a USB 3.0 port (side), as well as a USB 2.0 one (left side). Be careful here ... I immediately reloaded my Zen in a tri-boot configuration of Windows 7 Ultimate, CentOS and Backtrack 5R2. Windows will NOT load if you connect your external DVD to the USB 3.0 port, as the PXE does not recognize the port and you will get errors about missing drivers and you will not see the SSD drive. Once Win7 was initially loaded, I did visit the Asus site to download all the relevant drivers. With CentOS, Ubuntu and Backtrack ... no drivers were required, as these OS's recognized everything out of the box.

The built-in WLAN adapter (Broadcomm) works with Backtrack 5R2, but does not support injection, but can be placed in monitor mode. This is not a major problem, as I have found this to be the case with many laptop/netbook WLAN adapters - so I always carry an extra WLAN NIC just for the occasion!

Battery life appears to be more than sufficient - especially if you put Windows in Power Saver mode. Once everything was installed, the machine worked like a champ!

This product is thin, light, and very durable, and will be a great compliment to my Macbook Pro when traveling without adding much to the tote!
output: This is the tool for the "Mobile Technology Warrier" - Great for field testing with Backtrack

For much of what I would have thought the Kindle could do, it does so well.  Books in an eBook format (either from Kindle store on Amazon, mailed and converted PDF (best option for most PDFs), uploaded MOBI and converted/uploaded EPUB (both using Calibre) are easy to read.  Three problems.  First, PDFs are almost impossible to read.  The screen is too small to read a whole page at a time, and the zooming and cropping are poorly designed (I need to enlarge 110%, 120%, 130%, NOT 150%) and the scrolling when enlarged makes the document unreadable.  It should be smooth, or have that as an option.  [Solved--problem was in the leather cover, which was replaced by Amazon w/o cost to me.  Cudos] Second, my Kindle [no longer] locks up all the time, and will not turn on to normal reset sequences.  It takes some cryptic combination of long (>15s) and shorter (until the light comes on again) use of the switch to get it to come back to life.  This happens nearly every time, and totally resets the device (\\"reboots\\").  Finally, the way it tracks how far read is fine for non-fiction, but if your book includes an appendix at the end, it will always take you to that, rather than as far as you have always read, even if you only visited the appendix once or twice.  All that aside, it is handy.  I have switched to using Kindle software on an Asus Transformer tablet which is a much more enjoyable experience in all but bright sunlight, in which case the old Kindle shows the huge advantage of eInk.

The iRulu loses connectivity after about 12 feet distance from the router. Even sitting next to the router, I only got 2 of 3 bars on the WiFi indicator. Going to businesses that offered wifi connections was not much of an improvement.
2) Touch screen is ineffective. Even after calibrating the screen several times, I still had issues with it recognizing touch, whether it was finger or stylus. I don't have similar issues with prior tablets or my smartphone.
3) Tablet is slow. It take 1.5 minutes to pull up Facebook and other apps, and is slow transitioning between apps. Getting several \\"not responding\\" prompts.

Save your money, and buy a better tablet.

I've only had the monitor for about a day now, but I was so impressed by it that I just ordered another one. The contrast and clarity is truly amazing. I've used many different LCD monitors and while my favorite continues to be the Apple 20" Cinema display, this is now my 2nd favorite (and as I am getting accustomed to the pivot feature, the Apple display may be in trouble...). Yes, it comes with a pivot display mount that not only allows you to raise, lower, tilt and turn the montior to any position imaginable, it also lets you rotate the screen 90 degrees to portrait mode. Unlike the more expensive rotatable monitors that have an 'auto-sensing' thingie which automatically switch your display output between portrait and landscape based on the position of the monitor, this one requires you to use a software utility (included) to manually select the orientation of the output. To be honest, I didn't even realize this was a feature on this monitor. I based my initial purchase decision on the manufacturer specs and price. Since this was intended to replace a 21" Sony CRT on my development PC, image quality was secondary to form factor and price. I was very pleasantly surprised by the quality of the display and I was extremely pleased to discover the rotation feature.

I was originally going to mount this monitor on a VESA arm, but after using the included stand, I'm having second thoughts. The stand itself is the best that I've ever seen on an LCD monitor. It allows for good cable management and almost infinite adjustability while not presenting a huge footprint.

Anyway, so far, this seems to be an outstanding monitor for the price (actually cheaper than many crappier 17" LCDs I've seen). Though, you do need to shop around for the best price since I've seen it range from $549 to $800+. It's unusual to see such a wide range in the street price. I ended up getting it from Amazon because with the free 'super saver free shipping', it came out to be darn near the best deal (and I've had nothing but good experiences with Amazon so far).

Conclusion - do NOT buy one of these monitors! At this price and value, you NEED to get at least two (dual monitor setups are shweeeeet!!). :-)be darn near the best deal (and I've had nothing but good experiences with Amazon so far).

Instances.input:
Pros:
- Blazing fast speed
- Super-easy Setup
- Remote access from anywhere
- Prettiest UI ever on a router
- Free phone apps
- Better looking design than a Netgear or D-link
- Cutting-edge Cloud goodness

Cons:
- Bigger physically than previous generation of routers (still smaller than other AC routers)
- Although the HW design is more attractive than competitors, it is not quite as sleek Cisco's less powerful EA4500.
- Did have to reboot a couple times in recent weeks (or is this a Pro, because it can done remotely from Cloud app?)
- Speed Test gives very different speeds than reliable services like TestMy.net

My Experience:
Previously I had an EA4500, which was fantastic. But, in thinking ahead to future electronic device purchases, it seemed like an AC router was needed to \\"future-proof\\" my home.
Initially I purchased the Netgear AC router because it was the only one available. It was respectable for speed, but I sorely missed my Cisco Cloud apps, so the second the EA6500 came out, the Netgear got returned.

Performance:
Fast, really fast. I only have all N devices at home now, so I'm looking for even more impressive stuff when I add AC devices. There were a few times when the speed bogged down, and a reboot was needed. Since this the first rev of new router technology, I'm not to put off by this. (Cisco has already released some patches with improvements.)

Recommendation:
Buy this router if you value performance, think HW &SW should be a thing of beauty, and have a mindset capable of embracing the awesomeness that is the Cloud. Keep firmware auto-update ON, and you should years of stable use out of this router.

All HDD are not exact at what they advertise. This is not a terra and I think every terra byte will not have exactly 100,000 gigabytes available. You are forgetting the memory that needs to be required for the HDD to function. This was very easy installing it to the PS3. It gave me 860 gigabytes which is quite an awful lot than the usual 500 bytes that local retailers offer on their systems.

Here are some hints as to installing the hard drive.
Save all saved games, music, videos, and photos unto a hard drive with a usb that can be read by the PS3.
Next, take off the tab under the PS3, there is a blue screw hidden within a small tab. The PS3 that I bought was from this year so it is different than the others where the tab is located on the side.
Then, pull down a clip that you will see once you slide the black tab to the right. Take off the four screws that hold the HDD in place. Make sure not to damage the screws. Then put in the new HDD of your size.
Turn on the PS3 and make sure that your PS3 control is connected through the USB to your PS3.
You will need a USB flash drive that needs to have an update of 4.25.
Go to the playstation website to download this file. As soon as you have it on the flash drive hook it up to the PS3 and the system will read it and start to format and create a new PS3 HDD.
VERY EASY TO DO!!!!!
Excellent product I recommend

output: Really pleased, Came in authentic packaging and works great

Instances.input: I have a 15.4 screen size laptop which is actually about 14\\" long. Based on the other buyer feedback I bought this size (15\\").  It fit just right, not too hard to get the laptop in and not too baggy.

This tablet is fantastic. I moved from a Wacom that served me faithfully for almost ten years, and I was really nervous about getting something new, but the Ugee M1000L is quite adequate. My personal favorite things about it:

1. It can be switched from right-handed to left-handed, so I can have my shortcut keys on the right.
2. Every button/key can be customized, and there are SO many of them! Very useful and handy.
3. The customer service I received when I was having trouble setting up was very good. Ugee was polite, quick to respond, and provided screenshots and instructions to help me.
4. Excellent sensitivity in the pen - I use my tablet to draw in Photoshop so having pressure sensitivity for the pen width is important. It's also nice to be able to customize one of the pen buttons to change it to "eraser mode".

Things that could be improved:

1. The instructions are a little hard to understand; they read like they were generated in another language and a non-native speaker approved the English version. I was confused a couple of times by them because of poor sentence structure or vague terms.
2. All of the customizable buttons already have pictures next to them describing what the default setting is, which is nice if you're not going to change any of them, but not so nice if you customize them a lot (e.g., I have to remember that the button labeled "Close Window" is now my "Shift" button). I'm sure I'll get used to looking at one thing and having it do another, but I also might just try to rub off/color with a marker on the ones I've changed.
3. The driver CD that came with the tablet did not have the most recent driver, which caused a little confusion in the beginning for me because the tablet control panel looked different than in the instructions. If Ugee keeps updating their drivers, they shouldn't bother putting outdated drivers into the tablet package and just have people download straight from the website, as I had to do.

The cons are not enough to keep this from being a 5-star product. I love it and hope to use it for ever and ever.

One last tip - be ABSOLUTELY SURE that you completely uninstall any other tablet drivers/software on your computer, including Ugee software. I ran into some trouble while installing because different drivers were clashing with each other.

You can run an E8400 or Q9505 in this small form factor PC. So while the other Atom-based units are the same size, the power that you can get from this unit is head and shoulders above them. The unit uses a laptop-like power block so there is no power supply inside the box, so no fan required for this. So the unit is incredibly quiet. It has a specially designed heatsink that keeps the temperature down by having two small and quiet fans extracting the air out through the heatsink.  The unit can hold a Slim DVD/CD as well as two 2.5\\" drives, in piggy back style, or three drives if you wish. The unit comes with the small sized power/sata connector, which you need for a slim DVD drive - you don't have to buy one. I am running Vista 32 bit on it and it works a dream with a fairly reasonable score of 4.1 for the onboard graphics. You can't add a graphics card so you have to be happy with these figures or don't buy it.   The unit doesn't have a VGA output, so you need a DVI to VGA adapter if this is required, hardly an issue other than additional length added to the rear. The front of the unit has a large circular power button, blue led lit. Below this is a small orange LED for HDD activity.  Unless you are sitting it flat you need the stand or VESA mount adapter. You can buy a VESA mount adapter specifically for this model, which I bought and screwed into my desk shelf, alternatively there is a stand that keeps it vertical and allows a gap at its base to allow air flow. You can't stand it on its side directly on a surface because the air flows through one side and out the other. The top, front, and back are sealed - Block one side off and cooling will be ineffective.  Completely happy with this unit bar one issue which I believe is poorly thought out by Shuttle. The cooling heat sink still uses push pins, why would they use push pins when they are building the unit themselves? Why not have fixed nuts below the motherboard and allow the heat sink to be screwed down and thus maximise not only cooling contact but also stability. Considering most people will mount this unit vertically, the heat sink ideally should be screwed in. Otherwise excellent, it is a small powerful PC which uses 90W instead of the usual PC power supply, say 350W+. So big difference in power useage with this. The only reason you wouldn't buy one is for gaming, the lack of graphics options may put you off. Also the price, face it, this is a motherboard mounted in a case with a power supply. You could buy a case and motherboard and save $50 at least. Also this unit only takes 65W processors, you can't put a big quad in it, it has to meet the 65W requirements. The Q9505 is the largest quad you can throw into it.   So really it is the size that sells it. Other things to consider, the plastic doors on the front open for USB port and headphone/mic access. They look good but they are cheap plastic, I don't use them but I would imagine if you did, they wouldn't have a long life. Also if mounting this sideways, the DVD has to be inserted vertically, so if the tray doesn't have a pinch type holder to press the DVD into, you aren't going to use it much. I plugged my full sized drive into the PC installed software and then removed it. From then on I can just use a USB portable DVD drive to install software if required. I can then kill of the DVD setting in the BIOS and get a quicker boot time with the HDD being the only drive onboard.

{For Force GT 120Gb) Bought a second of of these and set them up in RAID0. Now I get 1Gb/s seq read/write... insane speeds. Both times I bought this I tested the speeds and found I got exactly the advertised read/write speeds. When using a single drive I tested again a few months later (Using TRIM, at this time no RAID) and had absolutely no drop in performance speeds. I expect some degradation over time now because RAID doesn't support TRIM yet, but I am ok with secure erasing every 3 months or so until them come out with TRIM RAID support.

For those slightly less tech savvy: this drive is VERY VERY fast, and is Well worth the money. You will absolutely see a difference in load speeds, especially in time it takes windows to load and time to open programs. Note, setting up and installing this device does require a little bit of research and work (secure erasing, firmware update if necessary), so if you know nothing about computers be cautious buying this.

Again, this drive had outstanding speeds in both AHCI and RAID modes. Could not be happier.

Another important thing to note: the latest firmwares 1.3.2/1.3.3 have vastly improved issues from previous versions.
I have NEVER gotten a single BSOD from these ssd's, in both AHCI and RAID setups.
I ran in 1.3.2 for half a year on the single drive, recently updated my older drive to 1.3.3 and bought another already at 1.3.3 for the raid setup.
Again, never a single BSOD (-my overclocking fails)

You will love this drive!
Amazing! It worked exactly as promised! And, it was the right one on the first try! How often does that happen?

True, it took a few weeks to get my typing speed (88wpm) back up, but in the end, it has been worth every missed key.  I don't use braces, creams, or splints (though I do frequently stretch my hands/wrists, as we're all supposed to when typing for long periods).  I've been so happy using this, my company even purchased one for our Executive Assistant, and she too is elated that her wrist and hand pains are disappearing.  Sure, it's $299, but think how much those doctor visits and round-the-clock Ibuprofen are costing you, not to mention the constant discomfort.  Without a doubt, worth every penny.

I bought this modem due to a positive experience with an earlier version SurfBoard 5100. The thing was over 20 years old and still going strong! I upgraded because I could only get 25 Mbps download speed when I was paying for 50 Mbps.

**Please note that this is a CABLE modem and may not work with DSL service. Consult your ISP re: compatibility.

I've had this modem for two weeks now and it works flawlessly. Setup was a breeze...it took me less than 10 minutes: ~2 minutes to connect to my Airport Time Capsule, then ~6 minutes to login to ISP site and complete new modem configuration process. The documentation included is easy to follow if you're less experienced and need a step by step guide to help you get up and running.
I average download speeds of 57 Mbps which exceeds the advertised speed for my service tier by 7 Mbps. My upload speed is right on target at 10 - 12 Mbps. I'm very pleased with the modem's performance.

Based on my experience and other reviews, I do think Motorola made a batch of defective modems. Download speeds with the first SB 6141 I received were EXTREMELY SLOW at 1 to 2 Mbps. I spent 3 days trying to troubleshoot the problem with Comcast and Motorola. I even called Apple to see if my new router may have been causing the problem. It turns out I had a defective modem despite the Motorola rep telling me it was impossible for the modem to be the cause of my slow download speeds.

I contacted Amazon to return the modem and I received a new one the next day. I haven't had any problems with the replacement SurfBoard 6141 that I received. I recommend buying from Amazon instead of direct from Motorola because customer service at the latter was suboptimal.

I recommend buying this modem. It's a great device provided you get one that works like it should.
output: SB 6141 Delivers on Faster Speed Promise...if you get a good one

Instances.input: I bought this device to go with a new Windows 7 machine I built.  Plugged the device in, the device drivers seemed to load ok, but in the end Windows failed to recognize the device (it worked with my old XP machine just fine).  I contacted Pluggable support, really not expecting much help and anticipating I'd have to return the unit and buy something else.  Instead, I received a very prompt reply, asking me to run a diagnostic tool and send them the info.  We exchanged several emails, and the support rep was always friendly, helpful and professional.  After about a week, a small package appeared in my mailbox; it was a new unit that the rep had personally tested and setup for me.  Note that I hadn't asked them to do that; they sent me a new unit on their own, without even asking me to return the old unit first.  I plugged the new device into my PC, and it worked like a champ right out of the box!  They then politely asked me to return the old unit so they could examine it, and sent me a link to print a pre-paid address label, so that it didn't cost me anything to return the old unit to them.  I can highly recommend both this device and the company that stand behind it!
output: Works great, and outstanding customer support!

After trying all possible standard recovery procedures that fixed most system crashes from the system 32.dll error, the files from the Windows 7 OS still could not be read. I decided to upgrade and purchase a new computer with Windows 7 and purchase this HDD reader from Cable Matters Company, and it WORKS!!!! No need to open up the computer case to insert the HDD, just plugin this this HDD reader into the USB drive, power on, place the HDD into the reader, and the rest is normal file viewing procedures. My DH got me an iPad for our anniversary last week. I wanted to protect this investment as soon as possible. I went to Target and Best Buy, the cheapest screen protector was $20. That seemed a little steep to me so I went on Amazon and started reading reviews. Some reviews of anti-glare screen protectors said that it blurs the screen. I have the new retina display iPad and this was a concern for me. Not wanting to spend a lot and not sure about the best product, I bought this one as a first try. You get what you pay for. My screen is protected but my first 2 attempts at applying this screen protector left LOTS of bubbles (over 40 bubbles, some quarter size). For the third time, I carefully applied the 2nd screen protector in two inch increments while applying pressure with a credit card to squeeze out the bubbles. I was left with about 10 dime size bubbles all around the edges of the screen (not actually on the display area), I have a jelly silicone case that wraps around the edges so I can't see the bubbles. The anti-glare screen works fine and I can read and see things just fine.

I see this screen protector lasting about a month or two before I will need to buy something better. If I did not have the jelly case, there is no way I could deal with the bubbles.
output: You get what you pay for...ok product

Instances.input:
I bought this to replace my aging bluetooth mouse and keyboard hooked up to my home theater PC. I have been incredibly happy with it. This uses 2 AA batteries as opposed to the 3 my other one took. It lasts a very long time, I rarely have to change it. The touchpad works well and is accurate, even set at a fast speed. I have never had any connectivity issues and setup was easy in windows xp 32 bit. It cost about $30 and to me it's worth $50-60 easy. It's also small and thin so it can be easily tucked away.
Buy this thing.

I bought both this and a PowerGen 10w charger and I couldn't be happier. The 15w model is in my opinion vastly superior to the 10w because of the plug design, it won't ever be half in the wall with exposed prongs. Also this doesn't have an annoying blue LED on it. I don't know if my phone can handle the full 15w but my iPad does and it charges noticeably faster than the stock charger when it's the only thing plugged in. I do wish it was just a split 50/50 design and not 5w/15w because there is no reason not to have the power available on the second port for a phone, that's a minor complaint though. This is a great replacement for iPad chargers but if you don't have a tablet that uses something besides micro-USB don't bother getting this because there is no way your device will be able to draw the full 3Amps, and if it somehow does I don't know how safe I would feel putting that much power through tiny microUSB pins.

So in conclusion great for Apple devices I don't know how well it works with just regular microUSB devices but they should draw as much power as they need and hopefully the manufacturer of your device set the input impedance at something sensible so you don't end up with fried cables
Good product bit flimsy

Have had the G930s for a year and a half now. A month ago, one side stopped working entirely, so Logitech sent me a new set. My experience with Logitech support was really easy, so they've got that going for them.

I use these on a daily basis and here are my general thoughts:
-Comfort: Very comfortable. They breath well, so you can wear them for hours without any discomfort. Easily adjustable, and sleek. My only complaint is that the padding could be a little more comfortable. They're nowhere near as comfortable as my Sony MDR-XB500s.
-Sound: 7.1 is great for games like Counter Strike. I'm not an expert on sound, but they sound pretty good.
-Mic: I loved the mic's functionality for a few months until I broke it. I am pretty gentle with these, so that was a bummer. It no longer stays in the raised position.
-Programmable keys: I've used these almost exclusively for Spotify. You can have spotify running in the background and these will automatically Backward, Play/Pause, Forward your music for you. I use this all of the time, I love it. The volume wheel works as intended.
-Wireless: This is the only wireless headset I've ever owned, so I'm not sure if the issues are specific to this headset or to all wireless headsets. They work perfectly about 90% of the time. At random intervals, the headset will disconnect and reconnect in about 5 seconds. Sometimes the audio becomes fuzzy. The 10% of the time where they're working poorly is extremely frustrating. If you're watching a show, and have to rewind 10 seconds every few minutes, it becomes a real nuisance. These issues have been present with both G930s that I've owned.

Note: These have no wired option. You can plug them in to charge, but it will still work on a wireless signal.

If not for the wireless functionality issues, this would be a great headset. I would recommend getting a wired Logitech headset. The wireless is not worth the unpredictability. I usually like Logitech products a lot, and have nothing but good things to say about similar *wired* logitech headsets.ings to say about similar *wired* logitech headsets.
output: Everything's great except for the (lack of) wireless functionality. Get a wired logitech headset instead.

I run a small computer shop and have installed roughly 100 of these drives in the past couple years. I have yet to have a single failure. WD knows these drives are quality: the 5 year warranty is an industry best.

Most drives include a 2 year warranty if you're lucky due to the likelyhood of mechanical failure in spinning drives. WD however has built a drive to last.

While not nearly as fast as new Solid State HDs, these drives perform well and if going from an older 5400rpm drive you will see significant speed increases when loading the OS and programs.

100% recommended.
output: Top of the Line Spinning Drive, 5 Year Warranty Says it All

This ASUS Transformer quickly became my go to laptop. It arrived with Windows 8.1 preloaded. That Operating System has wormed its features into 3 household computers and ASUS's use is just normal and acceptable for me. It keeps me from having to relearn from computer to computer.

I will, therefore, avoid discussing the elements of Win 8.1 and target the ASUS. I have to remember ASUS is a essentially a laptop with all of its features and some of its drawbacks and a tablet with its large volume of uses. Even though I have not had the time to test every single feature, I will say those that have not been tested are insignificant to my needs. For example, I use the tablet when at home. When on the road, I use a small device that I can leave in my pocket. The front and rear cameras are excellent and of sufficient quality and pixel size to use for almost any need. Keep in mind at this price point, the cameras are a positive addition.

HDMI, Bluetooth and USB outlets provide considerable flexibility in the type of work on my platter. In that regard, almost any data can be input or output via ASUS with its standard keyboard, touch screen and ability to access external drives. The quality of the output is the same on this computer as are the other computers here.

One condition present on the ASUS is a quick charging and slow discharging battery. That's nice. Additionally, the battery is accessible and readily changeable if and when that happens. Its small size suggests that the weight of the computer is the responsibility of the electronics (SSD and other components) and not the battery completely,

Instances.input:
I bought three of these USB 3.0 hubs when I thought there was a problem with the USB on my motherboard. Turns out the problem was the drive controller on my 4 year old motherboard, leading to a new motherboard which has USB 3.0. I'm an electrical engineer and \\"It just works\\" is one of the highest forms of praise for a technical product. I do not have any USB 3 devices to plug into it yet, but the (3) USB 2.0 hard drives that share one of these can each operate at full speed where previously a single drive could saturate the connection.

It comes in a cardboard package (no hard-to-open clear plastic packaging) containing the hub, wall wart (power supply), and they nicely throw in a (short) USB 3 A-B cable. (A-B cables are the kind needed to connect between the PC USB port and a hub.) I loaded the USB 3 driver for my motherboard (ASUS) when installing, so no additional driver was necessary.

When I get a USB 3 device I will update the review.

After 4 years of experience with 15.6in laptop, I think 14in is the best size as a carry-on.

Weight:This Acer laptop is 4.65lb. The battery is equally heavy as the brick so I guess the total weight would be above 6lb. What Acer could improve on is removing dvd drive (they're probably going to do that on the following series) then hopefully lowers the price by $30 or replace with 3.0 USB.

Battery life: I watched a movie with max volume 1hr45min which used 36% battery and music for 1hour with medium volume 21%, wireless was on but monitor was dimmed a little. So I think it can last 4-5hr with normal daily use.

Good features: Keyboard can switch to number pad.Quiet fan and good ventilation. 4 2.0 USB ports all on the sides(my toshiba had 2 on the back which are less useful). 1.3M webcam works good.

Performance: most of the 2008,2009 games are playable in detail graphics, 2010 games, some in high some in medium. (according to Benchmark graphics card) The only game I have tried so far is King's bounty2008. CPU temp went up to 65C, HD 38C in a RM temp that was 45F. In order to keep cool, the fan gets noisier.

My complaints: Some featured software that I don't know how useful they are, however, they definitely slow down the Windows start. MOST FRUSTRATION COMES FROM WINDOWS 7 HOME PREMIUM. COMPATIBILITY ISSUE WITH MANY PROGRAMS I HAVE BEEN USING. SO THE FIRST FEW DAYS,I TRIED TO INSTALL SOFTWARE, ERRORS POP OUT AND CRASHED 4 TIMES. OTHER LANGUAGE PACKS ARE EXCLUDED TO LURE ME TO UPGRADE TO ULTIMATE ($130). FOR BILINGUAL PEOPLE, IT CAN'T BE MORE FRUSTRATING WHEN PROGRAMS CAME OUT WITH ??%%??xx%%xxoo. THE OFFICE 2010 IS STARTER, NO POWERPOINT. MICROSOFT, I KNOW IT COST YOU A LOT MONEY DURING DEVELOPMENT BUT THERE IS NEARLY NO PRODUCTION COST. DON'T YOU WANT TO MAINTAIN MONOPOLY. I'LL PROBABLY INSTALL LINUX WITHIN NEXT FEW WEEKS. ALSO, LET US SWITCH TO OPEN OFFICE. BTW, BRICK GETS REALLY HOT WHEN PLAYING GAMES AND CHARGING.

Updates: The screen goes black then come back when switching between battery and plugin. Firefox always crash when it happens.

Overall, it is an above average laptop with good gaming ability. Portability can be improved, for instance, the brick, the dvd rom.

ps. maybe heavy brick has more longevity???NG.

Instances.input: I've had my kindle for about six weeks now and I have to say Amazon really created a great product. If you strictly want to read books, PDF's, listen to audio books without carrying several cumbersome devices, then do like I did and purchase this product right now. You will not be disappointed at all. The battery life on this thing is absolutely incredible. I've heard people say that their getting 10 days on a charge, I guess i'm lucky because I get at least at least 15 days on a single charge, and I use this thing every day.     The only issue I have with the Kindle is you cant map your buttons, I've been using it enough to the point that I really don't see how this isn't a feature that they considered right off the bat. I get the idea of having buttons on both sides of the kindle for changing the pages, but over time you will find yourself using the kindle in essentially your favourite position. Mine is the standard way with the qwerty keyboard at the bottom. I noticed this after about two days as I was playing a game and had to map my controller, I looked over at my kindle and said It's too bad i cant map that.         TL;DR     Amazon made a great reader but they should have made it so people could map the buttons on it.
output: Great product!!!! But could use a few tweaks

Instances.input: It's a kitchen sink approach to computer builds, but that's the deal with future-proofing (7 yrs. or so) computers. Mounted an Intel i7 5930K six core CPU, 32 GB of RAM, a GeForce GTX 980, and closed-loop liquid cooling for good measure. Likely way more than my wife will need for expansion, but with her use of Photoshop CS and other intensive art software, I felt she needed the elbow room to avoid bottle-necking and allow her to push the envelope when new software does start recognizing multi-threaded, multi-cored CPUs and GPUs more efficiently and intensively. And my advice is not to totally ditch mechanical drives. Get an SSD for booting and programs, the mechanical for backup, videos, pics, and music.In fact, get a couple mechs and throw 'em in a NAS array for giggles. Off site clouds be darned!
output: If you want a system to last without slowing down.

On the one hand, I do fall in line with the open-source geeks, and find it shameful that Linksys didn't provide OpenWRT support as advertised (I have not confirmed this, but I have little reason to doubt it).

However, that aside, this thing is a powerhouse. Coming from a Belkin N+ router from a few years ago, I'm amazed to see the range this thing can transmit, even in a moderately large house. PC Magazine reviews said it runs hot and there is a noticeable electronic odor. All I have to say is a lot of things run hot, including your cable box; this thing by comparison is much cooler, and emits no odor whatsoever (unless you're sniffing around the top, which would be strange in any event).

If you just want the thing to work without hassle, and you can afford this, by all means, buy it. For those of us (myself partially included) who are only after the open-source support, maybe it's a good idea to wait (heck, maybe even build your own Arduino -based solution. I'm wondering if anyone's tried it yet). But for the rest of us laypeople who just need a functioning router, it's an excellent choice.

Immediately flashed this router with DD-WRT for use as a 5.8ghz Bridge.

There isn't a 5.8 bridge w/ switch on the market in anywhere near this price range.

Underclocking the router's CPU and reducing its output power made a significant improvement in performance while acting as a bridge. The unit runs VERY hot with factory firmware/default dd-wrt settings.

Connection is stable at 300mbps on my 5.8ghz network and throughput is great.

Not sure on longevity, but I expect it to last a while given the underclocking of the CPU and reduction in wireless output power.
Can't tell the difference from the original when it was new.  Durability is unknown, but given the 18 month warranty I'm not overly concerned about, especially considering the reasonable price.

The reason I didn't give this 5 stars is because of the construction of the power connector. I plugged a molex connector into this card, but realized that it would not reach the PCIe slot that I needed to install the card into. I rearranged the power connectors inside my computer and when I went to plug in the molex connector a second time, I thought I about broke the power connector off the card. It was held in place by two small plastic pegs near the metal conductors, then two plastic clips near the edge of the card. I guess the force of pushing the molex connector into the card released those clips on the edge and the whole power connector bent back on the metal conductors. It took a little bit of maneuvering to seat it back in place and I think I am lucky that the none of the conductors were broken.

As for the driver installation, I've installed a few add-on cards over the years (USB in old Windows 98 machines, IDE/RAID cards, etc) that include CD's with drivers from multiple vendors. Sometimes you can tell which folder to look in by looking at the chips on the add-on card, but that causes extra work if the card has already been installed in the computer. This installation CD wasn't as bad as it only had 4 vendor folders, and only one contained USB 3.0 drivers, but I think it makes installation unnecessarily confusing to the consumer when the installation CD's are packaged like this.
output: Older computer now has USB 3.0 capability.

Instances.input: There is not enough I can say about this devise. It has completely changed the way i play video games. Initially I was trying to decide whether to purchase the G13 or the Razer Nostromo and i definitely made the right choice. The G13 has many more buttons (I use them all) and the joy stick is not a d-pad with a crappy covering.   Pros:  When I was deciding whether or not to purchase this, there were several reviews that really discouraged me, however, all of them were either wrong or didn't apply to me. The joy stick is not too pointy and actually feels wonderful. The contours of the pad are exceptional (I have medium to large hands). The software is also amazing and simple; drivers worked fine with windows 7. I use every single button on the device playing mmo's which is why this device has to be better than the nostromo. I didn't think i would use the lcd but it has proved very useful. The build quality is great. The tactile feel of the buttons is great.  Cons:  Here are a few minor complaints:  -The joy stick button is almost impossible to press to the point that there is no reason anyone is going to use it (i'm referring to pressing the joy stich itself, not the buttons around it).  -There is currently an issue with the software or drivers that cause the device to become nonfunctional when the computer wakes from standbye. The only remedy to this currently is to resart your computer or unplug and replug the device, however, i'm sure this will be fixed in the next update.  If you are interested in using a joystick for your games this is the device for you. You wont regret it.

Based upon the materials, construction and packaging, it is more pricy then it should be. I do not expect the cushions to last, they seem cheap (thin cloth that is not adhered to the underlying foam). Talking out of the other side of my mouth: I judge that heavy things are of higher quality...but you do not want a heavy stand.

So if the folks at Rain Design are listening: Consider composites (lightweight/strong and good thermal properties), many options will improve the cushions (integrated skins, gels, memory foams (look at keyboard and mouse pad supports)) and tighten-up the pivot to be more 'engineered' (consider that most of us are putting $2,000+ laptops on the stand). We want the stand to be as cool as the highly engineered device we are putting on it. Lastly, take a lesson from Apple on packaging. It does matter. If this is what I pulled out to the box, no complaint on the price.

Summary: It WILL keep the heat off of your legs. It is not sexy.

I purchased this in my pursuit of following the career of Jemima West. Glad I did.

Taking place in Paris immediately following the Franco-Prussian War, the show is steeped in the mores of the period, and it does well in transporting you into that world. The story is centered around a particular government-run bordello, or \\"maison close,\\" named Paradis (I don't know if \\"Paradis\\" existed in history, but the characters at times mention a competing brothel, \\"le Chabanais,\\" which did exist in Paris, and was quite famous).

There is a fair amount of depth to the plot, and if you are paying attention to the subtitles instead of the subtleties, it's easy to miss the facial expressions and mannerisms that help to tell the story, and you're likely to miss some understanding of why characters behave as they do towards one another. At times Maison Close resembles a sophisticated soap opera, but there is an insightful intelligence to it that usually lifts it well above lesser dramas. This series could have been so bad, but the quality of the acting, the sets, and sometimes the dialogue ended up with me giving the season 5 stars.

It's distressing to watch how Rose (Jemima West) is forcibly inducted into the bordello; I imagine how this scenario could have happened given the circumstances in 1871, so I don't have any reason to doubt the portrayal by the screenwriters as anything but realistic for the period.

While the adult nature of the premise ensures nudity, the sexual content here isn't more graphic than what is seen in a typical HBO drama. Speaking of HBO, Maison Close is on par with that level of programming (it aired on Canal+, a French premium cable TV channel).

There isn't much room for humor in Maison Close, but they still manage to pull it off tastefully on random occasions. The most memorable example is a visiting Dr Lombardi who pokes and prods our heroines and then informs them of some conclusions from his research; the good doctor gets his just desserts after presenting his biased, half-baked findings.

Overall, this first season of 8 episodes is a forbidding yet addictive show to delve into. Despite murder, mayhem, and the unfortunate exploitation of prostitution, Maison Close doesn't leave you in a pool of misery after indulging in it.h; the good doctor gets his just desserts after presenting his biased, half-baked findings.

Overall, this first season of 8 episodes is a forbidding yet addictive show to delve into. Despite murder, mayhem, and the unfortunate exploitation of prostitution, Maison Close doesn't leave you in a pool of misery after indulging in it.

The Antec P183 delivers on many of the claims made by the manufacturer while also committing design mistakes that are sure to aggravate purchasers.     The case is certainly quieter than any case I've ever owned that wasn't touted as 'silent', however, true silent computing enthusiasts would not be impressed by the decibel output of this tower 'right out of the box.' Having said that, for the average consumer the case is certainly quiet enough.     Equipped with both standard fans, and an additional after market 'silent' 120mm fan I installed myself, the only sound discernible from the case when placed beneath my desk is an extremely faint hum. Upon moving the tower to my desktop the hum becomes a faintly pulsing white noise that waxes and wanes as the fans rotate. This humming white noise quickly fades into the background unless I expressly focus upon it.    The case has ample room inside to install most any component desired. Extremely tall after market CPU coolers may cause some difficulty, but by and large, clearance should only rarely be a cause for concern.    The P183 suffers from a few small annoyances. The case door swings open to the left - something almost, but not quite, rare enough to be called an oddity - and this can make it awkward to use for some people. The sole reason I make a note of this is because most people I know tend to place their towers to the right of their chairs, either on the floor or on their desk. The reason for this? Perhaps it is because most case doors tend to swing open to the right! This may be an arbitrary comment and may in fact actually be viewed as a positive by some purchasers so your mileage may vary. It took me a few weeks before I quit attempting to open the door in the wrong direction but that may say more about me than it does about the case.    The door, in addition to opening the 'wrong' way, also covers the power button when fully closed. Since the door comes with a lock, this could perhaps be viewed as a securityprecaution, however, there are holes in the door that allow one to bend a finger through and turn off the power without ever opening the door. Why cover the power button when the door is closed if it doesn't prevent anyone from accessing the button? In addition to this, most power supplies have a master power switch that is freely accessible on the back of the case so this button issue is purely a pointless annoyance and nothing else.    The Antec P183 also suffers from a few minor quality control issues. Behind the aforementioned door are a number of small filtered gates that cover the various bays in the case. These gates are designed to add an additional sound buffer and to collect particulate matter that may be sucked through them by the case's airflow. Whether the gates succeed at these two goals is difficult to determine, however, while I can not comment on their noise reduction and filtration I can comment on the build quality.     The very first thing that happened when I attempted to open one of these gates is that it broke away from the case and fell to the floor. Upon closer inspection these plastic gates are held in place by a fragile nub of plastic - considering the rest of the case feels so solidly designed, this fragility truly stood out in a negative light. Luckily, even though the gate has broken off, it can still be clicked in to place and, for the most part, it stays put unless someone attempts to open it.    All in all, this is a solid case. I wouldn't advise anyone pay the full MSRP but if found at $100 - $150 dollars I believe it is a purchase that contains a lot of value.
output: Antec P183 - Overlooked details leave this case rated as 'good' instead of 'great'

Love it. Owner of a Kindle 1, Just got my Kindle 2 and it is everything I wanted 1 to be and more. Wireless, Screen, Size, Weight all excellent and portable.     That being said I do have some negatives:    1. Would have liked an SD slot. These memory cards are ubiquitous so being able to toss one into the Kindle to hold additional books would have been great. 2 GB is a lot, but will quickly fill up based on my experience with the Kindle 1. That being said, Wireless somewhat rectifies this as I can delete and redownload books I am currently not reading.    2. Removable Battery: Would have liked this feature from K1 to carry over to K2.     3. No cover/case. Come on, economies of scale dictate this be a nominal amount on the bottom line. I did order the recommended leather case, and I am certain in the future I will use different cases, but an inexpensive pleather case would have been expected.     So there you go. I love the device and expect to get much use from it. I would have given it a 4 star because of the above 3 \\"problems\\" but i gave it a 5 star to counteract all the boobs who don't have the device and are giving it 1 star because of their issues with Amazon Prime or other such nonsense.

This is light duty Cat5 cable at best, that I wouldn't even use for residential networks. The seller indicates that it is capable of 1000Mbps (Gigabit), and the packaging itself only indicates transfer rates of 100Mbps, a long ways short of Gigabit. The packaging also doesn't indicate if this is Cat5 or Cat5e cable. On top of this, when you contact the seller to return the item, they still want you to pay for return shipping when they clearly falsely represented this product!
I recommend paying a couple of bucks more to get good quality full copper cable from a different seller!

Instances.input:
I bought a 64 GB Transcend SD (SDXC) card, had problems with it on a Vista computer, and sent it back for an exchange.

The second card I received exhibits the same problem.

This SD card arrives with exFAT formatting. It works perfectly in the Windows 8 and Windows 7 computers I have at home.

At my office, I have an older Vista computer. According to the exFAT spec, exFAT should work with Vista as long as Service Pack 1 is installed. Neither of these cards did, however. Instead, there is a message stating the card must be formatted before it can be used. If I try to format it in Vista, NTFS, exFAT and FAT (not FAT32) are provided as options. It won't format the card using NTFS or exFAT and if you format it as FAT, the card only shows about 4 megabytes of memory rather than 64 GB.

I rated this at 3 Stars since I don't have another Vista computer to experiment on. It could be something unique to the one Vista SP1 computer I did try. That computer has no problem reading other cards, though. A Transcend 16 GB (SDHC) card formatted as FAT32 works great, and I've used all sorts of USB flash drives, compact flash cards and so forth without any problems for years.

I had intended to use this Transcend card to transfer large video files back and forth from home to work, and also to backup my music collection. I wasted $47, and I see the price has since gone UP to $55.

I'd suggest trying another brand.
output: My Vista Service Pack 1 Computer Won't Read Or Format This Card

Instances.input:
I've used pretty much every portable tool... smart phones, net books, laptops, and several other tablets.
The thing that makes this tablet different is the S Pen digital stylus. You can write and draw on this tablet as
efficiently as you do on paper. Unlike using a stylus on a capacitive screens, the S Pen tip glides smoothly
and accurately on the glass ... like pen on paper. So you can take notes or sketch out diagrams easily. No
other stylus-tablet combo worked for me.

The handwriting recognition (converting my chicken scratch to text type) works fabulously. And a huge bonus is the ability
to have multiple programs open at once... so I can read or watch video and take notes at the same time.

Compare CPU specs and screen resolution all you want. The Note works great for all the other things (like music,
web, video and books). Maybe you can see the difference side by side in a store.... but no other tablet I tried works this
well for note taking or drawing. My other 3 tablets are now collecting dust.
output: The S-Pen makes this tablet a real productivity tool

I picked it up at The UPS Store. Took it out of the box, turned it on, saw that it was charged. The wireless indicator was all bars.  I scanned the instructions, pressed home, selected Time magazine and a book, and had them in the machine in less than 20 seconds each.     Then I started reading them.  (While in the parking lot where I had picked it up moments before.)    First impressions:    1) My Kindle was preregistered and said \\"Welcome Randy\\" on an early screen, and was ready for me to buy stuff.    2) I own the Sony PRS-500 and 505, and the screen is the same quality, as well as page-turn speed. The buttons are very different and better...the turn page button is 5 inches long, the \\"turn page back\\" button is a half inch long. This makes much more sense than Sony's minimal equal-sized buttons.    3) The fonts are MUCH MORE PLEASING. Sony basically has one font and three sizes, this has much more and look better designed for this kind of screen (rounded serifs, etc)    4) It has a dictionary you can go to when you don't know a word (Sony doesn't).    5) Bestsellers are $9.95, compared to $16.95 Sony.    It's too new for me to go further, but I'm very surprised and impressed so far.    There is more white plastic (not puke-yellow like in the photos you've seen for a few months) around the screen than Sony has, and the Kindle is much thicker, but still lightweight. Yet holding it is easy, and the \\"next page\\" button being practically the whole right side of the book is ideal.    The wireless connectivity, the interaction with the internet on the screen, takes this out of Sony's reach.    I honestly didn't expect to be be buying books within minutes of opening the package, before I even got home from picking it up. WOW!    THIS DEVICE IS FOR AVID READERS ONLY...so much negative comes from non-readers that want it to play movies, tv, radio, audio books. This device is to replace text-oriented store-bought books...and not much more. So yes it sucks as an HD movie player. whatever! If you read constantly, want to aquire books from thin air on a whim, the Kindle is for you.    Add-on note: The size of the device (at its largest) is EXACTLY the size of an unopened DVD--that can't be a coincidence...all 3 dimensions.    UPDATE A MONTH LATER: I'm hooked on several blogs delivered several times a day (I wssn't a blog reader before). I'm reading MUCH more, carry this thing with me everywhere I go. I've found I'm a more adventurous reader...I try the free first chapters and am reading many more books I wouldn't have tried before.    I read a lot of criticism of this product by many that have never used it. So many of these negative 'reviews' seem to be based on such small concerns, its like hating a car for its hubcap design.    This thing has changed my life. I went from avid reader to voracious.    Adding the blog reading, and spending odd hours going to the web browser on a whim...I hope the $399 price doesn't stop someone from such an important device. Books popping into a device instantly, with FREE internet access...I haven't touched my Sony 500 and 505 readers since I got this thing.    (Yes, I still read 'normal' books, magazines, and newspapers--the Kindle is another option that has expanded my reading world)
output: My first half-hour with the Kindle

If you are trying to find an inexpensive wireless adapter for your Linux computer, this works very well. I had a computer with Fedora 13 Linux wired to an ethernet cable and wanted to be able to move the computer anywhere in the house. I unplugged the ethernet cable and pluged the [[ASIN:B002VX0GJY 802.11g USB WiFi Wireless Lan Adapter w/5dBi Antenna]] into an available USB port. I went to the network icon in the status bar, selected the wireless options and put in my router's info and Viola! I was connected. No special drivers to install, no special setup, just the normal wireless networking modules in the Fedora repositories. In order to install the unit for all users I had to supply the root password and now we can move the computer anywhere in the house. I highly recommend this for Linux users.

An added note: The router I am using is a Netgear 54Mbps Wireless Router WGR614 V8 and they are quite compatible.
output: Truly Plug and Play in Fedora Linux
