Instances.input: My kids spilled juice on the keyboard. I thought that I was going to have to buy a new laptop. I ended up finding this on Amazon.com and bought it, it worked. Easy installation and is the exact same as it used to be.

WOW! Where do I start? I can't believe that I almost passed this keyboard up for a different one...that would have been a HUGE mistake! I have a Dell Computer, running on Windows Vista, and I have had many different kinds of keyboards through the years... I almost passed on this because a few people mentioned that the keyboard is more \\"laptop like\\" and I have a desktop, and now that I have the keyboard, I say... What in the world are they thinking, it may not be big and bulky, but I'm telling you that it is absolutely PERFECT in EVERY way! There is nothing more that I could want from a keyboard! First of all, when it arrived, I was impressed with the packaging of this product by Logitech, wow, it made me feel like I was really getting the royal treatment just opening it up! Then I noticed how solid it is, and heavy for a keyboard, it isn't going anywhere, no sliding around on my desk that's for sure! I popped in the Disc in my computer tower and in seconds it was ready to go, I've never had an easier time setting up a keyboard and mouse before...By the way, I purchased the Logitech MX Revolution Wireless Mouse with this wired Keyboard, and the installation of that was just as easy. I almost purchased the Revolution Keyboard with the same mouse, but I work alot in the dark after my husband has gone to bed and I don't want to wake him, so I would have to say that the main reason I bought this keyboard is because it is illuminated perfectly, It has never been easier to work in the dark, each and every key on the board is lit up in white, not hard on the eyes at all, and the top row is mostly in orange. Since the light shines up through the letters and numbers on the keys, it is absolutely the easiest to read with no difficulty at all! It also irritates me when the white paint on the letters would start wearing off my previous keyboards, this isn't likely to happen on this keyboard because this one is done with a laser. Also, it IS EXTREMELY quiet, I have never had aquieter keyboard, which is also important because I was always irritating my husband with all the clickety clacking of the previous keyboards when he was trying to sleep. I am so glad that I just happened to stumble across this keyboard while studying up on countless keyboards, I didn't even know that Logitech put out an illuminated keyboard. I have spent more money on keyboards than I care to think about, but this one I believe I will have around for a good long time. It is very solidly constructed and even though I was very hesitant to purchase this one, I just told myself, I'll return it if I don't like it, but to my delight, I am so happy that I chose this one, I would not return this one if they offered me double the money to give it back...I am so glad that I took a chance on this one!

The primary purpose of this review is to point out that the wireless \\"WDS with AP\\" mode can be very useful if you have multiple DAP-2553's in your network. I purchased my first two DAP-2553's over a year ago to reach from my den, where the internet connection is, to my living room, where the home theater is (35' thru 4-5 walls). Being a noobie at this multiple router thing, I assumed that my only choice was to set the den DAP-2553 as the \\"Access Point\\" and the living room DAP-2553 as a \\"Wireless Client\\". That worked on firmware 1.12 on 5GHz for over a year.

Then I got an iPad 3 and the wireless coverage in the living room was totally unacceptable (AP was in den) . While searching for solutions, I discovered \\"WDS with AP\\" mode, which allows each DAP-2553 to function simultaneously as both a wireless client and an access point. DOH! I upgraded the firmware to 1.25, then set all three (I had added a third DAP-2553) to \\"WDS with AP\\" mode. For this to work, you have to enter the MAC addresses of the other DAP-2553's. The instructions are a little vague, but here's what worked for me. DAP-2553 #1 is connected via ethernet to the internet (Trendnet 2.4GHz router) & to the den desktops & to the den printers. #2 and #3 are ethernet connected just to clients. I wanted #1 to talk Wi-Fi with #2 and #3, but there was no point in having #2 and #3 talk Wi-Fi directly with each other, so #1 contains the MAC addresses of #2 & #3; #2 contains the MAC address of #1; and #3 contains the MAC address of #1. The MAC Addresses are entered in Basic Settings > Wireless after the Mode is set to \\"WDS with AP\\".

I'm not sure whether WDS will work with a multi-vendor mixture of routers or even multi-model within the same vendor. The D-Link FAQ seems a little outdated in this respect. I have taken the conservative approach and stuck with a single vendor and a single model.

I tried to set this up using built-in AP Array functionality, but couldn't get itwork (SCAN would never recognize #3 even though all 3 were ethernet connected during setup) and, anyway, I was left wondering whether AP Array was intended for the scenario where each unit had its own ethernet connection (poor documentation?).

I discounted one star because of having only a single ethernet port; the difficulties with documentation and setup (sometimes I have to Save changes twice and sometimes update/reboot takes awhile); and my uncertainty about whether range would be better if I had purchased a different brand/model.

My experience has been that once setup, the DAP-2553's work well. Wireless speed in my living room is now satisfactory. I intend to get a fourth DAP-2553 to connect an additional Blu-Ray player in another bedroom. If I was not already invested in DAP-2553's I would check out some of the newer 450Mbps (and up) models (instead of 300Mbps). My cursory look at the 450Mbps models indicates that they are even more expensive than the DAP-2553 and the one at which I looked closely does not appear to support anything similar to WDS with AP ([[ASIN:B006QB1RPY ASUS RT-N66U Dual-Band Wireless-N900 Gigabit Router]]). But perhaps I haven't interpreted the specs or user manual correctly.
output: WDS with AP mode is useful with multiple DAP-2553's

The OOMA voice-over-internet system has been rated the best in terms of quality, and I've certainly found that to be true after months of use. I'm far from an early adopter, and not all that tech savvy, but this is easy! The instructions are clear--it's really a plug-in.    What you need to use the Scouts is a little unclear, however. First, you do not need to keep landline service. But you DO need your landline wiring, which turned out to be a problem for us. I wanted to keep the main unit in my office and a scout downstairs in my husband's. But since we have separate land lines, this didn't work out. But that's the only problem we had--I bought an inexpensive $25 handset, hooked it up, and voila!    One concern with the VoIP systems is whether the companies that offer them will survive. I have hopes for OOMA, however. They got a capital infusion in the fall, landed a big electronics retailer for distribution, and got a great write-up in Fortune magazine. Who knows what will happen in this economy, but I hope this one is a survivor.

I have a Denon AVR-1613 receiver and although it was made in 2012, it doesn't have built-in wifi and I wanted to take advantage of the network features like listening to internet radio, controlling the receiver remotely via iPhone app, etc. This wifi network bridge / internet adapter was perfect. The installation was real easy: connect an ethernet cable to your laptop or PC, the adapter assigns an IP to your PC, browse to the built-in setup web page (more on this later) and specify your wifi settings.

I've been in IT for awhile now so setup was easy to me but there was one problem that perhaps someone not so tech savvy would have problems with. In the instructions, it says to open your web browser and it'll automatically take you to the setup page. This didn't work for me for some reason....and I'm not sure why it would because when you open a web browser, it usually opens up your home page. What I had to do was look at my ipconfig settings and see what the gateway address was and then I plugged that address into the web browser. Just an FYI if you run into the same issue. Other than that it works great

The only good news is that the lock looks very secure. Hopefully that will dissuade a would be thief.

Instances.input:
This product simply failed to cool my wife's Alienware m11x.

Without external cooling this laptop will hit 90 degrees celsius and shut itself down. We placed the laptop onto the cooler and plugged everything in per the instructions, and she started gaming. While she was gaming she monitored a temperature graph and ended the test at 86 degrees celsius. She said the bar was still raising after it had hit 86 degrees but she did not want to risk damaging the laptop, and shut it down.

With the rate that the temperature was climbing she was confident that it would have hit 90 degrees and activated its thermal protection feature.

We did another test and pointed a cheap blower fan (from wallyworld) at the laptop and it did MUCH better than the Thermaltake Massive23. While gaming with the simple fan, she hit a record of 69 degrees.

For a hard data comparison we compared idle temperatures.

Idle without external fan = 60 degrees celsius
Idle on Thermaltake Massive23 = 58 degrees celsius

Putting aside the utter failure of this product to cool a laptop, how are its other features?

I ordered 2 of these from another retailer, and one of the 2 was dead. They have a good physical design and feel sturdy, so I ordered 2 more from amazon. One immediately gave the 'invalid disk, please format' error, the other one waited until I transferred 2 files before returning the identical error.  Both showed up as RAW in Win7, and on my 2008R2 server.  I tried chkdsk, which failed, and then I tried formatting them in the hope that the format would mark a few sectors as failed and the rest of the drive would be fine.  Nope.  Every single sector was marked as failed. "15232512 bad sectors were encountered during the format. Invalid media or Track 0 bad - disk unusable."  So out of 4, I have 3 bad flash drives.  I know that sometimes stuff just happens, but 3 out of 4 from two different retailers points to something systemically wrong.  Something like a very high defect rate, poor packaging design, an internal issue with the USB to flash bridge, or the flash itself.  I know that only getting 4 is not a statistically valid sample, but it is enough for me to not buy this usb drive.  Update:  I wanted to give a quick update on this review.  3 of the 4 that I got were DOA, but one worked fine.  That one is still going strong.  Besides the first few weeks, it has been hooked into my USB player in the car.  That means it gets to deal with 130+ degree interior car temps along with way below freezing temps (hit negative 48 last year on 2 days).  So the one drive that worked for me can sure take abuse and is still kicking after 4 years.

Instances.input:
I bought this pen wanting to replace the standard S-pen that came with my Samsung Note 10.1 2014 edition. I love the tablet and love the ability to write precisely on it. However, it is simply not able to become a paper replacement given that the included pen feels like writing with a tooth-pick. So I was excited when I saw that a top-notch company like Wacom provides a more pen-like option. Given its price (almost 10% of the tablet price), I was expecting a high quality pen.

Unfortunately the stylus failed on two counts for me. First, it was a lot lighter than I was expecting. I was expecting a lot more heft similar to a nice roller-ball. While it is nicer than a cheap ball-pen, it's closer to the weight of a uni-ball than a high-end pen. Also, and this may be forced by the electronics inside, the weight has been placed mostly in the cap, so when you write with the cap at the back, it is rather end-heavy. So while this was unfortunate, it is not the reason for the poor review.

I have returned this pen simply because the off-set is intolerable. It appears that the tablet reads the pen at the base of the tip which is about 1 mm from the end of the tip. Given the years of writing and hence expectation that the ink will be where the pen meets the paper, this is extremely annoying and essentially unusable. Perhaps someone with large handwriting may not notice, but for me it was not a useful replacement. What is extremely disappointing is the fact that the free S-pen writes perfectly well. The tablet picks it up and there is no off-set. Unfortunately with its plasticky feel and lack of girth, it is not comfortable for long periods of time.

On the positive, I love the idea of the rubber tip. One of the other down-sides of writing on glass is that there is not the "friction" or "scratching" that one expects from paper. The rubber tip to provide that extra grip is a great idea. I would have used a softer rubber for more friction, but it is still better than hard plastic.

One would have really thought that since Wacom provided the technology for the "pen" in this tablet, they of all people would have produced a really high quality pen. Unfortunately this is not it. Perhaps a later patch or upgrade might fix it, but for now my search continues. I would hate for this tablet to be relegated to a nice iPad simply because no one can make a good pen. If you do know of one, please mention it in the comments.
output: Significant off-set makes the pen worse than the included S-pen

I have fully tested this drive with "HDDScan" and it has passed with flying colors. This model is for NAS enclosures(RAID setups mostly but not required) and thus has a few features that the standard consumer drives to not have to make it more reliable and suitable for RAID configurations from simple(Raid 1) to more advanced(RAID 5,6,10,01,ZF2,etc.). It also has a warranty a year longer than consumer drives and can be furthered with 3rd party warranty(read fine print before doing so, so that you fully understand how it works.) All these factor in to why it is more expensive. The downside is that these are optimized to be media storage drives and to be in a RAID configuration to limit the bottleneck(limiting of performance) of a single drive. These drive spin around 5400RPM or less and thus arent the most speedy. If you do not need higher performance(their is a pro version of these drive that spin at 7200RPM) or will use a RAID configuration with striping across multiple disks, this is an excellent purchase.

If I should have any problems I will update my review accordingly.
output: Good drive if you know what you are looking for.

This is a nice lightweight laptop. They call this black but it looks silver. It's sleek and slim but it does have a few potential drawbacks. If you're used to the ultrabooks the arrangement of the keyboard won't bother you. There's no number pad. I'm used to a full keyboard so I'm still adjusting to typing on this one. I'm constantly lifting my fingers to check their position. The keyboard does have one cool thing about it though. It can light up for nighttime use. I found the touchpad easier to use on this laptop than on my Toshiba. Generally, I HAVE to have a mouse.

It is a Windows 8 laptop and as a user of Windows back to when it was simply a GUI (Windows 3.0), I am still trying to get used to the idea of dealing with Windows as a smartphone-like operating system. I am not sure that I like it. It just seems unnecessary. For example, it has a Netflix button on the front page. You have to download an app to use it. Why would I do this when I can simply go online on this same laptop to stream from Netflix?

The hardware is nice. Particularly the quiet keyboard and fast startup (partly due to the solid-state hard drive). The hard drive seems small - one of the tradeoffs of solid-state hard drives. The lack of an optical drive (DVD or CD) at first bothered me, but I rarely used it on my previous laptop. This laptop does not have a 15-pin VGA output, which could be a problem if you use projectors for presentations (particularly older projectors) at conferences, though it does have an HDMI output. There is a headphone jack, but no microphone input.

Adobe Premiere Elements and Adobe Photoshop Elements are included, but you will need to purchase a key for the Office 2010 products installed, which might be the most difficult thing to swallow. This means no Microsoft Word. Prepare to purchase this if you're buying this laptop for a student. It does come with protection from Norton. So that's good.

3.5 - 4 STARS: Your perception ofthis laptop will depend on how you intend to use it. Both my husband and I have been using it since it arrived and the above review includes both of our observations.

I bought this keyboard about two weeks ago. I had so many problems with it during that time that I finally gave up and returned it for refund. This is the first Logitech equipment that I've ever had so many problems with. In my home we have six keyboards altogether (some of them actively used, others on a shelf). Of our six keyboards, five of them are Logitech keyboards. As I type this review, I am using a Logitech keyboard, an \\"old-fashioned\\" corded keyboard with the keys in a straight line (with an \\"old-fashioned\\" Logitech corded mouse). **It works better than the keyboard that is the subject of this review.**    The initial, original, starting installation of the WAVE keyboard and accompanying mouse took HOURS! The software (\\"Setpoint\\") is probably very sophisticated (24 Megs? I should hope so!) but I'll never know for sure. I got it running and I could use the keyboard and the mouse, but the full installation of the latest revision of the Setpoint software was never accomplished.    So I tried to update the program. The Logitech website insisted on presenting their 64-bit update no matter how many times I checked off the 32-bit update choice. Then, clicking on the DOWNLOAD button on Logitech's site produced nothing. No response. Zero. Zip. Then I went to another download site (\\"Hippo\\") and downloaded the proper update. Then I attempted to install it and finally succeeded after several tries. Then I tried to run Setpoint. It refused to run, stating that an \\"essential\\" file \\"khalwraper.dll\\" was corrupted AND THEREFORE THE INSTALL COULD NOT CONTINUE. I did a search on the net and learned that  \\"khalwraper.dll\\" is a virus of some kind, affecting the registry. Then I used another program to clean my registry. Setpoint still wouldn't run, again making the statement that that  essential file \\"khalwraper.dll\\" was corrupted. Then I called customer service. I spent a lot of time in discussion, and I mentioned and named and slowly spelled out the letters of the offending file, \\"khalwraper.dll.\\" The technician instructed me to uninstall Setpoint, using the Windows Control Panel Option to do so. I did, and that is when I finally lost my patience! The uninstallation of Setpoint left me with no mouse at all! (Have you ever tried to run Windows without a mouse, using keyboard commands only...?) After a lot of wasted time, I managed to shut down the computer, pull out all the Logitech Wave components and replace those components with this old-fashioned, non-wireless, non-ergonomic dinosaur. This old dinosaur works, at least.    I packed up the Wave, returned it to Amazon for refund. Now I'll try to upgrade my dinosaur. Again.    Some words of warning about `ergonomic':  The word, \\"ergonomic\\" doesn't have a consistent meaning when used to describe keyboards, in my opinion. I found that the most common meaning of \\"ergonomic\\" in this context was a keyboard that was flat (that is, no *wave* in the height of the keys) but with a curve to the keys' layout, a convex curve from the typist's viewpoint.  The word, \\"ergonomic keyboard\\" sometimes excludes the so-called \\"split\\" keyboard in which the keyboard keys are separated into two non-curved halves, one for left hand, one for right hand. Sometimes these halves are on the same chassis, sometimes not. Be careful when choosing an \\"ergonomic\\" keyboard and/or mouse. What you need and what you actually buy may not \\"match.\\"    Some words of warning about wireless keyboards/mice:  If you wish to upgrade your keyboard and/or mouse, think carefully about what you want to change and why. If you use a desktop computer and only a desktop computer, think carefully about your need for wireless devices. How could using a wireless keyboard enhance your work on your desktop computer? Do you really need the freedom to move the keyboard all over the room? What's the point? On the other hand, a wireless mouse **might** be useful if your corded mouse gets its tail tangled in the paperwork or other debris on your desk.Think carefully! Maybe a corded keyboard with a cordless mouse is the answer. Don't go wireless unless you must! For those of you who use a laptop computer in a desktop environment, your needs are different. Think carefully.    Decide. And when you have, look around and buy **exactly** what you need, no less, and **no more.** If you can't find wireless devices which meet your needs, look harder! Corded devices are available! And, in the long run, I do recommend Logitech.
output: What a waste of time and money!

Instances.input:
I recently order this Maxtor hard drive from Amazon. To my surprise when I open the package it was a Sata II (3.0gb interface) hard drive. It was suppose to be a Sata I drive as stated in Amazon and even in its own box. I'm not complaining about this, but this brings some problems to the table. My motherboard primary Sata controller is the VIA 8237 and it doesn't support Sata II even when you limit the drive to 1.5gb interface. Luckily my motherboard had a secondary controller the Promise Fasttrak 378 it handled the drive with no problems. I guess you could get either a Sata I or II with this hard drive kit, something to have in mind.
Overall this drive is great, very quite and fast. 5 stars

Looks fantastic and everyone is always remarking how great it looks  ... if I take 2 minutes and give them a brief demo of the MAC their jaw drops. Do not think that I will ever go back to a Windows PC again ... once you have a MAC you don't want to go back!! Saved a few dollars ... plus no sales tax buying through Amazon. Great work sessions provided for free by Apple, plus the techs at Apple are always great to talk with. Also, if you are converting from a Windows PC to a MAC I would recommend the book \\"Switching to the MAC\\", it is very helpful.
output: Apple knows how to do it

This SD card USED to be one of the fastest. Now it is merely adequate.

I bought the 64GB version and inserted into my Samsung Galaxy S5 (latest Samsung phone).

The performance, although still adequate, is less than stellar. For example, to load the Amazon Kindle app, which is about 35mb and I purposely placed it into this SD card, it takes about 7 full seconds to load. The same app on my iPad takes around 2 seconds to load.

Still, if you aren't too much into your smartdevice performance, then I wouldn't worry. But if you do care about how fast your smartphone can take pictures (assuming your pictures are stored in SD cards) or how fast your apps will load, then you should purchase a much faster SD card for your latest phone.

Pros:
1)Adequate performance.
2)Hassle free packaging.

Cons:
1)Not the fastest, but still adequate.

I to was dropping drives left and right after purchasing this HUB, especially my Mushkin Enhanced Ventura Pro 32GB flash drive. Went to the manufacturers site and looked for Firmware and driver updates (which should be the very first to try when something isn't working proper) and to my amazement tech support is telling consumers that their USB Hubs do not need firmware updates. LOL, all high-tech electronic devices need firmware in order to function, and just like drivers and applications get updates, firmware is no different. So knowing that the device probably uses a standard design and is not proprietary I googled to see who makes the chipset, and within 5 mins I found the answer. After discovering that Via makes the HUB chipsets for USB 3.0 I made a visit to their site to instantly find a Downloads section with firmware for their USB 3.0 Hub controller, again 5 minutes tops and I found the new Firmware Upgrade Tool (dated March 2012) and Upgrade Instructions in a PDF. Five minutes or less later I am running Firmware version 9.50. These devices come with firmware 7.40 which is old and full of bugs. Only time will tell if the newer Firmware is solid or not but so far my drives have not once disappeared as they did on Firmware 7.40. Below are the screenshots of the successful before and after flashing steps I took on Windows 7 x64.    I now own two USB 3.0 Hubs a D-Link and now a Tripp-Lite and both are running firmware v9.50. By the way, the internals on these devices look damn near identical using the exact same logic and they both now function exactly the same. Yes, I opened them to make sure they had the VL810 chip, lol I'm a computer geek, what was I supposed to do? ;)    Before flash [...]  During flash [...]  After flash [...]    My Ventura Pro went from transfering a 1gb iso in 15 seconds to 11 seconds. That is roughly a 30% increase in performance. Also worthy of note, is the fact that the drive would disappear permanently after removing it from the computer until I did a restart. However after the new firmware update it now seems to function as a normal USB flash drive. I also updated my NEC/Renesas USB HOST Controller firmware and drivers from Station drivers as well.    Please people stop giving stuff bad reviews until you do a little research. No more than 15-20 minutes tops and I fixed the problems with the HUB myself...

The Kindle Fire HDX is a well made piece of hardware. The screen is fantastic and the UI is as smooth as what I've come to expect from various iOS devices (iPhones and iPads), which are still the standard for me. As many reviewers have pointed out, the rear facing buttons are a bit odd, and with the front-facing camera the only clue to orientation when you pick the HDX up, it was always a 50/50 shot as to whether I was pressing the power button or volume up when I wanted to turn it on. Also, despite the pictures, it definitely seems designed to be used in landscape mode.

In general, as a primarily iOS user, I had a difficult time making the transition to the Fire OS. I tried to use the Kindle as much as possible for 2 weeks, but still found navigating the OS cumbersome, especially task switching. This was compounded by the lack of even a single physical button on the front. I also was not impressed with the Silk browser. There were also fewer apps, and I had to repurchase some favorites (PleX). There is also (obviously) no way to mirror the display to an AppleTV (this functionality is promised to be coming between the Fire and PS4, but I don't have or want a PS4).

Finally, the main reason I got the HDX was to try Kindle FreeTime for my kids. I signed up for FreeTime Unlimited, which unfortunately lives up to its name too literally: there was no way for me to filter what my kids could and could not access. There are videos, apps and books that I'm ok with them being able to access, and some that I'm not. While I could control the amount of time allotted to each activity, I could not control access to content. This was a deal breaker for me.

For the price, its a great device, especially if you are new to the tablet or mobile ecosystem. However, if you're already part of the iOS world, I'd strongly consider an iPad mini with retina display. Or, if you're currently living in Android land, the Nexus 7 is a no-brainer.
output: Wanted to love it, but sent it back. Great hardware, OK software, not iOS.

I was replacing my (relatively new/fully functioning) Samsung 850 EVO 500GB SSD with this brand new Samsung 850 PRO 512GB SSD. I had a full system image of the W510 (there were no proprietary \\"hidden\\" partitions on this system, just a straight Windows install), restored it to the 850 PRO, the laptop booted without any issues, and everything looked fine. No errors in device manager, and it appeared as if it was a complete total clone of exactly what was on the EVO drive. However, all the USB ports on the left side of the laptop (one 2.0 and two 3.0) lost functionality. (Lenovo Thinkpad W510, Win 7 Pro 64 bit) I took out the 850 PRO, reinserted the 850 EVO, no problems -- all USB ports functioned perfectly. Took out the 850 EVO, put back in the 850 PRO -- no USB ports. Wash. Rinse. Repeat. (Device manager is showing a Code 10 error for all USB devices whenever a drive (flash or HDD) is inserted, but shows no error(s) otherwise when no USB devices are installed/inserted.)    This is insane. (And no...fortunately...I did NOT do the dreaded firmware update; Magician said I had the latest firmware already installed.) So I am at a loss here. It's the weekend and I can't call CS for some relief/RMA. I have 3 Samsung 850 EVO 500GB SSDs installed on my other laptops, and have never had any problem. I decided to \\"upgrade\\" to the PRO from the EVO and man...what a mistake.    UPDATE: I called Samsung CS and was told, in no uncertain terms, that this could not POSSIBLY be a hardware conflict with my Thinkpad W510 -- it HAD to be a software issue. So I took a Lenovo rescue disc, installed it so that everything was pristine/out of the box fresh, and for a little while the USB ports worked. Then they stopped working.    So...being the stubborn type of person that I am...I went to my Lenovo V570 laptop (that had a Crucial 500GB SSD) and used a Paragon system image backup and restored to the Pro 512. It worked. No problems. I then reformatted the 512 and used a OneKey system image backup. That worked. Then I reformatted the 512, went back to the W510 and tried two different types of system image backups -- same problem; it would boot up, everything looked okay (no errors or yellow warnings in Device Manager, Event Viewer was solid, etc.), but as soon as I plugged in any USB device it was a no go.    Therefore, I'm stumped. The drive works, yet it doesn't work. It works in the V570 but it doesn't work in the W510. I've had 3 different drives in my W510 and they all work -- but the Pro 512 will not. (In fact, there's a Samsung EVO 500 in there right now and it works fine.) Something's going on here. But rather than send this SSD back only to receive a \\"refurbished\\" drive (how in the world does a company \\"refurbish\\" a SSD anyway?) I'll use it in the V570 even though that was not my original intent. My original intent was to install the 512 in my W510 and give a friend of mine the EVO 500 for her Thinkpad T410. Now I'll give the relatively brand new Crucial 500GB SSD to my friend instead.    NOTE: Since this drive does work in one of my laptops I've upgraded the stars from 1 to 3.

First off, this tablet's drivers are coded about as well as a solid brick. The CD drivers it came with were buggy and had only the barest of functionality with Windows 7, 64 bit. Input lag, unresponsive strokes, constant resetting, not letting me enter the settings menu, you name it. It took several hours to parse through all of the different versions of software before finally finding one... in a Deviantart thread. Even with the latest drivers installed, the tablet buttons refuse to accept new programming.  Now, with all of this, why aren't I giving this a 1/5? Simple. Because even with the faults, the H610 still functions as an excellent alternative to the more expensive Wacom Bamboo (which I previously owned). It's sleek, lightweight, and beautifully designed. With a surface that's smooth, responsive, and an absolute joy to draw with! If Huion can get its act together, and start writing half decent software, they could easily wipe the floor with the overpriced Wacom lineup. If you want a tablet without the extra trinkets, or if you have a pc/mac that doesn't run 64 bit Windows 7, this tablet is the way to go. Otherwise, just stick with the Bamboo and Intous.
output: Amazing Potential, Crippled by awful Software.

Check your specific monitor and video card pinouts first before buying: To those considering buying a DVI cable, this one is a DVI-I cable.  Your monitor and video card DVI connectors need to have the pin inputs that are immed above and below the flat, long pin of the DVI connector.  Otherwise you will not be able to connect using this cable.  For example, I have a laptop that has a DVI-D output connector, and I cannot use this cable without also purchasing a DVI-I to DVI-D adapter. (do an internet search on dvi-i and dvi-d pinout to see a diagram of the connector and compare the DVI-I pinout to your monitor and video cable)
output: Check Your DVI Monitor and Video Card Pinouts First !!!

Instances.input: 1. It must have good or great voice quality. I've used 3 different VOIP products that were okay, but this ooma devise is simply outstanding voice quality.   2. It must be simple to set up. Not geekish, and constantly needing software or customer service attention.  This sets up in 5 minutes, and is working with a temporary telephone number letting you try it out for 30 days to see. Never had a problem yet.  3. It must be inexpensive. Can you say $0 phone bill? Sure you pay up front, but look:  you save $40-$60 over typical local phone/long distance. I figure that my break even point is 4 months.  4. It must have cool features. Look, this ooma unit is way cool. Don't even think to compare to the average telephone company.  5. It must be a stable company. Okay, I'm no prophet whether this company will stay or not, but who is to say that ANY voip company will be around in 2-5 years. If you MUST have absolute certainty here, stay with the local phone company. But, consider that churn is a major detriment to phone companies especially when it is easy to change back. Read the reviews of happy customers, and think how this business plan is made for people to stay with them. Yes, money up front will not require constant recapturing of fickle customers  6. It must have... \\"got to have\\" features. Listen, the premier features cost an extra $99/year or $12.95/per month. You get to try them for 90 days free. Don't need them, okay, your main ooma still works,but they are there if you need and like them. I do.   7. If you need really cheap long distance or ready to leave your computer on all the time, or can accept less than steller voice, go find other solutions, but this ooma unit is the real deal.   8. Nobody really has great customer service anymore . . .except Amazon and few others, but I got through to this company in less than 5 minutes on my call. Signup and number porting is simply on-line automation. I don't want to have to be calling a company. I want service to be functioning from day 1. I did.  9. Sounds like I work for the company? I don't! I took a long hard look at it. Be a sceptic and do your work. But, if you try this unit, you may find that YOU will be writing a stellar review after a few months of using ooma.   10.  Sometimes you find something that just works. ooma just works! And it is cool.
output: Cool, Awesome, More Bang for Buck

I bought this to transfer some data onto an old 80gb IDE drive just to use as backup. I plugged everything in (Note: you have to power this device, as well as the Hard Drive) and left the jumper where it was (far right) when it was installed in my old computer 10 years ago. This is probably all in the instructions, but I'm not sure, I didn't read them (haha).

After doing this, it was automatically recognized in BIOS and windows 8 and I copied an pasted files on it just like I would with a flash drive.

I have not used this for an IDE optical drive or any other IDE device - just the Hard Drive. I have also not tried to convert a SATA device to IDE. I cannot comment on how well it performs these tasks.

Only knock on it: my power cord is kinda cheap. When I unplugged it, it sort of broke (a cord broke loose). I fixed it though, and it will work again when I need to connect it. Didn't really matter anyway, as my power supply came with all the right connections to power it.

Instances.input: Solved my older TiVo problem in a flash.  I researched which adapters were supposed to work and this turned out to be a clear winner.  I plugged it in and it was like plug and play.  Recognized and working, immediately.  No muss, no fuss.

Small and thin can be places in a lot of out of the way locations.

CONS:
Out of the box firmware is bland. QoS is a joke. But good enough for 90% of the home users
Gloss black. Fingerprints and dust seemingly come out of nowhere to attach themselves to the glossy finish
USB ports are only USB 2.0. Whats the point of a Gigabit ethernet and a USB 2.0 NAS/FTP drive... THINK people.. THINK!
Print server is a joke.. supports like 20 printers that nobody owns.

Currently my wifi sniffer shows -48 for 2.4 and -58 for 5Ghz from about 20ft away both are at 300Mbps.

With DD-WRT on it the device has much more use than stock... but the add-on hardware (USB 2.0? Really?) is really a let down.

For the price its a good router that covers 2 bands.
output: But good enough for 90% of the home users Gloss black

I am a professional website designer and amateur writer. I needed an alternative to my full-size laptop, something I could take with me nearly everywhere. My criteria were small size, light weight, long battery life, solid state storage (for ruggedness), and Linux (so that I was not tied in to an increasingly bloated and slow Windows upgrade path). I chose the Eee PC 901 after extensive research, and it is exactly what I wanted.    The screen is, naturally, small, but it is the crispest display I have ever seen; some pages are more readable on it than on my 19\\" desktop monitor. I have little difficulty touch-typing on the keyboard, once I got used to the size and placement of some of the punctuation keys. It boots almost instantly, and loads software as fast if not faster than my desktop XP system. Its wireless connection is the most painless I have ever dealt with, though it does seem to have difficulty with low-strength signals: if the signal strength meter reads below 50% for an access point, you're probably not going to get a connection.    Aside from its expected professional use, it is so useful in a personal sense that I hate to have it out of reach. I can read e-books in bed. I can comparison shop from a bench in the mall. I can play Sudoku while I'm waiting for a haircut. I can stop in McDonald's for a cup of coffee and a quick check of Google Maps directions (many McD's now have public WiFi). I can check what that bright star is from my back yard. I can watch streaming movies in my easy chair. And I'm doing all of this on a computer that would fit into a big coat pocket or average-sized purse.    I'm very glad I got the Linux version and would recommend it to anyone without reservation, no matter what their current OS. It is FAST. For the average person who just clicks on their word processor or Web browser or whatever and gets to work, it's just as easy to use as Windows; for anyone who's comfortable shelling out to the Linux command line, the additionalpower is amazing. The update system works more smoothly than Windows Update ever has. The included software does just about everything most users will ever need, and then some: the StarOffice suite, Web browser (Firefox) and email (Thunderbird), a personal information manager, an instant messenger program compatible with most of the IM programs out there, and an extensive collection of learning, productivity, and game software. It integrates seamlessly into my LAN, and I have no difficulty using it to, for example, edit a document stored over on my primary desktop machine, or vise versa.    The Eee PC 901 isn't for everyone. If your eyes have difficulty reading small screens or your hands don't fit on small keyboards, this may not be your computer. Plugging in an external keyboard, mouse, and monitor will alleviate that problem, but that does kind of defeat the whole purpose of a netbook. The touchpad is a bit touchy, though some tweaking of settings and retraining of fingers helped a lot there (and I love the two-finger scrolling function).    You might need some extras. The onboard speakers are, in a word, pathetic; I recommend purchasing some battery-powered speakers, or just using a set of earbuds. Also, if you're not fond of touchpads, you'll want to add a pointing device of your preferred type; the three USB ports make this easy, without the need to carry a hub around with you. Plus, although Linux is amazingly efficient at disk usage and the 20 gig of SSD drive space will stretch a lot farther than it would on a Windows machine, you will probably want to pick up a SDHC card or two (I like the 8 gig ones) for spare data storage.    This is an amazing little computer, and I can't recommend it highly enough. My only regret is not buying it sooner.
It works fine. I have recently found similar products at better prices when you consider shipping and handling. Overall it does what it is supposed to .

I anticipated that these 120mm fans would move a lot of air at the cost of being really loud, but they're rather quiet even when at full speed. I have a Mass Cool 120mm fan and these are significantly quieter.

The extra yellow-wired connector was present on these fans. I only mention this because someone else mentioned that they were not present. The connector is a bit awkward to try to "cable manage" but otherwise these fans are very easy to use.

Plugged them into a USB hub attached to 64 bit Vista computer and they started working without any problem. I have no way to evaluate performance compared to others available.     Be aware that they have no power switch. If they're plugged into the USB port they turn on as soon as you turn the computer on. They turn off when you turn the computer off. I only access the files on them once a week or so, so I turn them off by unplugging the USB cables from the hub. There's no light to let you know they're on (there's a data transfer light in the back, no light in front). They make just enough noise that you'll hear them, though, if you put them on your desk.
output: No power switch, no power-on light

I just got this and I think that I'm going to return it. I moved to a new office and got a new computer with a shiny, gorgeous new monitor (the Dell Optiplex all in one 9000 model, 23 or 24\\" inches with a flat bezel - or maybe it's no bezel, but it's completely flat across, no indentation where the screen is). The florescent lights shine on my computer screen all the time, it's like having 3 large white shiny bars across my computer screen. So I decided to go with this anti-glare screen protector to reduce the glare.

First of all - you're paying $90 for a piece of flimsy plastic that you tape on your computer screen with the included sticky tabs. There are two sides to this screen, one side is shiny and does absolutely nothing to reduce the glare. The other side has a bit more of a matte finish and reduces glare by a small amount but not much. The screen is still shiny where the lights shine on the monitor.

Secondly - the tabs which are used to attach the film to the screen are flimsy pieces of hard tape. They fall off, aren't very adhesive, and look awful and cheap. If you touch the sticky part your finger print ends up on it.

Thirdly - the screen gets DARK. I have the screen on the highest brightness setting and it's grey.

Also - the screen is blurry - text isn't as crisp as it is. I can already feel my eyes starting to strain.

I'm gonna try it for another week - if I don't get used to it it's going back. I'm not pleased, especially given the price.
output: cheap feeling, grey screen, flimsy tabs

Instances.input: Product as advertised
Right item, right price, shipped fast.

First, let me say, I am glad it is not pink (ha ha).

Next, let me say, I love my Kindle!

This is my first Kindle. In fact, on the day of the press conference announcing it, I kept refreshing the Amazon home page until I saw the Kindle announcement and could order one! I wasn't going to take the chance on it being sold out and having to wait for it.

My Kindle arrived earlier than the estimated delivery date. That was cool! I charged it right away, but that didn't stop me from buying some books while it was charging. It took approximately 3 hrs and 15 minutes to charge completely...not bad. I haven't had to recharge it yet (it's been almost a week, and I've been using Whispernet a few times each day).

Reading on the Kindle is wonderful. My eyes are much less tired, since I can adjust the print size AND it's not back lit like a computer screen. The five-way controller makes it easy to scroll and select things. I also purchased the Amazon black leather cover. It's very nice and makes the Kindle feel like a \\"real\\" book if you want to hold it that way. I've been folding the cover back, though. I do wish the leather cover came in red--I'd get one of those, too.

Philosophically, let me just say that to me, the Kindle is still a book. It may not be paper and allow me to turn pages, and it lacks the \\"artistry\\" of covers, typeface, paper and ink BUT it feels like a book when I read it. I see the Kindle as a welcome addition to my library, but it's not going to replace it all. I will still buy \\"real\\" books because I just plain love them. And there are lots of books that aren't on the Kindle that I want to own, like collectible editions, craft books, art books, photography books, and anything heavy in graphics that are enhanced by a beautifully crafted tome.

I am happy with my Kindle. It meets my expectations. And I don't think it is too expensive, when I compare it to my other electronics. The Kindle does a lot and the cost covers the Whispernet aspect which I am glad I don't have to pay for on a monthly basis. I give the Kindle four stars because mostly, I don't believe any gadget is perfect. But I will recommend it. Thanks, Amazon!am glad I don't have to pay for on a monthly basis. I give the Kindle four stars because mostly, I don't believe any gadget is perfect. But I will recommend it. Thanks, Amazon!

I purchased this replacement battery in September of 2012. It's lasted me nearly 2 years, and it's performed well for most of that time. It has very slowly lost its ability to charge fully, but I have been using my laptop nearly every day for work, sometimes exhausting the full battery up to twice a day, for as long as I've had this battery installed, so I'd say it's done about as well as one could reasonably expect any replacement battery to do. In the beginning, I was getting between 4 and 5 hours of use out of one charge. After nearly 2 years, I only get about a half hour or so, but it's served me well enough for the money that I'm going to go ahead and buy another one.

It may be worth noting for some buyers that this battery will probably extend beyond the back of your laptop. As it is an "Extended Capacity" battery, I expected as much, but I noticed several complaints about this in other reviews.

Instances.input:
We're a major gaming household and have four desktop computers (two for gaming and two for TV/movie/music media centers). We've been slowly trying to convert as much as we can to wireless in an effort to minimize our cable management. Therefore I was excited to add this wireless adapter to my main gaming desktop. Here are my thoughts on the TP-LINK Archer T9E AC1900 Dual Band Wireless PCI Express Adapter, 5Ghz 1300Mbps + 2.4Ghz 600Mbps, Beamforming, 3T3R;

Pros

+ Designed to handle gaming systems.

+ Respectable Wi-Fi speed.

Cons

- A little on the large side.

- Requires some software updates.

- Speed could be a little better for the asking price.

I've been wanting to make my gaming PC wireless for a while now but have been hesitant. The TP-LINK Archer T9E AC1900 Dual Band Wireless PCI Express Adapter, 5Ghz 1300Mbps + 2.4Ghz 600Mbps, Beamforming, 3T3R allowed me to achieve this goal with little to no worry. Installation was easy and the adapter has worked its first month with no issues at all. It was great to finally get rid of some cables running to my PC case and it made managing things much easier. If you're in the market for a reliable wireless adapter for your PC I'd definitely give the TP-LINK Archer T9E AC1900 Dual Band Wireless PCI Express Adapter, 5Ghz 1300Mbps + 2.4Ghz 600Mbps, Beamforming, 3T3R a try.
output: A solid wireless adapter from TP-LINK

Instances.input: The product arrived in a crushed box due to poor packaging and after opening it, it seemed ok but when we tried to connect to the internet via, Ethernet, Wifi, and straight wired into the cable. For what you are paying for them, these speakers are incredible.  I tested the issue that some people are reporting with other sets going into sleep mode. The speakers will go into a sleep mode if the input volume is too low. This can be rectified by making sure your input volume is around 50% or higher. I usually keep the input volume around 75% and adjust volume with the included control unit, and have not experienced this issue (other than recreating it for testing). As others noted, the system has a good mid range, moderate bass, but is some what lacking in the high range. It could probably even use a little more amp than what it came with, with out much distortion.

This fan has worked great to cool a cabinet for my HTPC. It is quiet and seems to be of high quality. This is the second type of fan like this that I have tried and I am happy with this one.

Update: Going strong @ over 6 months. Still silent and moving plenty of air.

I like the larger keyboard and this is light, small and very sturdy since it is metal and not plastic like you find on many Winbloz systems. Highly recommended.

As well, any audio CD I write with this drive longer that's longer than 60 minutes will report errors when being read from this or any other audio drive.

(Using other drives, everything is fine.)

I'll be contacting Amazon in hopes of returning this device.
output: Plextor quality has certainly gone downhill...

Instances.input: I bought this for my husband for his birthday.  He needed a replacement for the briefcase he has been using for 8 years.  He loves it.  His only complaint is that the padded section for the laptop is not removeable.  This bag holds several textbooks and many files.

I've bought a couple of the Apple keyboards for my work and home PCs and one of them died. I was looking for a PC-centric counterpart and there are very few choices out there. That being said, this is an excellent replacement. The key feel is a bit different than the Apple keyboard; it's just a tad stiffer. Whether that's a good thing is really a subjective thing, but I actually like it.

The one thing that is preventing this from getting five stars is that my keyboard's spacebar wasn't working quite right out of the box. I use the right side of the spacebar, and I noticed that it wasn't registering keypresses most of the time. I ended up having to pull the spacebar off and re-jiggering the stabilizer bar under the key so that it wouldn't stick. This was a bit nerve-wracking, as reassembling a scissor switch is no easy task due to how fragile they are, much less the extra pieces involved with a non standard key such as the spacebar.

That being said, I would buy another one of these keyboards should my work Apple keyboard eventually give up the ghost.
output: Fantasic counter-part to the Apple keyboard

Ok...So it's been 6 days since, I have been toying with this thing.     Does it work?   Yes and No. Before buying this, i was only able to get my neighbors wi-fi from one tiny spot on the end table. Now I am able to sit on my bed (3 feet away and surf very slowly). Even though the signal shows 4-5 bars, the connection itself only pulls in about 2-5.5 mbps, so in all reality it's kinda slow.     However, I am able to use this downstairs on a certain area of my sofa (very uncomfortable may I add) where i can surf at speeds about 15-20 mbps (Not bad at all)    Yes, I know \\"Get my own internet\\" you say. I say \\"hell no\\" At $50/mo. I will continue to use my neighbors. Could care less what anyone thinks. If it's un-secure, i am using it.     This antenna is ok for the price. If you need just a little boost to grab a hold of that connection that keeps getting away from you then this could help, but if you think your going to plug this in and get every connection on the block YOUR DREAMING. I can get a connection that was only available once in a blue moon, but it is so inconsistent and slow I can't even say it's an added connection.
output: A Little Over-Hyped in my Opinion

Instances.input: Awesome!!

DO NOT BUY! It is defective and they CHARGE YOU to send it back to them. I bought battery to replace in my Macbook (circa 2008). I was debating between this one and just paying $99 at the Apple store for a new one. I opted for this one assuming that if it didn't work, I could just return it. When I put the battery into my computer, the Mac said the Battery needed service. It wouldn't even charge.
Works, tiny. Exactly what you want.

I bought this to replace a Logitech keyboard that was getting a bit worn and dirty. This keyboard comes with volume, calculator, file explorer (my computer), media player and playback keys (Play, pause stop fast forward and rewind). I use this keyboard with Linux / Ubuntu and all the shortcuts work perfectly without any configuration.

This mouse is a joke... Has so many problems...

First of all, Synapse is the worst program I've ever seen. Takes a long time to initialize when I reboot and not always stable, sometimes I can't even change my DPI, it just doesn't react... Sometimes initializes with highest DPI, mouse flies away and doesn't recover for some time...

Mouse's firmware is horribly broken. Battery indicator is completely wrong for instance. This is a common made mistake across all the companies, they usually set the battery percentage on their devices based on the alkaline batteries, not the rechargable ones. A ni-mh battery is considered to be at full capacity while the voltage is above 1.3V but this mouse considers it to be at 2/3 capacity which is correct for 1.5v alkaline batteries. So after I take it from charge, it literally stays at 3/3 capacity for only 15 minutes, and goes on all the day with 2/3 capacity indicator. So inaccurate. Funny part is that Synapse shows accurate information about battery's percentage, while mouse is not.

Setting up the sleep timer on Synapse has no effect on this mouse, because it doesn't work. It goes to sleep, and wakes up again after a few seconds even though it's staying idle... so sleep function is also broken, a complete nonsense.

If I choose the option to turn off all LED on it when my screen is off, sometimes they never come back on when my screen comes on.

Sometimes when it is waking up from sleep, battery indicator lighting goes completely dark while other parts shine. Or sometimes it does the same thing while just waiting idle. At least this doesn't affect how mouse operates.

When I dock the mouse to charge it, under normal circumstances, its lights should be fading out and fading in (pulsing) in a nice smooth way that looks good at night, but this almost never works. Either lights go completely dark or completely on (bat. indicator is always on) At least it charges...

I've read much worse problems about this mouse's first revisions which are using the previous firmware actually. Those terrible DPI and lag issues are solved with the last firmware at least but other issues that I wrote here still exists and because most of the people doesn't care about these mostly \\"cosmetic\\" issues, they are usually not being mentioned anywhere else.

Overall this crappy mouse sure as hell doesn't worth it's premium price.

Why 2 stars but not 1? At least it's doing what it is supposed to... Tracking is smooth, has no problems and no lag at all.

UPDATE 01-12-2014;

Contacted Amazon and requested a replacement, hoping that my mouse was really a faulty one... Well, the replacement one was even worse. On top of all the same problems, it's tracking sensor wasn't even working properly and the palm rest area was loose, not tight as it should be. A complete trash. Just returned it and got a refund... Don't waste your money on this crap, buy a Deathadder or Logitech G400 and save your money.

I am very happy with this monitor... so much so that I have one for home and for work. But while featuring an incredible picture (which is great for all my at home applications), I've been disappointed with some of the other features.
Beyond the lack of pivoting for W2K (not a problem at home, using W98-2ndEd) and the marginal speakers (fine for home), I bought this monitor because of the two video inputs. I am driving two computers at work and want to quickly switch back and forth between the two. Unfortunately the VP181 often seems to believe that the dormant computer is not providing any video signal and so when you try to toggle, it claims that there is no active signal and reverts to the original computer's input. Sort of frustrating. I have to jiggle the mouse of the dormant computer before toggling the VP, then it switches.
Also, while the switch interface on the base will not be a problem for the light user (who is driving only one computer), a single button to hit to switch both video and audio input from computer 1 to computer 2 would be nice. Currently, the user needs to switch the video and audio separately. Seven pushes of the buttons (preceeded by a jiggle of computer 2's mouse).
output: Fantastic Picture but some interface problems...

Great card! Installed flawlessly. Virtually silent and runs cool. Leave the switch on the end of the card set to ON. That enables the integrated fan control which only runs the two outside fans above 60degC. The button on top turns on UEFI bios control if your motherboard supports it. If you don't know what that means it's okay the card will just fine without it but it's a very cool feature soon to be a standard on all motherboards.

I upgraded from a 3.5-year-old Sapphire Radeon HD 6950. Performance is as expected. I always buy the model of anything that's a bit down from the top tier because performance is going to be sufficient and the price much lower. Photoshop and Lightroom filters blast through large multi-megabyte images like a hot knife through soft butter. Games are all on max settings. Sufficient is a gross understatement. I love this card.

But here's the thing that started all this: My grandson dropped my PC (not his fault, I was pushing him pretty hard, my bad) while we were moving a new desk into my office. Finally diagnosed the resulting failure to the 6950 at about midnight. Did some quick homework and decided on the R9 by 2am. Okay, that's decided now how do I get it fast? I have a business to run and this is my main work PC.

Newegg had the same R9 for $10 less than Amazon but with lots of shipping cost. You can say what you want about Bezos but he really knows how to make available to customers not only what they want but how they want it. With my Prime account I ordered it to be delivered the same day. The card arrived at 7:30pm that evening for 6 bucks shipping. Wow! Thanks, Jeff, you rock! Now if we could just convince you to become a Lew Rockwell Libertarian...

I guess the tablet itself is not guilty of anything wrong, instead Blackberry is guilty for letting us (innocent consumers who naively bet on this artifact) down. I shall confess i thought i was kind of closing a big deal when i get this playbook for an unbeatable price in the market, but it turned to be just a bait. Where should I start? first, lack of applications. Lack of interesting applications, of course, playbook hosts plenty of insignificant, nonsense and useless applications, but not the interesting ones. No Skype. Not a single decent PDF reader. It has a powerful camera, but of no use without convenient applications. It's simply the same as nothing, i hold nothing in my hand. It is well built, yes, it got this classy feeling you perceive when holding something solid and well constructed. But lacks features so simple and common sense as, for example, a \\"hold\\" button to prevent the device from starting when cleaning the screen's surface. Result: annoying cleaning session. The charger lasted less than a month, i had to purchase another. The device now doesn't keep the WIFI settings when restarted, i have to insert EVERYTIME i restart it, the WIFI settings again. Wasn't like that at the beginning, but seems that aging has done bad to it. Visited hundreds of forums searching for answers, but nothing could solve the problem. Browser was great at the beginning, now is simply obsolete. No updates, and the worst thing of all, no hope. No hope for anything, for any improve, for any change.

Simply unacceptable. Blackberry should stand trial for this.

CAUTION: NON-EXISTENT WARRANTY/SUPPORT. HUAWEI DOES NOT SUPPORT THIS PRODUCT IN THE USA.

I was initially very happy with my purchase, as I travel frequently and I found the device worked very well.

However, 6 months after purchase, the device would no longer create/broadcast a wifi network. It would continue to function if it was connected directly via USB to a computer. I tried to find a way to RMA this product for a replacement, only to find that there is ZERO support from Huawei, and that the supplier Multiplex Systems (Amazon does the order fulfillment) is evasive at best, and has ZERO customer support to deal with this (I was eventually directed to a gmail address multiplexsystems@gmail.com and have received no response).

This is a grey-market item, and thus it should be clearly noted that there is essentially no warranty.

This device when under heavy load runs hot, and I think therefore it would be unwise to purchase this without some form of warranty.

Buyer beware. Stay away from Multiplex Systems, and stay away from this product!
output: STAY AWAY.  GREY MARKET ITEM WITH ZERO SUPPORT/WARRANTY.

This is a great product, which is something I've come to expect from Asus. The things I'm sure you are worried about are picture quality and I'm happy to report that this is one of the best monitors I have used. It's screen is very bright due to being LED backlit (yes, the title says it LED, but it's actually LCD with LED backlighting which looks fantastic, so there's no need to worry about that) and the picture is crystal clear, with no mirroring issues or dead pixels to speak of. This monitor also comes with a 3 year warranty, which I have struggled to find monitors that cost more than this and are worse. It also looks nice, with it's curved base, nice silver lettering, and its glossy finish, it's a very pleasant thing to behold. And now comes my few niggles. The reason you're probably looking at this monitor in the first place was the integrated speakers, which, lets be honest, no one expected to be that great. They are okay, but they lack the punch of actual speakers from a stereo or headphones. I tried both the stereo and headphones option and found that the headphone jack has wiring issues causing a lack of audio for one of the ear cups or speakers. I fiddled with it and it eventually worked, but that really shouldn't be an issue out of the box. I haven't done further research into whether this is a widespread problem, but I am sure there are only a select few cases. My final issue, which is really more of a personal thing, is that while the glossy finish looks really good, it collects dust and shows it quite prominently.
I would say after all that, I would definitely buy this product and would recommend that everyone buys it. This product is really great with a few minor issues that are mostly just from personal experience. With its plethora of ports it's a highly versatile product that should be a great buy for anyone.
output: Great Monitor with one small downside

So, I have butter fingers and drop things constantly.  The most recent victim is my iPod, with a totally cracked screen.  So when I got the Note 8, I knew I needed a strong, protective case.  This does the trick.  It definitely protects my tablet.  For added protection, I can use the front cover, that doubles as a stand if I'm using it for movie watching, or when I need to follow a recipe in the kitchen.  Not only is it protected from dropping, but from food stains! It's not waterproof, but I don't plan on taking it swimming with me, just maybe the beach.  I also use it at the gym, on the bus and train, and don't worry about dropping it.  But with most OtterBox products, there is a flap that fits tightly over the headphone jack, and the charging jack.  It takes a bit to pull it back and push it in, so it should be sand proof.  The one minor flaw is that it weighs a ton, easily doubling the weight of the tablet, without the cover.  Add the cover and it's even heavier.  But added weight is nothing compared to having to buy a new tabled if I break this one.
output: Indestructable, with an added workout bonus!

UPDATE 09/10/12: I found the problem and the unit works great. There was a tiny piece of clear tape on the PCI connector that I guess remained after I had removed the large protective tape wrap. USB 3.0 speeds are high and the card reader seems fast also. And it does read 16GB SD cards! I stayed with the VIA drivers 1.90a. There is also an updated driver available on the Uspeed.co website. (notice it is not .com)!

The fact that it does not use up an internal motherboard USB 2.0 connector for the card reader function is a nice feature. The only interface is the PCI connector.

I had sent an e-mail request for help to Lapmate and they responded within one business day offering to provide a new unit so I would have to rate the seller service as 5 stars also. Their contact info is here on AMAZON in the item listing.

I would now give the unit 5 stars!
Jim D.

Original Review:
I bought this combination PCI TO USB3.0 CONVERTER with Card Reader as it seemed to have just the functionality I need. Delivery was quick, the unit appears well built and simple to install. The one I got has the PCI-E interface but no USB cable to motherboard as mentioned by some people here.

Instruction sheet is a little hard to read but hey, what is there to connect but plugging in the PCI 1X connector, connecting, a molex power connector and putting in four screws....simple it seems at first.

I installed it in a new LENOVO M81 desktop running Windows 7 Pro 64bit, i5-2500 processor with 8gb of memory. Power on, the red light comes on, put in the install CD and after a short period I get an error message during the driver loading. The disk was in a plastic wrapper and does not seem to be scratched. Tried installing drivers several time but no success.

Tried various usb 2.0 and 3.0 hard drives but even though I can hear the drives spin, nothing shows up in windows. Same with card reader trying 2GB and 6GB SD cards.

After reading some of the reviews here I downloaded the VIA drivers 1.90a for chipset 800/801. These seemed to install but I get a message \\"cannot find hardware....\\" and the install fails.

After a few hours of trying to get the thing going, I am not sure what to try next. Any ideas would be appreciated as I would like to keep the thing if I can get it working. Right now it is a one star but could be a 5 if I can get it working!

Jim D
output: GREAT PRODUCT DOES IT ALL!-GOOD SUPPORT FROM LAPTOPMATE..:)

Instances.input:
First off, I really do like these speakers. Nice quality, compact design, stylish look. Creative Labs makes decent quality products and this is a solid entry in their product line.

Now for the reality part:

Manufacturing something in white so it matches most iPods then slapping the name \\"HD\\" onto it doesn't make a product great or justify the seriously hefty price tag. These are a decent set of Creative Labs speakers, not an outstanding set of Bose. And contrary to the name, there's no such thing as \\"HD\\" speakers, particularly in a 2.0 configuration. There are surround sound speakers, THX certified speakers even Blu Ray True HD compatible speakers. But in the end, they're all just speakers, based on the same tried and true technology that's been around since the advent of recorded sound; a cone inside the speaker vibrates to sound impulses. That's it. All the fancy monikers only denote an ability to interpret particular frequencies with varying degrees of clarity and devoid of distortion. This is not the same as the evolution of standard TV to HiDef or DVD to Blu Ray. Hence the term \\"HD speakers\\" is just silly and misleading.

Sound quality:

I like to listen to Native American music, and the surest way to tell average speakers from great ones is to play Native music and see if they can handle both the highs of a cedar flute, and the lows of a nice drum. If they can do that, they can play anything. The sound quality of these is crisp, with decent lows but they do struggle a little at the high end. I hooked them up to my laptop on their own at first, and the sound was just average. Then I used a splitter to add a second set of speakers (also Creative Labs) and suddenly the depth and dynamic range was much improved. Point being, these are just an ok set of 2.0 speakers on their own.

Real world use:

I'd say these are good if you want to hook up your iPod and listen to music in the kitchen while you cook, or hook them up to a laptop and get better sound than your tiny laptop speakers alone can deliver. But there's no way these could come close to delivering the dynamic range of a quality stereo system. And by \\"quality\\" I don't necessarily mean you have to spend a lot of money.

The fact remains that sound quality is dependent on the speaker cone's ability to vibrate. The larger the cone, the better the vibration, and the better the sound. Very few compact speakers deliver good quality sound, and these are no different. Particularly without a proper subwoofer. It's just a fact of the science involved. When was the last time you went to a concert or the movies and saw tiny speakers hanging on the wall? Hence my beef with the term HD, it suggests something that isn't true and is merely an attempt to justify a hefty price on a product that doesn't merit it.

Setup is easy and basic. Plug them into the wall, then your music source, and you're set. There is a connector cable between the two speakers themselves, which is only useful if one speaker blows out and needs to be replaced. But at that point, I'd just replace them both. And the connector for the two speakers is one of those pronged ones, similar to an S-Video cable. Not fond of those since they tend to fall out easily.

Bottom line - I guess I'm not giving a glowing review here even though I do like the speakers. I guess I just feel they're too pricey and didn't buy into the HD thing. Don't get me wrong, these are good for what they are. Just not great when factoring in all the other variables. Creative Labs themselves makes many others that are likely as good for less money. But if you gotta have white to match your iPod, then this is the one for you. As a final observation, they do look expensive, so at least that jibes.e you cook, or hook them up to a laptop and get better sound than your tiny laptop speakers alone can deliver. But there's no way these could come close to delivering the dynamic range of a quality stereo system. And by \\"quality\\" I don't necessarily mean you have to spend a lot of money.

The fact remains that sound quality is dependent on the speaker cone's ability to vibrate. The larger the cone, the better the vibration, and the better the sound. Very few compact speakers deliver good quality sound, and these are no different. Particularly without a proper subwoofer. It's just a fact of the science involved. When was the last time you went to a concert or the movies and saw tiny speakers hanging on the wall? Hence my beef with the term HD, it suggests something that isn't true and is merely an attempt to justify a hefty price on a product that doesn't merit it.

Setup is easy and basic. Plug them into the wall, then your music source, and you're set. There is a connector cable between the two speakers themselves, which is only useful if one speaker blows out and needs to be replaced. But at that point, I'd just replace them both. And the connector for the two speakers is one of those pronged ones, similar to an S-Video cable. Not fond of those since they tend to fall out easily.

Bottom line - I guess I'm not giving a glowing review here even though I do like the speakers. I guess I just feel they're too pricey and didn't buy into the HD thing. Don't get me wrong, these are good for what they are. Just not great when factoring in all the other variables. Creative Labs themselves makes many others that are likely as good for less money. But if you gotta have white to match your iPod, then this is the one for you. As a final observation, they do look expensive, so at least that jibes.
output: Good Speakers but lets inject some reality...

I am an IT consultant, and I like this monitor so much, I have now bought close to 30 of them. Six for personal use. The two issues I have had with most monitors in portrait mode is that they either seemed too tall, or not wide enough. This monitor solves both of those problems. The resolution of 1600x1200 means that you get a width of 1200 pixels in portrait mode which I find is wide enough. I have on occasion found 1080 to be too narrow, but rarely feel that way with these. I also feel that I can still \\"see\\" the whole screen on these. With a 22\\" or 24\\" monitor in portrait mode, I felt I needed to move my head to scan from top to bottom, because they were so tall. I have two workstation that I primarily use, each has a mix of these in portrait mode and 22\\" or 24\\" displays in landscape. I find that I typically use the portraits for email, browsing or anything involving text. I don't do much work with video or images, but I have never noticed a problem with the speed of these monitors. Nor have I noticed any problems with the colors or whites, that others have mentioned.
The other nice thing about these are the inputs. There is VGA, DVI, Composite Video and S-Video. You can even do PIP with the analog video signals. There is also a built in USB hub in you need it. The only thing I am not crazy about are the menu controls, but they are no worse that most other monitors out there, and they are real buttons, that don't seem to get accidentally hit.
Granted most of what I have said pertains more to the resolution of 1600x1200 than the quality of the image, but doing a quick search on Newegg of monitors with this resolution, shows that the rest of them are at least twice as expensive. If you are looking for a portrait monitor, I can't see a better deal out there.
Exactly as I wanted, works perfectly ordered 3 of these in total for my new Coolermaster Elite 430 case/PC build.

I really wanted to like this machine. I've been using linux for 5 years, and would like nothing better than to see peace, love, and linux spread throughout the world.    The biggest problem, which caused me to return the machine, was that I couldn't get wifi to work. The Eee was able to detect my wifi network, but when I told it to connect to it, I got \\"No DHCPOFFERS received.\\" If you try a google search on \\"eee pc\\" \\"No DHCPOFFERS received\\", you'll get a bunch of hits on Asus's forums, where lots and lots of users are reporting the same problem. I might expect some hassles on a machine where I installed the drivers myself, or where I installed the wifi card myself. But when I pay for a machine that's got a preinstalled OS and preinstalled wifi, I expect it to work. I called Asus's tech support, and they figured out that the machine was shipped with an RaLink wifi card, when it should have been Atheros. They told me it wasn't going to work, and my only option was to return the machine.    Other impressions:    I expected the screen to be small, the trackpad to be awkward, and the GUI to be unresponsive, and they were. This is a netbook, so that's what you expect.    Xandros, unlike any other Linux distribution I've ever used, requires you to click through various EULAs to use the software. There was a EULA when I did the initial boot, and a EULA to use Star Office. This is lame. Open-source software does have licenses associated with it (e.g., the GPL), but they're not end-user licenses, and there's no reason to make the end user click through them.    The default desktop is cluttered with useless junk like special icons to get to Wikipedia and Google Maps.    They seem to expect you to access certain functionality through cryptic key combinations like Fn-F1 (open a wireless connection) and Ctrl-Alt-T (open a terminal window). This is not so bad if there's some other way to do it, which was the case for the wireless connection, but didn't seem to be the case for theterminal window. It's fine if they want to show certain functionality less prominently because it's not of interest to all users, but there should still be some way to discover it through the GUI without having to do a Google search.

Instances.input: I've used everything from Netgear and Linksys...and never have I been happier than with the SMC series of Switches.  With my Netgear switches, if I ever had to reset the router, I had to power cycle every switch in cascading order...ugh.  These, you turn them on and forget they are there...haven't had to power cycle one.    Now, the 16 port doesn't have a fan.  So, I like to use these in places where I want silence...like my desk/office or living room type situation.  Because of this, they can run warm....so, do give adequate spacing in your rack or on the shelf.  The 24 port has a built in fan, but the fan does generate noise....so, it keeps cooler, but is noisier...better for server closet type applications.      For an unmanaged switch, SMC is rock solid...I've got about half a dozen of these deployed (and the smaller 5-8 port units in addition) and they have served me well.
output: Gig-e speeds on the cheap, and quiet.
