Instances.input: I spent about a month, meticulously exploring the e-readers market. For me, it comes down to getting an experience close to reading an actual book and that means: no email, no browser, no programs - just pure reading. Kindle gets as close to feeling like I am reading an actual book as it can get in my opinion. The display is amazingly paper-like and it doesn't have any distracting features.

I received this tablet a while ago and I have had a while to use it so I have gotten to figure it out. The tablet I recieved wasnt like the one in the picture, it was black not grey and looked a little bit sleeker than the one shown. I messaged the seller about this and he said he sent me the updated version of the tablet.This tablet has a great speaker, I was very surprised at the quality of the speaker, when I put it on full volume it's usually to loud. It also has a USB mini and HDMI mini port on it. The USB mini port lets you add a USB mini to USB cord and you can plug anything USB like a flash drive, mouse, keyboard, iPod, or anything else that plugs into a USB port and it lets you connect your tablet to your computer and share files. The HDMI mini port lets you plug your tablet into your TV so you can use your tablet on a bigger screen. This is helpful if you are watching a movie or you need a bigger screen. Another great feature is the micro USB port that comes built in, this lets you expand the storage of your tablet so you aren't limited to a certain size. If you get multiple micro SD cards you can have limitless expandability and if you get an sd adapter for the micro sd card you can use it in your camera and then view the pictures with your tablet. (The tablet comes with a free 4gb micro sd card so you already get double your storage.) The tablet also has a button that simulates a home button so if you click on the home button, it will close the app you are using. Another great thing about the tablet is its front facing camera, this cameras quality surprised me when I used it. Even though it doesn't have the most megapixels of other tablets out there, it still works great if you want to take pictures of yourself or if you want to video chat. Overall, this tablet is a steal for its price. It comes with some great free apps and it even has google play. You get a fully functional android tablet for less than half the price of other tablets, even though it isn't super powerful, as long as you don't try to run 5 ram intensive apps at the same time it will work great. I also created a video review of this, you can view it at [...]

Instances.input: Bought this for my son 2 Christmases ago.  He loves it and it is a constant companion with him.  Easy Kindle reader, he's put lots of apps on it and internet and email.  He loves it.
Working great a good product at a good price.

It's been a little over a year since I made the switch from traditional books to the Kindle Paperwhite, and I couldn't be more satisfied. At first I wasn't sure whether I would get used to the differences between reading a traditional book and reading on the Kindle. For me, these included the weight and size of the Kindle versus that of a traditional book, and more importantly, the act of swiping at a screen to get to the next page. In addition, I had concerns about eye strain (I absolutely hate reading off computer screens), e-book availability, battery life, and visibility in different conditions. However, my concerns disappeared within a couple days of receiving my new toy.

I was able to find a number of free, interesting books available through Amazon, which I would have never come across otherwise. While I did not come across any mainstream titles or recently released books, this came as no surprise. I was, however, pleasantly surprised at the selection of e-books available through my local library's website. Ultimately, I've found that the majority of best sellers are available for Kindle, and usually cost a bit less than their hard copy counterparts.

I especially love my Kindle for traveling. It is small and lightweight enough to tote around in my purse/carry-on, and has enough battery life to last throughout an entire flight. The backlight eliminates the need for the abrasive overhead reading lights, and keeps you from bothering the people trying to sleep in the seats around you. Whether you're reading in harsh sunlight or pitch darkness, the Kindle Paperwhite won't disappoint!!
output: A Must-Have for Travel & Life in General!!

Instances.input:
Before putting any memory into my machines I always run a diagnostic utility called sys_basher, a Linux utility that test uses extensive test patterns that exercise every address in the DIMM. This utility ran for almost 3 hours and completed without any faults. That's what we want to see! I now had the DIMMs in machine for over two weeks, no problems, and I see less paging as I replaced 8GB by 16GB for a total of 32GB.

The DIMMS are rated for 2400 MHz. The tests were run at a default DRAM clock rate of 1600 MHz. The DIMMs can be overclocked on some machines in the BIOS, whether that is possible or depends on the chip set. Whether overclocking is used or not the fact that these DIMMS can support higher clock rates improves timing margins (and thus reliability).

Below are reports from sys_basher:
DIMM BANK 0
Total Width: 64,Data Width: 64
Size: 8192 MBytes
Configured Speed: 1600 MHz, MAX Speed: 1600 MHz
form_factor: DIMM
Start Addr: 0000000000000000
End Addr: 00000001FFFFFFFF
Interleave Position: 1
Interleave Depth: 2

DIMM BANK 1
Total Width: 64,Data Width: 64
Size: 8192 MBytes
Configured Speed: 1600 MHz, MAX Speed: 1600 MHz
form_factor: DIMM
Start Addr: 0000000000000000
End Addr: 00000001FFFFFFFF
Interleave Position: 1
Interleave Depth: 2

PASSED, ran for 10060.60 seconds

The RAM worked perfectly.

This DIMMs are provided by Silicone Power.

Ali Julia review
output: Capable of being overclocked, even if overclocking is not used timing margins improve reliability

Instances.input:
The performance seems to be within the advertised specs when using the ATTO benchmarks as a stand-alone drive, but that's where all the good news come to an end. When trying other utilities such as Crystal Disk benchmark, is a whole other story. The drive reads are still okay even though they are below the advertised specs, but the writes are abysmal at around 78MB/s. Thinking it was a glitch from the application, I tried the same benchmark on my already installed Intel SSD drive. To my surprise, the much older Intel SSD blew the Kingston drive away with both utilities and writes were always well above 300MB/s.

I gave it the benefit of the doubt, so I went ahead and configured it as a cache drive with Intel's RST as I originally intended. I got the same 78MB/s writes not just with the bench tools, but also by writing from my main SSD to the newly configured array. What's actually truly sad is that the mechanical drive can actually write faster than that by itself, effectively defeating the purpose of the drive to be used as a cache device since it will be recording incompressible data such as multiple OTA TV shows (this is a Media Center PC).

To add insult to the injury, I also have an issue with this SSD where the HDD light on the computer now remains ON at all times, combined with my disappointment this is now an irritant and complete eyesore. Removing the Kingston SSD resolves this, and I can put back the old SanDisk mSATA drive without causing this new issue.

In a nutshell, I am sorely disappointed with Kingston and I am going to have Amazon issue me a full refund. The advertised specs are a total joke using known gimmicks such as compressible data algorithms with ATTO to "boost" their numbers with the Sandforce chipsets and I should have known that these specs were too good to be true for an mSATA drive. Buyer beware of boosted benchmarks by this manufacturer, stay with Intel or Samsung branded SSDs if you care about real performance.
output: Not what I expected, misleading specs

Instances.input:
I ordered this item thinking I was going to get a LG screen (what originally came in the MacBook). Instead it is a Sharp screen adapted to fit the MacBook. There are no screw provisions at the top of the screen for the webcam to fasten on to, the cord for the backlight was longer than OEM, and the pigtail for it was soldered and heatshrunk instead of being soldered straight to the board. The graphics cable port was \\"adapted\\" to accept the MacBook's video cable. Overall, I wasn't impressed nor disappointed. I was just hoping for a better fitting screen. I am happy to say it arrived quickly and works great so far, but I feel that the build quality was subpar for a $97 screen. The screen was shipped in a nice, oversized box and was very well padded with about 10 feet of bubblewrap around it. I paid $65 for a replacement screen for my girlfriend's Toshiba that she decided to use to weigh herself, and that screen was a direct swap without any extra legnth cables or adapters. I feel like this screen has the build quality of a $50-$60 screen. Not $97. But it's not my money or my laptop. I just was the one to fix it, and it earned me a quick $100, and saved the customer over $500 if she would have had Apple replace the screen. I'm not saying it's a bad screen, I just want future buyers to know EXACTLY what they're getting.

Cheers folks,

Kevin
output: It works, but it isn't perfect.

I waited a long time before upgrading my Geforce 660Ti video card to this one and it was still working fairly well for most games but the price was right and I got a $60 game that I was planning to buy offered as a bonus.
The install was indeed easy and it works perfectly well. It is worth noting that the Window experience user rate did not change at 7.9 (max for windows 7).
Now for the novice users, here are a few very basic explanations about Nvidia video cards:
- 970 stands for:
9 is the release version
70 is the performance level
This means that a Geforce 690 will be outperforming a 970 in pure performance. (check the prices and you'll see how expensive it is still).
- You should pay attention to the amount of RAM your card will have as some games are very demanding in that level. I mention games because these cards are mostly for gamers. Unless you process lots of pictures or videos, a much cheaper card will be enough if you do not play the latest games.
- Your choice of card should be depending on your video resolution. If you are using a 720p, that card may be too good for your needs. For a long time, I was using a projector with 720p definition and my games would run smoothly with a 3-4 years old card.

In comparison with the 660Ti, I can say that:
- This card has twice the performance stats with FutureMark of the 660Ti. It may not translate into twice the amount of FPS but it definitely shows some improvements.
- It is much more silent than the 660Ti which could get fairly noisy at times. In comparison, I never hear the fans for this one.
- It has a better temperature control.

In conclusion, I am fully satisfied.

Instances.input: I ordered this mSATA SSD to replace the SSD in my new Dell XPS13 Ultrabook.  It has performed fast and flawlessly for the 6 months that I have had it in use.  This still seems to be the available SSD of this size in mSATA format (Samsung makes one but will not sell it direct to consumers).  Note: I understand SSDs at great depth - I previously contracted with 3 SSD manufacturers to write Windows Storport drivers for them (and a BIOS bootrom for one).  SSDs begin to suffer from accelerated flash wear and slower performance (dropping response time by 20x is serious) when they are kept too full (even though the manufacturers over-provision somewhat).  The SSD flash manager then has to move things around to get free pages, with excessive erases and the SSD slows horribly (a page of MLC flash has about ~5K erases before it starts to fail).  The rule is to never allow your SSD to be more than 50% full (Dell marketing does not understand SSDs and does not provide for an SSD of this capacity in their Ultrabooks).

Where to begin. ECS is a sub par manufacturer. Throughout their history, their products have been made with one thing in mind, volume/price ratio. The more they sell of their inferior products, the less their return percentage will rear its' ugly head. There is a reason why a biostar motherboard, for instance, costs 20.00 more. The components (caps, solder, pwm, I/o board, components, etc) are intended to last longer than the provided warranty period, albeit not more than 4-5 years on I/o boards made today.
The worst aspect of the ECS sales model is their rebate processes. Most companies outsource their rebates to a third party to process for them. ECS has partnered with a company called VELOCITY FULFILLMENT, INC. Needless to say, rebates are NOT getting processed. Very soon, in fact, we may see a class action suit gathering steam against both of these entities.

ECS DOES NOT HONOR ITS' REBATE PROMISES.
What they do very well is pass the buck to their third party (like Velocity Fulfillment) for rebate fulfillment
In the end, no one seems to be responsible and the customer gets hurt.

There is enough precedence in our legal system to remind these retailers they will be held responsible when the shoe drops. The rebates, after all, are advertised on websites like amazon and new*gg and is a compelling force in making a purchasing decision for many of us. The responsibility lay squarely on all three (seller who took your money, mfg. who made the product and offered the rebate via the seller, and the fulfillment company that stands to gain from not processing your rebate).

AMAZON, you have a great reputation amongst online shoppers. Hold your mfg. partners responsible for unprocessed rebates, or you may end up paying for it out of the profits you make when you collaborated in the first place.
output: My fellow amazon shoppers, stay away from ECS

I had very high hopes for this one; I'd been through two cases so far that were marketed for both the original and the Retina iPad mini ("iPad mini 2") that initially fit, but then started cracking at the corners and breaking away until they no longer held the iPad, much less protected its corners.

This one fit in-store, so I took my chances. Things looked great for about a week, then the first cracks started showing. And then a few shards came off. Today, the upper right corner broke off, and my iPad would not be protected if it hit there.

The problem with this and just about every other case originally designed to fit the first iPad mini is that the first one was .01" thinner than the Retina iPad mini. Sounds trivial, and even seems meaningless when you first try cases, but that extra little bit appears to be just enough to put extra stresses on the cases.

In short, if a fitted case promises to fit both an original iPad mini and a Retina iPad mini, it was designed for the first one, and will probably not last very long in use on the newer one. I have no idea about the size of the Retina iPad mini 2 ("iPad mini 3").

If it had stayed intact, I'd give it 5 stars - it's a fantastic case, aside from that whole crumbling at the sensitive corners less than a month after I bought it part.
output: Great at first, but corners cracking away after three weeks and will soon be useless (iPad mini 2 - "Retina")

I have had my Gateway netbook for less than a year, but it is laggy and freezes and now I've had several re-boot screens. I only use word documents and the internet on it, so it is definitely faulty hardware. Now, faulty hardware happens, but I do judge a company by how they treat their customers after their product has been bought.

I had to call Gateway (aka Acer) for recovery discs because Best Buy is going to diagnose the hardware and I need them. Of course, the netbook has no disc drives, so I need Gateway to send me the \\"discs\\" on a USB drive (I'm assuming).

I called their customer service and could only get an automated \\"person\\" to answer. The \\"person\\" said I needed my serial number. I gave it (four or five times). It was not recognized. Rather than realizing there was a fault with the program, the \\"woman\\" hung up on me and refused to put me through to customer service without my serial number. I am very uncertain why the program did not recognize my serial number, because I spoke clearly and do not have an accent. I'll admit, the last time or two was rushed because I was getting very angry, but the first two times I spoke slowly and clearly.

Now I have a netbook that is well under a year old, no way to get Windows and no means by which to get support from Gateway (which is run by Acer, btw.) Their customer service is not only horrible, it their automated system does not recognize your serial number, it is non-existent.
output: Faulty product and very bad customer service

Keyboard Skin 5/5: The skin has their logo on the space bar. It fits fine and has a great matching color. It was free and works well, it's fantastic. The quality was the same as another skin I bought.

Case Color & Functionality 5/5: Despite what other reviewers said, I thought the color was more vibrant than on the picture, but it is fine for me. If you're looking to protect your cover from scratches and still be lightweight, it's perfect. The back feet make it great for movies!

The Case 1/5:This case would've had a 5/5 if it wasn't for the scratches. I bought the case to protect it from damage, yes, but I did not want scratches already on it.

Satisfactory Level 2/5: Everything was fine up until I saw those marks. If it was on the bottom it would've been alright.

Overall Rating 3/5: It would have been a 5/5 if not for the scratches on top. I'm one of those troublesome customers that can't stand a few light scratches, but to have such an obvious one right on top that people notice leaves me unsatisfied.

For full disclosure, I received a free AC3200 Nighthawk X6 Tri-Band WiFi Router (R8000) from NETGEAR as part of review program.

As someone coming from the standard Uverse wireless access point after giving up on dealing with mid-tier Linksys, I must say I'm ecstatic to finally have a router that was a breeze to setup and provides a fast steady connection without any more time spent tinkering or resetting. It just works.

The GUI on this router the best I have had to deal with. Without referencing install documentation I had the router hard wired to my primary computer, a secured primary wireless network (802.11ac!), a secondary network, and a guest network in under 15 minutes. There is a great feature called "Smart Connect" which allows one SSID to be broadcast for multiple radios. The NETGEAR genie user interface made it easy to find the appropriate settings and know which setting I should choose. An intuitive UI is something that other manufacturers I've dealt with just haven't been able to accomplish as successfully. The parental controls available appear to offer all functionality I would ever need - if I was in a situation that it was necessary. Logs and other settings provide all the information I could want.

All of my devices connected flawlessly. Sustained wireless speeds are a bit higher than before but the main benefit has been NO MORE DROPPED CONNECTIONS! My devices all stay at full bars throughout my house and only drop down to 4 when I go outside on the opposite end of the house (where I previously had spotty reception). Plex streaming to my chromecast no longer stutters as I frequently experienced before the router upgrade.

TLDR; if you are looking for a great router then you should definitely consider this one as you won't be disappointed. Bonus, it looks amazing.

Instances.input: As cheaply made as this cover is, the fit of it is spot on.  For a cover as cheap as this, it is fairly common to be ill-fitted with misaligned orifices.  With this one, however, everything lines up perfectly.  All the holes are centered where they're supposed to be and allow for total and easy access to what you need to access; even the hole for the BlackBerry logo is perfectly centered.  It's a very snug fit that doesn't allow your PlayBook to jostle around inside the cover.  It will no doubt keep it looking new for years (or months, the way technology goes) to come.    My only complaint with this cover is that I'm sure I will have to remove it every night to use the charging pod I just ordered.  That isn't a knock against this cover, as no case or cover currently available is going to work with the charging pod.  My only other complaint is with the stylus.  It's not very good at all.  The screen has to be PRISTINE in order for the stylus to work even moderately.  It's much easier and faster to just use a finger as intended.  One nifty feature about the stylus, though, is that it has a handy little pin inside that can be used to do a hard reset of the PlayBook if necessary.  Just screw the clip end off, and voila'!    In a nutshell, this isn't the prettiest cover out there.  In my opinion, it kind of cheapens the look of the PlayBook itself with it's random-looking shiny pieces, but I challenge you to find one that has a better fit.  Add a screen protector and your PlayBook will be very cozy and protected from most any bumps and scrapes.  I would venture to say this cover will even provide some protection against impacts from a short fall to a hard surface; excepting the screen, of course.  Aesthetics aside, you will not be disappointed with your purchase if functionality as designed is your main concern.

This Mini PowerBank 6000 mAh is USB portable charger. I cannot tell you how Awesome it is and I'm so happy with my purchase. My problem was always having my phone with a very low battery by the end of each day. I use my phone frequently during a day for phone calls, texting, checking email and I am always on the go. BlinkOne PowerBank came with Micro USB cable and user manual. This stylish, light, durable, powerful and portable charger saves me everyday that I love it even more! It is very simple to use that even a caveman can do it. BlinkOne powerbank has dual USB which lets me charge multiple devices at the same time. I just connect my device to either USB port on the front and press a power button. That's all I have to do to start a charge. I don't ever have to worry about overcharging my handheld devices because once they are fully charged, powerbank will auto shut off. It can supply power to any handheld device. I use it on my Iphone 4S, Ipad, and camera. They charge fast as if they were plugged into an outlet. In addition to everything, it has built-in 4 bar indicatior showing power usage level. It even has a strong LED flash light as a Bonus. It really helps me to find my way around when it is dark. I wish I had this mini powerbank earlier when I was stuck in the middle of nowhere with my phone dead. This is a reason #1 to have this perfect for all occasions multipurpose device because in case of emergency it will HELP. BlinkOne is the most affordable compared to other powerbanks out there and I know it will last for a very long time because it is backed by BlinkOne Lifetime Warrenty. I am going to buy it as a gift for my family members these holidays!!!

When my old (about 4 years old) power supply failed, I pulled it out and discovered that it was an Antec TruePower II 550W power supply.  Now, there are two things about power supplies, one, they rarely fail, and two, when they fail it's probably because they were overloaded.  I knew that Antec had a good reputation for power supplies (along with Corsair, PC Power and Cooling, and some others), so I included it in my search for a replacement.      One thing I found out was that Antec has by far the best website among power supply companies.  Good or bad, I knew exactly what I was getting, including how many cables the unit had, of what type, etc.  Without this information, it's very difficult to buy a power supply.      The Antec power supply is somewhat \\"modular\\" in that it has a few cables (four) which can be plugged in to the power supply or left uninstalled, as needed.  I installed only one of these cables, and that one only to power the cooling system.  Thus, by far the majority of cables are permanently attached to the power supply, making it less modular than one might believe.  Some information suggests that modularity (in the form of plug-in cables) is not a good idea anyway, because of the added electrical resistance, but it does keep your installation somewhat cleaner.      I should mention that all the wires are grouped into connector groups and bound together with mesh cable protectors, a system I found much easier to deal with than tie-wrapped wires.  I used only a couple of large removable wraps to keep the cables in place: the manufacturer's cable protectors did everything else.      It's difficult to be satisfied or not with a power supply until several years have passed.  I am satisfied for the present, but if this unit fails in less than five years, I will probably try another make.
output: A Decent Power Supply, So Far

The 2nd seemed to work fine - but after a few weeks now suffers the same thing.  I missed the deadline for returning the first dock because I was traveling.  The 2nd one died outside of Amazon's return window.    So, 2 months after purchase, both are useless.  We simply can't trust them to work.    The original Thermaltakes are still working fine - some are now 3 years old and going strong.    Maybe others have had better luck. It also runs 16GB of vengeance memory like a champ, and has no problems with the GTX 770 on it either. Looks great and has all the trappings of a high-end board.

My husband and parents both recently got new computers, and both used this little device to move over all their stuff. Both were transferring from XP to Vista.

My husband at first did it manually with the device, which he said was kind of a pain (moving things from Outlook Express to Windows Mail etc). I used the EasyTransfer and it worked great. IIRC, the 'fat end' goes into the NEW computer, and the other end into the old one. I may have that backwards - try it both ways until you see both computers' stuff on the new computer. The directions kinda suck, but the tool is pretty self-explanatory.

Anyway, it transferred over files, basic preferences (desktop background etc), emails, and basic email settings (from OE to Mail), and also Internet Explorer favorites. Note that it will NOT transfer passwords that you've told IE to 'remember\\" (a good thing in my book, for security). My parents had a little shell shock with this since they are bad about writing down that stuff and also bad about updating new email addresses to get the info - but that's a different story.

I haven't used this on my Mac, but I'm sure it would work fine. So final analysis - for someone who has a TON of stuff on a computer and no external hard drive to move it to, and who cannot/does not want to network the computers wirelessly, this is a good solution. I still wouldn't pay more than say $20 or so for it though, since likely it'll only be used when you get a new computer, and anyone with some knowhow could easily network or move things in another way. A great find on Vine for me though - thanks Amazon!
output: great, esp for non-tech savvy types

I have had the DIR-826L for 11 months. There is only one month to go on the warranty.

This DIR-826L would periodically drop the network connection and I would reset it. The drops have continued to get more frequent such that I had to reset it almost daily. Recently, we just started feeling that the Internet was really slow. Initially I did not associate that with this device, so I called my internet service provider about networking issues. The service provider and I determined the problem was in my wireless router.

I replaced this DIR-826L with an older Linksys device that I had available, and my network is back to full high-speed functionality.

I have extensive background in both electronics and the networking. Before I called technical support, I ensured that I have the latest firmware installed. Even though I had done extensive network troubleshooting already, and had upgraded the firmware techsupport wanted me to rebuild my network again, install the firmware again then, call them back again if all this did not work.

I refused to do all this because I had done it all before I called them. Based on my background in electronics, I am convinced the problem is a result of the continued deterioration of the router components and the effect of heat on those components. The router has always been quite warm to the touch. The representative I was talking with did periodically confer with others. I believe he was trying to get me authorization for an RMA, however they would not give him permission. I told him I appreciated his personal efforts and realize that he was just following instructions. However, D-Link had won. They have avoided providing me another router to try.

All I could do now is post my experience on Amazon where I bought the router, then look for one from another company.
output: 11 Months of Network Issues before things got so bad I called tech support

Instances.input: I purchased this item November 11, 2009 ~ it is now nearly 2 mos. after that and this hub has gone completely dead. I started having issues with this about 1-2 weeks ago when I noticed that the mouse I have hooked up to it kept having issues. I only kept about 3 or 4 items connected to it at all times, some of which weren't even \\"on\\" all the time. For instance, I had my camera connected, but only operated it when I needed to upload pics. I also kept my phone USB cord connected, but only used that when I wanted to sync songs or charge it briefly. Other than that, just my mouse was hooked up and maybe my USB 5lb. scale for shipping purposes. Like mentioned before, I've had this less than 2 mos. and the whole thing is now dead, but gives me pop-up errors on the screen saying that the connected USB is not recognizable. About a week ago was the first error, so I unplugged everything, let it \\"simmer down\\" for a few, then plugged everything back in and it worked great - until now.  Now, nothing will work. I specifically purchased this one because it wasn't the cheapest one for sale ~ you always hear \\"you get what you pay for\\" ~ so I paid like $25 for this one hoping that it would work better than most. Also, I liked this one because it was a 7-port hub, which was plenty of ports for my extra stuff. In addition, I bought this one because it included the a/c adapter. I didn't buy this item here. I think a lot of people like this product because it is more feature-rich than others. USB out, in particular, is of great interest to people who would like to use it to charge cell phones and iPods. This feature does work, but you must remember to move the switch from USB In to USB Out. You will also need to use the hand crank to manually charge the external device. It is a kind of tiring, because you will feel a much greater hand crank resistance compared to cranking to charge the flashlight's internal battery! BTW, instead of manually charging the internal battery, you can also connect the flashlight via the included USB cable to a computer's USB port, and in about 12 hours, it would be fully charged. Remember to move the switch to USB In when you do this. A fully charged flashlight will NOT charge your iPod or cell phone via the USB Out port, you must use the hand crank! You'll probably be pretty tired, but at least you can make that important phone call! :) One other point, if Duracell had designed a small storage compartment for that vital USB cable and connector, it would have been even better.
output: USB charging does work, but you must ...

To start out, I love the hardware that is my my Kindle.  The device is perfect at what it is designed to do, namely provide a medium for the display of printed media in an electronic format.  The hardware is very thin, light, and the battery life is amazing.  The e-ink display does a great job for display b/w and grayscale images in both low and bright light.  The 3G data modem does a great job in both the US and internationally.      The software is good at what it is designed to do, although there could be some improvements to the intuitiveness of the software.  My biggest beef that prevents me to recommending the Kindle to other buyers is the lack of compatibility with, what has become \\"industry standard\\" electronic book formats.  The lack of compatibility with Adobe® EPUB & PDF eBooks makes it incompatible with the formats, for example, most libraries use to lend books.     Thus, Amazon has done a pretty good job of adopting the \\"Walled garden\\" format that Apple has had great success with.  Unfortunately, for those of us that hate limitations in choice, the walled garden business models just don't work.      I hope that Amazon will fix this unacceptable decision in a future software update.
output: Great device, walled garden is problematic

We have 5 people using the Kindle in our house, including 3 kids, so we figured a cover is an absolute MUST. There are many covers around, but I found that most of them are either ugly (I HATE leather cases) or way to expensive IMHO.
This one has some excellent features:
* available in many colors
* thin and sleek
* made out of plastic, not leather or some other weird material
* has a "smart cover" that puts the K in 'sleep mode' when it's closed and turns it up when it's opened
* has a rubber band that keeps the lid in place while shut
* the lid can fold and keep the K upright which is convenient
* very attractive price

some things I liked less, and hence the "mixed feelings":
* my main concern is build quality. The plastic rear cover looks and feels great, but the lid and the rubber band look like they might not survive long and I hope I will be proven wrong
* upright position is not adjustable

Overall this is a great value for the price
output: I really like it, but have some mixed feelings

If you have an older computer, or in my case a small form factor with limited expansion, this product appears to be a good choice for adding capacity.  After two months in service things seem to be pretty stable.  Will update review if problems appear. We were suffering with an old D-link DCM-202. The thing would disconnect sometimes 6 times an hour. And at times only parts of a webpage would load. Like all the text but no pictures. Or some would load, others would not. We would always yell out \\"stupid Charter is down again\\". I wasn't sure if it was the modem or Charter. But I finally gave up and purchased the Motorola SB6121. The install was fast and working with Charter was equally as fast and now we have a modem that will run all day with no disconnects. And even though according to Charter I didn't need DOCSIS 3.0 for my level of internet speed I do notice a significant decrease in the time it takes for websites to load. And going to one of those speed checker websites reports download speeds that are at least twice as fast as they were with the D-link (although I think those reported speeds are a little misleading). I'm extremely satisfied and would recommend this thing to any Charter subscriber.

Update 9/3/13: Unfortunately Charter now supplies modems for free and will not let me use this one even though it is Charter approved. They were having too much trouble with people not knowing what they were doing with their personal routers I guess.

Unfortunately, the SB6180 is not on Comcast's list of "suggested" or "approved" modems. If that hasn't changed when you buy it, the CS and lower level TS will tell you it's "Not Supported", and you need to buy a different modem. Comcast tried to get it working as a SB6121. Failed. Then I called back and told them it was a SB6141. That model is on their list. Anyway, the first hour long call didn’t get it working. The second one did.

The configuration file my local Comcast office is using: d11_m_sbg6580_silver_c01.cm
Speed? I don’t know what to think. Comcast’s and DSL Reports say it’s between 10 and 24 Mbps. And my service is “rated” at 6 or 12 Mbps. If I were given to hyperbole, I say I got a 400% increase in speed after installing this modem. The truth is probably somewhat less. Comcast appears to be upgrading the 6Mbps service to 12Mbps. Still, 12 to 24, just by using a different modem? Not bad if it’s real.
good product, good price, quick delivery, couldn't be more pleased.  Keep up the good work

Instances.input:
...I was building a custom high-end PC for extreme graphics work, and after much research decided to get this case as it was spacious and had LOTS of fans built into it.

...The case is Outstanding and i love it!..All the techies I work with in a post-production house are highly impressed with it as well, so much so that they all want one now, so it is safe to say it is sturdy, roomy, and very quiet!

...However, the 'BUT!' in the title refers to the delivery...or botched delvery...which is NOT the sellers fault at all, but Totally on Fed-Ex!

...I had this delivered to work, and I copied and pasted the address from google-maps, but Amazon got one number off, ( NO idea How? )...so instead of it being 4110..it was 4100....no big deal, just 4 doors down, so when I saw the order info, I corrected it on the online delivery-info, and went down to tell the folks at 4100 that Fed-Ex may deliver a package there, so please send them to me..( seemed fool-proof, right? )...WRONG!

...Somewhere along the line in the massive Fed-Ex system, a computer decided the name of the company and address did not match, so had the package sent back to the warehouse. When I saw this online, I attempted to correct this online, but with no luck, so I called customer service. Explained the situation, they typed in the corrections, and told me it would be delivered the next day.

...It did NOT arrive the next day, so I phoned again and they apologized but said the driver could not find the address, which was 4100 (?!)...I went thru the entire fiasco again, explained it all, and they promised it would corrected and be delivered the next day.

...It did NOT arrive the next day! When I checked online late in the day, it said it had been delivered?...HUH?...WTF?!

...Went down to 4100 for the 5th time, but they had not even seen the fed-Ex guy that day, so phoned again, and they promised to investigate and phone me back...which they did a few hours later, but I knew this conversation was not going to go well when the person on the other end of the line called me by a wrong name! Turns out they had a temp-driver who was new, and he had a package with a smeared tracking number, so he called dispatch, and they thought it was MY package, so gave him MY tracking number and it was delivered, but to the wrong person at another address, and it wasnt even MY package!

...The dispatch-manager called me the next day to explain this, but that call started badly as he also called me by a wrong name! I was starting to lose faith in the system by this point!...DAMN! He then told me they thought they knew where MY package might be, and it would be delivered the next day....( I have heard this line several times before by this point! )....

...I am leaving out several more phone calls and conflicting stories, but it was Finally delivered late the next day, but the frosting on the cake was the poor driver came in and called me by the wrong name as well! ( So now I have a new name with all the guys at work, too! )....Thanks, Fed-Ex!

...It actually took 10 DAYS to get this package to me! Unbelievable! I know Fed-Ex delivers millions of packages every day all around the world, but this one was a very noteable exception! I ordered each component of this new PC online, and ALL the rest were delivered by UPS with out a single failure or delay. In fact, one order I placed at 6:35PM, and it arrived by 10:30AM the Next morning, without my requesting it be overnighted! (?)...No idea how, but that aint a complaint, folks!

...Big corporations like Fed-Ex normally work highly efficiently; just like the freeways here in SoCal, but when a problem occurs, it is friggin Amazing!

...I can look back on it now and smile, but it was pure Hell when I was going thru it! I am sure each of you reading this have similar horror stories about some company or another, so I am chalkingthis up as the tiny abberation in a usually excellent company's performance, but had to vent about it anyway....

...Now, I just have to get used to my new name!...LOL!.........

I'm an avid gamer heavily into online FPS games. So it goes without saying the mouse is one of the more important equipment to a gamer like myself. I took a look at this mouse, looked very snazzy, and the design seemed rather ergonomic. Didn't have a store display model I can play around with, but I still purchased this anyways.
Been using this for about a week now. If you're a FPS gamer, you'll realize that when you move your mouse, you often times lift the mouse up and reposition and move the mouse again. This wasn't made for that. There is a groove for the thumb but the groove on the right side seems to have been made for the ring finger, but feels more comfortable placing my pinkie finger there.
And because of that oddly placed groove on the right side, I'm constantly struggling to find a good position to lay my hands on. I've been on the recieving end of someone's muzzle many times because I was preoccupied with trying to find comfort.
For basic window navigation and web surfing, it's okay. The back page button is real handy, and the autoscroll down button (right below the wheel) saves me the hassle of constantly scrolling the wheel. However, the forward page button and autoscroll up button is placed in an awkward position, requiring you to reposition your hand just to reach those two.
Not a horrible purchase by far. Haven't had trouble...yet.
edit - 3 June 2004:
I just noticed this. Try this the next time you're in a store with a display model of Mx 510. Flip the mouse around so the buttons are pointing at your direction. Now, put your LEFT hand on the mouse. REAL comfortable, aren't they? The thumb groove is not crampy, and the pinkie and ring finger now has a VERY comfortable spot!
Did logitech put the grooves on backwards?! My goodness!

I purchased this drive a little over a month ago. I connected it using the Firewire port and it worked great, but later I noticed the drive had dissapeared. When I clicked on \\"My Computer\\" it was no longer there. I could get the drive to return by rebooting or powering the drive off and then back on. This happended numerous times so I disconnected the drive from the Firewire Port and connected thru the USB Port. Expericenced the same problem. Next I connected thru the eSATA port and the exact same problem continued. I went to the Western Digital support website and left a message describing the problem. While waiting for them to respond, I continued to search their website for an answer. Finally, I found the fix. Go to [...] click on \\"Downloads\\", click \\"MY Book\\", then click on the type of My Book drive you have, in my case it was the \\"Home Edition\\". Here you will see a list of software available for download. I chose to download the \\"My Book Home Firmware Update for PC\\". After downloading, I installed it and the problem was fixed. I tested the drive on all 3 ports and the drive works perfectly with no more disappearing acts. Several days later I received a response from Western Digital Support advising me to run diagosic software to troubleshoot my problem. They were not only late with their response, but a waste of time. In summary, this is a good drive. Buy it, install the firmware update and you're good to go.
output: Great Drive Once You Update to Latest Firmware

This is a peripheral that has complex capabilities and permits to perform a variety of functions related to digital photos and graphics. There are two parts to this product, the actual physical tablet and the software included. The tablet allows using a pen that has the functionality of a mouse and more, including right and left click buttons. Handling the pen is a little awkward at first, especially because the starting point of the pen on the tablet alters the initial positioning of the cursor on the screen. This definitely makes sense, since it is necessary for being able to draw on the tablet using a set point of reference, but if you are using the pen for normal mouse functions, it takes a while to get used to. The mouse provided has the typical functionalities of a wireless mouse and does not provide any benefits beyond this. There are also customizable buttons on the tablet, similar to the hot keys you have on your keyboard for browsing the web, accessing your email, etc. One in particular allows for zooming in and out, which is very handy when working on pictures trying to perfect them.

The software provided with the product is pretty advanced too, and maybe this should have given me a hint regarding how user friendly the product was for novices. Corel allows creating artwork and has a variety of tools at your disposal. This is where I found the pen to be most useful, and I even tried creating handwritten notes, being reasonably successful. Photoshop provides tools to improve your digital photos and alter them in creative ways. My experience with this software is limited, so I had a hard time extracting serious benefits from using the tablet in this environment. I can see though, how professionals or serious users would benefit from using the pen and tablet to alter pictures. In my case, I could see the usefulness of Photoshop, especially with the nik Color Efex add on, but I did not understand how to incorporate the tablet usage in this process.

The installation of the drivers for the hardware and the software suite was straightforward and even though it took a few minutes, it was completely hassle free. I think Bamboo could definitely improve their User Guide with further ideas on how to use the tools in combination with the tablet. Overall, I believe that advanced users will find this peripheral very useful, but the rest of us are likely to be overwhelmed by its complexity.nstallation of the drivers for the hardware and the software suite was straightforward and even though it took a few minutes, it was completely hassle free. I think Bamboo could definitely improve their User Guide with further ideas on how to use the tools in combination with the tablet. Overall, I believe that advanced users will find this peripheral very useful, but the rest of us are likely to be overwhelmed by its complexity.
output: Definitely for advanced users, not so much for the rest of us

Instances.input:
UPDATED: This thing is great BUT installation can be very hard and the tech support is ONLY by email.

NEW RATINGS: INSTALLATION WOES ... 1 star
\ DEVICE ONCE INSTALLED 4 stars

My installs process took about a week and required help from Microsoft Store techs and a visit from COMCAST. The product is complex, requiring support either from its vendor (good luck) or from the three companies involved Microsoft, Ceton and Comcast. Ceton only offers voice support at $99/hr/ They also offer \\"free\\" email support limited to part of each day and with all the limitations of any email system. They do not even offer chat!

However, after a loot of complaining here, rep did contact me and she was terrific.

Here is the story:

To even get started you need to go to a local Comcast store to get a cable card. We did that .. an 1 1/2 hr trip.

I tried doing the install and kept getting error messages. Ceton's email service blamed these on MS. When I could get NO further help from Ceton with installing THEIR software, I packed my hardware and took it into a local Microsoft store.

The MS store was great. The issue was not MS or even Ceton. The issue was incompatibility problems between Ceton's software upgrades and MS' Media Center upgrades. MS got the software installed BUT they do not have a Comcast cable.

Give MS three stars for their support.

I went home and tried connecting with Comcast. As far as they can tell their system was working and they have exchanged data with the cable card. BUt ... they had to send a tech out.
Comcast did all they could over the phone.

Comcast warned me I would have to pay $200 if the fault was in the Ceton device or SW. Lucky for me the fault was in the way the cablecard was set up and Moses .. a great Comcastr tech... fixed it.

Now it works and it is very nifty .. EXCEPT it works through MS Media Center. So far I have not found a good intro to using Media Center ... this appears to be something folks at MS consider \\"intuitive\\" Maybe it is but then I must not be. Online instructions for setting up Media Center involve very long settings within the program and the interface lacks the usual MS niceties like a help system.

Bottom line, after several days effort I am using the thing and like it a great deal. Not sure how to balance the ordeal of the install and lack of tech support with the product itself.

This was take two for me on cases for my Transformer Pad Infinity. I like this style of case, and my first try was the one from [[ASIN:B008OHFT5W Acase]]. The main gripe I have with the one from Acase is that it did not fold flat which made thumb typing and gaming a challenge. I received confirmation from other reviewers that this case did fold flat. Here are my thoughts on this product.

Although I knew this ahead of time from previous experience, I give HHI credit for including a small instruction sheet showing how to insert the tablet into the case. While this case does fold flat (satisfying my stated requirement), it seems a little flimsy. The notch for the most upright stand position creates an undesired hinge in the case making it unstable on any surface that is less than completely flat. When I use the tablet in the case with my Bluetooth keyboard, it hangs a half inch or so off the end of my lapdesk. It makes me uneasy where I never even noticed this with the Acase case. It also requires a little extra force to close the case, and I can see this cause a show of wear over time. Finally, don't be lured in by the inclusion of a free stylus. It is a joke, and the one that came with mine broke during shipping. The loop on the case is unlikely to hold a real stylus as my Belkin one is about twice the diameter of the loop.

In the end, I cannot recommend this case. While I like that it folds flat, its overall build quality is suspect. I would defer to the Acase for now, but like U2, \\"I still haven't found what I'm looking for.\\"
output: Nice Features, But Suspect Build Quality

Instances.input: If you are experiencing issues with Nvidia or Radeon drivers crashing during graphically intensive situation, with an error along the lines of "Nvidia kernel driver has stopped working", this may be cause of a simple setting.  Within BIOS, there is a setting for the PCIe link speed under the chipset or north bridge configuration.  This should be set to GEN1 or GEN2. This ensures that the PCIe bus lane is operating at an appropriate bandwidth to accommodate for this riser. I found best results with GEN1, and there is negligible video performance reduction.

HC-05 is a pretty standard configuration, so I ordered anyway after seeing many datasheets and such from other places. This proved to be less helpful than I had hoped with this piece.
In the amazon description the information says:

I was able to power the device and even send 3.3v to the key to switch into "AT" mode.
Unfortunately, even though I can test that I'm sending signals through the pins, this module never seems to receive or transmit.
I've tried the expected default of 38400 baud, then 9600, 19200, 38400, 57600, 115200. No data ever gets through to the device it seems (though I see it going elsewhere).

Perhaps it's just a defective solder, but even so I'm avoiding the CZ-HC-05 "gomcu" version of this module now in favor of equally accessible and seemingly more tested JY-MCU models.
output: Lack of documentation and conflicting information

Instances.input: This unit that Amazon asked me to review is a warranty replacement for the Kindle that I bought a year ago. Within a week the same problems that appeared with the original have started with the replacement unit. I use the unit in an Amazon leather carrying case with elastic closing strap. That case makes the unit very convenient to use. The problem is that the unit spontaneously locks up with no prior warning. Typically, I put the unit in the \\"sleep\\" mode between uses. It can be a matter of hours or several days, and the unit will not reactivate. When that happens, holding the on/off switch sometimes reboots the unit, sometimes shuts the unit off and sometimes does nothing. The only sure way or restarting the unit is to plug it into the AC charging adapter. When the unit revives it is on the \\"home\\" page, and fortunately, I can return to the last page read by clicking on the book title. Each time the unit freezes, however, the clock must be reset.  This behavior was an irritation recently when I wanted to read on a plane flight and could not. I revived the unit at an airport gate charging station between flights.  Were it not for other features that I like about the Kindle, I'd rate it one or two stars. Those other features include the downloading convenience, ease of note making, and the pick up where you left off feature. Also, a favorite feature is the text resizing and orientation control. And, I like the synch capability with my desk top and laptop PCs. The non-reflective screen readability is great. The search feature and bookmarking are awkward, but no worse than my wife's color Nook. And, you can't easily flip through pages and then go back to where you were reading. Also, viewing maps and any kind of illustrations is dreadful. There simply isn't enough image/pixel detail to zoom in. I find the Nook no better on these issues. But, at least she has never had the lock up problems. While Amazon has started to put actual book page numbers along with their mysterious location numbers, the lack of page numbers with some books is an irritant. I didn't buy the Kindle for the purpose of having a quasi tablet. I bought it to reduce the accumulation of dead timber media in our house and for ease of use in travel. I don't have to lug half a dozen books for pleasure reading. And, despite the Kindle's limitations with PDF files, I can access my camera and other techie manuals on the Kindle.  So, as with all electronic devices, make a realistic assessment of your needs. And, scope out the serious user reviews. But, be wary of anyone who writes, \\"I love my ....\\" It's an electronic gaget which like money is totally lacking affection.
output: This warranty replacement is no better than the original

Instances.input:
My 2009 Macbook Pro 15" (running Mavericks) was starting to slow down, crash, freeze, and generally function erratically. After doing tons of research it seemed like my hard drive was failing. Instead of buying a new Macbook, I went ahead and decided that I'd save some money and just buy a new drive.

The data transfer went fairly quickly using the included cable, and after installing the drive my laptop started right up. My startup time has been cut in half, and my laptop is functioning much more quickly. Much of the erratic issues I was having with the laptop have stopped. I don't have any quantitative data on the performance boost, but programs launch noticeably faster, large files open/process much more quickly, and programs that were freezing/crashing before now stay open.

I couldn't be happier, and saved a bundle of money. I think I can go at least another year before replacing my laptop because of this SSD.
output: Samsung 840 EVO used in 2009 Macbook Pro 15"

Instances.input: I just replaced my 2nd 1tb drive, both turned out to be the .11. I know this now b/c on the latest RMA which i'm packaging right now, the Seagate rep offered to change it to a .12 on the return. I lost a significant amount of work both times, although less the 2nd time because I was paranoid after the first. I work in an industry where large video and image files are the norm, and I can't spend a bunch of time burning files that I'm working on. i need reliability in my storage.    This used to be an incredibly reliable company, and it's too bad that their large capacity stuff is so lousy.  In the case of this one, the model# I bought didn't match what the drive detect program read it as, so it couldn't apply any of the downloaded firmware updates (even though drivedetect was showing it as needing one).  The rep at Seagate told me I'd have to download it directly. When I did (I was doing all this b/c the drive was running too slowly to use) the drive was bricked and my OS told me I had to reformat. I'm getting rid of everything I own made by Seagate and never returning. I haven't had products this bad since Maxtor.  Probably not a coincidence they bought them.  Avoid at all costs unless you don't care about your data.

Fantastic skin for the keyboard! It fits flawlessly on my Macbook Air. Do give it time to adjust to the keys. The skin is actually form fitting over the keys with a bit of a lip on the edges, so your keyboard feels very nice. The padding does trigger the Air to pop open when held upright, but that's expected given the super tight design of the Air itself. It also muffles the sound of your keys, making it more pleasant for everyone.

People also must know that the ventilation design of the AIR uses the keys itself to push the air out. This is the same with the Pro. Just download smcFanControl to run your fans at appropriate speeds and track the temperature. A side effect is that because the machine is venting through the keys, the bottomside of your skin will collect all that dust and debris coming out. You'll have to do a lot of cleaning, but the positive side is eventually all the dust that was going in the first place will be gone.
output: Fits snug to my Macbook Air

Instances.input: Look, these speakers are magnificent. First of all, they have an amazingly attractive look. Second, but most importantly, they produce amazing sound. The sound quality in these speakers is superb! They have a very crisp and balanced sound with amazing depth. This is a great system for a reasonable price. I listen to them at my friend's house all the time and I've never been disappointed. They're fine for pretty much any genre. From my experiences with them, I've never heard any rattling from the subwoofer (which some people claim). That would be caused by blasting and overloading the speakers (which many people do without realizing it). Also, make sure the equalizer for an iPod, laptop, or CD player is turned off. That will cause a powerful car-woofer bass which overloads speakers (which could cause rattling) and really irritates me! Make sure you don't bang them around which might also be the cause of rattling due to damage. Overall, I'd highly recommend these. I listen to a lot of Pink Floyd (which requires high end sound due to the music detail) and I'm picky about my sound when I listen to them. JBL, you've done it again.

Instances.input: I bought this product because my daughter needed a more natural way of using MS Paint than a mouse.  Reviews were good and pricing was great. The product is well made and is sturdy enough for kids.  Installs quickly and all applications recognize it as input device and use it.     I have two big negatives on this product though:    First of all the pen is too big for a small kid to use.   Well, it is kind of big for even me and I do not have small fingers.   A thinner pen would have been nice.    Secondly, and the worst feature is that the tablet, once plugged in, represents the   entire visible screen of the computer. That is, if you touch any part of the tablet  with the stylus, the cursor jumps there. If you are drawing on a MS Paint page, for example,  when you want to draw at the corner of the sheet, you end up being at the corner of the tablet as well.   This is very non-intutive and very very annoying feature, especially for people who have been using  mouse most of the time. When I have to leave the drawing area and go to a menu item in the application,  it takes quite a guess to get there because I can not drag the cursor the way I do with a mouse.   With a mouse, if I am at a corner, I can lift the mouse from the pad, move it to middle of the pad and  then use it and the cursor continues from where it was left earlier. With this tablet, it is not so.  The cursor follows the pen throughout the pad. A \\"Mouse emulation\\" mode would have made it lot easier to  use.     Also the button on the pen is somewhat hard to use while drawing fine features. A switch at the tip of  the stylus would have been better.     Because of all these reasons, my daughter (and I) lost interest in it quickly and it is now sitting  there, used as another mousepad.
output: Nice tablet but mouse-emulation option should have been there

Pros: It is extremely solid and well built which great for self defense in a home invasion.

Cons:
Firstly, I do Remote Technical Support. Our system tools and the keyboard don't play nice. If I press the key combination of Ctrl + Shirt + Delete it breaks our tools. The Macro keys T1 - T12 simply do not work without their software which causes more issues than it is worth. It is very loud and the keys can be very hard to press.

Secondly, the software provided causes system issues with both Windows 7 and 8- Stops working - Keyboard doesnt respond- etc. I have had a few BSOD Error 0x0000009F. In English, drivers and/or controllers break. Though this could be a multitude of things Case - MOBO - Drivers - OS. However, this only happens when the keyboard is connected. Connected to the MOBO or the Case... which leads me to believe it is the keyboard.
output: Drivers,  OEM Software, and BSOD Adventures

If thundering bass is desired, these aren't the speakers to consider. However, if your main goal is pleasing, balanced sound in a compact package, look no further than the Bose Companion 2. Audio quality is stunning for a package so small. Highs are crisp/clean, and bass is commendably decent--surprisingly so, when you consider the tiny modules that are reproducing this bass--but it's what I was expecting from Bose before turning these on for the first time.     This system won't shatter the house frame, but that's not necessarily a bad thing. In fact, a speaker system that I purchased last night by a well-know manufacturer, complete with a monstrous subwoofer, is being returned tomorrow. I honestly prefer the sound of this diminutive Bose system--and as icing on the cake, it includes a spare set of input jacks for connecting another audio device, as well as a headphone jack.    Marvelous sound, attractive design, and an excellent value. I'm very happy.    1/9/2005: Brief addendum--one month after the purchase, I'm still very pleased with these speakers. They're a worthy replacement for the Boston Acoustics BA-735 speakers that have served me well for several years...and a bit of computer space has been reclaimed in the bargain, since the Bose speakers don't utilize a subwoofer, which I haven't missed in the least...I'm still in awe that speakers this small can reproduce such big sound.    I rarely comment on another review, but I couldn't help but notice a blanket condemnation of these speakers from a self-appointed \\"expert.\\" In checking that individual's other \\"reviews\\" at Amazon, I was struck by the number of Bose products that this person goes out of his way to trash...a disgruntled former Bose employee, perhaps?    The term \\"cheap electronics\\" was used by this \\"reviewer.\\" Of three speaker systems that I tried before settling on the Bose (one from Aletc Lansing, which was a nice unit otherwise, and one that was distributed under the Compaq name), this was the ***only*** one of the three that didn't sporadically pick up some type of amateur radio interference...Bose is doing something right that two other manufacturers couldn't manage.    Try the speakers for yourself. Unless boombox bass levels are desired, I think you'll be pleased. This was my first Bose purchase, and it won't be my last.
output: Big Sound from a Tiny Package

I wanted to replace my parent's (and in-law's) computer with something modern. They were using very old computers with Windows XP, and were complaining about the slow speeds. They aren't computer savvy, nor do they do a lot with their existing computers, so I thought this was the perfect solution for them. I really wanted to get the Core i5 or i7 version, but I couldn't wait any longer because I'm flying out to meet them. I'm not looking forward to explaining these devices to TSA.

I bought 2 NUCs, both with the exact same hardware:
- Crucial m4 256GB mSATA
- Crucial 16GB (2 x 8G)
- Belkin 6ft AC cord
- AmazonBasics 2-Pack, High-Speed HDMI Cables

My total cost was $1109 for both, including the NUCs, or about $555 / NUC. The 256GB and 16GB is overkill for my parents...but I bought the components as if I was building for myself. Plus, I'm hoping these will last them 5-10 years.

The initial install was very easy. It took about 10 minutes to unscrew, install the components, and screw the chassis back together again. Maybe less.

Installation of Windows 7 was super quick too. It only took between 5-10 minutes from a flash drive. The updates, however, took about 2 hours (still very quick compared to HDD), and the NUC got very warm to the touch. It also got audibly louder, but not annoying or \\"very loud\\".

So, here's what I noticed:
- I didn't appreciate that I had to buy an AC cord. I'd rather have a cord than the gimmicky Intel sound when you open the box.
- The NUC had an old BIOS version, so I updated it.
- The fan control in the BIOS was set to CUSTOM. I set it to BALANCED, which lowered the CPU temperature threshold before the fan went faster, by a few degrees C. I was surprised that the threshold was set so high, something like 77C.
- On bootup, the fan rotates at ~3K RPM, which I thought was very high, since I'm used to 600-1200 RPMs. But then, these are tinyfans, so I guess that's normal.
- I also told BIOS to use the maximum amount of RAM it wanted for the integrated video, since there was a lot of memory available.
- The network driver, and 2-3 other drivers, had to be installed from the Intel site. I had hoped that Windows 7 would automatically install them for me.
- After everything was patched and setup (with Office and other necessary software), Windows 7 boots to desktop in about 15 seconds.

I'm also setting them up with dual 27\\" monitors at 1920x1080 resolution. I hope it's easier on their eyes. 1920x1200 on a 24\\" or 2560x1600 on a 30\\" would be too tiny for them.

So far have had great results with this product. I'm a huge SSD fan and I wanted to get a high quality one for my latest main build (Samsung very rarely disappoints). I love the space, the speed, and the helpful software that comes with it that walks you through things you can do to increase performance, benchmark etc. Love the warranty too (on the off chance that it spontaneously combusts ).
Def a 5 Star product

Instances.input: I bought this device because I couldn't find a sound card that would fit the Dell Inspiron 580S I got to replace my 5 year old Dell Dimension. I bought the slim chassis machine because it was a real bargain given the video card, a 750 Gb hard drive and 6 Gb of RAM (which I increased to 8 Gb on the cheap) which allowed me to afford the cost of a quad core processor. I had a Creative Audigy sound card in my old computer and, in comparison the sound from the integrated chip set in my new machine was horrible.     I only listen to the 32 days of a large variety of music I have collected in iTunes. I don't do games and I don't watch movies. I have a 5 year old set of Creative 2.1 I-Trigue speakers I used with my old computer. The Audigy card drove them very nicely.    I plugged the X-Fi Surround into the computer and Windows 7 (64 bit) installed it without a hitch. I downloaded the newer driver from Creative and then installed only the Console -- to get the equalizer.  I plugged in the speakers, thanks to the provided RCA adapter, and played the first movement of Vladimir Feltsman's version of Bach's \\"Italian Concerto,\\" followed by Warren Zevon's \\"Werewolves of London.\\" I was absolutely delighted with the quality of the sound which was much better than that of the Audigy, which was very good. The X-Fi Crystalizer performs as advertised with respect to bringing compressed sound files back to life. I also like the almost ethereal sound of my really nice Sennheiser headphones.     I am very satisfied with this little box with the big knob I don't have to use because the I-Trigue volume and bass controller does. It produces sound very close to as good as my daughter's XiFi Titanium card with comparable speakers. There is virtually no difference in headphone performance.     I would recommend it without qualification to anyone who needs an external device and has resources similar to my computer. It will get the job done -- very well.

Just got my Valkyrie up and running. The unit is pretty well built. Door in the front folds down and you can access the two removable drive bays. Make sure you read the PDF manaual on the included disk before installing. It will save you a lot of hassle as the quickstart quide is near worthless. Not mentioned in either guide or manaual is the removable drive bracket has a spacer you need to remove in order to install your drives. This took me a minute to figure out. The PDF on the disk is also the only place where it lists your username, password, and default IP which you need.

Took a while to figure out how to configure windows 7 to see the valkyrie. Follow the instructions as per the pdf manaual and then in Win 7 under advanced sharing settings make sure to turn off public folder sharing, turn off password protect sharing, turn off use user account and passwords to connect to other computers. The way win 7 is set up by default does not work.

Make sure the valkyrie is using the same workgroup name as the rest of your network (done through valkyrie net tool - access via web). I had some trouble getting raid 1 configured, I finally formatted both drives at the same time through the web utility and it all of a sudden worked, where as formatting them one at a time and it did not seem to work. Not sure if this was the fix but formatting both drives at the same time certainly is faster. Just start one drive formattting and then imediately start the 2nd drive formatting. All of a sudden my raid 1 valkrie was up and running properly. I didn't try every combination but these setting worked for me.

I bought this router a few weeks ago when I purchased my new G4 iBook, on the recommendation of a co-worker. I was originally planning to buy an Airport station, but its additional features (such as a built-in modem) are really of no use to me. So I decided to save the $100+ and go with the Linksys. I also went for b over g since the speed of my connection is limited by my DSL line, and I'm not going to be doing a lot of filesharing among my computers, so there didn't seem to be much sense to spend the extra money.
I've had the router set up for a couple of weeks now and everything is working like a dream. I have an iMac and a PC connected to it with ethernet cables, and then I have my iBook with an Airport Extreme card. Setup was fairly easy -- it's done through your internet browser (I did not install any of the included software). My iBook immediately recognized the network when I fired it up, and reception appears to be fine throughout my 2-story house.
A word of caution: the router runs on a 2.4Ghz frequency, so there is interference with cordless phones that run on the same frequency. I've given the product four stars because a day or two ago none of the computers were recognizing the internet connection, but plugging and unplugging the ethernet cable out of the back of the router seemed to fix that problem, oddly enough. It's not a huge inconveniece, but I hope it doesn't happen often.
I'm also thinking about purchasing a wireless USB adapter (the Linksys WUSB12) for my TiVo to add to the fun -- no more slow phone downloading of program info!
It is a very lovely replacement product. I was very saddened when my original Kindle Fire died, but when I contacted Amazon they sent me a new one. Now I can continue reading happily.

UPDATE: *DOWNGRADED 1 STAR FOR SCREEN QUALITY* After using it for a few days, I noticed that when the brightness is set to anywhere from 0 to 20, there are faint (but visible) slightly darkened horizontal bars moving down the display. This is most visible in middle toned areas of my desktop, such as neutral grays. It's quite distracting. I sent an email to Panda City and they assured me that this is normal (though it could be because I JUST had them pay for shipping to clean my display for free, and they didn't want to offer another repair request). Regardless, I can't unsee it. (Note: I've asked several other people on Youtube who own this product, and they did not report this issue!)
...............
As of the time of writing, the Yiynova MVP22U v3 is hands-down the best 22-inch non-Wacom alternative.

DESIGN
Other 22-inch HD non-Wacom alternatives have some perplexing design choices: the downward-facing cables in the back, the fact that the monitor rests on the power/menu buttons, etc. However, the Yiynova alternative doesn't have any of these: The cables come out of the side, and the monitor buttons are unobtrusively in the backside. I also enjoy the large bevel around the screen, which allows me to draw towards the bottom without the desk getting in the way of my hand. Compared to a Wacom 22HD, it has fewer buttons, and therefore less customizability. My only caveat is that Yiynova decided to place the buttons on the top of the screen--it's not unusable, but it's sort of an awkward spot. However, they work fine and are firm to press. I have never had driver issues with the buttons--I was able to program them with no issues. Some may prefer Wacom's textured surface to Yiynova's glass, but it doesn't bother me. It's really a matter of preference--however, the reflectiveness of the screen does become a minor issue.

SPECS
It's a full 1920x1080 screen--the colors are great, and it looks great. Plus, it's got an IPS screen with great viewing angles. The UC-Logic based digitizer provides lag-free tracking and VERY nice pressure sensitivity. I've used Wacom Graphire and Bamboo tablets for years, and the pressure sensitivity has never felt this great. I've also briefly used a Cintiq 21UX and the Yiynova feels just as great.

DRIVERS
If you're doing research about Cintiq alternatives, you'll hear a lot of red flags about the software, no matter which non-Wacom alternative you're looking for. I can't speak for Huion or Monoprice, but as I understand it, most of those companies--Yiynova included--have made many improvements with software support. It works perfectly with all Adobe products and Mischief (by The Foundry), which is all I've been able to test so far. I've had a few hiccups at first--but I contacted The Panda City and they advised me to delete some lingering Wacom driver files that remained despite my reinstall. PROTIP: Uninstall all Wacom drivers BEFORE using UC-Logic based digitizer products, and install the proper drivers BEFORE you plug the device into your computer, especially if you're using Windows.

ANY DEAD PIXELS?
No. No dead pixels in my unit. However I can't speak for other models. If you have 5 or more (or something like that) they will replace your unit, as far as I know. I can't confirm this because I haven't had this issue.

A MINOR NOTE
The MVP22U has a glass panel in front that is held together by little plastic hooks around the edges (which come from the black plastic piece in the back). I received my unit with the glass panel a little bit raised above the plastic hooks on the top. I assumed this was normal, so I installed my unit and it worked flawlessly. However, after a while I noticed that dust started to settle underneath the glass, because it would fly in from the raised glass panel. I emailed the Panda City and they assured me that this was unlikely, because the inside is apparently sealed. They said that the issue is easily fixed by gently pushing in the glass so that it locks underneath the plastic hooks. Somebody on Youtube confirmed that their unit also arrived like this, but they did not report any dust issues. REGARDLESS, The Panda City offered to clean my unit for free, and they even paid for the shipping (which is offered to customers within 3 months of their order, at least for this model). So, it was a bummer to lose my MVP22U for about 1 week, but when I received it back (just today) it's like new! They guy handling emails at Panda City is a real good sport. He diligently answered my emails promptly and was very patient with my numerous inquiries. Despite this minor problem, I highly recommend this model.

I'm VERY happy with it. The price isn't cheap (even though it's half of the Wacom offering) for a relatively little-known company, but I'd say the build is very solid, it works great, and if Panda City keeps up their level of customer service, it's DEFINITELY worth it.stic hooks. REGARDLESS, The Panda City offered to clean my unit for free, and they even paid for the shipping (which is offered to customers within 3 months of their order, at least for this model). So, it was a bummer to lose my MVP22U for about 1 week, but when I received it back (just today) it's like new! They guy handling emails at Panda City is a real good sport. He diligently answered my emails promptly and was very patient with my numerous inquiries. Despite this minor problem, I highly recommend this model. I'm VERY happy with it. The price isn't cheap (even though it's half of the Wacom offering) for a relatively little-known company, but I'd say the build is very solid, it works great, and if Panda City keeps up their level of customer service, it's DEFINITELY worth it.
output: The best non-Wacom tablet monitor out right now!
