Instances.input: Love this for WOW. Drivers/software not great

I am a software engineer...have been building my own PCs for ~15 years now. I bought this for my pre-teen as a replacement for his old PC. It's great! Here's why:
1. No bloatware! Usually commercial PCs are loaded with bloatware and you need to clean them before you can even use them. The only thing I had to uninstall was Windows Media Player (slows down boot) and this is a Windows problem....not a bloatware or Dell/Alienware problem.
2. Best bang for your buck on the market
3. Packaged driver updates via AlphaUI

The AlphaUI kinda sucks. When you click it, it will log you out of Windows, then log you in as the AlphaUI user, then load the UI. Not only is this a bad user experience, but the two accounts know nothing about each other! So any data you save under your account (like saved Steam games), AlphaUI will know nothing about them. My solution for this was to delete the AlphaUI icon from my kid's user account's desktop. He just always uses the desktop, not AlphaUI. I am trying to raise an intelligent human, not a console junkie. :) The only downside is updating the AlphaUI is how the box upgrades the drivers....so I sneak in his room once a month, load AlphaUI from the start menu, update AlphaUI, boot back to desktop.

The CPU, RAM, and HD are all easily upgradeable. In my desktop testing, the HD is the bottleneck. Drop an SSD in and this thing would sing.

Overall, I am super impressed.

Goal: Purchased 3 plugs for our 1979 ~2500sq.ft split level house in hopes of reliably feeding an HTPC machine with 40Mbit/s (5MB/s) and an internet-capable stereo with 8Mbit/s (1MB/s)

Background: Wifi G and N were tried, but provided unreliable performance: drop outs when the microwave was in use, and insufficient bandwidth for high-bitrate movie scenes, causing an unacceptable movie watching experience.

Electrical layout: the server and HTPC machines are on different breakers but on the same \\"side\\" of the circuit breaker panel. The Internet stereo is on the other side of the breaker panel.

Installation: one of the easiest yet. Truly plug-and-play, without any software installation or configuration needed. Each Zyxel unit is plugged directly into the wall socket. Each wall socket has two plugs, and the other plug is used by a power bar with lots of stuff hanging off it. I'm also not using the encryption feature.

Performance: The server-to-HTPC leg (same side on breaker panel) moves 10MB/s via NFS protocol, or roughly 80Mbit/s, and the server-to-stereo leg (different side on breaker panel) moves roughly 2MB/s. For the stereo, the Zyxel shows an \\"amber\\" speed indicator colour, indicating a reduced 10-40Mbit/s rate, which is in line with my benchmark results. Unlike wifi, these units provide reliable and steady bandwidth with very little deviation.

Overall these units have met my goal, so 5-stars here! Internet music and movie are now hickup free.

Warning to those expecting 500Mbit/s (or even 200Mbit/s) --- the HomePlug governing body has drastically overstated the real-world speeds for all three of their HomePlug standards [HomePlug(85) HomePlugAV(200) HomePlugAV2(500)]. My best speed of 80Mbit/s using AV2 units now only matches that of the HomePlug's first 85Mbit/s standard. Going by these results, Maybe I can expect 500Mbit/s speeds when the HomePlug alliance releases a 3,000 Mbit/s standard, sominus 1 star here.

Don't waste your money on this thing.

Instances.input:
This router does what it says it will do.

Reliable N, that falls back to G if any device connects to it as G.

So, if all of your devices have wireless N, save your money and buy a router like this.

But, if you have G devices then I recommend you by a dual band wireless router [[ASIN:B002HWRJY4 Netgear N600 Wireless Dual Band Gigabit Router WNDR3700]] or [[ASIN:B001AZ01EO Cisco-Linksys WRT610N Simultaneous Dual-N Band Wireless Router]] or [[ASIN:B0049YQVHE ASUS Black Diamond Dual Band Wireless-N 600 Router (RT-N56U)]].

Also, I recommend that you stick with the same company for all of your wireless networking. For example, if you need to extend the Belkin Wireless Router, do so will a Belkin wireless extender or router (preferably from the same model year).
output: Works with N if all Device are N, If one G Device all fall back to G

There is also a lot of complaints about not being big enough for all the things in the picture plus their lunch and an umbrella. Well for that you need a backpack. sainsmart board with the new tb6560 chip but conections are a bit confusing for someone still learning if they are not familiar with clk cw and enable pin outs that go from the board to the parallel port breakout since it has 2 connectors for each. Cw clk and enable pins of both negative and positive which for me were totaly confusing and when googled you will not find anything about this one,do not be put off by this it is a actually a very minor thing just confusing to someone not very experianced in electronics the connectors are cw- cw+ which on most boards are labled as Direction , clk- clk+ which in most boards are labled as step , and enable which are still eneable.This is not where the confusion set in for me that part is pretty much standard and cw and clk are very commonly used the confusing part is when you see that each of these have both a + and a - connector and the board you are hooking it up to does not have both as well ... Hmmm real head scratcher there and googling this board will not get you any results that will explaing this ...

WELL NOW your thinking Oh crap I just wasted my money ---- NO YOU DID NOT this board actually has many more configuration options than the other board listed by Sainsmart on amazon that actually costs more it simply has the connector that is 5v+ broke out into one for each signal and labled as cw+ clk+ and enable+ you simply tie all three together and hook them to the 5v+ from your parallel port breakout or microprocessor

I did blow mine up but that was entirely due to my lack of knowledge in electronics and hooking it up in various ways trying to get it to work The nice people at sainsmart have done everything they can to help resolve this and I have not asked for a free replacement because while this boards connectors are a bit confusing they are correctly marked for anyone familiar with electronics and I am the one who caused the issue here I actually like the layout of this board much better that the other two I had purchased if the other type and will be ordering several more just like it.Even after I told them I was at fault they still asked what they could do to help with resolving this and I told them I do not expect a free replacement but that a bit of a discount in the replacement would be nice when I order it I am very impressed with their commitment to customer satifaction and quick response to customer inquiries when contacted.

remember eneabl+ CW+ and CLK+ all connect to the 5v+ on your device suppling controll signals the 5v+ on a arduino for example and you have no problem
output: very nice product for using to build you first cnc if you doing dyi and learning

Instances.input: I purchased the Kindle for my husband, who loves anything technical. You may think that it is just an improvement on reading, but it is so much more. You download books onto the Kindle. Many books for the Kindle are free or very inexpensive. The font size can easily be magnified so that anyone can read from it. If you do not want to read, it will audio read to you. The size is perfect and so lightweight, you can take it anywhere. My husband's favorite part is the FREE 3G. When the DSL was down at his work, he was able to check his email and search the internet. The battery life is exceptionally long. We like the graphite color instead of the optional white. After doing research, we found that people who bought it in white, discovered that the plastic cracks much easier than the graphite ones. We put a skin on the front and back, a screen protector, and bought a carrying case, to protect it even further. You can read in all kinds of light without glare. You have all your books in one place. You can highlight a word and get the definition for that word. If you are reading a book and it references another book, it allows you to go to that other book. It even has 2 built-in games. The only downside is that it doesn't have color, but that is not a problem for us. The Problem is that my husband has turned into a Kindle junkie.
easy to use and you start to see the difference as soon as you put it; it makes your screen less glare.

I really like the Kindle Fire HD (KFHD). I have had the Kindle reader, the Kindle Fire 1st Gen and the Kindle Fire 2nd Gen. So I was super excited to keep moving up the Kindle chain. There were a few problems right from the get go but I have to say they were resolved. I was able to hook it up to the WiFi. After about an hour, my KFHD kept dropping the Wifi every minute, literally every minute. It was so annoying. I called Amazon, they were nice but were unable to fix the problem. They thought I had too many connections to wifi which at the time there was only one. Amazon wanted me to try connecting to another wifi, well not possible until I got to another place or something. They would follow up with me the next day. I went ahead and did a factory reset on the KFHD and reset the wifi. It finally worked and no more dropped wifi. The next problem I had was trying to have gmail and calendar synced. It kept giving me an error that I didn't have permission. After about 3 hours trying to work on it looking online, it looked like alot of people had problems syncing gmail and calendar. I was tired and went to bed. I was able to sync my yahoo and work email calendar. The next morning I tried it one more time. I don't know what I did differently but this time it worked.

One more thing that is a little annoying but not a deal breaker is that I cant tell when it is charged. My regular Kindle Fire had a light that was orange when it was charging and then would turn green when fully charged. There is nothing like that on the KFHD.

So let me say this, I love my Kindle Fire HD, there were just a few hiccups at the get go.

I will give this an A+ for sheer clarity in bright light. It is much easier on my aging eyes. The smaller type is readable so you can pack more per page, and it doesn't shut off if you take your time to read it. It is not quite as bright as the pictures indicate and it does glare in direct sunlight. You have to hold at an angle from external light. It is readable in dark in case your power goes off, but a bit blurry in the background. Despite these flaws, it is far more clear than what I've tried in the past. Handhelds only give you a paragraph or two at a time, small letters are difficult to read. I tried Ectacto Jetbook, which is similar but letters are a bit digital looking. A laptop computer is good for getting a lot on the screen, but bulky.

It is obvious Amazon Kindle is creating a momopoly in the world of ebooks and I resent that. Downloading is mainly by WiFi and surfing on the Kindle only gives you best sellers at top, it's a pain to find more interesting independent writings. It will download other formats, but not very well and not very easily; the file manager on this is lousy only pictures, and you can only see a few files at a time, and you have to enter page number to turn.

I would had liked a page turn button, screen will get greasy after a while. Pressing finger responds variously and pages tend to black out a second before turning. I'd like to find some stick to press, as usual these small devices are poorly designed for men with big fingers.

Anyway, it's better than what I've had to be, but it needs work and more flexibility on the software and downloading. It seems like the software is built in the hardware. Looks like it is set up for \\"planned obsolescence\\".

The price has come down on these quite a bit since I purchased them, but even at this price, I would not buy them again.

When they work, they are great.

The problem is the cheap manufacturing. I could live with the right ear piece breaking off for a while by forcing the cheap plastic guide back into its hole, but last night the left earpiece broke off as well. This despite the fact that I have treated these with kid gloves realizing my head is slightly larger than average. I'll be looking at the Logitech D930 which are supposedly made with aircraft grade aluminum.

This is a great, inexpensive, alternative to the overpriced Apple OEM battery. True, as other users have noted, the \\"aluminum\\" sticker on the unit does not exactly replicate the shiny outer shell of the PowerBook G4. Honestly, who cares? If you're really that worried about the aesthetics of your laptop battery, perhaps you should spend the $129+ at the Apple store.    I did give the battery 3 stars for construction quality due to the fact that it does not install flush with the laptop body like the original...by a whopping 0.03125 inches. Truthfully, the only complaint I really have about the unit is that the button for activating the charge indicator lights is less-than-responsive and does require a bit more force than the original. Mind you, it *does* work, but you have to want it. Minor inconveniences, considering the cost.    The battery came in working order, fully discharged and has recharged successfully seven times since my purchase:      Battery Installed:                Yes    First low level warning:        No    Full Charge Capacity (mAh):   4247    Remaining Capacity (mAh):     4206    Amperage (mA):                        -1372    Voltage (mV):                        12475    Cycle Count:                        7    Four out of five stars for the replacement battery. If it will make my coffee for me in the morning, I will happily grant the coveted five-out-of-five star rating.    Cheers!

I already read my first Kindle book and I bought it only a week a go. My daughter has had one for a year now, but I've never used it. At first glance I thought there was a screen cover on it for shipping. The screen is incredible. If you've never seen one, you'll be blown away.  This 3rd Gen Kindle is smaller than my daughters. I think they made some good improvements after comparing my new one to my daughters 2nd Gen. The 3rd Gen has next-page and prev-page buttons on both sides of the screen. It boots up faster from the off (not in sleep).  This device seems very delicate so I am wary about putting it down too hard. I can't wait for my Kindle cover to come in the mail so I can handle it with confidence.  If you have been thinking about getting an eReader, Kindle is the one. Downloads are fast, the screen is easier to read than a real book and you can carry thousands of books in one device.

I was in DIRE need of some replacement speakers for my computer here at work. The speakers I inherited with this computer had absolutely no depth or clarity. The hunt was on to find a set of speakers within a modest price range. Nothing too cheap, but also nothing too elaborate. Two of my co-workers have Altec-Lansing speakers they are very happy with but I was looking for something with a bit more style.
Here is where the Creative I-Trigue 2.1 3300 speakers come into play. Not only do they have rock solid components and specs but they are VERY stylish. The whole system screams quality. The desktop units are solid metal stands with a translucent plastic back that look simply gorgeous next to my flat panel monitor. The woofer not only hits hard and with utter clarity at all volumes but it is built like a rock. Plus, as you know, they have a wonderful wired remote with a headphone jack built right in.
As for the clarity, you could not ask for anything better at such a modest price. The highs are unbelievably crisp and the bass hits hard & clear at all volumes. The mid-range sound is not muddy like your often time hear with computer or self-powered speakers. The key in all this is at very low volumes, while other people are working in the office, the sound is still beautiful and crisp through the entire dynamic range of the speakers.
If you have the money, go for a Klipsch product, but if you want a GREAT value with beautiful sound and style pick yourself up a pair of these. I am far from being sorry.

I purchased this for a desktop in order to prevent having to run an ethernet cable all throughout my apartment to the router. It worked fine for a few weeks and then suddenly I would randomly lose connection or simply not find anything at all. When I would try to uninstall the driver, it would hang up my computer.

Unfortunately when I went to return it to Amazon, I was told that I was out of the return window. (Bummer)

When I contact Asus I am informed that they cannot refund it (for obvious reasons) but that they can issue a RMA for it. Issue is, I have to pay to ship it to be repaired. While I appreciate the gesture of repairing the faulty adapter, I think I will just count my losses and learn to read more reviews. (I have already dished out enough money buying the darned thing). So, now it looks as though I am stuck with a faulty adapter. (Thank goodness it was cheap)

My advice to you, spend a little more money and buy a reliable product and please.... please read reviews!

I love playing video games on top of that I'm a programmer. so I pretty much spend most of my waking moments in front of my computer. i've also worked on the side as a mechanic. who knew that I'd develop wrist issues? (sarcasm) alternative mice could alleviate some of the discomfort. I bought a wrist rest. I've used a "whale" mouse (which is just a huge mouse). a trackball isn't too bad. I always wanted to try microsoft's ergonomic mouse, but I want my mouse wheel to click, their mice seemed to lack that tactile feel.

instead of paying at least 3x the amount for an evoluent vertical mouse, I thought I'd do the more economical thing, and buy something that would feel similar. mostly to see if I would like a vertical mouse in the first place. I do feel less strain on my wrist. ergonomically, it feels like a good mouse for me, it does take some time to get used to.

so why is it missing 2 stars?
-the nano receiver DOES fit in the mouse, but it doesn't quite fit securely enough for me to feel that it would be there if I dropped it.
-there is no software available to download and adjust the buttons. It may seem minor to some people, but I get more use out of minimize & close on my mouse, I've used that combo for the past decade or so. not having it is weird for me.
-I could live with the other 2, but the worst offender is the scroll wheel, when you use it the screen goes up and down like a jackhammer. sometimes it'll be in the same spot, sometimes it'll be the opposite direction you wanted to go. it's very disorienting when I'm programming since the code all looks the same.

bottom line: I'd skip the frustration and bite the bullet to get the evoluent vertical mouse.

I've had this mouse for around 3.5 years and it has outlasted my previous laptop. Battery lasts a good deal of time, 3-4 months, depending on how often I use it, and takes just 1 AA battery (also, to note, it must conserve power as I generally leave the USB plugged into my laptop). Also the mouse works great on various surfaces and fits perfectly in my hand. It's clicking is a little louder than I would prefer, but completely tolerable. The only con, is that upon trying to install the drivers on my new laptop, is that the software is not compatible with Windows 7. However, the mouse is still functional, including the general scrolling of the wheel (up, down, left, right) but has lost the functionality of the side button. Still plan on continuing use with this mouse.

I have owned each of the Kindles (except Fire) including the Paperwhite gen 1 which I gave to a relative so I could buy the new gen 2. All my previous Kindles, plus my computer, IPad, and Nook had no problem connecting with my router, however my new Paperwhite gen 2 refused to connect to this same router. After 2 replacements and countless hours with Kindle help including sending them files which the techies mulled over for two weeks upon which they insultingly replied that I had been entering an incorrect password. Now, I checked with my router company for the info to send the techies during which I verified I the correct password. Finally, I was just so frustrated I just got a refund. One of the "help" folks told me Amazon had shipped a bunch of Paperwhites without correctly finalizing (that is not the word I want but can't remember the correct word). I don't think one has to be a genius to figure if my computer, IPad, and Nook, and the Paperwhite gen 1 connected with the router then something is obviously wrong somewhere in the software. It appears they can't find it, but for the time being I am stuck reading my Kindle content on my computer, IPad and Nook. I am waiting for the Paperwhite gen 2 3G to come out so the wifi will not be any problem, but really resent spending the additional money for a problem I didn't create. I am currently considering ordering another gen 2 to see if they have solved this problem, but the hassle of returning via UPS is also a consideration.

I love my Kindles because they are just the right size and weight for someone with arthritis in the hands. My IPad mini is really good too, but I can't access all the features of the Kindle. Will be so glad to get my Kindle back.

Has anyone else experienced a similar problem? If so I would appreciate any input or help offered.
output: Problem with Paperwhite connecting to wifi?

This guy was pretty easy to open up and install the memory and hdd. I had to go out and buy an HDMI cable, though (forgot about the no VGA...). It is a very well manufactured case - looks slick. Once RAM/HDD were installed, I held my breath and pressed the little power button...and no display, just a really bright blue LED (like Trey's experience), and no noise/beeps or anything else. After gnashing teeth, removing HDD and trying different HDMI ports, and triple checking that my RAM was really 1.35V, I saw that the RAM SODIMM was not seated all the way in the slot, though it was evenly seated. Once I inserted it in *all the way* it booted right up. Good times. Installing Linux (Fedora 22) now, and system seems to work great. Does NOT run hot (for me), so far.

My Memory: Kingston KVR16LS11/4 4GB DDR3L 1600MHz 1.35V SODIMM
My HDD: Crucial CT120BX100SSD1 120 GB 2.5" SSD

The vendor's page for this product: http://www.jetwaycomputer.com/JBC320U93.html
output: Sweet Dual-LAN NUC...just seat your RAM!

Instances.input: Got a great deal on mine from Staples.  I've been using it for almost a year now and its worked flawlessly.  Other student's envy its lightweight and tight dimensions.  My only complaint, and its commnon to these laptops, is the CPU fan.  It would have been so easy for averatec to put in a quieter fan.  The fan comes on when you startup windows...sounds like a little hair dryer tucked inside.  When I first started class, my classmates and I would make jokes about how it was \\"blasting off\\" every time the fan came on....which is every 5-7 minutes, and then the fan only runs loud for about 30 seconds.  So, with that being the only complaint, this thing rocks.  I imagine if the loud fan REALLY got to you, you could take it in to a shop and have a quieter fan put in....not sure how feasible that would be, but cant see why it wouldnt work.  UPDATE: Sept. 17, 2005  I figured out how to solve the loud fan issue.  You need to run the fan diagnostic in the BIOS at startup.  The computer will then calculate the proper speed of the fan based on what you're using it for at the time.  After that, the fan was MUCH more quiet.  DO IT QUICK!
output: Not perfect, but for the $$$ you cant beat it

I can see why asus is the largest name motherboard company, the features and performance of this motherboard is unmatched, I have went thru several motherboards with the same exact CPU and ram..

Not many manufactures make a mini-itx FM1 socket motherboard and I went with Asrock at first and the performance and stability was so bad.. i just figured it was because it was the first generation APU's.... the VRM's on that one broke and i used the warranty to get a new one.. and it was the same exact thing going on... another year went by and that motherboard finally broke as well...

It has been 2 years since Asus has made this motherboard and it was very hard to find. With blind luck someone sold it on at the time I needed another motherboard...

I was so scared it was not going to work.. but the motherboard came in its original packaging and all the original parts still with it.. the motherboard overclocked far beyond what my old ASRock's was able to do.. on the same exact components.. I may never go back to another brand after this experience...

This was perhaps the greatest purchase of my life.. and i will do it again 50 times over if given the chance.

Tried several routers from D-link, Belkin and Buffalo at $45-$90 range, Belkin Surf so far is the best in coverage, signal SNR, speed and ease of use. Does not have much setting (like power, radio etc), but works very well. Easy and clean.  Did not went too far with USB, QOS etc, these needs firmware/software to run through and make the thing complicated, tends to get problems . If someone want some controllability over the radio or networking, this is not the one. It only provides very basic function and setups. Enough for a basic home network.  The network I have, 1 desktop, 2 Macbook, 1 WII, 2 DSI, 1 Thinkpad, 1 printer(wifi), 1 VOIP box -  AT&T DSL internet  1 year after update  Netgear WNDR4000, bought and tried to replace this Belkin 2301. The throughput, tested by iperf, and distance were all failed in comparison. Same spot, same setup, no WEP/WPA...  Returned Netgear and gave up the 5G for right now.
output: Very nice router, for the price

Pros: I would say that it is slightly better than a standard Walmart shelf Targus stylus. I like the smaller nib, and the nib glides more smoothly across the screen than the Targus ($12) and the generic stylus I have. Pen writes smoothy, and seems to be high quality.

Cons: The nib is slightly too small at the tip and you have to put MORE pressure on it to get the screen to register it. So it kind of defeats the nib being smaller as a benefit. When you hold it higher up, the pen cap wiggles from side to side throwing off your preciseness a bit. The pen produces very light and thin writing. A fine tip ball point pin. Makes it harder to read. I would not use it for sketching.

Instances.input: We purchased this as a going away gift, and it couldn't have been more perfect! She is going to love it, and the quality is great!

I ended up buying two of these for a couple of Toshiba laptops in our house.  These things are great.  Light-weight and comfortable.  The angle is perfect also.  Obviously Logitech spent a lot of time and effort in research before it went into production.  The big Toshiba (Qosmio X505-Q830) fits perfectly on the top with no overhang although it's about 10 pounds and I can only tolerate on my lap for about an hour.  Most of the time I leave it on the kitchen table still on the lapdesk.  I like it that way actually.  But the Satellite T135 plus the Logitech Comfort Lapdesk is a match made in Heaven.  I've watched my daughter use the two in combination for hours and hours.       Never had any slippage problems like some Mac users claimed.  The lapdesks can be turned almost vertically before the Toshibas will let go.       The desks seem to be relatively sturdy and look like they will hold up for quite a while.  I'm happy and that's all that counts.
output: Best design by any company anywhere, at any time

I've only had it in my laptop for 3 weeks, and so far so good. To its credit, I first installed it on my kids' MacBook, because it is much easier to install on those than my MacBook Pro, so I could be sure it worked before I went through the trouble of taking my laptop apart. So, it got a system installed on it twice with a zeroing erasure between. It seems to perform fine, and I'm glad to have the extra space. As a side note, I went to the local Mac store to see what they were selling, and they had the same drive for twice as much. It's a shame that they mark it up so much, I might have bought it there. This was a worthwhile experience for me, and for anyone who isn't afraid of taking apart a laptop. So long as your warrantee has lapsed and you don't carry some Mac Care like plan, this is a very economical way to get more memory.     As for comparing this brand to others, I can't say. I would have gone with WD, but I had an external drive by them that crapped out, but that's a very different product, and often you can get unlucky with these things. I don't think I put my drives through much of a workout, so I'm not the best judge.

Instances.input: I was initially disappointed.  I had a difficult time trying to do a clean install of Windows, so I tried the migration software that came with it.  The software is actually very easy to use and did a good job of cloning my old C Drive. While the Samsung SSD 850 EVO speeded up my boot times, I felt it could do better.  After a few tweaks using the Samsung software, it did speed up but suddenly developed a BSOD problem.  I nearly gave up until I updated the drivers in my ASUS motherboard and activated AHCI in the registry. (google it) After i did that, no more BSOD's and my performance speed more than doubled. Windows now boots up and ready to use in less than 30 secs.  Photoshop is up in less than 5 seconds, and nearly everything, from my browser to my windows explorer feels snappy and fast! Do yourself a favor and update your motherboard and chipset drivers before you install.

Instances.input:
As I was picking out parts for my new gaming rig I was searching for a video card that would not overheat like my previous GTS450. After reading the online stats on this card I pretty much knew this was the one for me.

Pros:
Low power use
2 big, quiet fans
Newer(est) technology for GPUs
4 simultaneous displays
Fast as hell

Cons:
Does require 6pin PCIe power connector from power supply

Paired with AMD FX4130, 8GB DDR3 1600 RAM.

CS:GO doesn't even make this thing work.

Borderlands 2, Far Cry 3, and Borderlands: Pre-Sequel all run at max settings with little to no frame drop (1600x1200 resolution). Far Cry 3 and BL:PS both ran better with the AA and AF cranked back a bit but I also am ALWAYS streaming twitch/netflix in HD on my 2nd or 3rd monitor which requires quite a bit of graphics horsepower. And have been working on a photo/video project and had the GIMP and movie editting software running. Absolutely no complaints. This is probably the best bang for your buck card available as of Oct 2014 and will help pay for itself by using 1/2 the power of a card that has comparable performance.

Absolute great buy, I've never been happier with the GFX performance of my PC. Just stop looking and get this card. Great product A++++

I replaced a Cyber Acoustics CA-3908 (read my review) with this system and what an amazing difference.  Sure, it costs $100 more but well worth it.  The sub is rock solid but not quite as tight as I would like but certainly workable.  The satellites are simply awesome - very clean and clear.  The sub is absolutely HUGE so buyer be ware of this if you don't have room for a large sub.  The toggle unit is wonderful - you have EQ options (jazz, classical, pop, etc but this did not seem to make much difference) as well as programmable such as Wide, concert hall, stadium, karaoke, theatre, etc. and both speaker and sub volume control at your fingertips! It also changes the input from computer, aux 1 and 2 for things like iPod or TV.  I have a 32 inch LED with only has an optical out for sound.  I want to listen to Blu-ray 5.1 surround on this 2.1 channel system.  So, I purchased a Gefen Digital Audio Decoder for $89 that can decode the 5.1 sound to a 2.1 by having both a coax and optical input.  I bought this and all the necessary cables in Amazon - the SP2500 only has a 3.5mm input (both Aux 1 and 2) and the Gefen has a dual RCA stereo output so you will need a 3.5mm male to RCA male cable.  It works GREAT and this sound system would get a 5 if the sub were a little tighter. But no matter, I am very happy with this sound system and the toggle switch really makes changing the sound a breeze.
output: Not quite audiophile quality ... but very close!

If you're considering purchasing this card, then you are probably imagining maxing out the current gen games and the games currently slated to be released in the near future.

As for myself, I purchased this card to max out Titanfall, and The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim at 1920x1080 on Ultra quality settings, and it does that at 60+ FPS. This thing will also max out Farcry 3, Minecraft, Bioshock Infinite, Batman: Arkham City. These are the games I own and have tested on, but it's safe to say that pretty much any game you throw at it, it's gonna be able to max it out with little issue.

I'm upgrading from an AMD/ATI Radeon HD4870 card, and the performance gains are incredible to say the least. The old card has recently started to struggle keeping up adequate frame rates. I have to hand it to the HD4870 though, that thing can still run today's games reasonably well at some lower resolutions and slightly reduced quality settings and lower FPS. But enthusiast gamers want to turn on ALL of the bells and whistles, and this card allows me to do that.

As far as the software goes. I have to say, I do like the NVIDIA geforce experience software, although I do miss the AMD/ATI overdrive settings on the Catalyst software. This card does NOT support the geforce LED visualizer, as it appears to lack the reference design LED screen. That's fine, but a little extra eye-candy would definitely be welcome. Not gonna ding the card for this though, as the price/performance is excellent.

- Physical aspects.

It is a triple fan design, the first image on the card is definitely incorrect, although the second photo does show the correct product.

The card is very large, the specs page says it is 10.5 inches long. If you're not sure your case can fit it, then definitely do a little measuring first, from the back of the case where the DVI port will stick out down into the inside of your case, and see if you can accommodate a 10.5 inch card.

The temps stay nice and cool from what I've noticed, though I do have a case with great airflow (Antec 1200). The card is actually pretty quiet, and I have noticed no coil whine from mine (I did read about this card having a coil whine issue though, so take that for what it's worth).

- Power demands.

The design specs recommend a 600W minimum power supply. Definitely make sure you meet this, as an underpowered card will run poorly or not at all.

The card needs an 8-pin PCI-E power connector, AND a 6-pin PCI-E power connector. I have a Thermaltake Toughpower 850W modular power supply. I had plenty of 6 pin cables, but no 8 pins. Luckily, the card is supplied with a "two 6 pin to one 8 pin" converter cable. What I'm saying is make sure you have at least three 6 pin cables available if you don't have an 8 pin and a 6 pin.

- Conclusion.

This card is a BEAST (as of this writing 03/23/2014), and will run all of your games maxed out at least up to 1920x1080. I think this card will last me a few years into the future at minimum as well. If you have the case to fit it in, and the power to feed it, then it will give your great performance at maxing your games at awesome frame rates.inch card.

The temps stay nice and cool from what I've noticed, though I do have a case with great airflow (Antec 1200). The card is actually pretty quiet, and I have noticed no coil whine from mine (I did read about this card having a coil whine issue though, so take that for what it's worth).

The design specs recommend a 600W minimum power supply. Definitely make sure you meet this, as an underpowered card will run poorly or not at all.

The card needs an 8-pin PCI-E power connector, AND a 6-pin PCI-E power connector. I have a Thermaltake Toughpower 850W modular power supply. I had plenty of 6 pin cables, but no 8 pins. Luckily, the card is supplied with a "two 6 pin to one 8 pin" converter cable. What I'm saying is make sure you have at least three 6 pin cables available if you don't have an 8 pin and a 6 pin.

- Conclusion.

This card is a BEAST (as of this writing 03/23/2014), and will run all of your games maxed out at least up to 1920x1080. I think this card will last me a few years into the future at minimum as well. If you have the case to fit it in, and the power to feed it, then it will give your great performance at maxing your games at awesome frame rates.

The EnGenius ESR9850 appeared to be exactly what I wanted - a home router that supported 802.11b/g/n,, UpnP, WDS, good reviews, and at a fair price. Setup was straightforward and my 802.11G and 802.11N devices came on line easily. Potential purchasers should be advised however that the unit's backward compatibility to 802.11B devices is questionable. I have two such devices that are indeed compatible with my prior router, the Belkin G FSB7234, yet neither one recognizes a wireless signal from the ESR9850 when it is in mixed mode. Engenius' tech support, for their part, had me try various alternate settings, but none solved the problem. Yet in the face of reasonable doubt as to its 802.11B compatibility, they refused to consider that my particular ESR9850 could be defective, asserting that \\"if it were defective it would fail 100% of the time.\\" In other words, since it worked for my G and N devices there could be nothing else wrong. And let's be clear - it's advertised to work with B devices, doesn't work with my B devices, but they are satisfied that nothing is wrong with it.  So regardless of whatever is really at the root of the problem, I'm stuck with an Engenius router that does not perform to its advertised promise.  What do they do about it? Referring to my problem, they've told me \\"We consider this matter closed.\\"  And here's something else potential buyers should beware of - Engenius' return/repair policy. Check out their RMA Request Form on their website. You'll discover that if for some reason your Engenius product malfunctions you will have to fill out the form, send it back to them with your proof of purchase, wait for them to grant authorization, wait for a carrier to deliver the product to them, wait for them to do what they have to do to fix it, pay them what they decide you owe them, then wait for the return shipment. Do you want to be without a router for that length of time? What kind of position would you be in if you felt the charge for repair wastoo high? Providing an alternate router for troubleshooting and/or for keeping your network up during the repair/replacement period is evidently not a popular Engenius policy option either. I know because I suggested it, and they deemed it \\"not necessary.\\"

I usually hate changing my home router. My wife works from home and when problems occur work time could be lost. I had an old router that definitely needed to be replaced. Software and hardware was way out of date and the wireless signal wouldn't reach through the whole house requiring me to use extenders in the upper floors or depend on the hard wiring that was built into the house.

I am pleased to say that not only did the router install easily but the signal is now reaching the entire house. (7,000 square feet over three stories.) I have retired the wireless extenders and the additional router that I had used for the additional hard wires. We run three computers (pc and mac) 2 iphones 2 ipads and apple TV with no problem. Guests have their own limited login (which appeared with no additional set up work) and have had no problem accessing the system.

Oh, and as a bonus, I was able to unhook my backup drive from one of my computers and hook in directly into the router, getting rid of one piece of equipment on my desk.

I'm happy as a clam.

I have owned my 1 TB hard drive for a few days so I cannot review the stability of the drive.  However, all I had to do was to connect the drive to an electrical outlet and connect it to the computer.  The drive did not power on until it was connected to both the electrical outlet and the computer and as long as the unit is connected to the power sources, the white power light remains lit.  The light is very small and to me it is not that bright.    My computer added the software that is located on the Hitachi drive first before it added the hardware, the drive.  The drive shows up as one letter and the software shows up as another letter.  The drive arrived as 32 bit so I copied the software to another drive, deleted the partition and created a new partition in which my drive was created prior to creating a new partition.  I did this several times because the software remained on the Hitachi drive even after I reformatted the drive.  Then I notice that the software is recognized as a CD-Rom and a UDF file system which may explain why I could not delete the software.  The software takes up 295 MB of space leaving the drive with 931.07 GB of space or 99 percent free space.    I am able to copy and paste files on the drive without using the software just as you would do with almost any drive.  You are able to click on the drive without the software popping up.  I did not use or add the software nor do I have intentions at the present to use it.  However, these things are listed on the software's menu, Get Ready to Relive, Automatic Organization, Stunning 3D Browsing, Local and Online Backup, Instant Sharing (Facebook, and two other icons as I cannot recognize the other two icons), Install Lifestudio, Learn More, and Formatting.  The software is powered by Cooliris.     I am running XP but I also have other OS' and I do plan to connect them to the other OS' as well.    The drive came with a power adapter as well as the USB cable in which the length of the cables are long enough for my use.    I did not take a star off for not being able to remove the software because they run independently of one another but I would love to use the 295 MB of space that I cannot recover.  Therefore, I decided to put it in my review so each reviewer to decide how important not being able to reclaim the 295 MB.  Hitachi, please allow us the ability to decide if we want to keep the software or to delete it because I do not plan to use the software.

I am using this USB drive to create a bootable back up for my new computer.  Its a great way to go rather than cutting a DVD.

If you think you'd like to have two 500-GB drives slipped into your computer's floppy-disk (1.4-MB) 3.5\\" slot, then this is the way to do it.  It's fairly well-built, very well designed, and very easy to install.  All screws are provided; and fit/finish is first-class.    You don't need any accessory power leads (as in the LP4 to 2 SATA power splitter), because the unit comes with special SATA power leads with four additional wires to a connector for each drive bay to drive blue (disk present) and red (drive active) LED indicators.  The blue's a little bright, but not bad.  The red becomes magenta as it mixes with the blue LED which is on all the time a drive is installed in the bay.    This is a terrific product.  I bought a second unit for another install because it's so good.  If you don't need extra internal drive space, don't bother, but if you would like removable storage for off-line backup (esp. home video), definitely consider this economical and practical accessory.  At $72 for 320 GB (late 2009), WD Scorpio Black 2.5\\" drives are cheap and reliable storage. Alternatively, go ahead and purchase, record, and store 71 DVD disks.
Awesome bag. Perfect size & quality, at the best price.
Working as intended!
Used this product several time and it functioned as stated.  It offered me flexibility to use my laptop with difference media.
For it's price, it is a good deal. Light weight. Not fancy but It serves it's purpose. I'm happy with it.
This is a good motherboard , I had some trouble but that because I put my ram in the wrong ram spot, this is a very good motherboard though and I love the features that it comes with.

I have been using Keytronics keyboards for many years.  For a while I got away from them and was not pleased with what I had so I went back to Keytronics and am glad I did.  Keytronics keyboards are large enough so that my fingers are not stumbling over each other trying to get to the keys.  The action is solid enough to let me know when I have activated a key.  They are reliable and will hold up for years.  They have a variety of layouts available but I prefer the standard 104 key set up and they have it.  I should mention that I am a fast touch typist and that I have way more productive/reliable results with the Keytronics units because of the key spacing and the action.  Highly recommended.
Excellent quality case! Perfect size for 8 inch tablet allows just enough room for a few extra small things. Would highly recommend!

I have had this bridge for a few years at my home entertainment center.  I download movies from DTV, play Xbox with no lag, and watch Netflix movies in full quality.  I have never rebooted this router since I set it up.  It just works.  I would like to move up to a Buffalo wireless N bridge if they ever make one.
Great product for ventilation for the computer and easy, light and portable.
Very cheaply made, should have remembered what my mom always told me, \\"you get what you pay for\\"? Won't be a protective cover for my iPad. Threw it away.

I like that there's a wheel built-in to the roller, but it feels awkward while holding it and I wouldn't recommend it. My previous Microsoft mouse was more rounded, and had a 'back' button built into the side of it - that one was superior in both form & functionality
Great for the price!

Beautiful case with a simple concept of operation.  Has a strong magnet for closing the front flap.  The material is gorgeous black with a nice feel but is also a dust magnet inside and out.  The main feature of this case is the rotating disc to enable the iPad Air to be positioned either landscape or in portrait mode.  You can place it in multiple positions by leaning its edge on the bottom through friction.  Overall, it is one sleek attractive iPad case that has an executive look.

The case itself is pretty nice. Very easy to put on the iPad, not as bulky as some of the other options, and very protective.  However, the screen protector / stand is a completely different story.  That part is cheap, flimsy, awkward fitting, and poorly thought out. It's like two different companies made each part.

I have had this case for my son's kindle for several months now and it has saved his kindle multiple times. He is 4 years old and has thrown his kindle during his tantrums many times! Thank you for such a great product!

Hello everyone:  I bought these speakers about a month ago after looking all over for home theatres and pc speakers.  I simply hooked it up to my flat screen through an av-av \\"x\\" cable.  Then my PS3 is hooked through HDMI to the TV so I can listen to games and bluray through the speakers by switching inputs on the tv.  Also the remote is pretty cool, you can choose between inputs from it.  Makes it feel more like a hometheatre than PC speakers.  The power is definitely far more than I need for my apartment, it really can rattle windows with its 300 watts.  Great for downtempo high bass music such as chillout or hip hop.  sounds just like a mini shelf system.  Also has a nice aux input in the front.  These are like affordable BOSE 2.1 cinemates, probably have more power, and cost at least a third of the price. Sony does it again.  totally recommend.

Good pasttime in addition to books to read. Haven't watched a movie or listened to music yet..but plan on doing that soon.. Wish I had an istruction booklet as some things are hard to understand on the applications.  My first Kindle had a booklet which explained options.. helped a lot..
Excellent - nice product !!
Awesome case for the price.  its not perfect, but for the cost what more can you expect.  Delivered quickly and works like a charm.
This is exactly what I was looking for to be able to tell my 3 kids laptops apart. The kids love how they were able to pick out any picture print it out and stick it on their laptop.

Easy to set-up and use and comes in very handy when traveling.  It adds a wireless option to provide wifi internet access to multiple users or devices.  Especially useful and convenient in hotel room with a single wired access.  Also it adds secured wifi access.
nice product for Samsung Galaxy Tab 7.0. It covers it properly and keeps it safe and intact if you drop it. I dropped it once pretty badly but it did'nt had a scratch because of this folio case

Before I got this unit, I had a VGA cable running from my laptop, across the living room, to the TV.  My wife wasn't happy with that at all.  Then I got the Warpia and set it up with the base unit connected to the TV (Toshiba Regza) with a VGA cable and audio cable.  It worked great.  I used the PC-Input setup on the TV.  However, I had to make sure the VGA resolution of the laptop was compatible with the allowable resolution on the TV, otherwise, no signal.  Then I bought a cheap HDMI cable and was able to do away with the big VGA cable - and I didn't have to fuss with the laptop video resolution.  PLUS, now that I had the audio-out from the base unit free, I routed the audio cable to my stereo.  Now I can run anything from Netflix or YouTube to the TV, and my stored mp3s to the stereo.    I'm running a Toshiba laptop about 12 feet from the base unit at the TV.  The laptop is running on a wireless network also.  I'm competely wireless.  Strong signal, no dropouts.  My wife is happy too.  Highly recommended.
Works perfectly with my MacBook Pro.
thanks for the adapter.  a little shorter than the one I use in my office but it works just fine and arrived the day I came home from the hospital and started my maternity leave.  perfect timing!!
Item took a little long to get due to shipping from China probably. But item was exact replacement and has worked great. Hopefully it will last, but for price I would easily purchase again.

There is a lot to like about the Kindle 2, but it takes some getting used to. It's fine if you're reading right along, but if you want to flip back and check something, or if you want to flip forward and find out how long the chapter is so you know whether to go to bed now, it is a pain in the neck.     I like its weight and appearance, and the way it turns pages quickly. I can't figure out what the keyboard is for. If I want to write notes, I don't want to do so with those tiny little keys.    But I'll keep trying. Buying books in 60 seconds is kind of neat.  Dave Howell

This link set up very nicely and smoothly. I am however noticing a definite decrease in signal strength to my PC which is only about 20 feet away from my router.  The pc however is downstairs, whether or not this has any impact on the performace of the link, I am not sure. I guess it works fine for the money.

exactly as it looks in the picture!! hahaha its wonderful and it was easy to apply, came with very detailed instructions that helped me apply it perfectly... along with the shooting panda came another gun that looks like a Desert Eagle, and a set of 3 mustaches haha love this and it was cheap enough to have bought it three times for the quality!!

My love affair with the G15 was cut short after 2 months. A spilled wine glass did it in. Not a pretty site. But, there are not many keyboards that could take a punishment like that, so I don't blame it at all.

Besides normal gaming and computer use, I used this keyboard mainly with World of Warcraft. I found that LCD widgets that were available for this game were not all that useful compared to the information that I could have displayed on-screen. And since I had a second (and third) monitor, the Ventrillo widget really was not for me either (in the sense that I could glance at the second monitor rather than look down to see who was speaking). Really, the widget that I did use most often was the CPU/Memory monitor. But even then, since I upgraded to a new gaming rig, there is no reason to monitor these statistics. After thinking that the LCD monitor would have been the best invention in the world, I have found that I do not need it at all. So, as I search for a new gaming keyboard, this will not factor in my research. Otherwise, I would have readily bought this keyboard again.

The letters are large and dark which helps my elderly father see the keys and the cover fits nicely over the keyboard. Although you can feel there is a cover on the keys it doesn't affect typing at all. I'm very happy with the product.
Works great in my Camera for High Speed Video recording.

With several different projects going on at the same time I have 3 different sections to keep up with them. I stop recording in one section and start up in a different one. It's like having 3 journals with me at all times. I never know when I'm going to need the right one so I have them all at the same time. This has kept my notes separate and I feel much more organized. The dividers have pockets, too.

I bought this Kindle cover for my dad for Christmas. He immediately put it on his Kindle. Over the next couple of days he mentioned more than once how much he liked it. He had been accidentally hitting the buttons on the bottom (or side, when he put the device in horizontal mode) and was finding the Kindle experience frustrating. With this cover he wasn't hitting the buttons. He also found it handy to be able to stand the Kindle up on the table.
output: Keeps hands off of buttons while reading.

Instances.input: I bought this controller for my nephew and he loves it. He said it makes the playing experience so much better. I received the item on time and it was in excellent condition.
It was everything I expected. A really great product for the price. I'd recommend it to anyone looking for storage space.
it fits my lap top perfect..

Bought this RAM after reading reviews on another site. Despite being rated for 9-9-9-27, it runs 100% stable at 1866MHz on 8-8-8-24 2T at 1.55V. It also looks nice, relatively low profile... Seems to be some of the best 1866 RAM you can get for the price.

I was looking to set up a third monitor for my home setup, and this product seemed to be promising.

Current Home Setup:
- Late 2012 Mac Mini
- Apple 27" Thunderbolt Display
- (2) 24" 1080P HDMI Monitors (1 Connected with HDMI on Mac Mini)

I found this product online, and looked to work for others in the same scenario. When i got this home, i installed the drivers (as warned and stated numerous times in the packaging) before connecting the device and the monitor to the Mac Mini. After restarting the Mac Mini, i connected the j5Create device to the HDMI Monitor and then to the USB 3.0 port on the back of the Mac. The display lit up and stayed black with no background or title bar. I could move my mouse over to the screen and see the cursor, but that was it.

I emailed and called j5Create tech support for help with this issue. They helped me uninstall the two files the package installed, and reinstall the drivers again. After another couple of restarts, the same results. Come to find out they do not have drivers for OS X Mavericks as of now (9/30/2014) and is in the works with no ETA. That said, hopefully they can release these drivers and drivers for Yosemite coming out next month. I did offer up testing for a Beta driver set, or to work with the engineering team during the QA phase of the release. I was basically shot down with a product that is DOA. Its unfortunate as this could be a great product, but the customer service and tech support at j5Create is a little disappointing.

Bottom line, at this point, the product does not work as intended and in the environment that i have.
output: Doesn't Work with Mac Mini and OSX Mavericks

Instances.input: I love the Cosmos Purple 2.4G RF optical wireless USB mouse for my Macbook 13" PRO AIR. It works splendidly and you will not go wrong if you purchase this mouse.  It comes in different colors but I chose purple.
output: Cosmos Purple 2.4G RF optical wireless USB mouse for MACBOOK 13" PRO AIR

Instances.input: After buying this product, I HIGHLY recommend that you use the Bluesoliel drivers with this product.  It doesn't seem to like the Windows bluetooth drivers.  I got this a year ago when my old Bluetooth dongle went missing, and this was good for the price.  The shipping (as to be expected form Bargain Cell) was great.  However, this device DOES NOT come with the drivers on a CD as said.  The device worked great for a year, but then it started to die out.  At the price, you can't be beat.  It has an OK range of around 20 feet, and works with almost any bluetooth device.  Overall, compared to the $20 dongle I have now, it may not be the best, but it's a great deal!  Ease of use: 6/10  Range : 7/10  Overall: 7/10
output: Does NOT include the CD, but still good for the price

Instances.input:
G,day from oz (Australia).
I recently purchased a CaseCrown Hard Case Cover for my Kobo Vox and I am pleased I did.It has good strong edges and the outside of the case is smooth and hard (hopefully making it easy to clean) yet strong enough to take a solid knock/s. The inside front cover has a soft foam and cloth material, good for absorbing the odd bump and knock.The front cover also has a pocket made with elastic and netting to hold small items.The back cover has the same materials as the front cover, but it has 4 straps (2 elastic & 2 leather like, could be real leather?) the 2 elastic straps hold the top corners for easy fittng and removal while the more sturdy \\"leather\\" straps help for a more snug fit.
I like the idea of been able to stand my Vox at an angle while reading using the supplied support, just make sure the velcro at each end of the support is holding securely or it may dislodge. What I also realy like is been able to zip close the case to keep dust and other elements out.
P.S I bought this case through AMAZON because where I live (Perth Western Australia a GREAT PLACE to live) I couldn't find a similar product. What I found rather funny though, was buying this case from the good old US of A for Australia and originally made in China.
output: A Hard Case for the Kobo Vox

Instances.input: Decent OEM video card, but does not play well with some other cards for dual monitor video. Check before buying if possible!
output: Decent OEM Style Video Card for Business they use, NOT GAMING.

Instances.input: As I was buying my 3rd Kindle Fire as a gift for my sister, the selection of cases was quite limited. In spite of the fact this case was priced comparable to the other two cases I had purchased, this one was a little too flimsy for my taste.  It did not seem to offer as much protection as the other cases and was not as functional. I told my sister I would not be offended if she returned it. I don't know if she kept it or not.
I bought this case for a new laptop and was happy with the fit and organization options that are in this case I did a lot of looking around before I chose this and am happy with my choice

I purchased 3 of these laptops and had to fly them to my nephews & niece.
- all three fit snugly into a briefcase type carry-on.
- Light! Even with the batteries in place, they were not more than 12 pounds total.

The capacity of this notebook is quite fantastic, I think, and these teens are loving them. We loaded them up with their games, movies & whatnot and now the kids are loving life.
The graphics come thru in brilliant clear images.
I bought an external cd/dvd drive for them to use, other than that, the laptops perfect.
Very sharp laptops, very sharp look, very light, high capacity.

Amazon helped me with a minor glitch that occurred with one laptop and it was fixed within 24hours of contacting them. LOVE the Customer Support - just total Six Sigma Quality.
output: Very light, very large capacity, perfect.

Instances.input: PRECISELY WHAT i WANTED, DELIVERED RIGHT ON TIME.  PERFECT.

Good price for a replacement battery for DELL Inspiron 1525. It fits without any issues and charges with the default power supply. Package arrived in a bubble wrapped aluminum pouch,not the box as pictured. Also, the it was ship from 'Laptop Battery One'. So I'm confused since the Amazon website stated 'Sold by: LB1 High Performance' which I thought was direct from the LB1 company.

First day of use, it lasted close to 2 hrs. I fully charged it and lasted about 1 hr only on 2nd day of use. My computer detects the battery while it is being charged. However, it does not seem to monitor the charging capacity correctly. Jumps from 87% charged to 73% charged to 50% charged to 71% charged and keeps dropping. Also states 2 hr 30min to 1 hr 40 min to 1 hr 30 min remaining, etc. Just jumping back and forth. While I'm writing this review, it states 61% charged with 1hr 17min remaining.

I'll observe the battery for a few more days and will update my review. Will give it 2 stars for now.
output: Good price for a replacement battery for DELL Inspiron 1525

Instances.input: The memory is working great!

I had bought this headset as an expensive upgrade to my old one, and being 100 dollars you would expect a headset like this to last, but within a few months of acquiring the headset the plastic connecting the ear area to the headband was cracked. I was treating it fine, putting it on and taking it off carefully and making sure it was set down in a good position every day, but it still somehow broke within just a few months, due to the terrible plastic that was used to make the sides. The sound quality was great, the mic was fine, overall it was a great headset, but after 3 months it is barely functional, and the ear phones are dangling by the wire that holds them in. Do not buy this. It is not worth the money. I have had much cheaper headsets last far longer and still have good sound quality, If you are looking for quality, don't buy logitech. The return policy was crap, so I couldn't get a refund and it broke for no reason at all. DO NOT BUY THIS HEADSET.
The touch screen didn't even work when it arrived.  They refunded me quickly but after doing further research the screen issue is a problem many have had.  Pass on this product
output: The touch screen didn't even work when it arrived. ...

Instances.input: Hi, I bought this fan for my DELL D630 laptop, thinking I would do preventive maintenance as it is a 4 year old machine, package was ok, but once I installed this fan, my laptop began to overheat minutes after I turn it on, so I run the Dell Diagnostic software to find the root cause, and to my surprise the new fan didn't pass the test it gave me the error code 3700:011B, which means FAN FAILURE, I could not believe they sent me a bad fan, so I decided to try the old fan that I was replacing and this one passed the diagnostic test without a problem, so I ended up cleaning my old fan and using it again, I guess if it ain't broke don't fix it, I have to say that disassembling the laptop is a lot of work, and I did it twice to put back in my old fan. Don't buy this fan, as it doesn't work, look elsewhere.

I like this case so much. It covers my iPad really well and protects it from bumps, scratches or dirt. I know that this case only provides a horizontal viewing mode but with all 5 choices it makes it very versatile. I get so many compliments about how great my case looks and that makes me feel like I purchased the right case. Thanks Devicewear I love my case.
IT's Amazon, it's working great. What else to say except, if you need charger for most of the appliances (cell phone, tablets, headphones,...) this is great.
Bought this for my fiance and he loved it!
Love my cover

Don't listen to those who say its not good quality. This unit feels sturdy and leather feels real! I have been using it on Nook for several months now.

As a side note, I just received one of this brand FINTIE for my Ipad Air, disappointed so far. Leather like surface if it is real, cheaper and grainier than this unit for my Nook.

Note: similar cover for Ipad smells and I read that in reviews before I ordered it.
Charges the replacement battery well.  Woks as expected.  Son is using in college so dependability is desired...so far so good.
Protects Airbook and iPad well but just wish there was a place to put the charger.  Looks really nice.  Graphic and fun.

I purchased this new router for my home where I work full-time.  My laptop does not have a CD drive and the box with the router only had a CD - no instructions manual.  I went to the Linksys website to download software but it didn't really work and I didn't know exactly what I was supposed to do.  I had to call my tech support guy in another office to walk me through installing it.  Turns out my IBM ThinkPad X200 (less than a year old) doesn't support WPA2-Personal encryption so I can't even use the -N technology for better/faster connections.  I'm pretty sure the product works well, but make sure you have a built-in CD drive on your computer so you can do the install and that your computer supports the WPA-2 Personal encryption so you don't waste money on technology you can't use.
This 32gb class ten works well in our 7" tablet, I think this would be a good choice for any vidio product, or transfering audio, vidio  or pictures.

My initial connection/set-up of my new external SATA HDD was analagous to getting Verizon FIOS TV for a house that is wired with coaxial cable - what's the point??  I bought an external HDD case that sported both fire wire and USB 2.0 connections.  Then I put a 7500 rpm, 16 MB cache, 1 TB SATA HDD into it and proceeded to connect it to the laptop with  the USB connection (dumb); the performance improvement over the previous external IEEE PATA HDD connected via USB was, (understandably) ZERO!  Not very smart on my part.  So, I bought this cable and a PCMCIA fire wire card and now my data transfer rate is extraordinary.  If you are going to use state-of the- art peripherals,  don't forget state-of-the art cables/connections.
The 30 pin to 8 Pin Converter Adapter For iPhone 5 iPad 4 iPad Mini iPod Touch was an unbelievable price, compared to the original $30.00 but it did not work with my original ipod.

For the price this cable/adapter does exactly what it says. No big deal, but I will say it gets so hot you almost can't touch it at the center adapter part. Make sure to keep it out in the open to get air. Otherwise, good purchase.
Love it!!!  This works great. I can do more then just read.  Great product for the price!!!  Received quickly and has worked great.

vendor was nice to accept return and credit without an issue
however ... be aware that these huge antenna units might cause impedence or other issues with
many wifi routers and especially in some environments with too many reflective surfaces might
overload or blow the output or inputs on your RF stages ...

Also they are so huge that they put huge mechanical loads on the RF ports they attach to ... and pretty much need to be braced up
with some other support

I have had this mouse for 1 week i am very satisfied with it. I am a huge runescape gamer and bought it for my laptop it scrools through all the menus and has great reactoin time. I hope this review has helped all the gamers to make the best decision possible on making their purchase. LOL

What a wonderful piece of technology! I have already downloaded 10 books (for free) to read and am delighted with the whole reading experience. I can not falter the delivery service to OZ one bit - I  ordered the wonderful Kindle on Sunday from Amazon.com, and received the parcel on Wednesday (only 3 days later). I'll be definitely ordering many more items (including books) from Amazon over the next few years.

This unit is a nice tablet/e-reader, and a good option if the iPad is out of reach cost-wise.  The screen is bright, and the system has a processor that makes it pretty responsive.  As an e-reader, it's not as comfortable as a paperwhite or other e-ink reader, since the screen is a bit glossy and it's a backlit device.  Overall, though, a compact tablet with an attractive price.

[[VIDEOID:moZX1W3R262V73]]A-Data is one of the major flash RAM manufacturers from Taiwan. Their claim to fame was their excellent performance to cost ratio. They seemed to have continued this tradition.

I needed a larger SDHC card for my Panasonic LX3, which also shoots HD video and raw photos, demanding high transfer rate and large storage capacity. When I found this package for a bargain price I took the bite, as it is also a micro SDHC format for uses with smart phones and PDA devices, among an increasing list of other miniaturized electronics that are adopting to this now universal standard (olympus and sony just abandoned their xD and memory stick on their latest crop of products/cameras). There is no premium for this versatility as other standard sized SDHC cards sold for about the same price if not more at the time of my purchase.

Frustration free package (see uploaded photos) is just a brown envelope with the manufacturer packaged hard case inside holding the adapter and the card itself. I believe the packaging is sufficiently protective. Amazon actually put this brown envelop into another small shipping box. It is probably not necessary, but I appreciate Amazon's taking extra precautions.

The microSDHC card looks well made, fresh off the press with no scratch or smudges, and printed digits. It fits very snugly into the SD sized adapter, that you have to push a little harder to get it in. There's no wiggle or shakes after it sits into the slot. Nothing feels flimsy about this package, which probably should be the par but often isn't.

Transfer rate also performed as expected. I have a sustained rate of over 6MB/sec during download transfers. There has been no problems using it with the LX3 by downloading straight from the camera's USB port, or using a SDHC card reader. I have experienced no problems (yet) and the card had been reliable, while providing the responsiveness (cycle time between RAW capture is negligent compared to a slower class 4 or even a class 2 card) and transfer speed (for large HD video files) that I seek.

There's not much one needs to do for a flash ram other than its reliability, functionality, and durability/build quality. This card apparently delivered on these fronts, while providing the dual-format versatility, at a price I can feel happy about. It's a little better than I expected, actually.

Addendum: Benchmark results for the card I received, obtained by using FDBENCH software using built in card reader on a Thinkpad X61s:

***** FDBENCH Ver 1.02 (C)2003-2007 ep82kazu *****
Drive D:\
Drive Size 100MB

Disk Read Write RRead RWrite (KByte/s)
10252 13615 10128 13233 4031

Copy 2k 32k 256k 1MB (Operations/min)
4054 7260 6288 2040 630

Copy 2k 32k 256k 1MB (Kbyte/Sec)
3923 161 2243 5861 7426

The read/write speed for contiguous files as demonstrated are well above class 6 speeds (6000KB/s). RRead/RWrite are random read write speeds. Apparently more fragmented the file the slower the transfer rate, which is also normal. For your reference only, as there are probably room for error depending on testing hardware and production batches.even a class 2 card) and transfer speed (for large HD video files) that I seek. There's not much one needs to do for a flash ram other than its reliability, functionality, and durability/build quality. This card apparently delivered on these fronts, while providing the dual-format versatility, at a price I can feel happy about. It's a little better than I expected, actually. Bought it for my dad and when I last saw it, it still looked new. Case is kind of thick, but it will protect the tablet if it were ever dropped.

This system has decent enough features and easy set-up.  However, even accounting for the expected limitations of this sort of unit, the sound is especially tinny and thin.  I've also found the remote to not be particularly sensitive.  I purchased this specifically to use at work, and even with my fairly lowered expectation that the sound only be \\"good enough\\" this fell below par.  Grade: D

The charger works well, but it's not long enough. It's super short, so I can't really work on my laptop while it's charging!
output: Works Well, But Not Long Enough

Instances.input: I ordered this case for my husband's kindle.  Overall, it's not bad.  However, the inside flap is of a material that cheapens the whole case and the zipper is not as pictured.  In the photo it looks very easy to open up the zipper completely whereas on the one I got there is piece of fabric that you literally need to tuck the zipper into to be able to fold the front back.    I'll review this post after I give it to him with his feelings.      I would like to add, though, that shipping was very fast and that I appreciate from third-party venders.      This is an update to my original review.  My husband is very happy with the case so I have increased my review to four stars.  I appreciate the very fast response from the company in reference to my issues, however it was recommended to me to take the piece of fabric off that is covering the zipper to eliminate the need to tuck it in.  Within five minutes my husband had managed to push the zipper up to far and I told him he could remove that fabric.  This is not the case, removing it would actually damage the inside of the case.  We got the zipper out, and now he knows not to push it in that far.

Not very stable.  Has more flex and wiggle than I am comfortable with.  Be prepared to bolt to the floor, and even then don't make it top heavy.  This rack is lighter weight and less sturdy than other open frame ones we have.
output: Has more flex and wiggle than I am comfortable with. Be prepared to bolt to the floor

Instances.input: Highly recommend.  Excellent for reading the keyboard.  Does everything Amazon said it would do.  A real find for many things that might require illuminating.

Clearly states it is for Alienware m17X, And it is NOT the correct wattage required to charge the battery and operate the laptop at the same time, the computer simply refuses to identify a 180w AC adapter as capable of operating the alienware laptop. So it reads " Plugged in, Not charging " while trying to operate the computer. I tried roughly 4-6 ways to fix the Plugged in not charging "error" but of coarse, I had to google tons of stuff, to find out Alienwares require 240w AC adapters to charge the battery to 100% and to operate at full potential. Before half of my graphics settings weren't even available with this 180w AC adapter Amazon displayed as being for the computer. Sure the dang thing can plug into the back of my computer and make it run, but it would slowly allow my battery to drain and die, thus I ended up purchasing a new battery along with the 240w AC  adapter. I paid only $10 for this which is a great value. I also bought the Amazon case at $45 and I will be returning it since it cost so much more than the MoKo case but doesn't deliver enough additional value. If you've got an HP TouchPad and the HP case for it, this case feels exactly like that one. It definitely doesn't feel as sturdy or as elegant as the Amazon case but at less than a quarter of the price and still of pretty good quality it's definitely a worthwhile purchase. There's no magnetic closure so your device won't turn on and off when opening and closing the case. If you're OK with that the only thing you need to be concerned with is that this case has no opening for the microphone! I'm planning to drill a hole for it and hope it doesn't look too bad. This is the biggest oversight with this case and would be an unforgiveable flaw were it not so cheap. The other thing I don't like is the elastic strap that holds the lid closed feels like it will stretch out after a while and become useless, time will tell on that one. On the positive side, it is a MUCH better stand than the Amazon case. The Amazon case acts as a stand by opening it to a V shape and turning it upside down. It feels very flimsy in this position and could very likely fall flat on a table surface. The MoKo case, on the other hand, acts as a very sturdy stand which will definitely not fail to hold your device upright. I took one star off for the missing microphone hole, otherwise this would get 5 stars, great price-performance ratio.

UPDATE: I received the same email as other purchasers got regarding the free replacement being offered when the new case is available. They state that the new version of the case will have magnetic closure and a hole for the microphone. If this is true I will be extremely happy to get the new version. Those changes will make this case an unbeatable value even at twice the price. I will update this review when/if the free replacement arrives.

UPDATE #2: I received the new version of the case as promised. The KFHD turns on and off when the case is open and closed and there is a cutout for the microphone. This is a great case for the money and I highly recommend both the case and the seller. It's a much better value than the Amazon case and the seller really stands behind their product. I am revising my review up to 5 stars from 4 stars.

You can tell as soon as you take the Hoverbar out of the box that it is a solid, well-constructed holder.  Numerous studies have shown that having two screens can almost double worker productivity.  There are numerous apps, either direct-connect or wifi-based, that allow you to give open apps on two screens.  You can use the hoverbar in conjunction with these apps to use one screen for reference or personal use, and the other for the work that pays the bills.  Customer service was phenomenal. Plugged it in.  Downloaded drivers from [...].  Works great no issue!  Has nice tactile feel.  Lighting effects are useful as I typically don't have any direct lighting in the room.
