My only negative comment:  occasionally, I hit the wrong key as it's layout seems a little cramped on the left side.  I think I'll adjust to it with long term use though.  I don't know that this is a problem, per se.   It's just different the the Dell keyboard I use at work.

The right-side fan does not work at all anymore, after only about four weeks.  I do not even use the computer every day, and it's completely broken.  The left fan does still work, but it's not great.  While the product gets two stars because my laptop doesn't go into thermal shutdown quite as often anymore, I can't in good conscience give it more stars than that.  My laptop still shuts down on average of 1-2 times every time I use it due to overheating.  The product simply doesn't do what I need it to do - keep the bottom of my computer cool.  It also has an awkward metal bar on the bottom that makes it impossible to use the laptop anywhere but my desk (e.g. I can't comfortably sit it on my lap).  It also is hard to fit my laptop flat on the surface because I have an extended life battery that protrudes out from the bottom of my machine (when you sit the laptop on a flat table, it is on an incline solely due to the shape of the battery pack).  This may contribute to the lack of cooling power given by the fan.  Lastly, the fan does not turn off when you hibernate the computer.  You actually have to push a button on the back to get it to stop running, which is pretty annoying.

It is also very inexpensive, it has dropped in price dramatically a couple days after I bought it, but oh well. It came in original packaging and was shipped securely.

This replaced a failed combo drive in an old Dell laptop. The laptop drive is held within a plastic frame that slides into the laptop and is held with a latch. Replacement required a easy sequence of steps:
* removing the drive frame from the laptop
* dismantling the plastic frame hold the old drive (8 small screws)
* removing the old drive from the laptop drive frame
* peel off the plastic front from both the old drive and the new drive and put the old plastic front onto the new drive. (This plastic front has the Dell logo and the led light. It fits the frame so that the drive will open and close properly. The new drive had generic plastic that was too wide.)
* Place the new drive into the plastic frame, reassemble with the small screws and slide it into the laptop.
Worked as expected without a problem. While I had no problem figuring this out, only 4 stars because it did not come with instructions or hints for non-technical DIY'ers.
output: Replacement DVD/CDRW for old Dell laptop

I have ordered this charger twice -- I know, fool me twice, shame on me, I was trying to save money but it's NOT WORTH IT! The second one I ordered, the little adapter itself that plugs into the laptop got so hot you couldn't touch it, and it was ruining my port -- charging power was intermittent. We took it to Radioshack and the lady said she has seen them catch fire! We spent a little more money on a better brand, and all parts are cool to the touch and no more problems! For your safety, don't buy this charger just to save money. I learned my lesson.

Instances.input: I bought this device to replace some a/b/g equipment as well as extend my network and provide a wired gigabit switch.    I used manual setup to disable DHCP and set the network configurations to mimic what was in place.  After some setup, everything provided a seamless and faster solution to my wireless devices.  I am not using the USB connection so I can't comment on that operation.  Solid and reliable -- that's what I was looking for and what I found with this product.

Got this mouse for travel. It is too small for an adult to use comfortably. The action on it is stiff and very loud. I gave it to my ten year old to use. He promptly told me it was 'annoying'. Ultimately, we just threw it out away because it was too much money to send it back. Also, the brand name is Belkin, not Toshiba. Doubt that Toshiba would produce anything this useless. The only reason this was given two stars, is that I like the retractable cord.

The price was good.  The product was said to be in excellent condition but it did show quite a bit of wear.  Also, three of the rubber small rubber stands were missing. Also, the shipping took a while, but I was reimbursed for that.  And the main gripe was that it came WITHOUT an adapter.  I assumed it would have one which was a mistake on my part. Once I got a power adapter router worked just fine.

The pros

1) good data transfer rates... I was averaging 20-50 mb/s between two external USB-3 hard drives and 40-50 between a single drive and the PC.

2) cheap - this unit was half the price of an equivalent unit at a local chain store (namely, fry's).

3) small footprint - doesn't take up much space, and can be tossed into my laptop bag when needed on the go (this unit weighs almost nothing)

the cons

1) power cord and included usb-3 cable are REALLY SHORT

2) the usb cable isn't very flexible. This may be a good thing in disguise (can't break it if you can't bend it too far) but because of the inhernt curl to it (from being packaged for a while) it tends to curl up (shorten) and drag the hub with it.

3) The power supply takes up to much space on a power strip... it wouldn't take much for an engineer to have designed this very low-output power unit so that it fit into one plug space ... most of the other peripheral companies have already figured this out...

Overall, I'm really happy with the unit for what it is. If I could pay $5 more and get one with a single width power supply, I'd do it... but they don't usually give dimensions on the power supply in the product descriptions... maybe someone will realize that's a selling point with most computer products (HINT HINT).

The Seagate Seven is every thing it is advertised to be. Over the years I've owned numerous Seagate drives and I have never had one fail. One reason I chose the Seven is the thinness of it; it packs easily in my computer bag and adds virtually no weight. Access time is good and overall I am happy with my choice. I highly recommend this drive.

Instances.input: A very solid tablet. I'm going from a 2013 Nexus 7 to this. My tolerance for hitches in animation are a lot higher than what I've seen from tech review sites and places like the Android subreddit so if you're the kind of person that is driven insane by some jerkiness in screen animations, then my user interface experience won't be representative of how yours would be. I will say that the UI has more jerkiness to it compared to the 2013 Nexus 7. This may be fixed in an update but right now the Nexus 7 I have is a smoother experience yet to me the screen jerkiness is pretty much negligible. It isn't anywhere close to being in every animation. To me it's so rare and minor that it doesn't even make me flinch. Now for the real review of which I never use tablet cameras so don't expect any insight for that ever from me.  This tablet from comparison videos and pictures doesn't look that much bigger than the Nexus 7 but when handling it, it is definitely larger. The weight feels slightly heavier than it but both are very comfortable for me to hold in one hand. The size of the 9 makes moving your hand around more to navigate more prevalent but the added size in an absolute plus to me. The screen is gorgeous. It isn't as eye popping as the Samsung Galaxy Tab S tabs that I've handles but the screen is a marked improvement over the 7. Whites look a lot more whiter and blacks look deeper. My tablet doesn't have any issues with backlight bleed. Reading PDFs/books and comic books is a huge improvement. I don't need to zoom in anymore. Websites are more legible and using the tablet in horizontal posture is now usable. Watching videos, the black bars do not bother me. Videos look great on the screen and the viewing angles are great. At least watching older 4:3 shows now fills the whole screen. Using Word or Excel benefits greatly from the size of the screen and the lower PPI compared to the Nexus 7 hasn't bothered me at all. Pretty much everything about this display is an improvement to me.  It doesn't feel like the most premium tablet but I keep it in a case so it doesn't matter to me. The main annoyance are the buttons. When I find them, I can push them easy enough but they don't protrude as much as the Nexus 7 so they're harder to locate. Since they're smaller pushing them requires more effort as they're almost so slim and flush with the tablet, it's like they're not buttons at all. That is annoying but I can deal with it. The good thing is that the Nexus 9 has the double tap the screen to wake so at least I don't have to use the power button. At least it doesn't look as bad the older Nexus 9s. The tablet has those HTC Boomsound speakers. They're a definite improvement over what I usually hear from tablet and phone speakers but they're still tablet speakers. They're very clear and louder than the average but nothing to be incredibly impressed with. I always use headphones. Big negative though would be the lack of a microSD card slot. I've learned to live with USB OTG cables and PLEX since Android tablets have sparse options, but I would definitely prefer microSD slot. This will probably be a tank of a tablet so I won't be buying a new one for years but the next one I buy will definitely need a microSD slot. In particular since SOCs have now reached a speed that I won't care how powerful future tablets will be in a couple of years, they'll all be incredibly fast for a device with limited multitasking functionality.  The tablet uses a Tegra K1 with their 64bit Denver based cores. It rips through games that I play of which are pretty much just old PS1 JRPG games that have been released on Google Play so nothing too hardware intensive. It smashes word search and tetris as well. My main reason to upgrade was because the screen size and aspect ratio of the Nexus 7 made reading a chore, but the other reason was video playback of higher quality videos on it were choppy. The playback would be fine with my Snapdragon 801 equipped Sony Xperia Z2 but the Nexus 7 would play them choppy. I've tested with the Nexus 9 some really high quality h.264 videos on it. They're 4k 75,000 kbps bit-rate videos and the Nexus 9 has no problems playing them. The Snapdragon 801 plays them just as well but the Nexus 7 can't keep up. The strength of the tablet is pretty awesome to me. Even though there are small animation jitters here and there, the navigation experience to me is beyond satisfactory for me.  An overall solid tablet experience is what I'd say about this. It has a great screen with great size. The weight is light. It's great for reading and watching videos. To me the experience isn't any worse than an iPad or Samsung tablet. I wish the volume and power buttons were larger as well as the tablet having a microSD slot. Also getting rid of all jerky animations would be preferable. Those make this tablet imperfect but I can get over any of that. If not this tablet I would recommend the Galaxy Tab S8.4 since 7 inches is just too small for optimal reading and it's just barely a good enough size for videos. 10 inch tablets that are 16:9 are too long to be that comfortable to use. 4:3 and 3:2 tablets are more solid in its usability in both screen orientations. Even the full size iPad is too big for me yet the iPad mini is too small to me. 8.9" tablet with a 4:3 screen ratio is good sweet spot to me. This tablet is awesome. It's a much better companion to a desktop than a laptop is to me now. I would recommend this tablet if people asked me.

I bought it for my daughter to watch videos on long car rides. Most of the time, the videos I've purchased on amazon don't work in the car because we aren't on a wireless network. I purchased and downloaded the videos onto the device specifically to watch them offline. It's an expensive e experiment gone awry. It's too annoying to take the time to describe the poor design but trust me, it's like nobody tested that feature before manufacturing millions of these things. I tried to branch out from Apple and give the kindle a chance. I was reAlly excited about the amazon downloads and Free time but since it rarely works it isn't worth the $200 savings over the iPad.

I highly recommend this purchase.

But now the monitor renders colors correctly and is worth every penny.  Running HDMI (which requires additional settings which are noted in other reviews).  One thing I like about this monitor is it allows full control of the lights on the bezel, including turning them off completely or dimming them.
output: Excellent monitor but needs MAJOR green and blue adjustments

Then I picked it up to carry it and at that moment I realized the issue: Because it's not completely snug, the laptop wiggles around in the sleeve when you're carrying it and it wouldn't be difficult for it to slip out of your hands. This isn't a fault of the sleeve because it's clear that this is a generic case for 13" devices. Followed directions exactly.  Made sure screen was pristine, not a spec of dust (used microfiber to clean with and lightly blow off too).  Did not install easilly, lot's of bubbles that couldn't be moved.  Would not recommend.  Oh, and to return it you have to pay a $3.95 restock fee and shipping, so I'm out almost $10 for something that's not good at all.  BTW, I have installed a lot of scteen protectors before, so I'm not new to this.    Update - 5/17/2011 - I was promptly contacted by the seller offering replacement, additional advice on install and assurances that they will stand behind their product at all times.    After receiving the replacement product, I viewed the video this time - this is a must as I only read the instructions - the video is much more clear.  Again I cleaned the screen until pristine with several lint free cloths and viewed the screen from many angles to check for dust particles - None.  Followed video installation instructions and this time the screen was much smoother and clearer, but in the time I was spraying the solution, etc a few micro dust particles must have landed on the surface (from probably moving the air around as I positioned the screen protector).  The result now after drying overnight is a very nice product, with a few minor bumps and one \\"smudge\\" (can't really explain how or what it is - it doesn't affect viewing, but I can see it when reflecting light).    Pro's:  Lifetime replacement warranty  Very high level of transparancey  Feels and glides better than the Gorilla Glass  Cleans easier and smudges less than Gorilla Glass    Con's:  Exacting install required - follow directions closely  Some screen imperfections show up in light reflection, but haven't noticed in viewing movies or docs, etc.  Not being advised to use for 1hr after install and allowing 4+ hrs to dry is a long time (unless you do it at night and allow to dry overnight as I did).  I'm not big on fluid required installs, but the fluid does dry fairly quickly.    Overall - I would recommend this screen protector if you are looking to protect the screen of your Transformer (I'm not going to open a discussion on Gorilla Glass) to prevent damaging the glass.  The overall result is very good, but not as good as glass alone.  Whether this is the same with other protectors, I don't know, but will summize it is (especially for a screen this large).    I hope this helps much more than the original review.  When I do replace this again (which I probably will) I will be in a clean room in a suit (just kidding :) ) - but realistically, if you can make one final dust check before you apply you will probably get a great install.

I was totally impressed with the description of the item when I was doing some research for a GN8 Book Cover that did not use Magnets. This book cover was reading quite nice. Upon receiving the item, I noticed that the tongue latch was a bit difficult to open and easy to lock into place. It does not seem, to me, that it will withstand the daily use and will eventually come apart. I have noticed that after using it for 1 day, a tear has appeared on the stitching that is holding the tongue latch. I give it about a month before it completely tears off. When holding the tablet open while browsing the internet or playing a game, whether it is in Portrait or Landscape, you will have difficulties holding it with one hand. The inside fabric is slippery.

Pros:
Beautiful Craftsmanship.
Note 8 snap in holder is ideal when looking for a case/cover.
Outer Material used begs to be held. It just feels really nice in your hands.
Tongue Latch works great to keep it closed.
Landscape stand.

Cons:
Not a good grip while reading or using the tablet in Portrait or Landscape mode, slippery and a challenge.
Nothing to help with holding it with one hand comfortably.
Latch is in the way.
No way to hide the latch when the book cover is open.
Already see a tear in the material where tongue latch is attached.

Room for Improvement:

Alternative 1: Tongue latch should have some extra ribbon on both sides that can be used to unlatch when closed, this would make it easier to open. Then, if you would like to latch the cover when it is open, another ribbon or material that would allow you to unlatch so you could close it. This can be a ribbon or same material as external and internal used to match and keep it looking sharp.

Alternative 2: An elastic band that is on the back to lock the cover in place.

To make it easier to hold with one hand, use a hand or two finger strap that is located on the inside of the top cover to make it comfortable to hold while the cover is open and latched, of course, this would only work with Alt 1 or 2.

STM, if you are reading this, my suggestions would make this a 5 Star Book Cover. You are on the right track, hopefully your R&D is testing the use of these covers.

That is all I can say about this cover. If you don't mind the latch or the fact you will struggle to hold onto the case while using your GN8, then this is a nice find. I will continue to use it, but I will be looking for that elusive perfect book cover for my GN8. If STM comes up with a new one, I will definitely consider it.s located on the inside of the top cover to make it comfortable to hold while the cover is open and latched, of course, this would only work with Alt 1 or 2.

I was so excited when my charger came in the mail. It was shipped quickly, as other reviewers have mentioned. The label said it came from X C and not MAC HOME, which I found odd. First, the cord wasn't as long as I expected, being that the listing said it was longer than the competitors (it was about 49\\"). More importantly, IT DIDN'T WORK.

I wrote a friendly note to \\"MAC HOME\\" letting them know that I'd like it replaced. They wrote back, said that they \\"sincerely regret the issue,\\" asked me what kind of computer I had and asked me to test the cord by detaching the plug and replacing it with another plug. I thought it was strange that they would assume I even had another working plug around, but I found one. Still nothing. Wrote back & told them that it wasn't the plug and I had a 15\\" PowerBook.

Now, let's take a step back. I am someone who takes my time choosing a product. While shopping, I double checked the advertised specifications - the wattage was exactly what the Apple store employee told me to get (65W), as well as exactly the same as my previous power cord. The voltage, part number, etc. - all of it were EXACTLY THE SAME. And, nothing in the listing for this product said anything about it only working on a PowerBook of certain screen size.

Forward to after I sent \\"MAC HOME\\" my second message, telling them I have a 15\\" PowerBook. They write back, \\"Please be advised...\\" (I'd like to interject that this is a strange way to start a letter to a customer addressing a product issue. But I digress...). Then they proceed to say that this model of power cord doesn't work with a 15\\" PowerBook, and that I needed to order an 85 watt cord, which I was welcome to order from them (which of course costs more and would take more time to receive). They said I was also welcome to return the cord I purchased through Amazon.

Are you kidding?! You falsely advertise your product and/or send me a faulty product and now youare telling me that to get what I paid for (ie a product that SHOULD work with my computer), I have to purchase something more expensive from you AND go through the return process?!

I wrote back, explaining that I'd done my due diligence and that the product I was led to believe I ordered should work with my computer. I also said that I expected them to send me a product that DID do what they said, without further cost to me. They wrote back and repeated what they had said before - that I was welcome to return the product through Amazon.

So, in summary, FALSE INFORMATION IN LISTING, PRODUCT DIDN'T WORK, NO EFFORT TO REPLACE IT, and IMPERSONAL CUSTOMER SERVICE. The only plus was the promptness with which everything happened, though what good is that when the product is crap?

I DO NOT RECOMMEND ORDERING FROM THIS COMPANY.that I was welcome to return the product through Amazon.

So, in summary, FALSE INFORMATION IN LISTING, PRODUCT DIDN'T WORK AT ALL, NO EFFORT TO RECTIFY THEIR MISTAKE, and FRUSTRATINGLY IMPERSONAL CUSTOMER SERVICE. The only plus was the promptness with which everything happened, though what good is that when the product is bad?

I highly recommend NEVER ORDERING A PRODUCT FROM THIS COMPANY.
output: MISLEADING AD, BAD PRODUCT, TERRIBLE CUSTOMER SERVICE

My wife has had a second generation Kindle for quite some time, and I've been secretly envying it all along.  So I was thrilled to get my own for my birthday two days ago - and today, when I had 10 hours of flights and layovers to deal with, I knew I'd be fine because I had so much reading I could do.  But, then the screen just quit working on the bottom half. I was reading it on the plane, turned it off and put it in my briefcase, then sat down on my layover to start reading again and the screen was shot - nothing but lines on the bottom and some vertical lines running up through the left side of the screen to the top.  Nothing hit it, it wasn't dropped, wasn't near anything magnetic, just an outright failure. I'm sure they'll replace it, but after reading how often this seems to be happening to people I'm not sure I want another...seems like the lower cost of these new ones may be the result of poorer manufacturing quality. Seriously bummed.  UPDATE 01/02/12: I've revised my rating to three based on the great customer service I received on this one - Amazon very quickly sent me a new unit via 2-day, without any hassles whatsoever. Hoping to revise the rating upward again after I have a few months with the new one to feel comfortable that my screen failure was a relatively isolated incident.

This thing is amazing. If you ever read books, buy it.

Positives:
-The screen is amazing. When I took it out of the box, I thought that the default image it ships with was a piece of printed paper. It's so crisp. The back lighting is nice for reading at night.
-The ability to look up words in a dictionary by touching them on the screen is very convenient. The Kindle also saves the words you've looked up, and lets you do a flash card game with them.
-Instant delivery is gratifying. No waiting.
-Unlike a paperback, the Kindle can be laid down on a flat surface without losing its page.
-If you like pulp-grade science fiction of the "25 Story Anthology Collection" variety, there is a huge amount available on the Kindle at extremely low prices.

Negatives:
-The Kindle lending library is difficult to browse, and can only be accessed on the Kindle itself-- not on a computer. I suspect that Amazon intentionally crippled this functionality to encourage people to buy books rather than borrowing.
-Some books are not available in Kindle format.
-Magazines are very limited. They're either not available on this type of Kindle, or they're priced terribly (a single copy of The Economist on Kindle costs almost as much as a physical copy at a newsstand. Really?).
output: Why do people still buy paper books?

The box design is another cause for concern. It's unsophisticated, like a rough draft. These are, in my experience, not good signs. It's not as if you can't throw a rock and hit a graphic designer.

---

Well, it was a breeze to set up and appeared eager and willing to store everything I have on hand and make it accessible from anywhere you can establish a web connection. There's a $35/month subscription which I understand makes it possible to stream your music or movies. I can see where this would be a neat device for someone who was on the go a lot and might want their personal or especially their business data at their fingertips.

Since I use a Mac the non-standard interface freaked me out. My kids have Windows computers and anything that remotely resembles that kind of interface makes my blood pressure rise, anticipating problems. Since the User Agreement said that the device was for 18+ users only that was kind of an issue -- could I use this for their data? I didn't think so.

If you have an iPhone or Android or a phone or device like that I can see where this would be a great device to have, unfortunately I don't own any kind of smart phone.

Overall, sorry to say, the non-standard interface, the companies I'd never heard of, the first-draft feeling of the graphics didn't inspire me to trust the device. If I were a Windows user this thing might seem like the greatest idea since sliced bread. Slick, fast, seems to do everything it promises to do -- I think I might be too much of a couch potato non-mobile user to get much out of this device, really. I have a couple external drives for backups or photo storage and seldom stray from home. This isn't a bad product, but I get the feeling that I'm not in the target market group for this kind of device.

---

Instances.input: I bought this case before going on a trip and I'm really happy with it. My iPad fits in it perfectly, nice and snug, and it makes me much less worried about what will happen if I ever drop it! Before I bought this, I saw a review that mentioned the case does not sit flat when it is open -- well, that is dead wrong. You may have to break it in a bit (duh!), but it'll sit flat no problem. It also sits perfectly on the little stand I have (I use one of those free-standing frame/plate holders! It works perfectly and only cost a couple bucks at Bed Bath & Beyond), no need to remove it from the case.     It's true that you can't really fit much else inside the case, but it'll hold your passport, tickets, receipts, etc, which is convenient for traveling. I keep the case on all the time. I should mention my main use for my iPad is work-related and for what I do, this case almost couldn't be any better. I manage a big team of visual effects artists and constantly run around checking in on the status of their tasks etc. I have replaced my stone-age clipboard with my hot-pink-encased iPad and a few sheets of paper in the pockets. What I'd really like to find is a small pad of paper that would fit in the case's pocket...    Oh yes, I also listen to a lot of music on my iPad and I've noticed no real sound quality difference when it's in the case.     Overall, very happy with this purchase. My only complaint has to do with the shipping, not the product. I selected 2-day shipping in order to get it in time for my flight, but it took 3 days and I had to leave work early to go pick it up from the delivery center, which is pretty far from where I live and in the exact opposite direction of the airport, before hopping on my plane.

Instances.input:
Most cases run tall, this one runs deep instead. Has no trouble fitting my rather large Radeon HD 5850 card and is nice and quiet with only a slight hum from the fans. If you have a skinny enclosure, make sure you can fit 9 1/2\\" of width before purchasing. Lots of holes to hide your cables behind and the extra width means you can get them all out of the way (full tuck) provided you have the right cable lengths. Lots of air thanks to the 200mm fan in the front. This also means it'll bring in a lot of dust. What I do is purchase a good home air filter and cut it to size to place behind the front air intakes but in front of the fan. Keeps the dust trapped and the components safe. I suppose I could reduce temperatures with a high end CPU cooler but the case keeps everything cool enough for a stock CPU fan. A LED on/off button at the top turns the red light off if you're not into that sort of thing. You'll also need to purchase a power supply separately.

My only gripes:
1) The money I saved will need to be spent on a [[ASIN:B002LE8BJA 200mm Case Fan]] because they didn't include one for the side panel.
2) The tool free 5.25\\" device works good but the 3.5\\" device doesn't work well. I worry about the hard drives coming loose during transport.
3) You may not be able to tuck the motherboard power cable if the power connector is at the top of the board unless you have a really long power cable.

I fell in love with the [[ASIN:B0016L3FDG NZXT Tempest]] case but didn't like the way their skinny drive rails came loose so easily. Had I known of the above gripes I probably would have picked it again but I still recommend this case as long as you don't plan on moving it around frequently.

Edit 5/2011: Gripe #4 - The top level 200mm fan is already starting to wear out and make noise. I use a can of air on the insides at least once a month to keep the dust out so I'm disappointed I have to replace a $20 fan in just over a year.
I didn't like the product, the quality was not what I expected. I plan to return the product and buy something different.
output: I plans to send the item back.

Instances.input:
Not a bad remote for the price nowadays (Fall 2013).

Probably one of the better remotes with a keyboard on it (for now).

It uses radio-frequency for the wireless instead of InfraRed so you don't need the device to be line-of-sight with the USB receiver dongle that comes with it. (the dongle appears to the host device as if it were a USB keyboard and USB mouse)

The wireless signal is good, but you can't reprogram the buttons on the remote (e.g. some are hardcoded to only be left/right mouse clicks, which don't work as well as keyboard-presses in software like OpenELEC / XBMC media center; I had to modify the XBMC keymap.xml file a bit).

You're unable to disable the "air mouse" function (that moves the cursor on the screen based on how you wave the remote, like a Wii controller), so I just modified OpenELEC / XBMC to use a blank mouse cursor icon.

This remote disables whatever side is on the bottom when it's held, which is good, but it means that you have to hold the remote relatively flat in order to get it to work most of the time.

I own three of these and a number of other wireless keyboard remotes, this one is currently the best out there.
output: decent, somewhat finicky, but probably still the best out there for now

This Samsung SSD drive arrived as expected via Prime along with the connecting cable purchased separately. Ran Samsung's data migration program, which appeared to work fine. Opened up the case to my Dell XPS 15Z laptop (there's a great youtube video showing how this tricky step should be done with this particular laptop) and replaced the existing drive with the SSD and tried to boot up. Received \\"BOOTMGR is missing\\" message, so no go.  Checked Samsung website and found remedy in support Q&A. Needed to boot up with a WIN 7 system repair disc. I didn't have one, so had to put old drive back into the laptop, create the repair disc in Windows, put the new drive back in the laptop (with the repair disc in the disc drive) and try booting up again.  This time success. So, you might want to have the repair disc handy, and be prepared to use it. Dinged one star because of the installation wrinkle. SSD is working great, speeding boot up, program loads, file loads, and shutdown.
output: SSD is great; data transfer process had a wrinkle

The keyboard is nicely finished, with good documentation in the included manuals. The Synapse 2.0 software downloaded and updated without issue. A few days into the use of the keyboard, the backlighting went out when I was trying to adjust the brightness via the buttons. Shortly after, the "R" key stopped working. Using the advice of another Amazon customer who also bought a Deathstalker, I tried disconnecting/reconnecting the USB cable from my computer. The backlighting was restored; however, the "R" key was not. I have shipped the keyboard back to the vendor for a refund.

In general, I liked the feel of the keyboard. The chiclet (or MacBook) style keys take a bit of getting used to, especially if you're a traditional no-look typist like myself. I may try another Razer keyboard, possibly the Black Widow this time because of its mechanical keys. It received high marks from Maximum PC. This thumb drive is limited in a number of ways. First, the USB plug-in area has a very wide base just distal to the USB adapter portion of the product. This creates a problem when using the thumb drive and a laptop (such as a MacBook Pro) with any other USB peripheral. Essentially, it takes up two spots because of the width. Second, the drive is partitioned. In actuality, I think it is two separate flash drives stored inside the device because there is no way to format and merge the separate 32 GB portions of the drive. Finally, the biggest problem is the slow data transfer rates. It makes transferring large files very painful. It's not necessary to purchase a really high end drive to get decent data transfer rates. I've used the Kingston Data Traveler, the SanDisk Cruiser, and the Corsair Flash Voyager with much better results. In summary, I would consider purchasing multiple 16 or 32 GB drives from the aforementioned companies over this drive with its many limitations.

In concept the Room Link is a brilliant idea. However, after hours of figuring out how to integrate this with the home network the benefit is disappointing! Sony products are indeed of Rolls-Royce quality however Sony manages to build in enough restrictions to result in Yugo functionality! The Room Link allows you to stream pictures from your PC/Laptop to TV only after you convert them into a useless Sony format and register them with media server. Effectively you use up twice as much space for the same pictures! You can only stream video you recorded with the Sony computer in Sony format!!! No possibility of streaming internet TV from PC/Laptop to TV, although that is lot les data than the Sony format!!! Music, as you might have guessed, has to be registered in Sony format! Yes, the Roon Link works but is so restrictive that it effectively NOT worth the money. It is that much more aggravating knowing that the technology unrestricted could be such much more!

I'll never buy a Sony product again.

This Haier Chromebook works great for my family as an additional laptop computer. The majority of time we spend on the computer is online, mainly social networking. This small and lightweight Chromebook is perfect for that. Some people will say why bother with a Chromebook when they can do networking from their cell phone. That is true, but some of us prefer a larger screen. In addition to web browsing, the Chromebook works great for one person watching online programming (e.g. Netflix or Amazon). In addition, it is good for listening to online music (e.g. Pandora or Amazon Prime). Other plusses of the Chromebook are that it powers up quickly, has a good battery life (10 hours), auto-updates (including virus protection) are built-in, and probably most importantly, it is very reasonably priced. In addition, it has two internal speakers, camera with microphone, HDMI port, 2 USB ports, micro SD card reader, audio jack (headphone-out and microphone-in), and a Kensington lock slot (should you wish to lock your computer). While it has limited storage on the laptop itself (16 GB), additional storage is on Google Drive (cloud).

A few negatives … The Haier Chromebook cannot run some of the programs we use, such as iTunes or software applications requiring a CD-rom. While its small size is often a benefit, we prefer viewing some things (such as spreadsheets and certain videogames) on our larger desktop monitor. The Chromebook keyboard has a different “feel” to it and it doesn’t have a mouse, so using the Chromebook takes some getting used to. Also, because the description stated, “Microsoft Office is not compatible, but Microsoft Web Apps are compatible,” I was concerned that certain email attachments may not be readable. I experimented by emailing Word and Excel documents from my Microsoft Outlook email to my gmail. Viewing (and editing) was NOT a problem; as it turns out, Chromebook automatically updates to allow viewing/editing of Office files. However, it is a downside that Microsoft Office itself does not work, as it is so widely used.

Despite its drawbacks, we are impressed with the Haier Chromebook as an additional laptop computer for the money. In fact, we are considering getting another. Would recommend, but be aware of its limitations.wever, it is a downside that Microsoft Office itself does not work, as it is so widely used.

Despite its drawbacks, we are impressed with the Haier Chromebook as an additional laptop computer for the money. In fact, we are considering getting another. Would recommend, but be aware of its limitations.

Instances.input:
I bought my Kuzy Hard Case in the color black a few months ago for my 13 inch Mac Book Pro. I often wait a few weeks to months before writing reviews of tech based products, especially cases, because it is important to see how they hold up in atleast the long term.

With that said, I am happy to announce that Kuzy has delivered on a wonderful product. For just 25 dollars, you are getting reliable protection, a sleek look, and very minimal weight. I bought mine in black, and I would highly recommend this color as the illuminated Apple symbol shines through the black case, giving it an awesome, modern look. The case itself fits very well and has no wiggle room. The firm fit hugs the Mac very well, looking as organically as part of the device as possible, adding to the style of the case.

Make no mistake about it, this case is indeed plastic but don’t let that turn you away from it. I was initially hesitant upon purchasing this case as plastic is known to have many problems including easy cracking, and a poor look but I have not encountered any problems with my case. This case has definitely protected my Mac because I can see visible scratches and marks on the case, where without the case itself, my Mac would have been damaged.

My only few gripes with this case deal with the installation and overall durability. When first putting on this case, it can be difficult because there are no instructions and you just kind of have to figure it out. You have to snap on this case, which comes in 2 separate pieces, one for the back of the screen and one for under the keyboard. Various times through the process, I was applying a lot of pressure and power and felt like I would either break the case or the case wasn’t locking into my device properly. You also don’t hear any snapping noises as pieces lock into the Mac, which only makes me wonder more of I installed it properly. But after a bit poking and prodding, it is easy to figure out thatthe case has been attached firmly.

Another large issue is that there are 4 rubbery pads at the bottom of the case, which help it remain stationary as you put your Mac on a table and type away. Unfortunately, my rubber pads fell off within weeks of getting my case! Because they are off, my Mac noticeably slides around easily with the case on. It’s not a huge deal but it is upsetting as the occasional wiggling and furious typing can move around the Mac easily.

If you have 25 dollars and are looking to purchase a solid, and reliable Macbook Pro case, I would highly recommend this Kuzy Rubberized Hard Case. For 25 dollars, it is a very sleek, lightweight, protective, and snug-fitting case that will definitely last for years to come, I’m sure.

Excellent quality.  Perfectly suited for my Acer tablet.  Openings built in for camera and speakers. Highly recommend.  Adjustable tilt.  Looks great.

I recently re-located my router in my house, causing some rooms in my house to lose wifi connectivity. After a little research, I found this wifi range extender.

In all honesty, I was pretty skeptical about purchasing it - especially since I saw some reviews indicating that it had caused a dramatic slow-down in network speed. Since I often work from home through a VPN connection, I was concerned that the reduced bandwidth would make it difficult to work from home. However, I figured that it was worth a shot to try to restore the wifi connectivity throughout our entire house.

I followed the very simple instructions to set up the device, and had it working within 10 minutes. It works exactly as advertised, and I haven't had a single problem with it. Also, I haven't noticed any change in bandwidth. I use this device with our Apple Airport router.

In summary, if you have wifi dead spots in your house, I'd highly recommend this range extender - it was cheap, easy to set up, and has worked flawlessly.

With this tablet, you have to follow the cursor on screen, and it is very disorienting. I think it is a good tablet for beginners, but overall, the one at work is a much better model and much easier to use. I will come back and tell you what the other tablet at work's brand/model is once I get back on Monday.

Instances.input: First, this is a Belkin FSU407-CU, not a FSU409V1 as stated in the tech specs.  Amazon should correct this.  Anyway, when I received the adapter, I tried to install it on my new Win 7 64 bit laptop and the driver supplied did not work.  I researched the web and kept getting responses that said there were no Win 7 32 or 64 bit drivers for this adapter, not even Vista drivers.  More research however turned up this website - [...]  Copy and paste this into your browser and you will find a link to a downloadable driver from the Magic Control Technologies site.  Download and install their U232-P9 driver package and after restarting your computer the darned thing will finally recognize the adapter and configure a driver for it!  Haven't used the adapter yet but I'll bet it works fine.
output: Belkin FSU409-CU does work with Windows 7!

Instances.input: This is an amazing computer. It's even smaller than the specs say. It says it weighs 5.4lbs, but it actually weighs 4.6! Lighter than most textbooks. Completely full featured, lacking in nothing, this is THE computer to have if you need portability but don't want to sacrifice features. It's super speedy and even includes a 24x cd burner (or a DVD burner if you pop for it). True portability in an affordable package. The most affordable powerbook ever. It's solidly constructed, sounds great and it's sexy as hell. Get one, you know you want it!

I got one of these at work a few months ago (I'm a full-time programmer). I like it a lot. It has good action, is quiet, has standard placement for the cursor control keys between the numeric keypad and the regular keys (2 rows of 3, not 3 rows of 2 like many others).

I didn't install the drivers from the CD, but many of the functions still work (XP pro), like volume, mute, email, browser. I don't use them that much, but now that I'm buying one for home, maybe I'll get more used to them.

I like the fact that there aren't a zillion buttons to choose from like some others, so you don't get overwhelmed and don't have to look for what you want.

I really don't think you can beat it for the price (usually under $15).

The only bad thing is that when you reboot, you need to press a button to enable the standard function keys at the top (there's a light that tells you when it's enabled). I often forget, but the first time it doesn't work, I remember. I don't really use them that much anyway - mainly just F5 for refresh.

Instances.input:
The current line of DELL XPS 15 laptops have a serious design flaw: overheating systems die from heat overload... And the warranty starts from some date prior to the purchase on Amazon.

The slim design does not permit enough airflow with the vertical facing fan allowing the system to run very hot. I consistently noted my Dell xps15 was a furnace but I mistakenly assumed the designers had accommodated for this concern. I was absolutely wrong. Not only do I have an expensive paperweight, when I contacted Dell xps customer service I learned my warranty barely had any time left though it's a brand new laptop. I wish I had known of these issues before plunking down 4 digits on a laptop with such serious issues. Please learn from my costly mistake, ensure you have an automatic backup solution for your files, buy a backup laptop to use when the Dell xps15 is in for repairs and only use with a very powerful laptop cooling system. Or save yourself the hassle and buy a laptop from a different manufacturer.

My Dell xps15 has been out of commission long enough at a critical time so I had to buy another laptop to use, an Acer with an i5 processor. In a few short days the temperature difference has been absolutely remarkable. I'm no longer sweating when using the Acer,... Yes, I was literally sweating and turning the ac colder when I used my Dell xps15 laptop.

Meanwhile, waiting for the empty shipping box from Dell ('overnighted' arrived 3 days later) I realized, by the time Dell repairs my xps15 and returns it, my laptop will essentially be out of warranty. When this happens again, which assuredly it will due to the unresolved heat issue, the repairs will be too costly to deal with, particularly since this will be an ongoing problem. The only long-term solution is a complete redesign of the Dell xps15 line. And a full refund. Which I don't see happening.

Buyer's remorse.
output: No optical drive,  bad design causes overheating - only use with a cooling pad! Or avoid!

Instances.input: A great way to trick my Microsoft coworkers.  Not really my intention, but it is funny how they all compliment my sticker on my MAC and then giggle when they see it is on my MAC.
So far so good!
There isn't really much to say about this headset except that it's simple and functional.  I prefer headsets that don't have the overhead band, and have a rather large head... these work well.

Now a days we don't seem to be using CD's or DVD's much any more. I remember when they first came out and changed everything. Now with the smartphones and tablets out there...CD's and DVD's are fast becoming a thing of the past. I can't even recall the last time I used a CD or DVD. I have all my music and movies on my computer and simply need to hook my smartphone up to my computer to transfer what I want onto it. I used to have a laptop but had to sell it a couple years ago. I began thinking about getting another but...I had to look at how I use technology now. I came to the conclution that I don't need a DVD drive which ended up nixing me needing a full on laptop. That said...I still liked the idea of the laptop style (keyboard and mouse pad). I didn't need anything super big...but having a tablet with perhaps a keyboard dock would fit my needs.

After awhile o searching...I found the Lenovo IdeaPad S2110. WIth it's keyboard dock it not only gave the tablet the look of a laptop...but it even went a step further and included a full SD Card reader and two standard USB ports in the keyboard. I was floored. I have an external USB drive hooked up to my computer which stores my movies. A simple way to move them onto the tablet is to either plug my external harddrive into the tablet keyboard or via a thumbdrive. Bingo...just like a laptop. The keyboard also includes the mouse pad...which by the way I've had no issues with unlike some of the posts on here. Some reviews I've read stated the mouse moves to fast. My opion...it's BS. As long as you don't race your finger across the pad the mouse moves across the screen just as any other mouse would on a regular laptop. And...there is an option in Settings to adjust the speed of the mouse. The keyboard is awesome and feels great to type on....not cheap. The buttons have great feedback...and the best part about the keyboard is it's internal battery. The fact that when fully charged...it deliverspower to the tablet is beyond awesome. I can go an entire day plus (depending on how much I use it within a day) on a single charge thanks to the keyboard. As the tablet's battery starts to deplete...the keyboard provides it with power thus...the keyboard's battery is the first to drain...then once it's depleted the tablet's battery kicks in and starts to drain. Awesome feature.

The tablet itself is two thumbs up. Awesome screen with nearly any viewing angle. Crystal clear. The processor is fast and keeps up with most games...so far any game I've downloaded. With it being Android of course...I've been able to set it up like a laptop. The additional bluetooth keyboard and mouse I purchased work great with this devise and in fact I've typed this whole post using the bluetooth keyboard. My only "sigh" was that the tablet itself doesn't have a micro-sd card slot. Since I'm using this more or less like a laptop however and will hardly ever have it out of the keyboard dock...the fact that the keyboard has a full size SD card reader meant I was able to place my 32 gig card there which serves as a "harddrive" if you will. An extra 32 gigs on top of the internal 16 gigs in the tablet. It was an acceptable give and take for me seeing how I'm using this tablet...but it might not be so much for other users who'd prefer the tablet have the SD slot.

Still over all...I would recomend this tablet/keyboard setup to anyone. It's solid...has some weight to it...and is super clean. I dare you to try it if you're looking for a tablet with a laptop feel. It's about the same size as a netbook...but should you want to use it as a tablet you can...that's the whole point about these hybrids. Once you get it...you wont want to return it...

I have had quite a few routers in my time and have never been a fan of Belkin. The one I had previously was very hard to set up and it took a lot of work just to put in a WPA2 security code. So of course, I was a little bit weary when getting this.

Prior to the Belkin N150, I was using a Netgear router that would constantly interrupt my PS3 streaming capabilities. It was also slow and I was just ready to be done with that one.

Now, for the setup of the N150, this is the first router I've remember owning that I had to install the Belkin software just for the router to work. Most routers just requires you to plug in the cables and it would start working. I found that a big no no as I want it to work right out of the box and not have to install anything extra on my computer. The configuration of the security was easy enough and I would suggest that once you install the software and the Belkin is working, you should uninstall it. The software itself is not really good and it cannot figure out that one of my desktops I connect directly to the internet via an ethernet cable and it keeps trying to turn the wireless card on my desktop on. You can still get to the page to configure the router's settings by going to 192.168.2.1.

As for the connection of the router, I did find that it was a lot better than the Netgear in that when I am watching a moving on my PS3 that is streamed from my computer, it does not cut out as much as the Netgear. With the Netgear, I was usually guaranteed to have a hiccup with each movie/show that I watched.

It was very easy for the router to be connected wirelessly and for the most part, it would keep the connection. Still, while it has been an improvement from an older Belkin I had, there are still some stability issues to be addressed and the set up was a bit tedious.

Still, this is a decent start-up router. If you are someone who has a lot of experience with routers though, you may not be impressed.
output: Slightly better than previous Belkin router I've had but setup is annoying

Instances.input:
I have had several netbooks, and this is slick little machine. Compared to the Atom, the CPU on this is really snappy. The relatively larger screen and full keyboard make this computer comfortable to use. It's nice and light and fits easily in my back pack. I don't mind the weight of it on my back on my bicycle on the way to the train. It's more of a small laptop than a netbook. I'm quite fine without a built in CD/DVD; I'd prefer not to have the extra weight and bulk, but I do have the Lite On Etau208 [...]

Amazingly this inexpensive little computer has not just a dual core processor, but three USB ports, an HDMI, a VGA Port, a LAN port, built in wireless, and an SDHC reader. It weight just two ounces more than my 9 inch netbook and is thinner. It also has a keyboard with the keys in the \\"right\\" place; a full sized \\"enter\\" key and full sized right \\"shift\\" key. The touch pad is multi touch, and even has two separate buttons for the left and right click instead of the cheap single rocker you find on many netbooks. The speakers are loud enough to comfortable listen to the dialog from a movie or TV show.

The snappy performance coupled with Windows 7 gives the whole experience of using this computer a very smooth feel that is very pleasant.

The only thing I'd change is that I bought the 1810TZ model and the 1810T model is only $50 more for a larger hard drive and 1GBmore of RAM. I thought this one came with 32 bit Windows 7 which I thought I needed to run a finicky program that I have. Ironically this computer actually came with 64 bit windows 7 and my finicky program, which has never run right on 64 bit Vista, runs fine on this. However, I am very pleased with the performance of this unit as it is. I do sort of want the forthcoming but not yet released tablet version but that on will weigh 5oz more and I'm not sure I'm willing to accept the extra weight.

There were only 3 SATA power plugs on my PSU. Looked around locally and then tried Amazon. Exactly what I needed and half the price at the only store in town that stocks them. I do not live in a large city, only around 100,000 and zero tech industry. Really big city about 50 miles away...never go there. As usual though, Amazon saved the day and, get this, it was a 'free shipping' item (main reason I bought it ;-)  ).

I have had two of these, the first one broke and they replaced it but not the second one has broken the same way. The cord plugs into my laptop very close to the heat vent and when I use my laptop to game it gets very hot, this softens the rubber and the connection inside the plug shorts out. Also the box part of the cord gets very hot when used and the cord started pulling out. I could forsee no problems with this cord if you lived in the Artic and only used it outside but if you live some wear not freezing you will have trouble with the cord overheating.

Then about a week later the microphone stops working entirely, and the headphones themselves are too tight and hurt my ears after about an hour of wearing them, the adjustments don't help much.

I bought this for all the reasons you are looking at it. Fast, whole house coverage, etc. After about 3 months of having it, 2 long phone calls with tech support, I have disconnected it and bought a Netgear N900 router. Actually, in the end it just completely shut off -- it won't power on and acts as if the power supply is dead. It is piled up at my feet as I write this and I scowl at it in disgust. Phooey.

It dropped my connection constantly on the 2.4G band, so I had to point everything to the 5G band. My iPhone and iPad could not connect to that band as they are limited to 2.4G. Tech Support throttled down the package size in order to improve the connection to the 2.4G band, but this is the kind of router that generated tons of phone calls to me from my wife and kids asking "why is the internet down?" It is 2013, that should never happen, and now I've had to spend more money to downgrade. (I have used an N600 successfully for years but I want to N900 to get gigabit ethernet for my TV.)

Buyer beware, I say wait for the next version to come out.
output: So much potential, so poorly executed

Instances.input: These plugs are poorly designed.  They do not fit well into the ports they were supposedly designed to fit into. What they need to do is to put slots into the side of the plugs that fit into their respective ports.  As it is, the USB port covers don't fit over the USB "tongue" (usually blue for USB 3.0 ports and white or black for USB 2.0 ports).  the same is true for the eSATA port cover (although they do have an attempt at a slot molded into the port side of the plug, it's just not deep enough and cutting it deeper with an exacto would be pretty tough.)  A bad design on a really basic low tech solution,  I'm not sure if other manufacturers have done the same thing or not.  Until I can find out I'm back to using tape. Ugh!
output: Bad design on a really basic low tech solution.

From the moment I took it out of the box is felt flimsy.  It's hard to describe well, but it just doesn't have the look or feel of a well-built mouse.    My experience using it has also been disappointing.  The button clicks are very stiff.  I frequently find the mouse scooting away from the target while I'm trying to click.  The surface for performing the gestures isn't smooth enough and the mouse is arched so highly that your fingers quickly tire from having to lift them to perform the gestures.  Because of the perceived flimsiness, the mouse lacks a well-controlled, solid feel as it slides across a surface.  The combination of this poor control and the tendency to scoot when pushing buttons makes me use the arrow keys and keyboard shortcuts rather than the mouse when editing text.  Getting the cursor to the right spot or getting the right-click to occur in the right location can be just too stressful.    It performs poorly on non-standard surfaces where other mice still perform well enough.  The arm rest of my chair is far from an ideal surface, but where as cheap mice track well enough and allow for clicking, this mouse fails to track at all or tracks far too quickly as if it's unable to make up its mind.  The button clicks are so stiff that they are nearly impossible to perform on the soft surface of my arm rest.    While it has a wide array of available gestures, they aren't for any activities that I frequently perform.  In my week and a half of owning the mouse, I haven't used any of them for window management.    Considering the price and the hype, I find this mouse very disappointing.
I am still getting used to it with the help of my grandchildren.

Instances.input:
I started using Logitech trackballs several years ago and have never been disappointed with them - in fact, I find it hard to use computers that have traditional mice! Recently, my TrackMan Marble gave out, and I replaced it with the TrackMan Marble Wheel. I found it to be a quality product as well.
Having used a TrackMan before, my thumb already was conditioned for use, but I still had to adjust the mouse settings in the Control Panel to make sure I could reach all parts of the screen. I have a little difficulty because I'm missing some muscles in my right hand, but I can still use the TrackMan well. I also appreciated the customizable buttons - the wheel doubles as a third button, which I use as a double-click button. There are many other options available, including the ability to switch the click and right-click buttons if you wish. I was disappointed to see that Logitech didn't make this a four-button mouse; I would have liked to see the three original buttons (from the TrackMan Marble design) remain and have the wheel/button be a fourth button. Also, I found the wheel to be a bit more difficult to use as a button - I tend to scroll as I click from time to time, which causes me to open things I didn't want to open.
The wheel is very valuable - I found that I missed it immediately when I went to a computer without one. The wheel makes scrolling much easier in applications, and you can set the scroll amount from the Control Panel as well, although you may have to find a compromise because you can't set the amount separately for separate applications.
The quality is excellent. You certainly won't have to clean it as often as traditional mice, although it still needs to be cleaned periodically (or more often, if you're into Diablo-type games). Cleaning is easy - just insert the tip of a pen into the little dot on the mouse, and with a turn, the retaining ring pops out and the ball can be cleaned.
You can use this in a USB port or as a PS/2 mouse; however, if you plug it into a USB port, understand that you may have difficulties if you have several USB devices or if you have an intensive device like a Zip drive connected. I've rarely experienced problems, but on occasion, if my Zip drive struggles, it locks up the mouse as well. This is more of a USB issue than a Logitech issue, though, as you can tell from reading the Iomega Zip reviews! Just keep it in mind.
I've never felt bad after buying a Logitech mouse, and this was no exception. The only suggestion I'd make to Logitech is to design a left-handed TrackMan Marble. I like to divide my home and work usage equally, especially when a Diablo II or Icewind Dale is released, and you can't get one of these for a lefty. Other than that, I give it high marks and would definitely recommend it.e; however, if you plug it into a USB port, understand that you may have difficulties if you have several USB devices or if you have an intensive device like a Zip drive connected. I've rarely experienced problems, but on occasion, if my Zip drive struggles, it locks up the mouse as well. This is more of a USB issue than a Logitech issue, though, as you can tell from reading the Iomega Zip reviews! Just keep it in mind.
I've never felt bad after buying a Logitech mouse, and this was no exception. The only suggestion I'd make to Logitech is to design a left-handed TrackMan Marble. I like to divide my home and work usage equally, especially when a Diablo II or Icewind Dale is released, and you can't get one of these for a lefty. Other than that, I give it high marks and would definitely recommend it.
output: Very nice trackball, but for righties only

Instances.input: First off, if you're considering just getting a pouch-like cover that doesn't open like a book, don't. The ability to hold the Kindle like a book is possibly the best reason for getting a cover. You really can't go wrong with the Amazon leather cover, and if you think it's expensive you should browse around a bit; most of the higher quality covers are in this price range, with some being even pricier. I don't believe this is a situation where an \\"official\\" branded accessory is being overpriced, as is often the case with such products.    Pros:   -Sturdy materials. The hard leather, stitching and lining appear to be solidly crafted. This case will long outlast the Kindle itself.  -Strap. So far as I can tell, the strap is unique to the Amazon case, and it's most excellent. Far better than button/belt style closing mechanisms I've seen in other covers.      Cons: The top hinge allows for some lateral play, meaning that the unit moves ever so slightly away from the hinge, whereas the bottom hinge is flush against the Kindle. This causes the kindle to be slightly crooked, with the top of the unit sliding away from the hinge a tad further away from the spine of the cover. It's a mild flaw that should have been taken care of while in the engineering stage, but it doesn't seem to affect the security of the connection. It also could be that this is an issue unique to my case, and if so, maybe someone could comment in that regard.     Possible improvements: I understand how the hard leather would be very durable and resist wear, but I think a slightly softer, cushier (even thinly padded) leather could have been utilized while maintaining durability. It would make the case a little more pleasant to hold, as the rigid leather can be a bit hard on the fingers, and a softer cover would provide a bit more impact resistance. And let's be honest: most people aren't going to keep their Kindle for nearly as long as even a soft leather case would last. We've had three Kindle models inas many years, with each requiring a new size cover. We don't need a cover that optimizes its materials to last a hundred years at the compromise of comfort.    Advantages of other cases: There is one aspect of some of the other cases that I liked-- some of them held the unit in place with sleeve-like attachment, formed with cutouts allowing access to keyboard and buttons. The reason I like this is because it does a bit to \\"hide\\" the device, other than the screen and buttons. This has an effect of making the Kindle a bit less obvious in its gadget-ness, covering the plastic (and the Amazon Kindle logo) with leather or what not.     Update, 12/12/2010:    I'm sad to say that I have become one of the unlucky bunch whose Kindle does not play nicely with the attachment hooks. The details of this issue can be read in a number of other reviews, so I won't go into details. I will say this: Many Kindles (maybe even most) work fine with this case. If you aren't one of the unlucky ones, you have an excellent cover. Most people would not suspect the case at the onset of problems, so I think the best advice here if you are really intent on purchasing this cover, or have recently done so, is to contact customer service at the first sign of freezing/rebooting.     Amazon Customer Service has been so exceptional throughout the ordeal that they still have my trust as a customer. Mistakes happen. Electronic devices are not impervious to unforeseen problems. How the company handles those problems is more important, and hopefully Amazon will make good on resolving the issue for those who experienced it.
output: Good cover, for the most part. EDITED with update.

Instances.input: I've just received and applied the protector. I _love_ it.   It seems to be of good quality, is practically \\"invisible\\", and leaving \\"fingerprints\\" all over the screen is much tougher now.  As for the application, couldn't be easier. The protector comes with two plastic maskings to be removed. You are supposed to remove the one with the red label to \\"stick\\" it to your iPad screen and then, when the protector is on, you have to remove the one with the black label.     Here's the method I used in order to place flawlessly the protector, without a single (not even a microscopic one!) bubble -- but do not use if you don't feel confident with it, or else you might actually get many more than following the instructions:  - After perfectly cleaning your screen (and making sure any curious pet is nowhere near!), pull the red label to reveal a horizontal strip of the sticky protector (toward the button, where you have the big circle cut). Place very carefully over the iPad, aligning it neatly.   - Then, holding the rest of the protector in a kinda diagonal way, peel completely the mask and let fall gracefully over the iPad. It will stick to it just perfectly. Remove any bubbles with card.   - Then remove black label mask. (If it seems like there's a bubble, it will most probably be because of this one.)

This feels a little clanky switching between the two, but once you are in a certain mode the mouse goes back to feeling very stable and sturdy.

It does still have a middle click, it's just the small button below the scroll wheel. This took a little while to get used to as well, but once you do it's like nothing ever changed. Overall a fantastic mouse, very compact, great feel in my hand, long battery life, great signal, and for the price nothing can beat it.

This mouse is fantastic. The features are second to none.   Adjusting the mouse speed is extremely simple and very useful; the adjustment points are customizable so they can be fine tuned.   The scroll wheel can be set for super fast scrolling or precise increments, works great if you need to swap weapons or get through a large inventory screen.  I haven't messed with the 3 side buttons much at this point, but they are well placed and easily clickable without fatfingering them all at the same time.  Ergonomically the g500 is good but takes a bit of getting used to, it slopes off severely which took my wrist a little while to get comfortable with.  The fact that this is a corded mouse had me a little apprehensive at first but I've actually come to appreciate it. The cord has never gotten in my way and its nice not to have to worry about batteries and mouse wake-up time.  The adjustable weight seems like a bit of a gimmick to me as I can't really observe a noticeable difference when playing between any given weight settings.  Overall, it's a great mouse and I'd suggest it to anyone looking for a real performance gaming mouse.

After cloning, I returned the boot order to it original order.    By the way, the Apricorn Univeral hard drive upgrade kit works with both SATA and PATA drives.

This is pretty much just what they say it is. It works just like the original Apple cable, and it is Apple certified.

I have a few of these cables. The ones that came with my phone and iPad aren't enough. I have one in my car, so I can plug in my phone and listen through my stereo; I have one in my office so I can charge up the phone or iPad there. I have one at home, and I have another in my bag for when I need to charge on the go. This one works well. It is, as another reviewer noted, slightly fatter than the original on the USB plug and the lightning connector, but it's not so big that it gets in the way of other things being plugged in.

(Note: I was given a sample of the product from the manufacturer for the purpose of testing and review, and since I can never have enough of these cables I agreed. Instances.input: This bag has two significant problems that really should be addressed.  Firstly, the padding is insufficient in the bottom corners.  There is enough padding at the bottom and sides, but almost no padding at the corners, which are the most vulnerable points on your laptop.  Secondly, the shoulder strap attaches to the bag with two plastic clips, and they can let go when least expected, especially when the strap was a little twisted before picking it up.  This has happened to me on multiple occasions.  The combination of these two problems has led to my laptop suffering corner damage from falling onto pavement when I picked up my bag by the strap, and it decided to let go.  If you have a nice laptop, this is an accident waiting to happen.
output: Beware of unpadded bottom corners and releasing strap clips

I ordered this product December 21, 2012 with 2-Day shipping in order to recieve it by Christmas as it was a gift for my girlfriend. Amazon ended up canceling my order without telling me and I didn't find out until I checked the shipping status on Dec. 23. After almost 2 hours on the phone and speaking to three levels of customer service managers, Amazon re-ordered my product, gave me a discount and promised it would be delivered by Dec 26. After Christmas had gone by I was informed that it wouldn't be delivered until the 27th. I again had to spend an hour on the phone to have the package rerouted since I was only visiting my family for Christmas and would be returning home the 27th. Amazon offered me a $30 amazon credit which I accepted but only was granted $10. We FINALLY got the laptop at home on the 27th and upon opening it, the laptop was inoperable, the LCD was non functioning. We immediately called Amazon and Dell and they said it could be fixed by a dell technician within 24-48 hours. As you can probably guess, this also didn't happen! After many phone calls and emails, we finally got the laptop fixed January 4, 2013. The laptop works fine and my girlfriend is happy but this was am experience I will never forget, I know this isn't the norm but it seems like everything that could go wrong did, and Amazon seemed to believe it was no fault of their own!

Bottom line: Good laptop especially for a student, good battery life, but go ahead and buy it at Best Buy so you don't have to wait, or deal with nonfunctional laptops!
output: Laptop came damaged, awful customer service, laptop is good, once fixed

It is accuracy and reliability of capturing the hand writing where it falls down in a big way. It is inconsistent in providing continuous capturing of hand writing and even starting to capture. I thought the fine tip would make it more accurate between touch point on the screen and capture, not so. I really wanted this device to work. Would have been nice to have the small light on the stylus change color or flash when the battery was low. Instead you get a staccato writing capture leading you to believe the pen is malfunctioning, a frequent feeling. All-in-all, a very big disappointment. Save your self $70 and buy a $10 stylus.

I bought this recently to replace a Fragmat mouse pad which I had used for about 6 years. The Razer Sphex is an incredible mouse mat. I've never used a "mouse surface" before, but I can tell you with all honesty that the transition from a standard mouse pad was seamless and indeed, a game changer. My mouse tracks effortlessly over the smooth, paper-thin surface. I have it affixed to my wooden desk and the grip is extremely strong- it hasn't moved one bit from the spot I placed it in. It seems durable and easy to clean, but I would still be careful not to spill anything on it or get to rough with it. To top it all off, it looks great in dark black with a couple Razer logos (and looks quite cool paired with my Razer Tarantula Keyboard).

This is a solid buy for this price range. I anticipate getting many years of use out of the Sphex.

One thing to note, I use a wireless G700s Logitech mouse laser mouse. Your mileage may vary with using an optical or trackball as the Razer Sphex was optimized for high DPI mice.

Original 2015 Review Here. See Update section below.   So far works well. Speed seems good Wan and LAN.  There is no separation between automatic WAN settings with DHCP and full manual IP settings. You can't use DHCP and also use a custom DNS server. However contrary to some of the other reviews you can go full manual and use a custom DNS server.  The options are pretty vanilla, not much that's highly customization. You can run more than one wireless access point at the same time. Here the options are limited too. One regular network and a guest network. I haven't tried it though.  Work on Charter networks.  Update Edit............... 4/8/2016   The real reason that I wanted this was for a little more control than what I would get from Charter. Every time I want to do any moderately sophisticated setting like open a port up on the firewall I get no decent options. Or what is provided doesn't work. I'm talking about you port filtering.  Has changing your DNS settings while using DHCP and port management not been around since the beginning of home routers? My TiVo will not work with the firewall on. VPN also fails. And there is weak firewall options.  I'm going to have to run my own firewall on an extra device. The whole point of me getting this was to have less devices to avoid more fail points.  Attached is the only Firewall options you get. Miserable. Do not buy. Too much money for what you get.
Still learning to use it. Not very tech savvy. Lots of fun and very convenient.

Excellent product. Very tiny, not as tiny as the EEE 7 models, but still small enough to easily slip into a backpack. Very light, easy to hold in one hand.    The keyboard is not as small as you would expect, when they say it is 92% of a normal keyboard, they mean it, it is only about 2 inches smaller than my desktop keyboard. The one drawback would be the right shift key, way too small and oddly spaced to be useful. Took a while to learn to use the left shift instead. Also, there is no keyboard flex as others have written, maybe they got older models.    The screen is nice and bright. Battery life is amazing, on power saving mode, with the screen just turned down slightly, wi-fi and bluetooth on, I get around 4, maybe 5 hours of battery life. 3.5 of constant use. The PC boots up in under a minute with what I have installed on it, and it has no problems since I've gotten it. It's also so quiet I can't even tell if there's a fan inside this. Doesn't get too hot either, very warm, but not lap-burning hot like many laptops do.    The speakers are what you would expect out of a laptop. The microphone and camera are good/above average quality and work well with skype.    Bluetooth connects well with no problems to my Moto Q phone, and my bluetooth headphone/headset.    Buttons on trackpad are a bit firm for my liking, trackpad is responsive, multitouch scrolling works well, but sometimes it hiccups and registers it as a \\"click\\". Also because of it's small size, it's easy to accidentally click on something when typing.    As for  the black finish, I like it, I don't get too many fingerprints on it, it does come with a cleaning cloth as well. A quick wipe every morning should solve anyone's problems. It also comes with a black carrying pouch/case.     I would also recommend getting the Logitech MX Revolution Nano. The small size of the mouse compliments the laptop nicely, and the nano reciever doesn't get in the way of using the  laptop pouch.    For most people, 1GB of memory(stock) should be plenty, programs load fast enough. But for users who open more than 3-4 programs at once, or even browse with more than 5 or so tabs open should consider upgrading to  2GB (DDR2-SDRAM 533/667, 200-pin). So far opening many tabs in Firefox and opening 3 programs at once cause the system to slow down for me.
