Instances.input:
Dual bands, good antennas, USB and easy setup, this is all that I need around the house.

Actually, I don't even need the dual band where I have this setup today, with so few wireless signals in the area. But it will no doubt be moved into an area that will and that's why I purchased this.

Antennas can be the biggest part of your wireless strength, so having good ones like this is a start. But if you still have signal strength or download speed issues, connect an external with antennas like this to your device. I have a couple of the inexpensive models from Etekcity and I can get full speed from 70 feet with 4 walls in between or a half a mile. My point is that the laptop or your devices antennas are the problem, not the router.

By connecting a USB external drive, now you can access those files from anywhere on your network. This is great for music and other files to be shared. You don't need to choose an expensive model either, because it's USB 2 and one of mine is an old laptop drive in a $12 case and 750GB is plenty even doing backups once a week.

Routers can be very easy to configure unless you've never done it before and this one holds no surprises. Find yourself additional web info if needed and TP-Link has pretty good CS from what I remember the one time that I called about another product.

A free download of Office Inssider can be helpful to find your cleanest wireless channels if you'd like.

I like to wall mount mine and having it up will help the signal too.

This is my 3rd model of TP-Link routers and I haven't had a bad one yet.

WIN7 Pro boot time is under 15 seconds.  Stitching 4 image panoramics in Photoshop takes place within a minute whereas before it would take up 5 minutes.  These are 25meg files from a D600.  Sometimes my photo files can exceed 150megs with adjustments and being saved as TIFFs.  One SSD is my boot and program drive and the other is my camera download and Work-in-Process drive. I wiped the 2 HDDs and re-tasked them to be external storage for my files in a Rosewill 2-bay enclousure.  So far could not be happier.

I'm really pleased with this battery charger. I needed a replacement battery charger for my Panasonic camera ASAP and bought one of these despite reading the previous reviewer's comments about the product being \\"cheap\\" and \\"flimsy\\" as it was available at an office supplies store near my home. It is lightweight but I never felt the product would break in my hand. It is of unusual design though as one must move the contacts to fit the battery you are using and if you aren't gentle, you could break one of these off, however, I see this as a bonus of the design-- no extra parts needed to fit different batteries! The spring-loaded cover holds the battery tightly in place and there is a small LCD screen that shows whether the battery is charging, if it's fully charged, or if the battery isn't in touch with the contacts. I love the car adapter as I didn't have one for my previous Panasonic charger.   I'm so pleased with this charger that I'm planning to buy a second one, just in case I lose this one too.

After all is said and done... I'll give this gizmo 5 stars for the leg application & it's clever design, but I encourage the company to improve some things.  I was hoping to use it to mount my tablet on a gooseneck floor lamp that has a flat plastic light housing the same size and shape as that couch arm in their photo.  Well... it doesn't grip firmly.  On a couch as shown it is just sitting there with a bit of tension so it stays upright and in place... just don't bump it.  They also don't tell you about the rubber bands that go on the inside to keep tension. The tabs where the rubber bands attach bend inward and don't seem like they will hold up to the task of creating a firm tension around my lamp either.  The thing just wouldn't grip. I wish it was made of aluminum or something with rubber slots for the tablets.  That said... I LOVE THE LEG APPLICATION!  That alone is worth buying this mount for.  It works great. It also sits nicely on the counter.  I crochet so I was following my pattern & watching Netflix on my leg while sitting down but when I got up to do some things in the kitchen I just brought it with me & set it on the counter so I didn't miss a thing on my show. PERFECT!  Then I took it with me when I went to lie down in bed and put it on a pillow.  So for this reason I give it 5 stars with a possible 6 when they work the kinks out of the design.  I think thicker rubber bands, make it out of metal or plastic with more tension abilities, fix those tabs so they don't bend inward...  and this baby would be perfect. Another great thing about this product is its ability to have so many applications. I'm sure I'll find a lot of other uses for it as I go along. I'm about to go put a push pin on the inside of my kitchen cupboard to use this in the kitchen too. Happy with my purchase all in all.
output: Ingenious versatile design but could be better.

Alienware is just a name, but what's in a name?

I have rode the Alienware hate bus for a very long time ever since I was younger prior to the company being purchased by dell. My friends and I would always joke around about Alienware and how expensive their computers were. We would go on to their website and try and come up with outrageous specifications in the customization menus back when single cores were big and dual cores were just coming out.

I never thought I would one day finally purchase one for myself but it all started with one of the smaller units, the M11x R2 which I purchased from Ebay. I was so impressed by the versatility, reliability and performance of that model that my perspective of Alienware as a company was changed completely.

I wasn't completely sold however and was not sure how far Alienware would go with having been purchased by Dell. I did a lot of research before ultimately settling on this model. I was looking for a laptop that I could use while I traveled overseas as part of my deployment in the military and was looking for something with a bigger hard drive, more power and a larger screen.

There were quite a few brands to choose from, including models from MSI, Lenovo, and even Razers own "Razer Blade" Laptop. I wanted the best bang for the buck if I was purchasing a high end laptop and wanted the best specs with as much reliable performance it could give me. I did not plan to overclock or make any adjustments to timings or voltages and I still have not found the need to with this particular model.

It really is an amazing machine, both in consideration with it's performance and the aesthetics. The laptop looks fantastic and is not overly flashy. There are a ton of options regarding customization for the desktop and the Alienware FX which controls the interchangeable lights on the keyboard, fascia and touch pad of the laptop.

In addition to this it comes standard with multiple USB ports, one of which is consistently on so you can charge devices without keeping the laptop itself on. There is also a slot loading DVD-RW drive that gets rid of the worry of having the drive snap off or coming loose over time.

A killer network card provides all of the speed I need on my current internet connection with extremely low latency in video chat, video gaming, and amazing speeds for downloads and uploads. I have never seen a laptop cap speeds before but this thing blazes through any application I throw at it in consideration with bandwidth and ping.

Included with the model I purchased is a Quad Core-I7 4700MQ which has plenty of power and 8 threads for amazing multi tasking performance and keeps up with the most recent demanding games.

This unit also has a single Nvidia GeForce 765M with 2GB of onboard memory with a native resolution of 1980x1080 or 1080p which is perfect for any current titles and the Nvidia Control Panel allows me to set specific settings such as forced Anti-Aliasing, Texture Filtering, Vertical Sync, you name it, this GPU has it.

The hard drive has 1TB of space in total and includes a seperate 80GB SSD. The SSD acts as a sort of boost to the slower 5400rpm 1TB drive in that it caches frequently used data and applications so that you can access the information faster. I have not tinkered with settings regarding this and do not know if even doing so is possible but I have noticed significant improvements in load times after using the same programs multiple times over a few weeks span.

The 16GB ram included with this machine is absolute overkill and I can't imagine anything out right now aside from heavy CAD software or photoshop uses anywhere near that amount, I did not necessarily need this much ram but it is future proof and saves me from having to upgrade in the future. In addition to this there was no way to select a smaller portion of ram so I just took it for what it was. Definitely not complaining about this feature but I can find no real world use for it.

Another nice notable feature about this machine is the fact that the power supply plug is on the back right of the unit. I have seen some complaints about this but find that this is perfect for me. I do not have to worry about positioning the laptop a certain way when it is resting on my lap.

All in all I am glad I purchased this machine. It was expensive and is definitely more of a luxury item than anything else but I am very satisfied. I would have loved to spend money to build a tower that has considerably more performance, perhaps even twice that of this current machine but as I am not sure where my life will take me in the next coming years I can't afford to cart a whole computer tower around and have to worry about not bringing it with me.

In any case this is a fantastic machine, if you have the money to spend on it, read this review then make your decision. I hope what I wrote here helps reinforce the fact that Alienware is no longer a name, even having been purchased by Dell this is still a well known reputable company that provides a quality product especially if you are spending top dollar and know what you are getting.

This is a great high end laptop. It will treat you well as long as you take very good care of it, just like anything else in life. Duty calls on my end over here so I will end this review with one final statement:

I have owned many laptops for the short time I have been alive, I have built a few computers in my spare time since they were still using AGP cards and 256MB of ram and an 8GB Hard Drive was "massive space". This is the best computer I have ever purchased.

Thanks for readingt it was. Definitely not complaining about this feature but I can find no real world use for it.

I have an RCA cable modem with RCN as my ISP.  A great service which I highly recommend. I recently bought the Linksys G-Router after getting my hp laptop needing to setup wireless at home.  I got it to work with no problem but then I experienced bandwidth loss and constant connectivity issues.  I wrongly thought that it was the router.  Fool that I was! After countless attempts at recycling the modem and WPA keys etc., I finally figured out that the modem could not support the wireless router and it had a short, plus RCA no longer carried it and the thing was ugly, taking up space.  I've since gotten the Linksys Modem (BEFCMU10) and stacked it with the WRT54G router and it works fantastic!!!  Be sure to call your ISP with the modem's MAC address to get online.  YOU WON'T get connected otherwise. My ISP had me up and running within 5 minutes.  Also some ISP's give you a discount if you supply your own modem.  Check it out.
Easy to use. I'm completely happy with this purchase. A good product for a good price. No need to spend more money.

Best portable Windows machine ever!
Had the first generation Yoga for a year and loved it apart from initial WiFi problems (that were somehow addressed (possibly with a driver update)) and lack of backlit keyboard.

Personally I consider 13" to be the perfect portable form factor - large enough to do actual work (including writing code) but not too large to be a nuisance. Touchscreen is handy in all configurations. While the device is too large and heavy to be a real tablet, tablet mode still comes in handy sometimes.

Yoga 2 Pro fixed issues with the first gen device - WiFi works great, there is a backlit keyboard. On top of that you get 6 hour battery life (twice tested in long haul flights) and excellent almost 4K display. I really couldn't think of anything I would have liked to add to it.

I love this little guy! I use this mouse wherever I go, and it is combat tested! I have taken it to the field and used it with my Panasonic ToughBook during training in the desert and deployments. I use it most often while traveling and it is quite the little champ, even though it is tossed around in my bag accompanying me everywhere. It does not feel cheap either and I love the texture. A neat little compartment is built in to the mouse where the battery is stored where you are also able to store the receiver dongle (common mouse engineering with Logitech). The buttons are easy to use with a little bit of stiffness behind them, which I like. The third scroll button is very easy, every once in a while it is a little to easy to manipulate. While listening to music I find myself accidentally brushing the scroll wheel up and my music goes from quiet office level to party level within a second (this is not good while I am at work). However, the overall quality of this wireless infrared mouse is fantastic and I would highly recommend for all!

Im a windows user, web designer, i bought it because zooming and panning is most thing that wasts time while working in photoshop and other programs like After effects, i was excited that there is a solution for this problem, however when i received it, i was disappointment. because when i opened the box i found out that the toolDial software that comes with it, is for Mac only, and the Windows driver douse not come with it!! So i searched around and found the driver at the logitech site, after the installation, i was satisfied and happy, because i found out the the navigator can do much more than i expected, and can be configured to work with any program, because all the controls on it can be configured to trigger an action like a keyboard stroke or scroll the mouse wheel, for example in photoshop, i set the ring to zoom and pan the image, 2 buttons to go backward and forward through the history, one button for the brush, another for the eraser and touch tuner (the above layer on the controller reacts to by touch like the iPod) to increase or decrease the brush size. Its totally up to you to set it in any matter you need to any program, i even set up few configurations for several games!

I don't regret buying at all, however i think that the seller at amazon should declare more clearly that the tool dial is no longer available for windows, you can find more at logitech's site.

Very pleased with these headphones.  They are quite comfortable (it takes hours before you start to notice them) and the sound quality is quite good.  While the active noise cancellation is not as robust as you would probably get from a more expensive set of headphones, it still works rather well.  At times I am on my computer with people in the living room talking, a TV on and an extremely loud dryer directly behind me in the laundry room.  With regular headphones, it became almost impossible to hear anything.  With these, while the noise is still there if you choose to focus on it, it gets cancelled out quite a bit, allowing me to easily ignore it and focus on whatever I'm listening to.  They also work quite well on airplanes.  I also bought the optional headset add-on, which works fine.  The only negatives I would mention are that 1) the battery case doesn't rotate very far.  Sometimes this can result in the "lock" on the case being loose and the cover falling off; and 2) it would be nice if the basic connector (without the headset add-on) had a volume control disc or knob.

This is a great router but I had a hard time upgrading this to tomato USB even though I'm pretty experienced doing this sort of thing. I tried to follow Timothy Brown's instructions (see his Amazon customer review) which were very good but I think there are a few critical points that should be expanded on (like a more detailed description of the CFE page, the fact that the light on the router is off during CFE mode, and most importantly for me, unplugging the router from the modem when uploading the firmware to prevent an error about connection being reset/interrupted.).

How to Upgrade this to Tomato USB in Windows (Warning this may violate your warranty and all disclaimers apply - proceed at your own risk):

First download the correct files for this router - see Timothy Brown's instructions in his Amazon review of this product for the correct versions and download locations. But the ones I used were the following which were the latest as of the date of this review:

tomato-F7D3302-1.28.7501.3MIPSR2Toastman-RT-Mini.bin
tomato-K26USB-1.28.7501.3MIPSR2Toastman-RT-Ext.trx

Then:

1) Connect the ethernet cable from your computer to the first \\"Wired\\" port (not the \\"Modem\\" port)

2) Plug your ethernet cable from your modem to the \\"Modem\\" port

3) Plug the AC adapter in to the wall and router

4) Set the windows machine's static IP to 192.168.2.10, net mask 255.255.255.0, and default gateway and DNS to 192.168.2.1 If you don't know how to do this google it for your version of windows as it varies somewhat (in brief: network and sharing center->click on your network connection->properties->ip4 protocol->properties, fill out the screen).

Here's a tutorial showing how to for Windows 7 (but DON'T use the numbers they show, use the ones above):
http://blog.mclaughlinsoftware.com/2009/11/26/windows-7-static-ip/

5) Do the 30/30/30 reset: Pick up the router and hold it front down resting against your desk, backside up, using a paperclip, hold down the \\"Reset\\" pinhole in the back of the router CONTINUOUSLY while doing the following: Wait 30 seconds, pull the ac plug out from the back while continuing to hold the paper clip in, wait 30 seconds, then plug the ac plug back in and wait another 30 seconds, all while continuing to hold the paper clip in. Now you can let go of the paperclip. You're done with the reset. The router light WILL NOT be on but the router IS still functioning.

6) Now UNPLUG your ethernet cable from the \\"Modem\\" port. I failed to do this and it cost me a couple of hours trying to figure out why I was getting almost immediate connection time outs in my browser when I uploaded the bin file (step 8 below).

7) Type in your browser windows \\"192.168.2.1\\". You should get a totally different screen from the normal belkin firmware. It will be a very simple page saying something like \\"CFE Mini-Web Server\\" and will have a \\"Browse\\" button and and \\"Upload\\" button, a \\"Reboot\\" link and a link to reset NVRAM. If you don't see this and instead, the light comes back on and you get the Belkin configuration screen you did not do the 30/30/30 reset right so go back and do 5 again. If you see no light and get no internet connection make sure you set your static ip correctly (see step #4 above)

8) Browse for and select the bin file you downloaded. Then click \\"Upload\\". On the bottom left of your browser it should show that it is being uploaded in increasing %. It will then give you a message to wait for a few minutes before you can reboot. Click continue when done. (If you don't get anything like this and it just times out and you get an error page see Step #6 above and take the modem cable out of your router! )

9) After router reboots navigate to 192.168.2.1 in your browser. It will ask you for name/password, type in \\"admin\\" and \\"admin\\". You should see the red tomato menu.

10)Click on \\"Administration\\", then \\"Upgrade\\", Click Browser for file and click on the TRX file (one of the two files you downloaded). Tick the checkbox to reset NVRAM settings. Click on \\"Upgrade\\" button. Wait about five minutes and follow prompts to wait, and continue.

11) When you're done you most likely will get a page failure error. Because the upgrade has caused the router's ip address (your default gateway) to be reset to 192.168.1.1. So you have to reset your static ip to 192.168.1.10, net mask 255.255.255.0, with gateway of 192.168.1.1 and DNS of 192.168.1.1. (similar to step 4 above but with the different numbers).

12) Now go to 192.168.1.1 and you should be prompted for the same tomato login of admin/admin. Once you login you'll notice new features (usb,nas, etc.).

13) Go to Administration page and change your password and login name to something secure.

14) Plug back the cable from your modem to the \\"Modem\\" port or you won't have any internet access.

15) You're done

*****************
UPDATE 5/29/2013

****************

*******************************************
Install a printer:
**********************************************

Follow this tutorial:

http://tomatousb.org/tut:configure-printer-in-windows

When done, test and make sure you can print from the computer

*******************************************************************
Extend Your Wireless Network on a single SSID
*******************************************************************
I use the Belkin as a 2nd router extending the reach of my [[ASIN:B000BTL0OA Cisco-Linksys WRT54GL Wireless-G Broadband Router]], on which I also have Tomato installed, so that I now have near 100% signal in the far reaches of my house where the belkin is. I used the following tutorial to set it up:

http://www.howtogeek.com/104007/how-to-extend-your-wireless-network-with-tomato-powered-routers/

Both routers use the same Network SSID name so that laptops don't have to switch access points as they go from room to room.

Although note that I ignored the advice in the tutorial to put the node on G for wireless network mode only and set the wireless network mode on the belkin to auto. This allowed my newer laptops/ipad that have N devices to use the Belkin's N protocol and gets much better range. I also ignored the advice on turning DHCP off on the belkin node and used DHCP on both routers. But I set different ranges (the primary linksys router was set to range of 192.168.0.2 to 192.168.0.125, and the belkin node was set to 192.168.0.126 to 192.168.0.129.). That way there shouldn't be any issue with 2 different laptops being assigned the same ip by both routers. So far it has worked without a hitch. I also set the DNS on the Note to the ip address of the primary router.

Note that if you have a wired connection between the two routers you can follows this (haven't tried this yet):

http://www.howtogeek.com/104469/how-to-extend-your-wi-fi-network-with-simple-access-points/

*********************************************************************************************
INSTALL AIRPRINT TO SHARE OUT YOUR USB PRINTER SO YOU CAN PRINT FROM IPAD AND IPHONE
*********************************************************************************************
I have an ipad but it couldn't print with that using my older USB only Samsung 4521f multifunction printer. Some newer networked/wireless printers have an \\"Airprint\\" driver installed which allows ipads and iphones with IOS 6 to print.

I investigated and found that I had a few options:

(1) I could try try installing Airprint to the router using Qui's excellent tutorial:

http://blog.qnology.com/2013/03/tutorial-apple-airprint-on-tomatousb.html

This allows you to print fromyour ipad without relying on any other computer being on all the time.

I decided against this option. It's complicated, depends on linux CUPS driver support for your particular printer, may be unstable, and more importantly, note that at the very end of the tutorial the Qui recommends instead to get a POGO Plug and install the software on that.

(2) After some more investigation, I chose a simpler option, which was to download and install an unofficial Windows Airprint driver on one of our Windows computers. This does require the computer to be on while you print from the IOS device but that usually is not an issue for me.

Here are the steps:

1) Follow the above steps to install tomato to the Belkin router

2) Connect your USB printer to the router

3) Log into tomato at 192.168.1.1 (unless you changed it to something else, like I have) and make sure the printer appears in tomato under USB and Nas ->USB Support (under Attached Devices) If it doesn't it may be a USB 1.1 device, so make sure USB 1.1 is checked and refresh the screen.

4) Follow this to install the printer driver on your computer:

http://tomatousb.org/tut:configure-printer-in-windows When done, test and make sure you can print from the computer.

5) Install Bonjour (if you have itunes installed on your Windows computer you shouldn't have to do this):

http://support.apple.com/kb/DL999

6) Download the unofficial windows Airprint driver onto the computer you want to use as your Airprint server (same as in #4 above) and install using the instructions here:

http://forums.macrumors.com/showthread.php?t=1293865

7) Make sure the computer in #4 has selected the printer attached to the Belkin router and is sharing it out.

8) Done - you should now be able to print from your IOS device as long as the computer in #4 is on and is sharing out the printer. If it doesn'twork make sure both the Airprint and Bonjour services are running, and/or reboot.

This worked for me using IPAD 2 with IOS 6 and a Windows 7 64 bit machine sharing out a Samsung 4521f printer networked through the Belking router with tomato installed.
output: Very Nice Router, Tomato Upgradeable but Somewhat Tricky - A How-To in 15 "Easy" Steps

First, this back pack has the best padding I've even seen. There are two heavily padded areas that hit right where the shoulder/wings are, which relieves pressure when there is a lot in the pack. Then there is a heavily padded area that hits right across the lower back, AND this same area is a zipper pocket for either papers or technology that needs that extra padding.

And about pockets - this pack has so many!!! Counting the zippered lower back pocket, there are five more on the exterior creating lots of space organizers. A person can literally carry an office worth, school worth, etc of materials in this roomy pack. I especially like the exterior, top zip area which is great for a wallet, passport, pens/pencils etc. Or, like my husband has used it, the pack is a great carry on for the plane carrying a week's work of clothes for a trip AND a small laptop computer.

Speaking of computers, this pack is really excellent for carrying a laptop. The interior back panel has a padded sleeve that is up against the padded exterior back panels. This protects the computer AND your back and shoulders. There is another un-padded sleeve with a Velcro closing for papers. The interior is roomy enough to hold several books, or lots of clothes or camping gear. Also, the shoulder straps are adjustable, heavily padded AND have MORE storage area! Yes, even the straps have pockets and straps to hold pens, a cell phone, a camping items etc.

This backpack is excellent for work, school, travel, or camping - just the best I've seen!

I couldn't be happier. These are users for a multiple of roles for me- VoIP headset, podcast rig, video conferencing (Google Hangouts) and general purpose stereo headphones. For VoIP and video conferencing, these are outstanding- the DECT wireless distance is just as good as my SNOM M3 handset and since you are hands free you can multitask and move around- great for IT professionals doing phone or remote support. Audio output (ear pieces) is excellent for speech. The audio input (microphone) is good but may sound a bit "hollow" to some- not quite as flat or "dead" as I would like it but still very clear which is important when doing podcast or screencast work. The most critical I can be is when talking about the "general purpose stereo headphones" case. There is no "bottom" to these ear pieces so you wouldn't be happy if want to use them for music streaming- that's not what they were designed for. Listening to talk / news radio is a much better use case but occasional music or movie listening shouldn't offend your ears too much.

I'm using these on a Linux system (Kubuntu 14.04 LTS) and its truly plug and play. As is typical in Linux, there are no drivers to worry about. You plug the base into a USB port, wait a couple of seconds for the system to detect the device and just select the mic or speaker devices as you would for anything else. It probably should be mentioned that I use Zoiper as the VoIP soft client to my Asterisk PBX and that client does not allow you to answer of hang up calls from the button on the back of the mic boom. It also doesn't light up when it use. That's not a big deal to me.
output: Excellent device for a number of use cases.

I have never owned a portable keyboard so I did not know what to expect. The device was well packaged. It appeared very professional. The included User Manual was also fairly well done. I was a little surprised that it took me awhile to understand the concept of the arm stand. I assumed once the iPad was connected that it would prop up on it's own. I didn't realize that I had to extend it away from the keyboard to actually use it.

Once the iPad was in place, the functionality of the keyboard is really nice. The extra features like the Home button and the Play/Pause buttons was a nice surprise. I did notice that anytime I use the keyboard after not using it for awhile, it doesn't immediately recognize the first keystroke that I do, so I have to initially press the keystroke twice. Also, I didn't realize that the iPad had to be placed with the Home button on the right to enable automatic Sleep mode when closing the cover.

I do like the feature of removing the stand separately from the keyboard. This case tends to be a very good complement to the iPad if used on a desk surface. The angle of the stand is a little steep when using it on your lap.

Also, when closing the case, it takes a little coordination to push the arm stand back in before shutting it. When fully extended, it is a two hand process as you need to lift the iPad away from the resting groove with one hand while sliding the lock mechanism and pushing the arm stand in at the same time.

I give it 4 of 5 stars due to the weight of the case, the fact you have to initially extend the arm stand to prop it into the resting groove, and the minimal difficulty in closing the case.

Overall, very professional and well crafted keyboard case. It will replace my iPad Air smart case when in the home and used as a permanent dock on my desk, but I will still probably use the Apple Smart Case when away from the home since it does take some time to setup and close.
output: Great for in-home use - Somewhat challenging when mobile

Ordered my first card (from Amazon LLC themselves, not marketplace); came with no adapter; eh, no biggy. Packaging coloring was a bit faded, and the back of the packaging was in Chinese first, then English. Huh.

Then when I tried to move files into it, it wouldn't take anything more than about 10GB. Photos would be randomly corrupted, and entire folder contents mysteriously vanishing/being deleted (but the folder itself still intact). Also had extremely slow performance; reformatting took 6+ hours!
These are signs of a bootleg card.

Asked for a replacement, and when I got it, wow the packaging was different.
The replacement had:
Front:
-Came with an actual adapter
-The printing is more vibrant, and the big picture in the middle is a thicker sticker than the first card.
-The picture is a tablet, versus a phone on the first card.

Back:
-Correctly labeled as MicroSD XC for a 64GB card on the top right of the back, not MicroSD HC on first card.
-"Ideal choice for premium smartphones and tablets".
-English durability text.
-English-first product description text; no Chinese at all.
-10 year warranty instead of 5.
-Recycling/disposal symbols arranged differently.
-The card is MADE IN KOREA.
-The barcode has more information.

Wow get your stuff together Amazon, what the heck?? How did this get in your supply??
I really don't want to start buying electronics from big box retailers for guaranteed genuine items but this is actually the THIRD time in a row I've gotten a bad card from Amazon (it was a Sandisk before this one), and I'm suspecting the one before was a fake now too since it exhibited the exact same symptoms.

Hope this helps anyone out there and took look out of you get these.

Instances.input:
[[VIDEOID:mo1GNY6GOSW6N2A]]I got the Quickcam Pro 9000 version, and I found this widely circulated statement of differences, allegedly made by Logitech's employee, on the difference between Quickcam Pro 9000 and Webcam Pro 9000:

--- begin excerpt--
Logitech updated the Quickcam Pro 9000 and released it on August 1st 2009 as the Webcam Pro 9000. The differences are as follows By Ladan Khamsepoor // Sr. Product Marketing Manager, Video Business:

There are a few subtle changes:
- While the QuickCam Pro 9000 offers VGA-quality video at 30 frames per second (high-quality video) on Skype, we made adjustments to ensure the updated Webcam Pro 9000 can perform up to VGA-quality video at 30 FPS on any video application, including Logitech Vid.
- The Webcam Pro 9000 was modified to be capable of adjusting to widescreen format and record 720 pixels (1280×720) at up to 30 FPS.
- Finally, software is no longer required for RightLight. Instead, we\'ve built it into the device, so right out of the box, you\'ll get the best image quality possible, regardless of harsh or dim lighting conditions. Perhaps too much information, but we also adjusted the firmware to make sure that RightLight engages only when necessary.

[...]
---end excerpt

Out of curiosity, I got a frustration free package and compared with a Quickcam version I got a little earlier.

Yes the frustration free package one got recognized by windows 7 as \\"Webcam Pro 9000\\" while the earlier version is recognized as \\"Quickcam Pro 9000\\". The drivers and softwares specified by Logitech's website appears to be universal and Both cam had a \\"driver information\\" showing driver version of 12.10.1110.0. The firmware version reads 5.0.1161 on the Webcam 9000 and 2.96.6009 on the Quickcam, suggesting possible different firmware families than increments of the same firmware. It also may suggest that there are differences in hardware as well.

Testing it in video mode--the quickcam version's flaw wasn't apparent at first, until one investigated closer. The HD video frame on the Webcam version is a little cropped, suggesting it used fewer pixels than the full frame sensor, or only 1280x720 out of the 1600x1200. You can see this when you switch to the 1600x1200 mode. That did not happen with the Quickcam pro 9000. At first I thought the Quickcam gave me a scaled down interpolation of the full resolution video, showing its full wide angle picture, which would have been advantageous over a cropped image on the Webcam version; but then I realized that it is really a scaled up interpolation from 800x450--in other words, full hardware HD video is simply not possible with Quickcam Pro 9000, while it is available on the newer Webcam version.

Despite the less-than-ideal method of using reduced sensor area that produced a cropped image (thereby negating the wide angle lens advantage at full HD setting), I speculate that the Webcam version did this to reduce CPU load for interpolation. Still, I wish a full frame scaled down 720p HD mode is available as an option.

What is more incredible is when I tried to record video. For some reason, the webcam version was able to record smooth HD video at full 1280x720, while the older quickcam version, despite the scale-up interpolation, had a lot of trouble with that resolution setting, or even at 800x450. I use a x61s thinkpad -- hardly speedy by today's standards. However, it goes to show something is done quite differently with the new webcam version, as the results are not even close -- I recorded non-HD videos that looked like still pictures jumping from frame to frame with in-tact audio using the Quickcam version, while the Webcam version was able to record fluid 720p HD videos without problems. Webcam version wins by an unbelievable margin here.

Then the photo test: i imagined both camera will show full resolution in photo mode, or 1600x1200. NOT SO! At 1600x1200, which is supposed to be native resolution for both of these cams, the Quickcam version showed a blurry picture that clearly seems interpolated, or a scaled up version of 800x600. The details are just absent, and looked identical to a 800x600 image. The Webcam was evidently at 2MP with details that cannot be there with interpolation. Why can't the Quickcam version take photos at its native resolution is beyond me.

The above tests made me wonder about these possibilities: 1. the newer driver simply doesn't support Quickcam pro 9000 version fully, and catered to Webcam version instead; 2.Quickcam Pro 9000 had always been a half baked product with these flaws, hence the upgrade; 3.something is wrong with the driver and/or the hardware as tested. If it's either #1 or #2, I find it incredible that Logitech was able to charge close to $100 for the Quickcam Pro 9000 version that doesn't deliver on its HD promises, and performed in reality only slightly better than my old Quickcam fusion.

Testing the cams side by side in real use such as skype and msn, the image quality didn't look all that different -- a little soft than my liking especially for a cam of this price range. AF performance is also similar. There is very little difference that I can discern, other than the ones mentioned above, which is not subtle by any measure.

For what it's worth: the webcam9000 that came in the frustration package is a little scuffed up compared to the Quickcam version I got in a retail package. The plastic on the camera is of a polished/mirror finish, so any hairline scratch/scuff/buffs show up instantly. There was none on the Quickcam Retail, but some on the Frustration Free Packed version wrapped in plastic bag. However I am not sure if it's really related to the packaging or production batches. I am anal retentive in that regard, but for most people it probably doesn't matter. The difference in the amount of plastic and packing material is mind boggling though. For the sake of the environment and savings, frustration free package is a real innovation.

With regards to \\"built in\\" right light -- that sounds a bit odd (i.e. it scarcely makes sense), as right light is built into logitech's driver ANYWAY and is always software activated/controlled. On both cams I was offered the option of turning it on or leaving it on always. I believe from the inception, right light was hardware dependent (earlier Quickcams simply couldn't support it), suggesting there were hardware involvement in the cameras anyway. The fact that you don't need driver support to run it doesn't make much sense--the webcam doesn't run without its driver.

Which is better? Webcam Pro 9000. The advantage over the older Quickcam version is significant--unless it's due to software/driver screw-up, which is a real possibility.

I am open to corrections and would love to learn what others find.uickcam version showed a blurry picture that clearly seems interpolated, or a scaled up version of 800x600. The details are just absent, and looked identical to a 800x600 image. The Webcam was evidently at 2MP with details that cannot be there with interpolation. Why can't the Quickcam version take photos at its native resolution is beyond me. The above tests made me wonder about these possibilities: 1. the newer driver simply doesn't support Quickcam pro 9000 version fully, and catered to Webcam version instead; 2.Quickcam Pro 9000 had always been a half baked product with these flaws, hence the upgrade; 3.something is wrong with the driver and/or the hardware as tested. If it's either #1 or #2, I find it incredible that Logitech was able to charge close to $100 for the Quickcam Pro 9000 version that doesn't deliver on its HD promises, and performed in reality only slightly better than my old Quickcam fusion. Testing the cams side by side in real use such as skype and msn, the image quality didn't look all that different -- a little soft than my liking especially for a cam of this price range. AF performance is also similar. There is very little difference that I can discern, other than the ones mentioned above, which is not subtle by any measure. For what it's worth: the webcam9000 that came in the frustration package is a little scuffed up compared to the Quickcam version I got in a retail package. The plastic on the camera is of a polished/mirror finish, so any hairline scratch/scuff/buffs show up instantly. There was none on the Quickcam Retail, but some on the Frustration Free Packed version wrapped in plastic bag. However I am not sure if it's really related to the packaging or production batches. I am anal retentive in that regard, but for most people it probably doesn't matter. The difference in the amount of plastic and packing material is mind boggling though. For the sake of the environment and savings, frustration free package is a real innovation. With regards to \\"built in\\" right light -- that sounds a bit odd (i.e. it scarcely makes sense), as right light is built into logitech's driver ANYWAY and is always software activated/controlled. On both cams I was offered the option of turning it on or leaving it on always. I believe from the inception, right light was hardware dependent (earlier Quickcams simply couldn't support it), suggesting there were hardware involvement in the cameras anyway. The fact that you don't need driver support to run it doesn't make much sense--the webcam doesn't run without its driver. Which is better? Webcam Pro 9000. The advantage over the older Quickcam version is significant--unless it's due to software/driver screw-up, which is a real possibility. I am open to corrections and would love to learn what others find.
output: Attempt to Investigate the Difference between Quickcam and Webcam Pro 9000

Instances.input:
I bought a Targus iPad cover at Target for $50 and did not like it. I found this item and placed the order and it is everything the Targus cover was not: Tight fitting, not too bulky, rotating screen and on/off feature. And, it was on Amazon for $14 less than the Targus cover.

The case itself is a smooth leather material and seems like it would be easy to clean if needed. The case is solid when used as a stand (the Targus one was not). While not flashy, it's not ugly at all. Let's hope it wears well but based on what looks to be very solid construction, I have no concerns.

This works fine if I want to use my neighbors wireless network.  Even a room away it has problems connecting to my network despite showing a strong signal.  My roku and other laptop work fine on my network so I don't understand why this makes an exception.  Even when manually connecting to my network it takes 3 or more tries.  Does just fine at my girlfriends so I can't say it never works.  After several months and reloading the drivers 3 times I'm going to retire this one and buy a Belkin.
Sure not the best "book for dummies" I've ever seen.
Installed shortly after getting the Fire and it is still working great 3 months later.  I would recommend it to everyone with a Fire!

Arrived quickly, worked right out of the box. If you're afraid of the price being "too cheap" for a good dance pad, don't worry - it's a great item. Buttons are very responsive to touch. It works on carpet. The only reason I don't give it 5 stars is because the dancepad's USB connection is sometimes faulty - not sure if it's my computer or the device, but this is the only USB device that seems to give me occasional errors.
output: If you're afraid of the price being "too cheap" for a good dance pad

Instances.input:
Maybe I just got unlucky...

Upon first boot, the CPU temperature didn't display in the BIOS. That should have been my clue to return it right then. It only got worse from there. Not a single one of the software utilities that came with this board would run. They hung & pegged the CPU. PS2 port would not recognize a keyboard even after shutting down, clearing CMOS and restarting.

In an attempt to give MSI the benefit of the doubt I turned to the forums and to their online support. The forums were no help and MSI's online support was 24 hours between each response and the responses were VERY beginner/generic (ie no help). I installed SpeedFan and it would run, unlike MSI's utilities, but could not read any temps, voltages, or fan speeds from this board. I also updated the BIOS which was a hassle because their Live Update utility didn't work either. I reseated the CPU and memory, all to no avail...

This board has good reviews, like I said, maybe I just got unlucky or maybe noone else has tried the PS2 port or any of the utilities yet... Regardless, lesson learned for me.

After a little over a week of messing with it, I disassembled my build and returned it to Amazon. 5 stars to Amazon, 1 to MSI. What a hassle. This was my first build with an MSI board; I'm going back to ASUS.
output: Multiple problems - MSI Tech support slow & mostly worthless

Instances.input: I worried about my new Kindle 3G being scratched in my purse or dropped while reading on the subway, but I didn't want to spend a lot for a case, so I opted for [[ASIN:B004ALXSTU Acase Genuine Leather Flip Case for Kindle 3 with Multiple Position Stand (Black)]]. As others have noted, it has a funny smell (though not as overwhelming) and is definitely not real leather. It also adds more weight and clumsy thickness than I'd expected, which kind of defeats the purpose of having a simply designed ebook as an alternative to real books. But it's still much lighter than a hardcover book, and with the sturdy padding I believe it would be well protected if dropped. The Kindle fits perfectly in the slot designed for it, and all buttons are accessible. The \\"multiple position stand\\" is pretty flimsy, but I have no plans to use that feature. So while it's not my ideal case (light, real leather), it does serve my purposes for now (sturdy, cheap).

Instances.input:
I LOVE THIS THING! So far, it has done everything I wanted and more! Very Stable! Very Intuitive. In fact, I would say this is probably the most simple install there is for personal NAS systems. All you have to do is plug it in and fill out everything on the web interface. Simple! Once you're done, you're ready to start putting stuff on it!

Also, for those of you who are running their own PLEX server, this has been PERFECT! I haven't seen any performance hits to the server when storing all of my video files on it. Please note though: This is not powerful enough to run the server from. It can't transcode videos fast enough, so don't turn it into a PLEX server. I'm running my plex server on my personal machine, and pointing it to the NAS where I store all my movies. I'm almost done getting all my DVD's and Blu-Rays on it! No more searching through my shelves for the movie I want to watch! It's AWESOME!
output: This Thing Has Changed Our Lives

Instances.input:
This universal laptop adapter is much smaller than the ones that came with either of my two notebooks. The adapter is a small rounded box about 1/5 the size of the brick-sized adapters that came with my notebooks. This one, by contrast, is small enough to fit in a small pocket. It has two small prongs that flip 90 degrees out the side to make a plug that fits any standard US socket. Being only two prongs I guess there is no ground so it will fit any outlet, not just a three prong one. Having the plug basically flip out of the casing means you have a nice compact power supply with a fairly thin, roughly 10 gauge six-foot long cable that comes out of one end. The cable has a Velcro strap attached to it so you can wind it up into a coil for packing away tidily. There are nine choices of plug which are 90 degree plugs to fit your laptop. Eight of these fit on a plastic strip for easy storage while the ninth oblong non-90 degree one is separate and will not fit.

Each of the plugs have a pair of pins. This is pretty standard really though each of these have a flat edge so that they only fit the cable the right way around. This ensures the right polarization of the cable.

This adapter works well on our Acer notebook. It’s tiny compared to the “brick” and fat cables that came with it. However, it has less output than the factory supply: 65w instead of 90w and 3.25a instead of four. It charges at about 2/3 of the speed which is fine for us. And works as well when plugged in.

Our other notebook is a low profile high-end Dell and none of the plugs fit. They have a smaller plug than any of the ones that came with this charger. I discovered that the oblong plug fits one of my external li-ion battery packs and lets me charge that about 50% faster than the charger that came with it.

I am very pleased with the convenience of such a small power supply. For the Acer I have a nice form fitting neoprene case with a pocket. But the OEM charger does not fit and has to be carried separately. This adapter is smaller than our mini laptop mouse and both fit in the pocket together. Very convenient.

It does get a little hot when plugged in. I guess the small enclosed size means there is not much space for it to vent heat from.

It would be nice if a bag was supplied for the plugs to keep everything together. Since I only need it for the acer it’s not a big deal.

The only things I’m not entirely happy about are that the six foot cable means you need to have an outlet close to where you are sitting. Three feet can easily be taken just by the desk height. The other thing is that even though the cable is polarized the prongs that pull out of the case are identical so you can plug the adapter in the wrong way. Normal, polarized plugs have one thicker stumpy one that fits a wider slot so you can only plug it in one way. When plugged in the wrong way the battery charging status icon does not show charging but doesn’t seem to do any actual harm. Just doesn’t charge the notebook battery. So you need to check that it is charging when plugged in.

I recommend it.M charger does not fit and has to be carried separately. This adapter is smaller than our mini laptop mouse and both fit in the pocket together. Very convenient.

Instances.input: I purchased the Dragon Touch after dropping my older Nexus 7 tablet in the street, cracking the screen badly. Instances.input:
There are tons of tablets PCs on the market today, and most of them are running either Android or iOS. But the real computing power lies in Windows-based tablets.

While it’s true that most any tablet will work just fine if all you need to do is visit a website or two, send emails, play a simple game or peruse Facebook, you really need the power and flexibility of a full-blown computer if you plan to do any real work.

If you’re looking for a true workhorse of a tablet at a great price, I believe you’ll find that the Quantum View 10.1″ Tablet and Keyboard with Windows 8.1 & Office 2013 is an outstanding option. This awesome device offers much of the power and functionality of Microsoft’s Surface line of Windows tablets at less than half the cost.

The folks at Quantum View managed to pack a lot of computing muscle into this tablet, allowing it to run Windows 8.1 and Office 2013 (both of which are included) much better than one would expect for a machine in its price range.

One of the first things I noticed when I removed the Quantum View 10.1″ Windows Tablet from the box was how sturdy and well-built it is.

Unlike most cheap Android tablets, this one is made to stand up to heavy use. And thanks to the pre-installed Windows 8.1 operating system and Microsoft Office 2013 productivity suite, you can begin doing real work immediately after completing the short and painless setup process.

Before doing anything else, I plugged the tablet into the wall charger and let the battery charge overnight. When I turned it on the next morning, Windows automatically launched the setup routine. After making a few quick selections, I found myself looking at a usable Windows 8.1 Start Screen. The entire process took all of about 5 minutes.

After that initial startup/setup sequence, this tablet now fully boots to the Start Screen in about 10 seconds thanks to the super-fast internal flash storage. That’s much faster than any of my Android tablets!

When attached, the keyboard and trackpad make the Quantum View a true joy to use. They both respond quickly and smoothly to the touch, with no apparent delay whatsoever. And unlike Microsoft’s much more expensive Surface, the keyboard and trackpad docking station is included at no extra cost.

The only thing lacking in this tablet is an optical drive, but that’s to be expected with any modern tablet PC. If you ever find yourself in need of one, you can always attach an inexpensive external USB optical drive to the tablet’s USB port.

Bottom line: If you’re looking for a Windows tablet that offers plenty of bang for the buck, I don’t believe you’ll be able to beat this excellent tablet from Quantum View. It’s powerful, it includes everything you need to get down to business, and it’s built to last.
output: While it’s true that most any tablet will work just fine if all you need to do is visit a ...

The mouse is plug and play, and doesn't come with any drivers. The receiver is tiny, and there is a place under the mouse where you can safely store it on the go. There's a button under the scroll wheel the allows you to switch between three mouse speeds. This is useful if you want to quickly change the mouse sensitivity in games or other applications. I cannot comment on battery life yet, but the mouse goes into power saving mode when not used for a while.

The mouse buttons and scroll wheel have good feedback and are not very loud. The mouse has nice soft-touch plastic on the top surface of the mouse, including the buttons and the flip tail. The grey parts as well the bottom sides are smooth and plasticky, though this is forgivable considering the price. The fish tail is sturdily built, and the mouse looks like it will last a long time.

I have used Microsoft Arc and Arc Touch laptop mice in the past and though they are smaller, they are much more expensive and not as comfortable as this mouse (likely because they're smaller). When folded the mouse is portable enough for your laptop bag, though not as portable as more expensive ones. Also the mouse looks a bit odd with the grey band surrounding the mouse stopping at the fishtail. I would prefer if it was completely black or if the fishtail part also had the grey, though it might be just me. Overall I would highly recommend this mouse for laptop use.

Instances.input:
I waited a year to write a review on this because I wanted to have ample time to experience it in its fully glory. Let's start with the design of the product.

This is one of the best-looking NAS devices I've ever seen. It's not NASty looking like some of the others. And it sits on my printer shelf, with my handsome white printer plugged into it - so it fits right in. Really nice looking. Quick-access USB port on the front for my weekly external backups and a power button I don't think I've ever used beyond turning it on the first time.

Reliability? Yeah. It's reliable. The volume has crashed I think twice in the last year. But all that means is it needs to refresh. A power-cycle through the web interface takes care of this. My drives and data have been safe and unaffected both times. I don't remember what I was doing that caused the crash - I think several of us gamers were mounting ISOs from the same directory. Something atypical, for sure. It's hosted my music, documents and photos without issue for a year now. And it's pretty quick. But not like lightning.

This was the main reason I bought the device. Because I read a ton of reviews and researched every NAS I could find for over a year before I made the jump. And I wish it was a little quicker. When I'm streaming music to another computer on the network, just using a mapped drive to the DS209 for the source, the music just cuts out for ten seconds at a time every ten minutes or so. Apparently none of these mp3 library apps cache the song they're playing. It does, however, work flawlessly when I use the built-in Audio Station interface. I just don't like it as much as Songbird or Banshee.

I was going to buy another Synology to hold all my movies, and stream them to my multiple HTPCs, but after seeing how it streamed music, I've decided to go local on those. Other than the speed though, I have had no problems with it. You can do just about anything you want with it. Add packages, run web servers, access it from the Internet... I've been absolutely and tremendously happy with this purchase. I just had to make a lifestyle change to get used to the music player. Not a big deal overall, and definitely not something that would keep me from recommending this product. Need a good NAS? Synology is your answer.ss it from the Internet... I've been absolutely and tremendously happy with this purchase. I just had to make a lifestyle change to get used to the music player. Not a big deal overall, and definitely not something that would keep me from recommending this product. Need a good NAS? Synology is your answer.
Amazing!!!!

I do a lot of online gaming and skyping and while I wanted a cordless headset so that I could move away from my computer and still talking (or listening) I often found my other headsets dead when I needed them and had no choice but to take it off and plug it in to charge. This headset however solved my problem. It allows you to still use the headset even while it is plugged in and charging. This allows me to use it wirelessly as I want, and then plug it in when at the computer for extended use (sometimes 12 hours non-stop!). It's comfortable, though a little heavy and large feeling at first until you adjust to it. I do have two "complaints" but both really aren't faults. The first is...the initial set up of this headset (for people who are picky about their sound quality) can be a touch time consuming as you set it for games, skype, movies, music etc getting it just right.

The second concern however is a bit more of a nuisance. I use a laptop and the dongle that connects to the USB for wireless use is not suited for laptops given it's length. On a desktop CPU where you are not near your USB ports it would be fine...but on my laptop I have broken and had to replace the dongle twice from it catching on things during movement. I wish they would make a shorter (mini) dongle available for use with laptops.

I have been reluctant to purchase a Kindle. My friend bought one of the first ones and while he loved it, I was wary. I love my library of \\"real\\" books. But those \\"real\\" books are just too difficult to manage while travelling. Using my laptop while in a cramped airline seat seemed to be just too much effort. So I pre-ordered the Kindle Fire after seeing the video on Amazon about it.

My biggest dislike of any Kindle really has to do with Amazon. Amazon pulled some purchased content from owners in the past and that made me very WARY, so I have not been using my Kindle Fire to purchase books. Instead, I have used it to borrow books, play games, watch videos and read email.

The day after my new Kindle Fire arrived, I was given an iPad *not an iPad 2* at work.

Size - the Kindle Fire is smaller than the iPad and weighs much less. Most people won't notice the difference but if you have arthritis or other limiting issues, it might be a deciding factor.

The thing I love the most about the Kindle is its size. I can toss it in to my purse. It is great for travel or sitting at the doctor's office.

Screens - both the Kindle Fire and the iPad have beautiful color touch screens. The iPad has multi-touch functionality. Both touch screens are intuitive and have great pictures. Since the Kindle Fire is smaller, of course the view size is smaller.

The Kindle Fire is really just an Amazon multimedia consumption device. If you are an Amazon Prime member, then you will love it. There is a lot of overlap between the two devices, but the iPad in the end has a lot more functionality.

The Kindle Fire requires an active Wifi if you want to watch any video or access web content. But, there is the option to download some items on to the system so that you can use them while Wifi deficient.

While the iPad has is no Flash capability, there really has only been one time that I encountered a problem with a website and flash.

The iPad excels at many things: movie watching, game playing, book reading, checking in at work, editing documents, downloading apps, etc. If the current iPad 2 entry price is too high for you, go ahead and buy a second-hand original iPad for about the same cost as a Kindle Fire. The original iPad is actually quite awesome.

Ease of use - my three year old has taken ownership of both the Kindle Fire and the iPad. He loves them both and uses them every day.

The Kindle Fire is a great buy, if you don't need to access work items. If you must access your Outlook then get the iPad - or get both.ing, book reading, checking in at work, editing documents, downloading apps, etc. If the current iPad 2 entry price is too high for you, go ahead and buy a second-hand original iPad for about the same cost as a Kindle Fire. The original iPad is actually quite awesome. Ease of use - my three year old has taken ownership of both the Kindle Fire and the iPad. He loves them both and uses them every day. The Kindle Fire is a great buy, if you don't need to access work items. If you must access your Outlook then get the iPad - or get both.

It is smaller in size that I originally thought, but this is a good thing. The descriptions are accurate to what I received. I am using this with a Samsung Tab 2 10.1. Item sync'd easily once my tablet recognized there was something out there to sync with. Keyboard functions like I would hope to. Looking to purchase one for the wife now...

The stylists work just fine. The stand seems to be able to hold up my 10" tablet without a problem or worry that it will fall off.

It's slim, the color is great, and it is markedly cheaper than the Apple smart case or what ever that was called.  After mine had finally given up on me after a year and a half of using it, I wasn't going to spend the money to get another one if it was only going to last me another year and a half.  So this case is a really good alternative if you want a slim case for your iPad but you don't want to pay for the original case recommended by Apple. One very minor issue I have with this product is that the front cover doesn't stay in its position when I fold it up into a triangle when using the cover as a mini-stand.  But I can live with that minor issue if it means that I paid less for my case.
output: Great alternative to the original Apple case

First off after getting it put together i'm quite happy with it. Although, getting it together in the first place was quite the ordeal. After taking out of the box the instruction booklet is small which isn't really a problem it shows you everything you need to know(kinda).

The first problem i had was with the base, while i was trying to screw in the connecting bolts i noticed they didn't screw all the way through and it was next to impossible to turn the hex wrench anymore (I actually stripped the wrench slot on one of the bolts) so after looking at the instructions again and although, it doesn't say, you might need the included spacers to get it to your liking.

After that the tightening bolt on the actual arms so they stay on the pole was missing, so after searching the floor the packaging and the included bolts i couldn't find it anywhere. So, after a bit of searching I found a bolt of my own that fit and used that. After I got everything put together i also had to tighten a few bolts on the arms so that it wouldn't just point the screen down immediately.

As much as I was hoping this backpack would work for my needs, it was unfortunately much larger & heavier (even with nothing in it) than I anticipated, plus 2 zippers have already broken, as well as the snaps to close the top flap, which are coming apart now.   I enjoyed some of the features, but there are a large number of negatives unfortunately. The front pocket where pens & other small elements are placed caused a bunch of scrapes on my hand when reaching down inside while the bag was full of my laptop, 2 textbooks, 1 or 2 notebooks, plus a folder or 2.  Additionally, I was very disappointed with the very small pockets which include a netting separator, which is completely USELESS! All it does is block the pocket from taking in all the items it could even possibly hold by half. If you put keys in there they get stuck, it was just a huge waste.  On top of that, the weight caused everything I placed in the bag to feel 2x heavier, which for someone who is disabled is a seriously negative quality.   The things I did like was the padding on the straps for the back pack was helpful, & there were some other good things, like the depths of the actual large compartments, allowing me to carry quite a bit of additional items, like extra water bottle & a container of fruit. But overall this bag, which starts out as a pretty impressively large pack that will hold a large 17\\" screen -- but notice that the majority of reviews were written very early on by other owners of the bag. Perhaps the other reviewers would have some problems of their own to list if the reviews had been made after the 6 month mark, rather than within 1 - 3 months.   Hope I didn't offend too much. I am out $75+ bucks for a bag I really needed to fulfill my needs as a graduate student, and it is harsh that now I will have to buy another bag for hopefully a lot LESS than what I mistakenly spent on this bag.
output: Disappointing for $75+ (Breaking after regular weekly use for 9 mos)

Instances.input: I stumbled across this piece of equipment by accident after I was searching online for a cheap extra phone line/service.  I have a home-based business and wanted the advantage of using the free distinctive ring we got from Verizon to go to its own voicemail or answering machine.  Verizon told us they would charge an extra $6 a month to have the distinctive ring (which we would use for our home number) to go to a separate voicemail, then told us it wasn't available in our area at all!  So I was THRILLED that there was a machine out there that did this and I immediately purchased the 5500 after reading all the reviews. LOVE IT!  I didn't even read the manual - just plugged it in, called tech support, told them what I wanted to do, and within 5 minutes I was up and running - EASY!  What I did was have our distinctive ring go to the answering machine and the other ring (business line) go to voicemail.  What I like about it, too is that the first ring rings both phones, not just the one in my office.  So if I'm downstairs, I can hear it AND look on caller ID to see who is calling.  And what is also nice about it is that if it is a business call and I want it to go to voicemail, it will continue to ring in my office without my having to hear it throughout the house.  BUT, if I am downstairs and DO want to pick up, I don't have to run up to my office - I can do it because it's the same phone line!  And I love that the caller ID works on all the phones, whether it's plugged into the Comswitch or not.  I figured I paid one time to purchase this unit what it would cost MONTHLY to pay Verizon for an extra line.  Love it, love it, love it!!  Works great - we're buying another one for our beach house!!
output: I can't believe I've been without it all these years!

Instances.input:
I started looking for a mouse that I can use for my laptop. I already had a large mouse for my desktop, but I wanted another small and portable one that I could easily carry with my laptop.

First, this mouse is light, small, portable, yet sits well in the hand. It has a nice grip that makes it very nice to handle.

Second, the battery life on this mouse is three years! That means that I can take my mouse with my laptop without worrying that it will need to be charged since it is a wireless mouse.

Third, this mouse has a very well made imaging sensor by Logitech, making it work on pretty much any surface. That means that I do not need to take a mousepad along with me when I take this mouse with my laptop.

The only reason that I took of 1 star is the fact that I have had problems with the Unifying Receiver before. I have had a total of 2 receivers that broke after 2 years and I had to replace those. Since this is a newer model, I hope that the receiver will last me longer.

Overall, it is a great, cheap, and portable mouse that I always take with me on the go.

Bought this to be a temp replacement for an old, slow laptop until I can drop money on something a bit more expensive. I work as a graphic designer and illustrator, so the majority of what I do is in Adobe Photoshop/ Illustrator. The newer versions of Adobe products have upped their requirements for GPU's and this one should have worked.
It was terrible, Photoshop constantly hangs up, stops responding and sits there processing, even on lower res files. Imagine my frustration when this computer actually performed worse than my old computer on the programs I use all day. With some more research, turns out that dual graphics don't enhance PS performance at all. And, the switchable graphics are buggy at best. I'm not a big gamer, so I can't speak to how well it works for that.
All the other (non-Adobe) programs worked well and were fast. It takes some time to get used to Win 8, which I'm pretty sure was designed by people who have never had to be productive at work. But that's consistent across recent MS design.
Other little things. The keyboard is not quite sensitive enough, but that takes some getting used to. It would be nice to have a button on the hardware to turn off the touchpad, which always seems to be in the way of my big fat hands. I'm typing along and all of the sudden I'm reading a Bing article. Surprise! Of course, I am used to a 17" laptop, so that's part of the problem.
The Dolby speakers are definitely louder than what I'm used to, of course, after a certain point, the have a lot of distortion/buzz. It's kind of like you are taking little tiny speakers and turning them up way past their actual range, wait, that's exactly what is happening. I don't expect much from laptop speakers, but if Dolby is going to tout their performance, then I'd expect more than the buzzfest that I got.
Soooooo, since this computer is practically unusable for my purposes, I'm returning it.
Didn't work.

Instances.input:
I don't believe this product works on hybrid drives. I was using it to clone my data from a laptop HDD before switching out the hard drives. New drive was a hybrid drive, old drive was a stock 5400rpm HDD. At first, I thought the product didn't work, but after deciding to do a clean install on the new drive, I found that it worked with the old stock drive. When moving my user data to the new drive, I noticed the data rates were not very consistent. It was topping out at 30 MB/s but was spiking up and down while doing it. Either way, it worked relatively well.

Honestly, even though I thought the product didn't work at first, I wasn't too heartbroken. It was $7 and it came with a nice plastic 2.5" HDD case. There's lights on the SATA end that let you know if it has power and if it has access to the HDD, this ended up being very helpful for me. It is a USB 2.0, so it was a little slower like I mentioned earlier, but at a $7 price point it is hard to beat.

All in all, it ended up working and being useful, just not in the way I originally planned for it. Price point is great too, even if it is USB 2.0. I can't justify 5 stars since it didn't work for my hybrid drive. I suspect this won't work for an SSD either. No problems with Windows 8.1 for me.

New drive: Seagate 1TB hybrid drive 5400rpm
Old drive: WD 5400rpm HDD
OS: Win 8.1
output: Did not work on my hybrid drive, may not work for SSD

Let me start by saying that my wife's hands are only slightly smaller than mine. I have small hands. This mouse is still too small for my hand. Unfortunately, mice have gone through an evolution as a small device. When you consider calling a mouse ergonomic, however, you have to consider the size of the hand holding it more than when you sell a regular mouse.

I work in IT, and have always loved my logitech mice with their relatively grooved and hand-shaped mice. They are, however, small and slightly unnatural for daily 8-hour shifts. The \\"live long and prosper\\" hand-hold you are forced to adopt to hold most mice (you know, thumb on the left, pointer and middle finger on the buttons, and the ring and little finger on the right side) produces strain on the ring and little fingers.

What the mouse gets right is the angle and grip. Unfortunately, my hand was more than a knuckle-length off the edge of the mouse, making using the buttons even more unnatural to me than using a \\"regular\\" mouse. Speaking of buttons, the mouse I received had some sort of problem where the buttons weren't snapped in properly (or the design is just flawed in this way) causing the right mouse button's leading, pointed edge to dig into the underside of my fingers. To further the problem, each of the buttons had a plastic click before the actual micro-switch click. I kept thinking I had clicked the buttons, but it was just something inside causing a click, and I hadn't fully depressed the button at all!

If you are trying to relieve some tension in your mousing hand, keep looking. This product is neither \\"Comfi\\" [sic] nor Ergonomic.
output: Cheaply built and awfully small for a small hand.
