Instances.input:
I have had this laptop for 6 months since I had it. I got this refurbished because Dell was running a special on their refurbished business class laptops, and I needed a new laptop after 6 years with my old one. Due to this being refurbished, I am not mentioning the price. If you buy this, get it through Dell directly in some way. The Amazon sellers selling this are shady or they don't know what they're talking about with this particular laptop. You can probably consider this a buyers guide, too.

After 6 months of owning this laptop, what are my thoughts on it? I think very favorably of the laptop, but there are some things you really need to know and the upgrades I consider essential. Like my SX150 review, I will handle this in sections.

Processor:
With this laptop, you can get multiple processor choices. These are:
* Core i5
* Core i7 4600M
* Core i7 4610M
* Core i7 4800MQ
* Core i7 4810MQ

My particular model has a 4800MQ processor. Dell has also switched processors in these very frequently so there are a lot of these out there with varying processors. If you want one of these, it's important to verify the installed processor before buying.
Also, a word of warning: Core i5 models generally lack dedicated video, as these use Intel graphics in most cases. Unless you have a Dell premier account, you need one of the i7 models for dedicated video. This isn't a deal breaker, but more or less something to be aware of.

Personally, I have had both a 4600M and 4800MQ model of this laptop. Personally, if you're spending this kind of money on a laptop I would go ahead and get a i7 model instead. An i5 in a laptop this nice makes no sense, especially since Haswell runs cool in laptops now, unlike the days of the past with Intel i7 laptops.

Personally, I think both the 4600M and 4800MQ are great processors for premium laptops. Unless you need a quad core processor for whatever reason, I would get it with a 4600M or 4610M. Quad cores in laptops only really make sense if you can justify having one.

Battery
For this particular laptop, you can get 4 kinds of battery for it
* 60WHr 6 cell
* 65WHr 6 cell
* 97WHr 9 cell
* 87WHr 9 cell

Now, let me tell you now that the 60WHr will not work well in this laptop. You're going to be plugging it in every 1-2 hours. If you have this battery, get rid of it as soon as you can. If you have the 65WHr(which I have), it's a little better. You'll get 4 hours at first, but once the battery starts to wear expect 2-3 hours out of this computer in most configurations. This started to happen when this battery jumped from 10 to 11% wear, and can't make it's mind up. Either way, this one will work decently but expecting it to last in this is a stretch. Keep multiple chargers if possible.

Once we get to the 9 cell batteries you're in really good shape with this computer. My first one of these had a 97WHr battery. I got 5 hours or more out of this computer, and for a machine of this class that's impressive. You can also get a 87WHr 9 cell for it. With this you lose 10-15% of the capacity, but instead you get better quality cells and a 3 year warranty. This battery is optional equipment, though. Dell does not include this as a standard battery with any E6540. You can buy it as part of the laptop from Dell, or on it's own later on. The choice is yours. Due to this battery being optional equipment, I really can't say how long it will last. I don't think it diverts from 5 hours too much, though. Personally, I'd buy it separate from the laptop, but do it at the time of purchase if you get it refurbished. New ones come with the 97WHr battery. Before doing this, verify the battery in the listing. If it says 6 cell, buy the 9 cell.

In short with the batteries you need to buy the right one for this laptop. The 6 cell 60WHr won't last, the 65WHr might last but it will dropin short order and you can get good runtimes out of the 9 cell variants. You really should buy it with a 9 cell battery for the best mobile experience. Dell's basic batteries have historically been garbage. This is no exception for the business laptops.

Storage:
Dell has also changed this a lot with time. Older variants will probably come with a hard drive. You will know these by them being 2013 or Early 2014 models with some form of a platter drive. However, these can appear from Dell Premier purchases too. Late 2014 models come with a 256GB SSD standard now unless you change it with a Dell Premier account.
What does all of this mean? Well, it means you have a range of drive types you can run into. Personally, you want an SSD, otherwise you may want to add this later on. A SSD will really show in this laptop.
I have seen multiple variants for drives. You can see what I have seen with this laptop over time below.
* 320GB HDD
* 500GB HDD
* 500GB SSHD
* 1TB SSHD/HDD
* 128GB Mobility SSD
* 256GB Mobility SSD
Due to all these changes in drives, I am not listing what machines to expect these in. Verify the installed drive from the service tag on the laptop. Trust the seller, but scrutinize them at the same time. Like the Amazon sellers, they screw the hard drives up too. If you have a hard drive, this machine is going to run very slowly. You want a SSD in this laptop if possible.

Memory:
These machines can have anywhere from 4 to 16GB of memory. If you buy one of the 4GB models, it's okay since you can upgrade the RAM. Don't stress too much, but get a good amount of RAM at the same time. I would suggest at least 8GB minimum.
Now that that's out of the way, a word of warning: THESE MACHINES NEED 1.3V DDR3 RAM! You can't use 1.5V RAM. The RAM you use in these is called DDR3L/LPDDR3. These names tend to be interchanged, so if you see either it's the same thing. But you need to check the operating voltage of the RAM before buying any for this laptop.
I don't know how true this is, but the i7 models MIGHT accept 32GB. Try it if you want, but Dell says 16GB. I have linked some compatible memory below.
[[ASIN:B00CQ35HBQ Kingston Technology 8GB 1600MHz DDR3L (PC3-12800) 1.35V Non-ECC CL11 SODIMM Intel Laptop Memory KVR16LS11/8]]

In short: You can get these with anywhere from 4-16GB of RAM. You also don't need to stress about it, since the RAM isn't soldered. But bear in mind standard DDR3 running at 1.5V will not work and you need DDR3L. For this reason I would strongly advise buying the RAM yourself, or asking someone who knows what to get on what RAM is compatible and runs at 1.3V.

Display:
You have 2 choices for a display. 1366x768 or 1920x1080. The choice is yours here, but 1080p is the way to go in my opinion. The reason being is practicality. Low res displays tend to not work so well with multiple windows, go getting the 1080p version is advisable. Both panels are matte.

Trackpad:
I can't say I'm thoroughly impressed with the trackpad on this laptop. Part of the reason for this is I think Dell could have made it larger, but still kept it practical. You also can't invert the scrolling in the driver, so you have to adjust to smartphone like scrolling. Once you get used to it, it's fine. If the size of the trackpad bothers you, nothing a mouse doesn't fix at least. But it is usable, albeit a little tiny for the size of the laptop. At the same time it isn't a clickpad, though. Yes, I'm talking to you Lenovo.
In the newest driver revision you should have traditional scrolling back. Well, at least in my case. You will have to remove the driver, clean the registry with a registry cleaner and then install it as a fresh driver to have similar luck.

Keyboard:
These have solid keyboards, and they make all these consumer grade ones I used feel as bad as they are. It's also harder to make a mistake on it, because of how the keys aren't flat like consumer grade laptops. And yes, it really does make a difference. You will find backlit and non backlit models. Get it with the backlit keyboard.

Webcam:
In laptops webcams are often a afterthought. This is kind of the case in this one, but it's not as bad as others out there. The mics do sound good, and quite frankly the mic is more important in a laptop. You can also buy it without the webcam if you wish.

Conclusion:
I have really come to like this laptop, despite it's shortcomings with the trackpad and the fact this one came with a hard drive and not a SSD.
The reason I gave this a four star review is how Dell has these set up for private buyers. Dell has one model that is undesirable and I would not touch. This model is the version with Intel graphics, a Core i5, 4GB of RAM and a 320GB hard drive. It also has the 1366x768 screen. This model is not worth it and you're better off spending the extra money on a better model.
Currently Dell has two to choose from. These are:
Core i5 4310M
Win7 Pro
15.6\\" 1366x768
4GB DDR3L
320GB HDD
HD Graphics 4600
This model is 1049.00. This is the model I would avoid.

Core i7 4610M
15.6\\" 1920x1080
8GB DDR3L
256GB Mobility SSD
AMD 8790M/Intel HD Graphics
This model is 1718.00

If you can get the i7 model, get that version instead. You'll be much happier with it.

Well, I hope you found this review useful. If you get a good one and not a lower end model, this is a very nice laptop and is well worth the money.ting voltage of the RAM before buying any for this laptop.
I don't know how true this is, but the i7 models MIGHT accept 32GB. Try it if you want, but Dell says 16GB. I have linked some compatible memory below.
[[ASIN:B00CQ35HBQ Kingston Technology 8GB 1600MHz DDR3L (PC3-12800) 1.35V Non-ECC CL11 SODIMM Intel Laptop Memory KVR16LS11/8]]

In short: You can get these with anywhere from 4-16GB of RAM. You also don't need to stress about it, since the RAM isn't soldered. But bear in mind standard DDR3 running at 1.5V will not work and you need DDR3L. For this reason I would strongly advise buying the RAM yourself, or asking someone who knows what to get on what RAM is compatible and runs at 1.3V.

Display:
You have 2 choices for a display. 1366x768 or 1920x1080. The choice is yours here, but 1080p is the way to go in my opinion. The reason being is practicality. Low res displays tend to not work so well with multiple windows, go getting the 1080p version is advisable. Both panels are matte.

It's also harder to make a mistake on it, because of how the keys aren't flat like consumer grade laptops. And yes, it really does make a difference. You will find backlit and non backlit models. Get it with the backlit keyboard.

Webcam:

Instances.input:
Just received a pair of the 32GB Sparks.

Primary use will be for regular backup of application/personal data.

Backup of some VM instances (6GB to 13GB in size) shows a sustained write speed of 15-20MB/sec ... not what you'd call blazingly fast, but acceptable for my needs. One of the devices 'temporarily disconnected' from my PC during a copy operation; this is Windows7 so I clicked on 'Retry' and the copy continued.

Dragging/dropping a 13GB VM directory to my plain vanilla 7200rpm drive started out with a 160MB/sec read rate but quickly fell off to a sustained read rate of ~45MB/sec

When a 6GB copy backup to a Spark finished I went to pull the device from the USB 3.0 port and got a nasty little surprise ... this little fella gets HOT! I'm not talking 'warm to the touch' but rather 'ouch, ouch, ouch, drop that thing now!' hot.

If this device was giving me writes at 80MB+ then the heat might be acceptable ... but for a measly 20MB?

I'll keep the devices since a) I got them on the (relative) cheap @ ~$20 and b) I won't be using them on a constant basis (eg, weekly backups). I would not have bought these if I'd known they'd get this hot. Crossing my fingers and hoping these don't burn out and/or suffer from the excessive heat ...

PROS: cheap, compact, decent storage size

CONS: slow, excessive heat

My rating: 2.5 stars

I bought this for my boyfriend. I was sick of turning the a/c down to the point where I was freezing (which takes a lot...I tend to keep my house pretty cold...my dogs hate it), so I was trying to find a lapdesk he would actually use. So far he's hated the three I've tried, probably since he tends to hate lapdesks in general. I saw this one -and it was going to be the last one I tried, and I'm so glad I did!! He has used it ever since - despite the 'you wasted money' look on his face when I showed it to him.

He forgot it home this past weekend when he was traveling, and after he got home earlier today I realized I need to buy myself one since I really didn't want to give it back to him. It's super comfortable to use - no bulkiness that you usually experience with these - and while neither of use a mouse, the slide out was still really useful for me since I could rest my notepad there while working & use it to jot down quick notes.

It fits his 15\\" macbook pro (ancient...but I think it's still pretty close to the same sizes as the current macbook pro's) and of course it easily fits my 13\\" macbook pro.

It doesn't seem to do much for the heat - but I wasn't expecting it to since none of the lapdesks I've ever used with a solid plastic surface ever do. But it's better than placing it directly on your lap since it removes your body heat from the equation.

And for the price - you really can't beat that...overall great buy.

Instances.input:
After receiving the drivers from the company via email, I installed the card and started up 10.8.2.

USB 3.0 devices are hit or miss if they're detected. My USB 3.0 hub is completely ignored and doesn't show up in System Info, my external hard drive shows up as a device but no disk is mounted, ever. USB 2.0 devices show up, but my [[ASIN:B0070UFMOW FiiO E17 USB DAC Headphone Amplifier, 18-pin Docking Interface]] can't be used at 24/96 - the sound breaks up constantly as if it can't transfer quickly enough. The couple USB 3.0 devices I have which do work, only show up after the computer is rebooted.

Unless the company releases a firmware update or a fixed driver, this card is basically worthless, sadly.

For those who are interested, the card shows up as:

Etron USB3.0 Root Hub Simulation:

Host Controller Location: Built-in USB
Host Controller Driver: EtronUSBxHCI
PCI Device ID: 0x7fc900007052
PCI Revision ID: 0x7fc900000000
PCI Vendor ID: 0x7fc900001b6f
Bus Number: 0x21

UPDATE: I have since returned the card; I purchased a [[ASIN:B00570PQAC Fresco Logic FL1009-200 DriveStation SuperSpeed USB 3.0 PCI Express 2-Port Interface Card - 5 GBps - Mac OS - Windows 7(32/64-bit)/Vista/XP - Includes NEW and Updated Driver PLUS Included Is a Molex SATA Power Adapter Cable]] and it works perfectly under Mac OS 10.8.2 with no drivers needed (Mac OS includes support for the chipset).
Seagate was helpful setting this up for my mac...we will see how it all goes from here.  Hopefully they will take another call from me, not tell me to call Apple...

I bought this recently as a spare in case my other GT701R modem dies. I will probably keep it despite a few disappointments since USB modems are hard to find, and I have had good usage out of my other modem. I was somewhat disappointed by this for a few reasons:

First, it's a much older version of the modem I currently have. Because of this it appears to have a few minor flaws that may have been fixed by the GT701R. Nonetheless, there may be workarounds for these.

The second thing about this modem is that it's a Qwest-branded modem, with Qwest firmware. Qwest was acquired by CenturyLink several years ago, so I hope this does not cause a problem. However, the Qwest firmware does provide a QoS feature that may be useful for certain traffic management scenarios.

The one thing I required from this modem is a USB interface for the way I network my two computers - saves having to purchase an external router. And the external power switch is a plus - much easier than having to unplug and replug the AC adapter.
output: A Good Little Modem - If You Can Find One.

Instances.input: The ASUS tablet when it works it's excellent. Had it repaired by the manufacturer. A month later started acting up again. Pressed the reset button. Reinstated all applications, also added new ones. No more problems. Works beautifully. Got WIFI info from my family and picks up the stores Wifi without a problem. Installed security n virus protection too, thru Google apps. It's better to be safe than sorry. Speaker is lousy, connected to external speakers.  Electronics is like a child you gotta figure out how it works and make adjustments when needed. Enjoy. :-)

then the fan started rattling after about 4 weeks of on and off usage. Still is a great product but hearing this rattling noise is extremely distracting and unwanted. The capability of being able to move the fans anywhere with the magnets is great and I really love that feature. It is fairly heavy as well when combining it to my 15\\" hp envy but it lets your laptop breath when you have it on your lap and the tilted design helps angle for when you're typing. Even without the fans it will give your laptop that breathing room needed, just be sure to remove the fans to allow for more airflow.

Edit 12-6-2012: Ok, it's been about 3 months and it was still bugging me that the fan was rattling, thus not letting me use the fans to cool the laptop. So I read around on ways to solve this problem and I found a solution that suggested using [[ASIN:B0083V8H0I WD-40 110054 Multi-Use Product Spray with Smart Straw, 8 oz.]] while this isn't the same model I used it's still the same product. So, I pulled back the affected fan a little bit to be able to spray into the bearings with the nozzle. I cleaned it up, plugged it in and now it works like before no rattling, YESS!

This might be only a temporary fix to my problem but for now I can actually use the fans again so I'm satisfied. Hope this helps any potential buyers should they ever encounter this kind of problem, cheers.

Instances.input: The drive gave up in less than 2 months. Last time though I left it plugged in and put my computer into the sleep mode. Right away I heard a clicking noise coming from the enclosure. Not thinking about it much, I simply pulled the USB cable out. 2 weeks later I was about to do another backup. I plugged the drive in and, as you might've already read this in other reviews, my computer refused to recognize it as a drive. I tried plugging it into 2 other laptops with same results.    P.S. Toshiba replaced the failed drive. No charge, I had to pay for shipping though. Thus I've upped the score from 1 to 2 stars just to be fair.   After the initial experience, I now make sure I disconnect the drive before shutting down my computer. And I don't think I'll be carrying this thing around with me just in case, so portability is out of question.

I got this docking station a couple of weeks ago but got around to testing it only last week.
This dock was a huge disappointment.
At first it seemed to be working - I inserted a hard drive and it was identified quickly enough. I started copying files to local drives and saw transferring at usb 3.0 speeds, which was great. But then suddenly the copying stopped with an error that the usb dock has malfunctioned. I figured it was just a random error so I unplugged and plugged it again and it got back to working.
But then it stopped again. I tried inserting different drives (I have 3 different hard drives from different manufacturers) - with all of them the same thing happened: I got anotification of a usb malfunction and I had to either unplug or even worse - restart the pc, in order to get the drives identified again.
I even went as far as to format the hard drives, thinking naively that maybe the issue was with the hard drives and not the docking station. But of course it didn't help.
I noticed that if I only plug in one hard drive at once - there was a slight chance that I was be able to transfer files for a while longer - but that helped only for a little while. Even with one hard drive the issue happened constantly.

BTW Yes it gets hot, incredibly hot, but I could care less as long as it actually worked, and it didn't.

So, in hopes of finding a solution, I turned to the manual that came in the box.
It had absolutely nothing written in it. No troubleshooting guide, no referral to any technical support - absolutely nothing.
I even tried to google search my tech issues, but since the brand is so unknown I got zero results.
Life lesson - always check the product you buy has support. This one certainly doesn't.

Now I'm stuck with a $35 door stop. Do yourself a favor and don't buy this product.

matt finish

Cons:

the cord could be micro USB instead of Mini, for better compatibility.

Overall. my typing experience has been much better with this keyboard. I actually didn't buy this mainly for gaming (i do game a little), i bought it mostly for writing papers, as odd as that might sound. I actually type much fast now, without the straight i would get on a membrane keyboard.

I read a couple dozen of these reviews, so forgive me if this tip has been mentioned hundreds of reviews ago! I just stumbled upon it and thought it might help some folks who have had difficulty getting good signal strength and speed from this router (while others have had great success).    I installed this router the other day in my home. I have an older iMac, older MacBook, new iPhone 3Gs, and a new iPod Touch on the new network. The signal strength and speed was very good (obviously much better than before with a 54 Mbps Netgear router). So I was happy with that.    But I also have a new Dell laptop with Windows XP Professional for my full-time home office up in the attic (three floors from the router). The signal strength up there was now not very good, and the speed, which previously was 54 Mbps, or very close, actually fell below 20 Mbps at times. I called D-Link support, which was fast and professional (and free). They had me make some simple changes to values in two fields within the Advanced Wireless tab of the router setup screen (using router IP address and a web browser on the network). This helped, but much less than I had hoped. They did tell me not to update the firmware, BTW, from what my router shipped with.    After the call ended, I was looking through the tabs in the router setup from my web browser and decided to turn On the Guest Network, which by default is Off. I did so using the same SSID as my main network, but added a number at the end. It also has WPA Security, and is on 24 hours a day, and I did not check the box enabling access with the other network. When I closed out of the router set up screen (and the router reboots by itself) the signal strength shot up dramatically and the speed was now at 130 Mbps in the attic. The speed fluctuates between 78 and 130 daily, which is fine by me. This second network is 2.4 Ghz (not sure what the main network is).    Now I use the Mac hardware on the main network, and my Dell laptop for work on thesecond network. This fix worked out great for me, hopefully it helps someone else!
output: Tip for better signal strength and speed...

INITIAL THOUGHTS, PROBLEMS, AND SOLUTIONS  I bought this product refurbished from bestdigitalbuy. I was happy with the product on first use. Later that night upon using it I was getting ready to install windows 8 on it when all of a sudden the tablet died even though it had 50% battery left! It would not turn back on and I was confused. I plugged it in charged it back up to 100% and it happened again at 60%! I contacted bestdigitalbuy and said my product seemed to be defective. They replied back quickly and with a solution! The BIOS settings for the battery needed to be updated. I followed the steps that they gave me and BAM! Just like that my tablet was functioning properly and running down to 0% like it should.    BIOS BATTERY SOLUTION (THANKS TO BESTDIGITALBUY)  [...]    FINAL THOUGHTS AND OPINIONS  I love this tablet and it is the perfect alternative for a new windows 8 tablet. Though it does not come with windows 8 installed you can install it yourself and it runs smooth and great. Not to mention it is 400-600 dollars cheaper than the new ones. It also comes with the keyboard dock for fast typing and easier use of microsoft office programs. In the end you get an amazing full windows tablet for the price of a low end 16gb iPad. Thats an amazing deal!    I recommend purchasing this product from the seller bestdigitalbuy.
output: Some initial problems but bestdigitalbuy helped!

Instances.input:
We purchased two of these units to upgrade our old logitech remote controls, and couldn't be happier with the outcome. The SmartRemote software has been easy to use and allowed us to customize our home theather experience. The fact that it's a full-fledged tablet allows us to check imdb, Nest thermostats, or just surf the web right from our "remote".

Overall, the unit is fast and solid, especially when compared to higher-priced altneratives.

If you are looking for nothing beyond another home network storage drive, this one is fine. If you are looking for network storage that you can access from anywhere, like a personal cloud, this product fails miserably. The major problems are lousy access apps and terrible support, better known as "the industry standard" these days.

After having temporarily lost the charger and my light, the storage pocket is a godsend. And after having dropped the kindle more than once, I like the Latitude's holds.  I've had the neoprene sleeve holder which is great for packing in my purse and drops, but lacked the slippery fingers protection while reading. I've already lost the top 1/2 inch of screen in 5mos. The Latitude seems to pack just as compactly as the neoprene, but with the accesories attached. I hope it holds up well.

I had the same problem with 2 small Logitech laptop mice and I hoped (in vain) this heavier (and more expensive) trackball would be stronger. Pressing the (most used) left button once now often gives double clicks: I want to delete one mail, the trackball deletes 2 or 3. I want to check a radio button, the trackball quickly checks and unchecks it. I close the top window of several stacked full screen windows, the mouse or trackball decides to close 3 (the close buttons being one under the other). I position the cursor in a text (1 click), the trackball selects a word (double click). I am a software tester, during manual (not automated) testing this hardware problem often causes unwanted effects.

When new the trackball was very light to move. I could "throw" the cursor from one side to the other with a quick thumb movement. With time the ball moves more difficult, I cannot throw it anymore. It requires several movements of my thumb to get the cursor over the screen. I have to take out the ball, wrap it with a soft cloth and carefully clean the contact points (support points) inside the housing, and it will be better again, but never like new, and more frequent cleaning is required every time to keep the ball rolling.

It's also more difficult to do precision work with the trackball (selecting text with very small font, working in Photoshop). A mouse is better there.

The only advantage of the trackball is that it puts less strain on my wrist. Until now I don't have thumb problem. So maybe I go for another trackball instead of a mouse, but whatever I choose, it won’t be Logitech.
output: Bad contacts inside the mouse buttons after less then a year.

This router was a disaster.  I tried to set it up behind an ActionTec modem.  At first, it worked OK for some of the computers in my network, but not all.  For several computers, it did not see them at all and would not provide them with a network connection.  This was true for both wired and wireless connections.  After an hour or two, it stopped working almost completely.  For the few minutes it would work (for some computers on the network, not others), it would regularly drop the internet connection.  Anytime I would try to access the browser interface for the router, it would hang.  I performed a factory reset several times, and had the same problems. I got this so we could control the HTPC from our bed. It is very light weight, has very good typing feedback (for a rubber dome), and doesn't have range or connectivity issues.    - It will not wake windows 7 from sleep correctly. It is not a problem with just this particular keyboard, but all wireless keyboards AFIAK. This is a HUGE flaw and I almost considered returning it after this finding.    - The key layout is not acceptable to me. The function key is where control should be, making the commonly used control +tab, w, and t awkward. Shift, tab, and control should all go along the left side so your fingers can easily find them. How often do I need to engage the (sad excuse for a) number pad? One more thing. The function key ONLY enables the number pad. There are no other functions. Why not get rid of the function key and replace it with a number lock key?    - The touchpad is very dumb. I assumed that the scroll feature would work as it does on laptops, where if you move up and down on the rightmost side it would automagically know that you want to scroll. Not so, instead the right side of the touchpad is a permanent scroll bar. Go anywhere near it during normal operation, and it likes to scroll. You learn to use only the left side of the touchpad, but still very lame.    - I think it shipped with nearly dead batteries. The first set only lasted a few days.    Basically, the marketing department designed this by committee. They turned a great concept brought to them by some insightful manager or engineer, and came out with something that isn't quite right.
Battery pack arrived as scheduled and worked perfectly.  I'm back to getting 2 hours between charges on this battery.  No complaints with this purchase.  We'll see how it performs in the long run.

Instances.input: First off I want to say I use this device for recording Xbox 360 gameplay only so I will be relating to that for most of this review. I have a lot to say about this device and it is all good. My friends and I are in a Xbox clan and we like to make montages of our gameplay, and I love to commentate. To do this we have to record gameplay onto our computer and edit the footage or make a voice-over(for commentaries). We usually have to use 2-3 programs. One to record, and sometimes only iMovie but sometimes Final Cut Pro and Adobe After Effects. In our clan, 3 of us have a Happauge and one has an EyeTV. We have come to find that the EyeTV hardware sucks for this process because you have to buy about 10 different splitters which can create a lag between what your Xbox is doing, and what your TV is showing. We also found that despite the terrible hardware, the software was outstanding. If you have that program up, and you just forgot to record your gameplay, you can go back through  what you just played and record it. Does that make sense? I'm not sure you can check out the EyeTV software on your free time. ANYWAY. We also realized Happauge's software is for PC. We all have macs. EyeTV software is for macs so we downloaded that legally (although we thought about the torrent) and it even has a hardware list to choose your device on and Happauge is on it! To conclude, buy the Happauge, and get the EyeTV software.

I had no problem with the assembly and felt that it was a clever design.  The trick for the hard-to-reach screws is a magnetic screwdriver.  Using that makes the assembly easy.  When the fan works, the unit functions perfectly.  When I initially replaced a \\"fanless\\" enclosure that had overheating problems with this unit, the overheating problems disappeared.  I just wish that the fan were more reliable.

I bought this to replace one of my older adapters.  The one this replaced was about 4 years old and I had lost the drivers for it, but was still able to use it with the M$ BT stack.  This one beats it in every way other than it's class 2 vs class 1.  This was no big deal for me since my priority was throughput over range.  I mainly use it to tether my phone to my laptop for EVDO service.  My old adapter would only connect at 1.0 Mbps.  Not bad, but it was bottlenecking my speed.  This adapter connects at 2.1 Mbps, so the actual connection is faster and I'm sure the EDR helps with the throughput.  The adapter says it will connect up 3.0 Mbps, so I guess my phone tops out at 2.1.  It says it also supports Sactternet and connections with up to 7 other active slave devices.  I haven't had a chance to test this feature yet, but would come in handy if I were to also use a headset, A2DP, mouse, and keyboard at the same time.      Range seems about right.  I got about 30ft (and that's with 2 walls and a washer/dryer in between) before the connection became intermittent.  For those wondering why this is not a class 1 it's probably because there is trade-off when it comes to range.  You can ether have more range or more throughput at the expense of the other.  I don't think there are any class 1 adapters that are also v2 + EDR.    I noticed someone else say that it did not just work out of the box.  For it to just work, it would have to be compatible with M$'s BT stack (I don't know if this one is, I didn't even try it).  Even if it worked, I've always found M$'s BT stack to be a little lacking in features and settings.  If you get this, do yourself a favor and use it with the included drivers (which are Widcomm 5.1, btw).  Important thing with BT drivers is to run the install shell before connecting the adapter.  Just follow the instructions, they are refreshingly very clear.      Supported Profiles:  DUN, FAX, BPP, LAP, SPP, GAP, HID, HCRP, FTP, OPP, A2DP, GAVDP, HSP, PAN,BIP, SYNC, AV, GOEP    Pros:  - Price  - BT v2.0 + EDR  - Supports Scatternet and up to 7 ACTIVE slave devices  - Uses Widcomm 5.1 drivers (versus Blue Sol that usually comes with cheaper adapters)    Cons:  - Class 2  - Does not come with a cap (IMO, just another thing to lose, and mine stays plugged in anyway)    I'm ordering 2 more to replace my other adapters :)
output: Can't beat it for the price

Bought the 32GB for my Disney World vacation and I took a LOT of pictures and videos and still there was so much memory left and the price was unbeatable!

It was delivered on time and manufactured by a company that gives every indication of caring about their quality. I bought several items such as the Cat5 cable, and it is all at least as good as expected, with an invitation to call them with any problems.

Well to start let me tell you that I don't usually overclock my computer because I lack the experience and by the time I need to overclock to get the performance boost there usually is a newer better and cheaper version of the item I should overclock (CPU, mobo, RAM or even video card), so with that in mind I can't review the overvoltaje usage or the easytune software. What I can tell you though is that this board is sturdy, well made the joints on it work perfectly, no loose parts, heavy with everything well placed and secured. If you do everything right the first time there shouldn't be any problems at post. Drivers available at the website are current and ready for Windows 7 and this is one stable board by all means, system temperature never goes past the 40 C even though room temperature is usually around 26 to 28 C.  Paired it with an [[ASIN:B003FVNC0Q AMD Phenom II X6 1055T Thuban 2.8 GHz 6x512 KB L2 Cache Socket AM3 125W Six-Core Processor - Retail HDT55TFBGRBOX]] and would probably get the [[ASIN:B002QG2H7K Corsair Cooling Hydro Series H50 All in One High-performance CPU Cooler CWCH50-1]] to do some very mild overclocking, also 2 kits of [[ASIN:B002N19KAK Kingston HyperX 4 GB Kit (2x2 GB Modules) 1600 MHz DDR3 Desktop Memory KHX1600C8D3K2/4GX]] and there was no problem at all with the BIOS reading everything correctly. I suggest you get a SATA 3 hard drive to take advantage of the onboard SATA3. If you are a gamer such as myself you already know that you need a separate video card, if you're not then the onboard video should be enough for even some 720p videos but I haven't tested it yet  The only con I can think of is the lack of USB ports at the back, I've used all the ports including the USB 3.0 ports for my devices (yes the USB 3.0 can work with USB 2.0 devices but you get 2.0 speeds) and even then I still need about 3 more ports at the back.  I do recommend this board and bought it because I had the LGA775 version of Gigabyte for years and it was as stable as a mountain, Gigabyte makes quality products.
output: Awesome board as has been expected from Gigabyte

But, now that I've have had it a bit, the color has really grown on me, therefore I'm glad I spent the extra few dollars. This is due to the fact (which I like and use mine 90% of the time flat on its back), is the cover is very supple. The fit is absolutely perfect. It was made for this tablet. I wish all of my covers, albeit my iPad Retina Lifeproof Nüüd fits impeccably, fit this good, and at this price point.
So, bottom line.....if you're looking for a great fit, protective case, at a great price.....look no further. Buy this case. If you're looking for more of a "kickstand", all plastic case, still look at this, but the case is a whole lot better than just a plastic, fairly good fitting "kickstand". That's my 2 cents.

Instances.input:
I had recently sold my last headset, and needed a cheap one until I could get a really nice headset. I looked at these and saw the positive reviews and thought I'd give 'em a shot.

SOUND: These actually sound pretty good for the money, better than I expected. Not as good as a headset like the Turtle Beach X12, but good enough for gaming.

MICROPHONE: The microphone on this headset seems to be good quality, my friends tell me they can hear me clearly. I also like how it's short and folds back in the headset.

COMFORT: I'm guessing these are supposed to be over-ear headphones (meaning the earcups cover over your ears, not press against them), but the size of the earcups are so small that people with bigger ears like me might find them uncomfortable. The main reason for this is because the padding is thin and not very cushion-y. After just 30-40 mins of gaming, I started feeling slight pain on my ears. If comfort is your #1 priority, these might not be the best choice for you.

QUALITY: From what I feel, this headset is fairly sturdy, and shouldn't break easy if you treat them with care (meaning don't throw them at your wall or step on them.). The cables seem to be of decent quality, and the volume control on the cord works well.

TL;DR

For the low price, this headset sounds good and the mic is good, but it's not the most comfortable if you have big ears or if comfort is your #1 priority when it comes to buying headsets. Should mainly be bought as a temporary headset until you can afford a nicer headset.
output: Good mic and sound quality, but not very comfy

They said they would ship me a new Kindle and have it to me by Monday Dec 10. On Friday, Dec 7 at 2pm UPS was knocking on my door with my replacement Kindle. I received a new kindle in under 24 hours. They didn't wait for me to return the defective kindle before the new one was shipped. Now that is outstanding customer service. I will now try my 2nd Kindle and hope that the \\"line\\" does not appear on this device in a week. Amazon, you are great and I will keep buying from you.

Instances.input: I used to use a mac book pro, so there are things I miss about mac having moved back to pc. I've had the laptop for over a month now, and for the most part, it suits my needs - word processing, internet, some design work. Windows 8 seems like it was built for a touch screen, which this laptop is not, so that's frustrating, but a Windows 8 problem. Also, one of the reasons I purchased this laptop was because I thought the touchpad was going to be like a mac - click with one finger or click with two fingers for right click, spread fingers to zoom, multiple fingers to scroll - but it doesn't. The spread fingers to zoom does work, but there is a small area at the bottom to right click and small area to left click. However, with no raised button, it's difficult to tell where this area is unless you're looking at it instead of the screen. I also can't get scroll to work for me. AND, the pad is so extremely sensitive that the slightest brush of your palm/wrist while typing will end up accidentally cutting/pasting or moving the cursor. Also very frustrating. I enjoy the color, the sound is fine unless you have it on a blanket/carpeted surface. The screen seems larger than I expected, which is great, but it's also a bit heavier than I was imagining.

I have a 3 year old who likes to play on \\"daddy's ipad.\\" Like most 3 year olds, her hands get sticky, and that gets my ipad sticky.  I bought this to try it out, (the big draws being price, easy to apply, and WASHABLE) and I love it! It feels thicker than other screen protectors, but no functionality is lost.  I admit I was skeptical about the 100% bubble free guarantee, but it delivers.  The rigid shape of the protector is the key I believe.  It applied perfectly on the first try, and I just let my 3 year old have at it.  I expected to see the normal fingerprints (and I was planning on just washing the screen and re-applying) but they aren't there.  I took it off and washed it anyway, just to test that out, and it reapplied just as well (I let it dry for about 20 minutes before re-applying).  Same result as before! No bubbles, and it stuck on great! And it looks great.  I have a black Ipad, and the black outline matches perfectly.    This is a great product at a great price! I highly recommend it! The only thing I don't like about this product is the instructions.  It is simply 3 pictures with little text.  (Very similar to IKEA furniture instructions).  It's very self explanatory, but it would be nice to know a little more , (ie how many washes it can handle and still stick, what to do if it doesn't adhere correctly, etc.).    That said, I really am a fan.  I just ordered another one in white, to be able to tell them apart.

I tried to live with it but it would lose power at times even without moving the cable.  I ended up removing the drive and throwing this thing away.  I'm aware that when I buy something very cheap like this that I risk buying useless junk.  Some things turn out to be a bargain though, this just wasn't one.

I was really excited to use this case, but the excitement wore off when I realized that this is the kind of case that you install pretty much permanently.

It's not literally impossible to take off, but very difficult (and interestingly not covered in the instructions!). So hard that you'd think twice about putting it on (also somewhat of an ordeal) for a limited period of time. So in other words: this is a case that you put on and leave on.

I'm not a big fan of the "screen protector" which, although maybe protecting the screen from scratches, makes using the touchscreen unpleasant because of the texture of the cover, as opposed to the nice smooth glass.

Out of all (I think 6) angles that you can stand the case in it's base, I could not find one that was comfortable to work on.

The long and short of it is: if you have a need to have extra protection of your iPad (rough working environment or kids) and plan to permanently keep this on - it's a nice solid case with good cutouts and covers for all the various iPad ports.

If you just want to use it once in a while for travel or to hand off to a child, it's not worth the effort.
output: Not easy to put on, impossible to take off

Instances.input:
Initially, the modem worked great. I was getting over 135 mbps download, I normally get about 100 mbps beofre the 'upgrade.'. After a week though, the speed would drop to less than 2 mbps. I would have to reset the modem and the speed returned to 130 's again. This went on for a couple weeks. At first, it was daily, eventually every 2 -3 hours. I contacted ARRIS customer support. They ran some tests on the modem and assured me my modem was fine and passed the blame onto the cable provider. I had several technicians from cable company come out to trouble shoot. They ended up replacing my line from the main box in the street to my box on my lawn. Then, the line from the box on my lawn to the box on my house. Eventually replacing the line in my house upto the modem. They also replaced the components in these boxes. After about the 15 visits and 2 months later, with the cable company insisting that it was a problem with my modem and ARRIS insisting that it was the cable company, I listened to my wife's advice. I hooked up my old sb141 modem. Now I am getting 140 mbps downloads consitently. ARRIS has managed to drag this along for over 30 days so I can't return the modem.

On a brighter note I have brand new cable lines run from the main box in road into my house.

I have been a strong supporter of the SURFboard modems for 4-5 years, starting with the sb121, then the sb141 and then sb 161. I have never had a problem with them until the sb183. The sb141 was probably the best modem they made. Product quality have suffered since they were taken over by ARRIS. Customer support is disappointing. If you own the sb141 keep it and don't waste your money upgrading to sb183. If you are looking to buy a modem, get the sb141 and hope that is does not break, because ARRIS does not stand behind their product.. Or go with some other company.

Please that once the cable company replaced all of my lines, the sb141 was as fast as thesb183.
output: save your money, get the relaible sb141 instead

I didn't have any problems with their router's wireless. But, when I purchased it, I didn't realize that the NAT connection software has a hard coded connection inactivity timeout. I thought it was my ISP. But, with some research after finding SSH Keep Alive didn't work, I realized it was the way this router comes configured. It's really annoying if you job involves SSHing into a large number of servers and running commands. If you change windows and work on a different server for a few minutes when you come back your connection has dropped.  You have to constantly keep reconnecting and re-authenticating. My web research seemed to suggest all D-Link routers are like this. Hopefully, they will change their software in the future to allow NAT configuration adjustments since there's no benefit to them for how it currently (doesn't) work. But, I use TP-LINK routers that allow persistent idle SSH connections and recommend them to all my Linux user friends. One Star because of the extremely annoying timeout configuration.

I had already bought a Griffin Survivor Case for my iPad2 before I bought the Otterbox case, the Griffin cover has much more, thicker and durable, rubber covering the body and edges of the iPad2 plus it has a built in plastic screen cover already on the case that covers the iPad2.  When I received the Otterbox cover for my iPad2 this week, I was expecting the same if not better quality than the Griffin case that I bought, but the Otterbox cover really won't provide the protection than I have come to expect after using the Otterbox line for my smartphones.  The one thing that I really like about the Otterbox case is that the plastic cover can be taken off and it has a built in mechanism inside of the cover where you can place your iPad2 in two different positions and it will act as a stand to keep it upright for viewing or typing depending on your needs.    If you're at home and don't use your iPad2 for anything outside of the house, this Otterbox case would work just fine, if you use your iPad2 while traveling on the train, vanpool or carpool to and from work, or use it for work and have it out in the elements then I would humbly suggest buying the Griffin case instead.  I would also suggest buying a little padded case with a shoulder strap for your iPad2, cords and accessories, that provides a little more protection and you can place this separate case in your backpack and/or just pull it out when you run to the coffee shop or out for errands and you don't want to lug around a huge backpack.    Other than that, I was slightly disappointed with the Otterbox case for my iPad2, I may switch back to my Griffin Survivor Case and use the Otterbox case as a backup or give it to someone who needs a cover for his or her iPad2.    The Griffin Survivor Case for the iPad2 can be found on Amazon.com [...]    The separate case, with shoulder strap that I would humbly suggest to carry your iPad2 around by itself can be found on Amazon.com [...]    (Make sure that you get a carrying case that's big enough for what will an extended size for both the iPad2 and the bigger protective cover, which will make the size of the iPad2 slightly thicker, longer and wider)    Dave

This is an excellent set of laser-tag guns for adults as well as children. Myself and several friends used to play tag at the local roller rink, however this was becoming a bit pricey to do regularly. This was one of the first sets of guns that we located online, and decided to give them a shot because of the high reviews. We have not been disappointed. We typically play at the local park, so we've really stress tested these guns. I would highly recommend if you can get a group of people interested (at least 4 is ideal).    Range:  Guns allow for team or solo play. Range is surprisingly good. We are able to consistently get hundreds of feet (easily 300+) of precision and accuracy even in bright daylight. We can basically target each other from opposite ends of the clearing at the center of our park.    Feel/durability:  Guns have a good, solid feel and weight is good. You don't feel like you are going to break them during normal use. We play with 3-5 sets of guns, and no one has had any serious malfunction over the course of the first year. Battery life is also surprisingly good. I would have expected to eat batteries, but even with cheap batteries you will get (at least) weeks of life.    Gameplay:  Solo or team battle (2 selectable teams). Guns are loud and bright which ads to the experience. Reloading adds a degree of realism: you have to eject the cartridge from the handle and then push it back into the gun. Guns rumble when you are hit, and have a slight recoil when you shoot. Gun holds six shots at a time and life can be set at 10 or 25 hits. LED meters on both sides of the gun show you how much ammo you currently have loaded, and how much life you have left. Guns announce your elimination when you run out of life.    Extras:  We have the scope and shotgun attachments as well. Scope is OK (it's a matter of personal preference). It has a cross-hair and a laser that lines up to show you where you are shooting. Shotgun attachment is a great addition. You can shoot normally through the shotgun, or you can pump the attachment for a shot blast. Shot blast gives you a much wider angle of dispersal, and if you are accurate one shot blast can register both on multiple enemies and on individuals more than once (up to three hits per shot, I believe). Shotgun is also hot-swappable in game.    I'm not sure if this line has been discontinued. It's getting harder to find new (at the time of writing amazon has none in stock). I hope that we can start seeing guns/attachments on store shelves again sometime! New attachment choices would also be nice.
output: Great fun for geeks of all ages

I'd put off buying this stylus for a while. Once I finally used it, I wished I hadn't put it off. The Classic Pen is smaller, lighter and more comfortable to hold and draw with than the bulky stylus that comes with the Intuos 4 and Cintiq 12WX. The rounded shape of the switch makes it more comfortable to use when compared with the squared edges of the original, as well.

Two minor things kept me from giving this 5 stars. First, and this is the same with the original stylus, the nib seats far too deeply into the stylus. I think another millimeter or two of protrusion would make it perfect. Nibs would last a little bit longer and it would feel more natural to draw with.

The second is that my Wacom drivers know the difference between this stylus and the original, which may be fine, but I had to re-map my preferences, shortcuts, radial menus and all for use with this stylus. And, thanks to Wacom's track record with drivers, this meant I had to uninstall and reinstall the drivers (version 6.3.6-3, the newest drivers available at the time). That probably shouldn't factor in to the rating of this stylus and is more an issue with Wacom drivers generally. Just be prepared to reconfigure all of this stuff if you buy the stylus.

In all, everything works and I'm happy and more comfortable digitally painting and sculpting with the Classic Pen. I understand that people's preferences may differ, but if you find the original stylus clunky to use and somewhat uncomfortable, this is the answer.

This security hard drive is great. I really like the added security of the RFID tag. You don't have to use the RFID tag, you can just set up a password, but the RFID is easy to use and only adds a second or so to the connect process. Just make sure you have made a note of the RFID key, should you lose the tag. The drive has a built in virtual CD drive feature. This allows you to boot into a windows image or run diagnostic tools if needed. I like the data destroy feature as well. As a test, I created a windows backup using separate software, Acronis, and used the drive to perform a restore. I then used the self-destruct feature to wipe the drive securely. I tried a lot of different data recovery tools with no success. So if I ever really need to do a secure wipe, I know it will work. The only real con I have and it's just a minor nitpick, is the touchscreen interface. When not using a stylus, I feel like I kind of need to tap harder than I should. Other than that it always seems to get what I selected right. The price may seem a bit high, but if your job involves you needing to take work data back and forth, then this drive is just right. You won't worry about somebody stealing sensitive work information with all the security features.

UPDATE: I received an E-mail today (January 11, 2014), from \\"The Spigen Customer Service Team\\", expressing their concern about \\"Positive\\" feedback for their products. Well that's great, because I am concerned about reasonable value for money spent. Here's something to think about: This product is marketed as having \\"Cushioning Protection for the iPad Mini-Retina\\". But what I received should be more accurately described as a \\"Black Plastic Cover with a Hole in it\\". I paid over $600.00 for a quality piece of electronics that, by the way, I use constantly and thankfully, IT works as advertised. At least you could have provided a clear plastic insert for the goofy \\"Hole\\" In back. Or better yet, just reemburse everyone who had to spend money on a screen protector for the back of their device, in an effort to actually obtain the \\"Protection\\" they thought they were buying in the first place. Look, in an honest effort to create a quality product, give people value for their money. A $30.00 product has felt protection on the inside and a nice, stable kick-stand on the outside. Be honest, you spent more time on your product PAGE than you did designing this product. I stand by my review.

This battery seems to be well made. It doesn't look or feel cheap, and it snapped right into place. However, because my most important factor is maximum battery life, I ended up returning this battery and purchased a much more expensive Duracell brand replacement battery instead.
After following their instructions for initially calibrating the battery, and after 3 full discharge/charge cycles, the maximum time I could get out of this battery was 2 hours 29 minutes. Not bad for less than $40 (including shipping), but I wanted better than that. Before returning this battery, I purchased a Duracell battery (just over $100) to do a comparison. After the same calibration method, I'm getting 3 hours and 20 minutes from the Duracell.
So, more than twice the price for not quite an extra hour of battery life? For me, yes, it's definitely worth it. For you, maybe not. If you don't care about maximum battery life, then I would say this is a good battery at an affordable price. And the company (BTExpert) is very easy to work with. They got back to me right away, and gave me no problems about the return.
A Note About 12 Cell Batteries — If you are unfamiliar with these, the standard battery with most laptops is a 6 cell battery, and fits flush with the bottom of the laptop. the 12 cell in theory doubles your battery capacity (I've unfortunately never found this to be the case), and it also raises the back of the laptop off the table about a half inch. It might look a little funny, but I actually really like this "feature". The cant makes it easier to type, and the extra airspace helps keep the laptop cool.

Good quality material-sufficient thickness to make a good screen protector and be reasonably easy to apply. The end result looks very good.

Pros:
-Comes with lint removal cloth
-Easy to use, rigid squeegee to push out bubbles
-Several pieces of tape to remove lint and dust particles from the underside of film while applying THIS IS A BIG DEAL and it's the first I've seen with this addition...

Cons:
NO INSTRUCTIONS INCLUDED so if you haven't applied one of these before you'll be lost and need to search on-line for how-to
Protective film only on ONE side. This is an issue because the squeegee applies pressure to the upper surface of the protector and can, if pressed with enough pressure mar the finish of the protector's surface.

QUICK HOW TO APPLY INSTRUCTIONS:

WHAT YOU'LL NEED:
a) One wide piece of baking parchment paper (18 inches) cut to a length of about 24 inches OR two pieces of standard width waxed paper cut to 24 inches long.
b) Some spray cleaner for eye glasses is nice but you can window cleaner IF you don't use too much (really just a spritz on a paper towel will do.
c) All the pieces from this kit laid out on the work surface (see step 1, below)

APPLYING THE SCREEN PROTECTOR (DON'T TOUCH THE STICKY SURFACE WITH YOUR FINGERS)
1) Do this on a dust free (or relatively so) surface. That means don't do it on top of your table cloth. Do it on a table top or counter top.
2) Wipe the table or counter top with a slightly damp cloth to remove dust particles then dry it with a piece of heavy paper towel.
3) Spread out a piece of wide baking parchment paper or two overlapping pieces of waxed paper (this is your work surface)
4) Take another paper towel and spritz it VERY LIGHTLY (half a spray or less) and wipe the iPad's screen and case. Get rid of all the smudges, dust and finger prints and be sure the screen is as dry as possible--completely dry is best.
5) Using the same paper towel, wipe the top of the screen protector sheet lightly and make sure it's dry. Do the same to the side that you will peel back before adhering the protector to the iPad's screen. This gets rid of stray dust particles and a bit of the static that builds up on the screen protector sheet.
6) Lay the iPad screen facing up onto the parchment or waxed paper surface and wipe the screen gently and completely with the dust removal cloth from the package. Be sure to get rid of any dust you can see (there's some you cannot see--more on that later)
7) Pick up the protector sheet and grab the tab with the number 1 printed on it.
8) Gently pull back about half an inch to one inch of this protective covering to reveal the adhesive side that will be placed against the iPad's screen.
9) Place this uncovered section on the iPad's screen at the correct end (remember--the camera hole and home button hole do go an specific ends so do this correctly.
10) At this time there may be some bubbles between the sheet and iPad screen. Gently push them out with the squeegee. It's easier to do this when you catch them near the edge that is just beginning to adhere. You can always pull the protector up a bit to get rid of bubbles.
11) PATIENTLY AND SLOWLY keep pulling the protective sheet back and off of the stick side of the protector sheet, laying the protector down a little at a time and using the squeegee to push out bubbles as you go.

THE TOUGH PART---
THERE ARE ALWAYS SOME MICROSCOPIC DUST PARTICLES THAT FIND THEIR WAY BETWEEN THE SCREEN AND THE PROTECTOR SHEET. THIS IS WHEN YOU USE THE DUST REMOVAL TAPE STRIPS.

A DUST PARTICLE CAN LOOK LIKE A BUBBLE. THIS IS BECAUSE THE PARTICLE IS 3 DIMENSIONAL AND AIR DOES SURROUND IT. YOU CANNOT SQUEEGEE THEM OUT.

THESE PARTICLES STICK TO THE UNDERSIDE OF THE PROTECTOR SHEET NOT TO THE iPad SCREEN.

DO STEP 12 BELOW IF YOU HAVE DUST PARTICLES.

12) Get a piece of the dust removal tape-pull it off the sheet it ships on. Hold it with the stick side up. LIFT the screen protector sheet just high enough to get the piece of tape under the protector sheet until you think you're in the correct spot. Stick the end of the tape strip to the underside of the protector and then pull it away. This should remove the dust particle IF you carefully noted the location of the dust particle. This part takes a while and can be frustrating. I learned to live with two or three because some just won't go away. IF A DUST PARTICLE will not come off with the supplied tape, try some scotch tape or a short piece of clear packaging tape-the adhesive is a bit stronger and can pull particles off that the tape strip included in the package will not. Fold over one end so you don't stick it completely onto the sheet as doing so will force you to use another protector.

13) Keep removing the protective sheet, laying the sticky side down onto the iPad's screen, using the squeegee to push out bubbles and the tape to remove microscopic (almost dust particles).
14) Finally the entire protective sheet will lay flat on the iPad's screen. Use the squeegee to push out any remaining bubbles.
15) Use the dust removal cloth from the kit to buff out any smudging caused by over zealous use of the squeegee.

Final note: The whole process takes at least 30 minutes and can take up to 45 to do carefully and properly to produce a result that is bubble free and has as few dust particles between the protector and screen. Take your time, be patient. Have a stiff drink AFTER your done.br />
12) Get a piece of the dust removal tape-pull it off the sheet it ships on. Hold it with the stick side up. LIFT the screen protector sheet just high enough to get the piece of tape under the protector sheet until you think you're in the correct spot. Stick the end of the tape strip to the underside of the protector and then pull it away. This should remove the dust particle IF you carefully noted the location of the dust particle. This part takes a while and can be frustrating. I learned to live with two or three because some just won't go away. IF A DUST PARTICLE will not come off with the supplied tape, try some scotch tape or a short piece of clear packaging tape-the adhesive is a bit stronger and can pull particles off that the tape strip included in the package will not. Fold over one end so you don't stick it completely onto the sheet as doing so will force you to use another protector.

13) Keep removing the protective sheet, laying the sticky side down onto the iPad's screen, using the squeegee to push out bubbles and the tape to remove microscopic (almost dust particles).
14) Finally the entire protective sheet will lay flat on the iPad's screen. Use the squeegee to push out any remaining bubbles.
15) Use the dust removal cloth from the kit to buff out any smudging caused by over zealous use of the squeegee.

Final note: The whole process takes at least 30 minutes and can take up to 45 to do carefully and properly to produce a result that is bubble free and has as few dust particles between the protector and screen. Take your time, be patient. Have a stiff drink AFTER your done.
output: Adequate Product Needs Instructions--Still A Good Deal

I got this as a HTPC primarily to play DivX and H.264 videos off the HD and streaming over the network (the blu-ray player was a nice touch, but I haven't really used it). It turned out to be noticeably choppy while playing back even 720P video connected to a 1080P display. This was using VLC as the player and the default install of Windows x64 Home Premium with all the latest drivers. I wound up replacing it with an Xstreamer Ultra + 256GB SSD for this purpose but didn't ditch the Acer.

The Acer Revo seemed like a nice always-on efficient home-server. I initially wanted to replace its 750GB HD with a 256GB SSD and tore apart the case to see how feasible it is. Unless you are willing to spend a day or so and are willing to break the thing, *DON'T*. The HD is screwed to the motherboard from the underside, and accessing those screws will take a lot of time and patience. I gave up and put all the pieces back in place before completely breaking the thing (BTW, it does have a small/quiet CPU fan with heat pipes connected to the GPU I think -- it's still virtually silent from a foot or so away). After all, a 750GB 5400RPM drive is not too shabby for a system with such a sluggish CPU.

After giving up on the SSD option, I installed Ubuntu Server 11.10 64-bit on it (a Linux distribution). The ethernet and wireless drivers were recognized automatically. I've only used the ethernet drivers but have no reason to believe that the wireless wouldn't work. I haven't tried the audio drivers either... that might be more tricky, but I didn't need audio for this purpose. Audio did work fine over HDMI when using it as a HTPC. So far everything that I need works great as a low-power home server. It seems to do a good job of switching from 800MHz to 1.3GHz when extra CPU power is needed. Don't get me wrong -- it's still slow. But at least I've found it a purpose, and it has pretty nice industrial design. eSATA would be a nice addition though. I don't like the crazy keyboard/mouse pad thing that it came with though... to each their own, but it's alien to those of us who type on regular keyboards on a daily basis. It also had range of less than 15ft, although there is a lot of interference at 2.4GHz here.

TL;DR It's too slow for most HTPC usage. It uses very little power but it comes at a cost. Don't try replacing the HD. It's not silent, but it's very close. Included keyboard/mouse combo is weird. It's pretty good as a slow-ish home server, but that wasn't its intended purpose.
output: A bit underpowered, and the "keyboard" is funky.

This is a Solid Entry Level Computer. We've had it for 2 weeks now and have used it extensively in that time. I've used desktops, laptops, tablets, etc. but this is the first time I've used this type of computer and I absolutely love it. The touchscreen is awesome and it is large, vibrant and bright. I would compare the quality to my retina iPad, it really is that nice. The response of the touchscreen is good and it also has a wireless mouse and keyboard which I am trying to leave off to the side to get a better for feel the All-in-One Touchscreen's original purpose. This is also my second Computer with Windows 8.1 and I must say it is so much easier with the touchscreen. I have been frustrated with my desktop that runs Windows 8.1 using a keyboard and mouse, the swipes and hidden things are annoying. There are versions of this AiO without the touchscreen and I really recommend spending the extra $50 or so on the touchscreen version. It really is what sets this apart from an average computer.

Keep in mind, this is equipped with the Celeron processor so it is not lightning fast but it has performed flawlessly. I've really been impressed with this machine. No internet lag, we've watched videos, full length movies and even our cable TV through an app with no intermediate buffering or freezing. We've loaded apps and games for the kids and they enjoy it as well. For a entry level computer, Dell has really nailed it here. We got this on a lightning deal so the price was rediculously cheap.

As far as setup goes, it was up and running in about 3 minutes. One cord plugged into the wall for power and pop in the tiny USB for the wireless mouse and keyboard. It connected to WiFi instantly and then it was time to start loading my e-mail, calendars, favorite apps, Internet favorites, etc. Once you get everything going, give yourself a few hours for Windows Updates to do its thing. The initial updates can be slow and its likely a combinationof the slower Celeron processor and Windows 8.1 quirks. It will take some time and you'll likely have some download errors. Be patient and after couple of restarts and forcing the search for updates you will get through the tedious process. It's a minor annoyance that doesn't warrant a star deduct in my opinion because after the updates it's been perfect.

This 5-star rating takes into account the value, speed and experience with a basic computer in a home environment. If you are looking for a high-speed gaming computer, look elsewhere. If you are looking for a great value on a computer for regular computer activities, this is the one.
output: Solid Entry Level All-in-One Touchscreen Computer

Right from install, the modem would consistently reboot every 10 to 20 minutes on the Comcast network giving us intermittent internet connections; an extremely frustrating experience when you work from home.  Suspecting some type of Comcast network signal quality problem provoking the modem to do this I called Comcast for technical support. A Comcast technician made an onsite visit to evaluate. All signal and power statistics were within and close to ideal operating thresholds and the cable modem reported the same when it wasn't rebooting.  The Comcast technician then replaced the modem with another model and the problem disappeared, verifying this modem as the source of the problem and not the network.  The technician with 12 years of experience, then went on to state that he was familiar with this particular model, the SB6141, as being notorious for this behavior despite being a "Comcast Approved" device.  He stated that some people have no problems with this model, but a large population do have this problem making for a very inconsistent experience.  The technician advised me to purchase either an SB6121 or Arris WBM760 if you can find it.  As soon as I return this modem I will.

Instances.input: I bought two units of this item for my pre-schoolers, who like to scribble all the time. Since I delivered the items to my boys, they have been hooked up and very excited about their new found slates. The stylus is very easy to handle for them. Though the visibility is not great under low lighting conditions, I still give this 5 stars overall for great build quality and affordability. The erase button works flawlessly. Did I also mention that no battery or utility power is required to use it? That came as a surprise as I had assumed it would require one or two AA/AAA batteries to run. Overall great value.

The keyboard works well and is about the same size as a netbook keyboard which is to say it is slightly smaller than normal but is very workable. Sync was quick and painless and it wakes up in about 2 seconds when needed. The unit i received was slightly damaged or defective as a piece of the cover was loose as if the glue was missing from that piece. It doesn't affect the functionality and doesn't appear to have gotten any worse. The whole unit roughly doubles the weight of the IPAD but it offers good protection against bumps and bangs.

Overall i'm very satisfied.

The bottom cover fits fine the first time I installed it. After about a month, it starts fitting loose. The Speck was the same thing, but it didn't start getting loose until about a year. I am assuming the heat from my Mac is causing this bottom covers to expand and losses it's grip. The bottom cover also doesn't seem to have a full coverage compare to the Speck. The Khomo has this four cheap looking bumper thing for the leg.

The top cover fits well. Maybe, it fits too well. I tried removing the top for this review and I had to pry the dang thing out. I managed to bend my finger nail back. This thing is not coming back on my Mac.

This is an okay case cover. I'm looking into getting another Speck.

I have a full review of the old blade on here as that was the laptop I replaced with this one, I will do this as a review for someone comparing the 2 or at least knows about the old blade. I have had the new blade for close to a month now replacing my old laptop... The old blade. I can tell you with experience as a laptop gamer (alienware m15x, Asus g52 and asus g73 prior to the original blade) this laptop is awesome, it gives you everything you want/expect from a gaming laptop, the biggest downside still being as with the old blade, the price. however at $300 less than the debut price of the original blade it is a step in the right direction for razer to give the customers more bang for you buck. For those of you laptop gamers like myself 17 inch display is the only way to go and the blades display is amazing, very bright, very colorful matte finish with no glare. I really like that razer truly listened to its customers and its critics about the old blade, everything people said was wrong with it or bad about it, razer addressed one way or another, even if not exactly the best way (or the way I hoped for), but they still addressed it for example, storage space (old blade 256g SSD) they doubled the storage space on the new one (500g HDD 64g SSD). I would have really preferred a 512 SSD. However they did address the issue of storage while doing the best to maintain performance with their caching software to the SSD for frequently accessed files. Performance is still impressive with program load times and boot time, however i think the old blade still held a slight edge with its ssd. More examples of issues addressed and fixed with the new blade; lid mechanism much improved, built in speakers clearly better, the secondary functions on the f keys are now backlit, fans are much quieter, all USB ports are now 3.0 up from just one. Last but not least to mention is the increase performance with the quad core i7 and gtx graphics with the 660m, most games (all of the ones Iplay) can now be played on high or even ultra settings at 1920x1080 while pulling descent frame rates. Anyone expecting performance beyond what this machine can do should not be gaming on any laptop. If you are thinking about getting a laptop and this is in your price range do it, you will not be disappointed, the only other laptop in the same class/price range as this is the MacBook Pro 17 inch and its really no contest if your a true gamer.

I purchased a ZaggFolio case for my IPad 3 with keyboard at $99 in July 2012. The skin started peeling off after one year of light use. (The iPad and case didn't even leave my house.) If you expect to get more than one year of use, purchase a case with keyboard from Brookstone or other manufacturer that stands behind their products.

The response from Zagg:
"I am very sorry to hear about the problem you have experienced with your ZAGG keyboard, Evelyn. You can use a mild adhesive to glue the cover back on to the case as this has worked for other customers in the past. Unfortunately, we are unable to replace the keyboard after the warranty has expired that long ago so we apologize for the inconvenience."

Obviously, the manufacturer is aware of the problem, but expects the customer to repair the defective product. Save your money and aggravation and go with another product.
output: Glue fails at 13 months, skin separates from case

Since I have just about completely filled the two hard drives with 3.5TB in my D-Link DNS-321 2-Bay Network Attached Storage, I swapped this hard drive for one of them to see if it would be recognized and could be formatted to work there. Although my NAS software recognized this hard drive and its 4TB capacity, it would not format and install this drive. That was, of course, not the fault of this drive. D-Link's manual clearly states that 2TB is the largest drive supported by either of the two bays, but I still gave it a try.

Next, I ordered a Mediasonic ProBox K32-SU3 3.5" SATA Hard Drive Enclosure from Amazon and installed this drive in it. Using Windows 7.0 Drive Management software, I allocated a single partition for the entire capacity of this drive, did a quick NTFS format and assigned a drive letter. Once I did that and confirmed that the hard drive was working properly, I used my Acronis backup software to mirror copy the 358GB of data and operating system from my Dell Inspiron notebook computer through a USB 3.0 connection to this drive.

When I do a similar backup onto a 1TB 2.5 inch USB 3.0 hard drive from my laptop computer, it usually takes about 3.5 hours. My backup to this hard drive took only 2.5 hours to complete; the obvious limitation being the speed of my laptop computer's hard drive. There is enough solid-state memory on this hard drive, so that when the drive motor has powered down, I can still look at what files and folders are on the hard without restarting the drive. That 8GB of flash memory cache also gives me really fast access to the files.

Computer users should be diligent, if not obsessive, about backing up important business and personal files. Using an external, high-capacity hard drive is one of the fastest and safest ways of doing that. The 4TB capacity of this drive is big enough for me to do eleven full mirror backups of everything on my laptop computer before I need to begin erasing old files. This drive is also fast enough to not make the back-up process a chore. Keeping this drive disconnected from my computer when I'm not backing up files will help prevent it from becoming infected if my computer gets a virus. Based upon my first-hand experience, I believe that this drive would give very good performance in almost any application.ld files. This drive is also fast enough to not make the back-up process a chore. Keeping this drive disconnected from my computer when I'm not backing up files will help prevent it from becoming infected if my computer gets a virus. Based upon my first-hand experience, I believe that this drive would give very good performance in almost any application.
output: Big and Fast ... Just Like I Like Them
