Instances.input: If you don't want to put a bulky case on your iPad mini, but get nervous just putting it down on the table where it can get scratched by your pile of junk, then this does the trick.  I use this with the Smart Cover without any problems.  The screen protector went on tougher than the back, but the small bubbles that were inevitable to show up disappeared after a few days.  The back went on perfectly and gives it a nice glossy look.  Please, watch the video on how to install it and, please, don't get frustrated doing it.  With the installation fluid, it makes it pretty harmless to remove and re-place the film.  So, please, take your time (those of you who watched the video will know what I'm getting at).  Plus, if you just lay the screen protector loosely on top of the screen, you'll see the camera hole doesn't line up quite right.  But, once you actually start putting it on with the squeegee, it stretches a little and it lines up perfectly.  I was also a bit skeptical about the back film covering the rounded corners.  It didn't seem to sit flat right after I put it on, but after it dried over night, it laid down more and I was able to smooth the corners down flat.  I've used it for a couple weeks now and everything is still looking good.  The corners and edges haven't peeled at all.  I also wondered why the hell I'd use a fluid to install this on something electronic, but I was just careful not to get the fluid in any of the holes and had a clothe handy to wipe off excess.  If you're nervous about dropping it, this won't protect against shock.  If you forked out this much money for the iPad mini, you're probably holding it like a newborn baby and won't let anything come near it.  I won't say anything else on that matter so I don't jinx myself.
output: Great for scratch and scuff protection.

Previously I could not connect to the wifi downstairs in my house and I also have horrible cell service at my house. My cell phone service provider provided us with an extension for cell service but it only works when connected to the wifi. Since the wifi didn't reach that far, the cell service extension didn't either. I purchased the range extender so I would get wifi downstairs and in my bedroom for my computer and phone. Voilà!!! Now I get service completely downstairs and in my bedroom. It's full service too- 5 bars.  Setup wasn't too bad-took no more than 15 minutes.  The only reason I gave it 4 stars is because of the price. Still well worth the price though.

I should start by saying that I ultimately upgraded this thing just a few days after having it. I was in the market for an ascetically pleasing computer, with a backlit keyboard and a Core i5 processor, that wasn't an overpriced Mac Book Pro. This laptop fit that bill. I wasn't that impressed with Windows 8. Fortunately this model has Windows 7 drivers, and so that transition was fairly painless. Being an ultrabook, it was difficult to disassemble for the upgrades that I made, but it was ultimately worth it. I replaced the 32GB mSata SSD with a 240GB mSata SSD & I made it the boot drive. I replaced the 500GB Sata drive with a 512GB SSD. I replaced the 4 & 6GB RAM sticks with two 8GB sticks. I replaced the CD/DVD burner with a CD/DVD/BR Burner (9.5mm ultra slim series). With all the upgrades, i still spent less than I would have on a Mac Book Pro, and I have all the features I wanted. The touchscreen monitor, Skullcandy speakers, USB 3.0 and SD/Multi card reader are added perks. The only things I can't upgrade are the integrated video (intel HD graphics) and the display resolution (1366x768). The graphics card is fairly decent (Photoshop & Illustrator CS6 load in less than 10 seconds), but not ideal for gaming. Ultimately, I am pleased with my purchase.
output: Pretty Awesome Performance on a Budget

Instances.input: The title says most of it. I bought two of these almost two years ago, one for work and one for home. I primarily used them to connect a keyboard and mouse to a Lenovo Laptop. From day one I had problems with the hub seemingly going dead - the key board or mouse would just quit in mid-click. We had 6 of these Lenovos at work, and our, since we build USB devices we quickly discovered the Lenovos were slightly off the USB spec in several ways. This made me cut the hub some slack, even though my USB devices did work better when attached directly to the Lenovo.   A few weeks ago the Lenovo died and I replaced it with an Asus. To my annoyance, both my hubs still go dead. I'm off to the store now to try some other brand.  Except for the dying thing these hubs are not bad. The purple light is pretty with the silver finish, and the price was OK. The Power brick is quite weak - trying to charge my phone takes 3x longer on the hub than with the phone's charger. I would not try to run a USB hard drive through this hub.   I'm giving it 3 stars instead of 1 or 2 because both hubs are still (almost) working after 2 years. That's better than a lot of cheap electronics these days.
output: Nice features, but mine hang too often.

This Case Logic Intrata 15.6-Inch Laptop Bag is very functional and is perfect for my wife's 15-inch work laptop. The case offers some nice features. Among the ones we like the best are the slightly wider opening at the top and the shoulder strap that attaches at the back of the case. Both of these are great because it makes it a lot easier to remove the laptop from the case. The carrying handle that doubles as a luggage loop is nice, too. The padding in this case is not over-the-top, but it seems adequate for an everyday laptop bag. (A little more would've been nice, though.) The front zippered pocket fits the AC charger nicely. There's a phone pocket in there, too, but I'm not sure if my wife will ever use it. Nice to have the option, though. As far as appearance goes, this case is not going to win any fashion awards. But the black nylon material and the overall design falls pretty much in line with other Case Logic products we've purchased over the years. And, based on our experience, Case Logic stuff holds up nicely over the years. This is a nice, durable, functional laptop bag. Perfect? No. But way more than adequate.

Will work for a few hours then drop the connection or will completely stop working.(Windows 7 32bit with WRT 150N router). There are a few ways to get working again. Disabling the wireless adapter.If that doesn't work use Windows Diagnostic. If that doesn't work soft reset your router and let it reassign an ip address.If that doesn't work then reinstall drivers and restart computer.If all that doesn't work you have to hard reset your rounter.That means completely wiping your router,reassigning ssid,and turning on security at the very least. Now that just with the drivers that come with the RNX-N180UBE v1086.38.1125.2010  . I alternate between the most recent driver and the one that comes with in box. The solution above will work for the drivers in the box. v1086.38.1125.2010 Now that should tell you that I rather deal with drivers from 2010 than ones from 2011.And that's because drivers issues with 2010 drivers are easier to fix. 2011 drivers will completely stop working.The only way to get up your wireless adapter working again with the most recent drivers is to hard reset your router and/or reinstall drivers. Which means headaches for the people who live with you and use the connection. Buy a different wireless adapter and don't waste your time with RNX-N180UBE.
output: Works for a few hours and then will drop connection or completely stop working.Don't waste your time and money.

The good part to this though is the clips are covered in leather so the Ipad won't be rubbing on plastic or something hard, but still something to be careful with as the when unclipping the case can snap back against the ipad if not being extra careful.

The clip that locks the case closed will rub the side as well.

Also, the stitching has some points that aren't straight or have some thread coming out. Very slight, but noticable if you look for that.

The clips may wear in better later after being mounted for a while. If that is a concern consider the slim case.

This Toshiba 1TB 2.5 Solid State Hybrid is a great choice if you need to replace or upgrade any 2.5 form factor hard drive with a 9.5mm body. A Solid State Hybrid is essentially a hard drive which has a certain amount of NAND Flash memory as the cachet, in this case 8GB of NAND Flash, a SATA 6.0Gb/s interface and the big a capacity of mechanical magnetic disk. It stores the most often used tasks and accessed data in the NAND cache for faster access. (Imagine the NAND Flash cachet as if it were a mini SSD within the SSH).

Besides price, the advantage of a SSH over a SSD, is that the SSHD doesn't have a limited lifespan like all SSD drives do. This SSHD might be still running in another decade, even if by then we will be using much bigger files and I would be needing a bigger drive too. But for now, this 1TB is simply perfect for my needs. I used my Toshiba Hybrid to replace the HDD in my laptop and it gave it new stamina. It reminds me of when I installed a SSD in my netbook and it acted as if I had added RAM and a newer CPU. This time, I noticed the expected increase in booting time, and a significant performance in general.

One thing worth commenting, it's that this Toshiba Hybrid is a 1TB 5400 RPM drive and I just use it to replace a 500GB 7200 RPM drive, besides the significant performance in booting speed, a 5400 RPM HDD uses less energy and gets less hot, so in an enclose case, like a laptop or All-In-One, the 5400 RPM drive is a better choice. Now, remember, we're talking about a Hybrid which delivers a SSD-like performance. This drive is great, I highly recommended it.
output: An awesome replacement for any hard drive of 2.5 form factor

Instances.input:
I have a 3570k and I love to overclock. With my previous cooler, the Scythe Ninja 3 air cooler, I was getting 98c during the IBT stress test at 4.6Ghz w/1.37v. Now with this cooler, at the same voltage, I'm getting 79c, that's a 19c difference. Now I can up my overclock to 4.8Ghz easily. And the Scythe Ninja 3 is no slouch either. It's rated as one of the best air coolers. I knew the difference would be noticeable, but I was expecting about 10c difference, not 20c!

It also comes with this great program that let's you choose between, silent, balanced, or performance profiles. I love this program, as you can control how loud or quiet your system is. And when it's on quiet, it's VERY quiet, close to silent. And that's where I leave it for normal everyday use. When you get it to high performance, yeah, it's kind of loud, but it's also very cool. And balanced mode, is closer to quiet mode than performance mode. And this is where I put it if I'm doing stress testing.

The H100i from Corsair is well worth the 110.00$ they charge for it, because it'll keep you system cooler than any air cooler ever could. And if your any kind of overclocker, you'll want to go with this for your cooling needs.

Instances.input: I bought this from Amazon, took the super-saver shipping and received it two days later, on a Thursday evening.  The packaging was more than adequate and the controller arrived without a scratch on it.  I've now had an entire weekend to play with it so these are my thoughts.    I run Windows XP and, like other reviewers, I ignored the CD and downloaded the latest drivers from the Logitech website.  The programming software works ok, but is nothing special.  My previous stick was the Thrustmaster Cougar and the flexibility of the Foxy software is in a different world to the Logitech one.  That being said, however, I didn't personally use the vast majority of those features and instead downloaded other peoples' profiles from the web.  Hopefully, the community will also supply a large number of profiles for the G940.    There is a minor nuisance with the software in that you can't assign stick functions, program a profile or, in fact, start the software at all without the controller plugged in.  This is inconvenient,  but not a showstopper.    The stick itself feels good in the hand and has a slightly rubbery feel to it.  It has a larger footprint on the desk than any other stick I've owned which, presumably, is to accommodate the force feedback motors.  The micro-stick on the joystick that looks like a POV-hat isn't, and the castle switch is instead used as the POV.  Not sure that I particularly like that choice but the micro-stick can be programmed to act as a normal hat if needed.  I've found I need to keep the dead-zone on the microstick axes relatively high to prevent unwanted inputs in flight as the calibration seems to drift slightly.     The throttle unit also feels decent in the hand but isn't exactly going to win any beauty contests.  The twin throttles separate easily and also recombine easily.  The action is smooth and the friction adjustable.  The lit buttons on the throttle base also function nicely as buttons and, I'm told, will function as working LED indicators in the future.  One of my gripes with the throttle is about the R1 and R2 rotaries.  It would have been nice to have had either a detent or at least some physical means of telling when they were centered without having to look at the painted line on them.  But if you're picky about that you can always file a small groove into the center-point yourself.    The pedals are lovely.  Nice and solid, and wide enough for me.  I'm 6\\"3 and find them pretty comfortable.  I've never actually used any other sim-pedals before but I fly little single engine planes in real life so have a pretty good idea how rudder pedals should feel.    I've been playing IL2 and DCS Black Shark and have been loving the force feedback.  At the default settings the feedback is nice and strong, and the force can be ramped up or down in the Logitech software to suit your tastes.  Using the trim function in Black Shark and having the stick actually stay in the trim position is fantastic and actually 'feeling' your warbird about to enter a stall in IL2 really helps with both my flying and my sense of immersion in the sim.    The 3-axis trims on the stick are great in IL2 and incredibly useful.  Once again, no 'feelable' center position but you can't have everything.    One thing I did after a few minutes of using the stick was to put a little piece of tape over the \\"dead man's switch\\".  This is a little sensor that detects whether the user's hands are on the stick or not and turns down the force feedback if necessary.  It's a nice feature in theory but, especially in black shark with the stick in a trimmed position, I find the stick will jump around if I loosen my grip on the stick and no longer cover the sensor, so I took the decision to cover it up permanently.  I just make sure to unplug the DC power to the stick if I leave it unattended.    Overall, very happy with the product with just a small wish-list for extra software functionality.

The cameras are superb, especially the rear camera, with several options that you can select for various tweaks for lighting, timer, portrait, burst, panoramic etc. My only complaint about the rear camera is that it does not have an LED flash like my Samsung SIII phone or my Motorola Xoom had; but then again, I had recently bought my Wife Samsung Note 3 8 inch tablet doesn't have one either. I wish I had have waited 2 months in buying her Samsung 8 inch tablet and bought her one of these instead and I could have saved almost $200.

One additional benefit to note: While it states that it can accept up to a 32GB Micro SD card, I put in my 64GB Micro SD card and it works, I have much more storage capability than what it states it can handle.

This is my third ASUS product that I have bought, the others included the ASUS EP121 12 inch Windows 7 tablet, a more recent ASUS VivoTab tf810c Windows 8 tablet and docking / keyboard base and this Memo HD7 tablet. My experience with ASUS products has made me a devout fan of their products and I will only buy ASUS products when that is an option.
output: Great Job ASUS: You consistantly deliver a product that users can afford, and that can perform as good if not better than others

We decided to buy this refurbished Kindle for my seven year old daughter for Christmas. Like me, she is an avid reader and the cost of books (and clutter!) was getting to be too much. She is a responsible kid so I knew I could trust her to be reading versus playing apps when that's what she was supposed to be doing. She already used my Kindle so I read up on the kid version and realized that is not what we needed.    I am happy with the FreeTime app trial and will probably stay subscribed to it. My kiddo doesn't have an email address--I didn't want to even mess with having to monitor that--so the FreeTime app let me register the Kindle in my name and add content she could utilize from my Kindle. That way my adult books and magazines weren't clogging up her kindle storage.    The Meyday feature was interesting. On Christmas Day I was surprised it was up and running. However, the customer service rep was new--she offered this up front--and obviously has never used a Kindle before. She helped me but had to put me on hold for minutes at a time while she learned herself. It still wasn't the outcome I was hoping for but it works for now. Plus, during our session we got disconnected at the end.    Bottom line: it's great even for a child who is an acid reader. We borrow books online through our states online library, and it's convenience is amazing.
output: Great product even for a chikd

Instances.input: It appears that many people have a strong Love or Hate relationship with their Fires.   Mine is leaning toward Love, with a dash of disappointment.  The 7\\" size was the initial draw for me to the Kindle Fire. And thankfully it has satisfied me. It feels great holding it and it isn't too heavy.  Also, the Anroid Market is not available on the Fire, but thankfully you can side1oad standard adroid apps.  The battery life is a little less than an iPad.  But Kindles have always been known for their long lasting battery. Even though this is a tablet, but I feel Amazon should have focused on battery life a little bit more.  The response can be sluggish at times, which I presume is because it only has 512MB RAM. This is a media device. At no time should it have any trouble playing a video. Instances.input:
I normally don't like to have an all-in-one solution as hardware of this kind is more reliable separate, but I needed something light for my home/personal use.
This has it all, router, gigabit switch, wireless-N, VPN, multiple SSID, VLAN, IPv6, static IP mapping, IPS, what else would one need? I'm also using this as a site-to-site VPN with another router (WRV54G). Avoid the WRV54G.

If you want a rock solid solution, I recommend the RV series. I replaced a RV042 with this WRV4400N just because I wanted the extra features, but the RV042 is bulletproof where the WRV4400N can be taken to its knees if you throw allot at it and you know what you're doing.

If you are a SOHO or for personal use this should be a great solution. Although if you need something more system critical then I recommend something else. But for what this is and what I am using it for, I love it.

I additionally bought my son the black version who stated that "it was faster/better than playing on my Android phone" (thanks, at least I get my phone back).

My only complaints are that 1) the battery does not stay charged long enough, 2) the charger cord is not long enough)

Would definitely recommend to any and all parents.

My laptop is the MASSIVE ASUS G74SX and finding a case or backpack that would fit without the words 'snug' or 'tight' was getting ridiculous. Add to the sheer size of the laptop there is a power brick... yes, its as large as a brick, you know those red things they make buildings out of? That combo was really redefining what most others called 'extra large'. Extra Large was still not enough for the G74SX and power brick.

This bag fits them both without strain. I really don't need tons of storage.. just haul the laptop and the brick and maybe a mouse and a few cables.

There are some things they skimped on:

The shoulder strap hooks are plastic.. all the 'hardware' is plastic. The latch closure is a metal wire, but every other part of the strap system is plastic.. that kinda worries me when my laptop and brick are weighing in at OVER 10lbs. It also concerns me that the D rings were not double stitched into the sides... that seems like a no brainer when your case is advertised for 18+in laptops... put a few nickles into metal parts and double stitch the weight bearing straps. I can feel rivets where they attached the carry handle... lets hope they are metal and not plastic rivets.

The material seems to be a medium weight.. nothing really light or very heavy.

I'm happy with the case... and would recommend it but I would buy a different case in a minute over this one for the above reasons.
output: Fits the massive ASUS G74SX chumpy plastic hardware

This is my second keyboard from Merc. I had the previous model without the light which made playing in the dark almost impossible, this was the main reason that made me purchase this one.

Keyboard:
The gaming pad section is good although the space bar in this section is not necessarily easy to reach or responsive. The main keyboard (currently use to write this review) is good. The combined numeric/editing function is really hard to handle as you will find yourself usually needing both at the same time. I barely used the special function key beside selecting for the light color.

Also the keyboard is pretty roomy so you may need a big desk space just for it and does not come with wrist rest...

Software:
The keyboard software is far from great which eventually requires upgrading when going from windows Xp to Windows 8. Programming the key for some special game is also a little bit cumbersome, in particular to assign the arrow key to the now traditional WASD combination.
output: Gaming Pad is good but hard to use the combined Numeric/Function pad

Instances.input: Bought six of these for my office, they are flawless!

The case fits the Kindle Fire 8.9" HDX very nicely. When I first put it it the case, it was very snug. the flap the covers and holds the tablet in, has velcro to hold the flap in place so that it reduces the fire from moving around. Like I said, it was already snug so it isn't moving anywhere.

The cut outs for all the buttons, cameras and speakers are precise and have ample room for their functions. The back piece that holds the tablet upright and at angle is large and firm, however - the little flap that holds the stand open, seems a tad bit small, perhaps even flimsy, but so far, has been able to do its job just fine.

The keyboard is much thinner that what the photos show. The buttons felt good to type with and the magnets that hold the keyboard in place on the cover, is strong enough that moderate shaking holds it in place.

My only criticism is that the locking flap that holds the case shuts, is left rather awkwardly in the way when you have the case open like a laptop. One other thing, though not certain if it's the case or the kindle itself or the application - but I have found that in certain situations, when closing the case, the kindle will go into sleep mode, other times it does not and the screen stays on until you remember to push the on/off button to turn it off (or it times out).

For book reading, which is why I really wanted it, it's really great, although the screen glare is too much for outside reading unless you're in the shade. I really appreciated Securifi's top-notch customer service.  The product worked great for almost a year, then died unexpectedly.  When I emailed customer service, they were quick to respond.  They walked me through some troubleshooting and when that didn't work they were quick to replace the defective unit.  They even called me when the new unit arrived to ensure everything was working again.  The new unit works great - it's a simple, easy-to-use product, backed by excellent customer service.

This is a solid mini desktop choice for home users including families and students, or home office use. It's a budget PC that has a lot to offer to a busy household looking for a computer that will allow users to surf the internet, email, complete homework, pay bills, listen to streaming music and watch Amazon Prime programming if desired.

If you're feeling adventurous, this PC could even be connected to a HDTV and used as a Home Theater PC to show Netflix content or similar if desired. (I like to get a [[ASIN:B005DKZTMG Logitech Wireless Touch Keyboard K400 with Built-In Multi-Touch Touchpad, Black]] and hook up PCs via a HDMI cable to my HDTV to enjoy PC on TV!) I would suggest upgrading the memory to at least 8GB before doing this however.

With a Windows 7 Home Premium operating system this Dell is compatible with most all software available for PCs, although it doesn't come loaded with a lot of it which allows you to fill up the huge 1TB (1000 GB) hard drive yourself!

The installed hard drive is a speedy 7200 RPM drive which can be upgraded to an even speedier SSD drive should you desire. (I did it with my Dell XPS running the same operating system and it made an incredible difference in speed and performance when using multiple applications.)

While no speed demon this PC is no slouch either. It's hampered a bit by only 4GB of installed memory (using 1 of 2 memory slots). The good news is that can be upgraded too! You can have up to 16GB of memory installed and that makes a profound difference in the performance of virtually any PC. The motherboard has 3MB of cache which is good - not great, and the processor is good.

Overall, this PC has a lot that someone looking to replace an older desktop would like, at a fair price. It wouldn't satisfy those who need enhanced graphics and sound, but for the price, it's a good deal.

NOTE: I do not own this desktop, but took the opportunity to review it after checking it out at a friend's house, thus there is no 'verified' purchase notation on this review.

-------------------------------------------------------------------

PROS:

+ Inexpensive with solid specs
+ HDMI port
+ VGA (monitor) port
+ Bluetooth connectivity
+ Both USB 3.0 and USB 2.0
+ HUGE 1TB 7200 RPM hard drive.
+ Memory expandable to 16GB with (2) memory slots
+ Windows 7 - still my favorite!
+ 8 in 1 Media Card Reader
+ USB Mouse & Keyboard included.
+ Build quality is good, even at low price point.
+ 1 Year Warranty through Dell
+ Gigabit Ethernet card
+ Not tons of bloatware (unnecessary software) added to this one.

CONS:

- Integrated 5.1 supported sound; no separate sound card.
- Integrated video graphics; no separate video card.
- Only 4GB of memory installed, which is minimal and should be upgraded to at least 8GB for good performance.

SUGGESTED ADD ONS:

No monitor comes with this desktop, but I've had great luck with Dell branded monitors, Planar (3 year warranties on their stuff...) and most recently ViewSonic.

Some you may want to consider include [[ASIN:B00EZSUVHK ViewSonic VX2452MH 24-Inch LED-Lit LCD Monitor, Full HD 1080p, 2ms, 50M:1 DCR, Game Mode, HDMI/DVI/VGA, VESA]], [[ASIN:B009O847CQ Planar PLL2210W 22\\" Widescreen LED Monitor]], and the [[ASIN:B009H0XQRI Dell S2440L 24-Inch Screen LED-lit Monitor]].

Alternatively you can also add this PC to your HDTV via HDMI. Big or small, HDTVs with HDMI ports can work as monitors too!

If you want some speakers to add to your PC, I can recommend this Bluetooth one: [[ASIN:B00MQDBRMO Polaris V8 Portable Bluetooth Wireless Speaker with FM-Radio, NFC, AUX Jack, TF Card Slot, Voice Prompts, LED Display, Build-in HQ MIC for Hands Free Calls, Up to 10 Hours Play Time, 2000mAh Removable Rechargeable 18650 Li-ion Battery. (BLACK)]] which can also be attached via a [[ASIN:B004G3UK5C StarTech.com MU3MMS 3 feet Slim 3.5mm Stereo Audio Cable - M/M]], or these [[ASIN:B00HPQ0H0K ARCTIC S111 USB-Powered Portable Stereo Speakers for Tablet/eReader/MP3/Computers, Balanced Treble/Superior Bass - Black]] which have remarkably good sound for their size.

As for software, I like freebies! On Amazon you can get this one: [[ASIN:B00H9A60O4 Avast Free Antivirus 2015 [Download]]] or a 60 day trial of this one [[ASIN:B00LLQ9API AVG Anti-Virus 2014, 1-User 60 Day Trial [Download]]]. Cnet downloads also has others that are free.

For keeping your PC in top shape with utilities, I also like CCleaner and Glary Utilities.

Another great add-on item for desktop PCs is a powered USB hub. These add connectivity to your PC to power more peripherals as well as giving the user the ability to charge their smartphones and tablets. I've had good luck with most Unitek products, including one that allows me to make my desktop setup a multi-monitor setup: [[ASIN:B00KEZM6B2 UNITEK USB 3.0 Dual Display Universal Notebook Docking Station Hub with DisplayLink HDMI/VGA of up to 1920*1080, RJ45 Gigabit Ethernet Port, Audio, and 2 USB 3.0 Ports, 5V/2A Power Adapter Included, for Windows 8, 7, XP, Mac]].

-----------------------------------------------------------------

SPECS PER DELL:

Instances.input:
My trusty M505 mouse developed a double clicking problem, I bought the M515 to replace it. What a mistake.

The M515 randomly stops responding for 1/2 second. This happens while moving the mouse as well as while scrolling the wheel. It's very annoying and frustrating.

Also, I thought the wheel felt very nice with some weight to it where it simulates scrolling action on a touchpad screen. However, the physical attribute of the wheel itself became an annoyance. The silver edges of the wheel has a hard corner where the M505 has a smooth rounded edge, which is easier on the finger tips.

I like that this has the battery compartment on the bottom as well as an on/off button. However, this is secondary and the mouse must work reliably first.

Not recommended. Try another Logitech mouse. Personally, I'm going back to [[ASIN:B00165XQWW Logitech V450 Nano Cordless Laser Mouse for PC and Mac]]

This is exactly what I wanted and I was thrilled to getting at such an affordable price. I got a new iPad 3 with the Smart Cover as a gift, but I was anxious about not having the back protected. I am a busy mom who throws her iPad in her oversized purse, plays with it with my young kids when we're out and about, and likes to take it on the treadmill. So I wanted something durable, simple and attractive to protect against water bottles, scratches and the detritus in my purse,. This sleeve is perfect. I can fit the iPad with the Smart Cover still on it inside the sleeve.it was a snug fit at first, but the sleeve is gradually stretching. It's a super durable, thicker material, but it somehow avoids being bulky and unsightly at the same time. I can slide in one of those cleaning pads or headphones when I need to without it permanently bulging or marking the sleeve. The colors are a little brighter than they appear, but not enough to make a big difference. I get tons of compliments and people ask me where I get it all the time. I just might buy a second in a different pattern- they are so inexpensive, it would be like getting to change out my purse. :)
output: Awesome quality, especially for the price

I got these speakers on the Dell Daily Deal for less than ten dollars.  They consist of two speakers about two inches in diameter, that are mounted inside tall plastic boxes.  The right speaker has a volume control on top, which is nice.  The volume control has an on/off switch, but no power light.  These speakers increase the sound from my Dell Inspiron E1505 laptop so that I'm able to watch movies without straining to hear.  The sound is a little \\"boomy,\\" but this can be helped if you use the graphic equalizer function in Windows Media Player.  At max volume, loud music or action sequences are distorted somewhat.  Overall it was a good purchase, but don't expect to fill your house with high end music.  Good for the price I paid, but I wouldn't spend $20 or $30 on them.
output: Good basic speakers for your laptop, but not for serious music

Instances.input: After playing on my friends kindle fire hd for the past month I purchased one for myself. I love just about everything about it. A few negatives are that you have to buy a outlet piece for the charger because charging it with the computer is a real pain in the rear. Another thing is the option of having books read to you. Great concept but I wish we could change the voice because the lady on it is annoying. Other than those two things I have no issues with it. First thing I did with it was skype my mom and I was amazed at the quality because it really did better than my computer. Plus I was able to carry it around with me.

Initially I was quite happy with the purchase. It connected more often than not and the static noises only got bad when the battery was low. However, now after 8 months of using it I feel I spent too much on this headset. The battery life never was great but I could watch a few episodes of a tv show in the first few months, however, it started going down exponentially after about 4 months. By now I have to keep it on charge all the time b/c it holds a charge for about half an hour. Well I thought I could at least use it as a non-wireless headset. The problem with that is that you can hear an added noise as it is charging. There is a constant hiss in your right earphone as you keep it plugged in. I was expecting a longer life out of this device and this is my second bad purchase of logitech products so I guess it is time to try something else. Sorry logitech, you just lost me for good.

Overall look and the feel of the keys is very good as everyone else has observed. No installation problems for me.

However the function keys are small and feel awkward. Also the middle mouse button does not seem to generate button code 2 for the X server.

I am going to exchange mine for the DiNovo coredless desktop which is on sale on BestBuy for the same price as this one.
output: okay but a few cons for power users

I received the board in a timely fashion and made the mistake of waiting past the Amazon 90 day return policy to setup my new pc (due to being swamped with work)... I immediately had trouble installing Windows due to ram issues. Eventually I got the motherboard to work, and found the LAN port was dead and the PC would crash every few weeks as a result of a RAM error. After several months of use with occasional crashing the ram issues got worse till eventually the PC would crash several times a day. At this point I decided to call customer support. After being told to replace EVERYTHING, from the ram, the hard drive, the power supply, and even the processor, tech support finally decided to replace the motherboard. Apparently ASUS has an absurdly long RMA process that takes several days to ship out, despite my urgent request that I needed a functioning PC for work.

I have been brand loyal to ASUS for over a decade, telling all of my family and friends to purchase their products when upgrading a PC or buying a tablet. But their unusually difficult technical support is really making me reconsider my opinions of this company. I have wasted dozens of hours with them, as well as money not getting work done because of their strangely rigid and inflexible RMA process.

I will update this post when I get a clear answer on my RMA status and can verify that the new board is working correctly, but right now I'm not holding my breath. As of now, I'd suggest trying out Gigabit, as when ever I have dealt with their customer support, I have gotten quick service without all the dinking around I got from ASUS.

I am replacing an ADDA brushless dc 12v 0.07a 1 ballbearing, model AD0412LB-G70 fan. The ADDA fan whines loudly and is new.

The fan that Startech sent is a Young Lin Tech dc 12v 0.06a 1 bearing + sleeve, model DFC401012M fan. The fan is rated at 5400 rpm, is 0.07w, has an airflow of 5.62 cfm and for noise is 24.87 dB. This information can be found on site at: en.yltc.cn>products>4010. This is a 4010 series fan.

Of course, the terminated connector is wrong. I had to carefully remove the plastic conector by depressing the metal tangs of the terminated ends. I then checked to see if the ends would fit onto the pins from the PCB. It did and I then put shrink fit onto the metal ends for protection. The PCB is indicated with a + so that I was able to know to put the red wire there so as not to reverse the connection.

Currently the fan is very quite and is working. Time will tell how long the fan will work. I used to buy these fans for $2 at the PC show and with the correct connector...lol, but being that I now have to pay for gas, parking and to enter the show, it's a good buy.

If chimera's statement and one star rating is correct then his model may be a DFS and not a DFC. It is possible to have the wrong item sent to you. It has happened to me more than once.
output: Appears to be a good fan so far.

Instances.input:
To make it short, I purchased this SSD and spent a whole afternoon to transfer data from my old hard drive to this SSD and installed to my laptop, immediately noticed that it freezes for about 1 minute every several minutes. I used it as boot drive so when it freezes I virtually can't do anything. The system running in memory thought this I/O device was still accessible but very slow - as slow as 0 Byte/s. I searched in Google and found this is a common defect of this model and no perfect solution to it. My computer has no problem handling SSD because I've been using a Samsung SSD and (almost) never have this issue. I really want to love it because it's read / write speed is quite high and I've spent 5 hours on it. But now I have to return it.

== Update 2012/10/15 ==

I received the replacement and have been using for several days and so far so good. It works out-of-box, I didn't upgrade the firmware, change Mac settings, or any kind of debug. This confirms that the previous one was indeed defective. The actual read / write speeds are about 515MB/s and 261MB/s, which are even higher than advertised.

This item, when working properly, deserves a five-star. However, it is likely to get a defective one. I don't know how likely it is but it did happen to me and when I searched for this issue, I saw a lot of people having this issue, too. Considering the risk, I believe four-star may be proper to describe the overall quality of this model.
The product is leather, affordable, durable, portable, sturdy, and light. I do not see any flaws. Highly recommended to anyone

The parts seem very sturdy, and I haven't had any problems with sagging, or unexpected movement. It has just about endless adjustment, and I've been able to move the arms to different positions very easily when needed.
I am perfectly satisfied with this stand and would definitely consider purchasing a second, if the need arises.

[[VIDEOID:mo34JI8AILK602Y]]This is a truly awesome case. I cannot stop raving about the synthetic leather, which feels incrdibly real. This case not only feels great but functions as well as a case can be designed. Together, this makes for just a wonderful case. But beware, I did some some reviews that stated that this case was not for the iPad Mini with Retina Display. I tested it with my original iPad Mini and it worked great.

PROS
*Synthetic leather is buttery soft to the touch, water resistant and presents a tremendous value. This case feels like a $50 - $75 dollar case but costs only a fraction of that.
*Rubberized plastic iPad holder clip does a great job of holding the iPad in place and also makes it easy to pop the iPad in and out. All ports on the iPad are easily accessed and the holder doesn't wrap around the screen, it takes advantage of the rim on the iPad to snap in and out
*Microfiber inside has a really cool looking deign- protects screen and is soft to the touch
*Magnets in the cover protect the screen and also work nicely with sleeping and waking the iPad Cover holds nicely in place when turned upside down.
*Variable pitch allows you to get just the right viewing angle. If you pull the iPad all the way out it makes for a nice angle for typing. Once positioned properly, screen doesn't slip and you can easily tap on the iPad and the case won't tip over.
*Super slim, adds a minimal amount to the iPad's size.

CONS
*None - I can't think of one thing Anker could do to improve this case, everything works perfectly and for this price this case is a steal!

I have seen and come across a lot of cases in my day and this is one of the best I have ever seen. The synthetic leather feels incredibly soft and will fool most people, it is that good. The case functions beautifully in holding the iPad, sleeping/waking the iPad, positioning the iPad and protecting the iPad. I really look hard for things I like and don't link and ways to improve the product and am just stumped. Hands down one of the best cases out there!

I was provided a sample by the manufacturer in exchange for a fair and honest review.for things I like and don't link and ways to improve the product and am just stumped. Hands down one of the best cases out there!

I was provided a sample by the manufacturer in exchange for a fair and honest review.
output: This is an awesome case...synthetic leather is buttery soft, form & function are beautifully done

This is a nice keyboard for the money.  Good key response, feels solid.  There are a couple extra keys for macros, not overkill like the G11 from Logitech.  All black with no silver accents, so it looks sharp.  Has good coverage as far as the blue lights are concerned.  The function keys along the top are a little dark, but its not bad.  Has a nice leather'ish wrist rest that comes along with it.     The only problem I have had with this is (I believe) software related.  The Razor utility that comes along with it that allows you to program the different keys.  It worked great for a couple weeks for me, then I started having problems.  Seems like something is always pushing the right direction arrow key.  Or pushing left then right over and over again.  It isn't right away, I can get about 4-5 minutes of good use out of it before this happens.  If the utility loads you can not stop this problem, even if you terminate the process.  If you pull the USB and re attach, sometimes you can get another good 5 mins out of it.  I had to uninstall the Razor software to correct the problem.  Rendering the extra keys useless.      Still, I'd rather lose those keys than the functionality of the entire keyboard.  I'm sure they will release a revision at some point to correct it.  Its still only v 1.0

Excellent router, poor quality power supply.
I've had this router for 4 years now, and it works great. I have a pretty big house, and I can get a good signal all over it. I have a Roku at the opposite end of the house, and on a different floor, and I get a great signal.

I give only 4 stars, though, because last night I turned off everything in the office to make some changes, and left it off all night. This morning when I turned it back on, no internet. The Linksys router power light was doing a fast flicker, and wouldn't boot. I bypassed it, and hooked directly into the cable modem, and searched google for a solution - the manual was no help. I got onto a Linksys forum, and quite a few others had this problem. They turned it off and on, and it stopped working. Turns out it was the POWER SUPPLY (wall transformer) that went bad. Fortunately I had a 12V supply with the same plug, and it lit right up. Thank you china for more junk quality.
output: Excellent router, poor quality power supply.

The Kindle is simply awesome and I use it every day. Here are some of the features that I enjoy:

My wife can watch the Tagesschau (a German news broadcast) and catch up on news from Germany.
I am reading the Game of Thrones series, then switch to HBO GO and watch the episode covering the chapters I just read in high definition.
I can check out books from the public library and download them from Amazon. There is not a large selection yet, but many are current and popular books that cost $10 and up if you would buy the Kindle version.
I check postings on facebook, check my hotmail, browse the internet, and play a game or two if I have some free time.
I use the calendar to keep track of appointments and meetings.
I can do sketches using a stylus and Sketch Pro.
All this in an easy to transport size. So needless to say that I am very satisfied with my purchase.

Received it today. Easy to setup. Very fast LAN Gbs and WAN. With Comcast WAN connection delivered over 27Mbs on Speakeasy. My old Linksys BEFSX41 could only pump 14Mbs max. Upload speed is the same ~730Kbs.  Also, some folks are tempted to verify Gbs speed with casual file copying from one PC to another. Not so easy: with modern hard drive you can only scratch Gbs bandwidth (~25% utilization max) simply because HD could only deliver about 30-35 MB/s  sustained read/write rate (~300Mbs). Gbs LAN could push 125MB/s on both send and receive channels (full duplex). In order to saturate the link you will need to spend a big chunk of green for raid 0, or 10 array with 4+ disks on both PCs. Took some time to set time restriction policy for kids PCs. As usual, it takes two blocking policies: one for early morning and one for late evening hours. Unit interface is impressive and you can feel the quality of router software and linux OS heart is beating in this speed devil. Unit came with firmware v1.7, upgraded it to v1.8 right away as it was available. Just a note: do not forget to enable automatic time configuration, otherwise router will show some funny date/time stamps in the logs. Very surprised with features and unit build quality. Xbox360 works flawlessly on Xbox-Live. Would recommend this router ...any time...
When I got it I plugged it in my laptop and charge it quickly. I have not had any problems. I will order from amazon again.

The DGN2200 has great features, solid design, and an intuitive menu.  But the problem seems to be this was built with cheap components.  I am not sure if I have a defective unit, or this is just a byproduct of Netgear using cheap parts.  I've read all the other reviews of people having stability issues etc, I hoped they were exagerating but the same thing happened to me.  The unit took multiple reboots to find the DSL connection, then the menu went unreadable...After resetting numerous times, finally got a solid internet connection after 2 days of troubleshooting!  Went to the WIFI page to configure and...unreadable text...This is not a Netgear bashing, I've used dozens of thier products in the past...Love the product if it worked properly.  If any R&D people ever read these posts, please use quality parts, I know I would gladly have paid another $100 for a quality, well made product...

I bought one of these SanDisk memory cards for my Garmin Nuvi 760 when my latest map update would not load. All I did was take the card out of the wrapper, plug it into the GPS, turn it on, and the Nuvi 760 recognized the memory card. The maps loaded easily, nothing else needed. I then bought this same memory card for my daughter's Garmin Nuvi 650, which was a different story. Not the fault of the memory card, but Garmin makes you go through some extra steps on some of their older models, including the 650, because they do not automatically save excess storage to the new inserted memory card. It is all explained on the Garmin site, but I ended up calling the Garmin help desk to make sure I had it right. They were very cooperative & helpful, but that's another story. Either way, this SanDisk memory card performed as well as can be expected, and I have nothing negative to say about it. Several months have gone by and both GPSs are working fine, even after a new map update. I would recommend this card for Garmin Nuvi GPSs.

Bought a "Patriot" branded model for twice the price at a local store, and this is exactly the same model branded differently. I am reading a lot of comments for the low ratings on here and have a couple of things to add:

1) This is not a "powered" hub beyond the little bit of power provided by the "bus power", so if your device relies on the USB 3.0 slot for power you can't use this for more than one device. For example, small 2.5" external hard drives with no other power source. You may be able to use two, but it's a gamble. If you want to connect such devices, buy a USB 3.0 hub with an external power cable to provide the additional power needed. If your external USB 3.0 device (hard drive, DVD, etc.) has its own power supply, this will work brilliantly!

2) Your motherboard must have driver support to additional USB 3.0 ports. Most newer ones do, but if you have an early 3.0 board you will have some trouble if you try to connect too many devices. This is a factor of the chipset used by the motherboard, not the manufacturer of this hub. If you have a 4th or 5th generation Intel i3, i5 or i7 processor, you will be fine. Some motherboards which support 3rd generation i processors will also be OK, depending on the chipset.
output: Great Product, But Read Before You Buy To Avoid Any Issues

I believe I have a first generation version of this latest Eye-Fi card, but my review is long overdue nonetheless.     Eye-Fi is brilliant. Simply. Amazing.     No more clunking around looking for those USB cords and computers getting angry with me for \\"improperly disconnecting devices.\\" Joy.     The absolute killer application of Eye-Fi is the ability to directly load pictures to online share sites like Kodak or Flickr.     I bought my parents a Wi-Fi Kodak sharing picture frame. After taking a round of photos of our family outings, all I need to do is click a button on each shot that I want to go to the frame. My parents, 250 miles away, get to see the photos moments after I take them!     When I stop to think about what is happening from my eye to my camera to my card to the internet, \\"amazing\\" is the only word that truly captures it. Wow.     Regardless of which model you purchase, a purchase from Eye-Fi is money well spent.

I have used an Ergonomic Microsoft Keyboard for several years now and have gotten so used to it that it is hard to type on a standard keyboard. I have two computers, one linux and the other windows xp. I use a USB KVM to switch between the two computers. The present MS Ergo keyboard I have is PS2. I bought this one because it indicated that it was USB. I found out after receiving it, that it is the same keyboard I had with a PS2 to USB converter. This PS2 to USB converter does not work well at all with KVM switches. A well documented problem on the web forums. I tried it and confirmed it has problems using it with the converter. I gave it away and bought the Microsoft 4000 wire keyboard. It is \\"real\\" USB and works fantastic with the USB KVM switch. So I would recommend spending the extra few bucks and getting the MS 4000 Ergo Keyboard. Plus it has lots of new features the old one lacks.

Bought a new laptop a little over a month ago and it didnt have serial ports which I need for my work. At first I bought another USB to serial cable but it didnt work with windows 7, so I bought this one (great price by the way). All I had to do was install the software and just plug it in. It worked the first time with no problems what so ever. I have been using them (I needed 2) for a month now with no problems. I wish the cables were a little longer though because I have to attach my old serial cable to it so it will reach the equipment I have to communicate with. The only other issue I have (not related to the cable), is when I use 2 at the same time Im not sure which COM port is for which cable. I have to use trial and error to figure it out.    I also run windows XP on a virtual machine in windows 7 and the USB to serial cables work just fine in that mode also.    I didnt rate technical support because I didnt need it.

The G 602 is one of, if not the best wireless mice on the market right now.

---------------------
Quick Pro/Cons
---------------------

PROS:
* Extremely Comfortable
* Pleasant finish throughout the entire mouse
* Plenty of customizable buttons (8)
* Software is simple, but has nice features
* Longest battery life I've ever seen on a wireless mouse
* All of this, while being wireless

CONS:
* Not a Unifying Receiver
* No free scroll , or sideways scrolling
* Not rechargeable

---------------------
Overview
---------------------
Lets talk about the overview of the mouse. It fits my hand quite nicely with a palm grip, and has a nice "sand paper"-esque finish where you thumb rests and also where your pinky and ring finger lay. However it also feels like there is a nice "clear coat" type of material to smooth out the finish. I quite like this texture as it provides some grip to your hand without being too rough that it hurts after a long period of usage. This mouse holds AMAZINGLY in the hand, for a guy like me with larger than average hands, finding a mice that fits my hands is a rather difficult task, but with the G 602, Logitech has found the perfect grip on a mouse, at least for me.

---------------------
Buttons
---------------------
All of the buttons on this mouse are customizable and can even change the DPI of the mouse if selected. The left and right main buttons have a nice click, and if you notice, the middle finger right button goes out a little bit farther than the left and adds to the futuristic aesthetic. The two buttons on the left side of the left mouse click are set to be DPI change by default, but I changed them to my liking (specifically being Middle Click / and Enter) The rest of the buttons on the side of the mouse are also very nice, and easy to distinguish between each one after using the mouse for a couple of days. Finally there is a power switch on the bottom which is pretty standard and does what it needs to, and a switch at the top to switch between Endurance Mode and Performance Mode. This mouse was clocked in at 250 hrs in Performance mode, which increases the polling rate of the mouse, up to 500. Endurance mode keeps the mouse locked at 125, which is perfectly fine for me, but Your Millage May Vary. I have personally kept it in Endurance mode the entire time as I don't find the faster polling rate to be that noticeable in games and other desktop activities. But it isn't re-programmable.

---------------------
Misc.
---------------------
The scroll wheel on this mouse is nice and has small intervals on advancing to the next few lines on the screen. I wish it did have the free scrolling wheel like on the Performance MX which I had before this bad boy.

It does however have a nice little slot to store the receiver, but the receiver is unfortunately not one of their Unifying Receiver, which I have quite a few of around my house.

It can run on just one battery, if the mouse feels too heavy for you.

The software is extremely easy to use and has some nice features, such as being able to set different profiles for specific applications and games.
---------------------
Conclusion
---------------------
This mouse is a game changer for me. Never again will I use another mouse without plenty of buttons on it, coming from a Performance MX this mouse has completely blown me away. This is the best wireless mouse for the money almost hands down, and I would recommend it to anyone. Even more, with it on sale ( I got mine for $40)
output: One of the Best Wireless Mice I've Ever Used

UPDATE: September 21st, 2016 This is my most popular review to date and there still seems to be a lot of interest in this drive so I thought I would update. I still use the thunderbolt drive regularly. The case is scratched because I leave it in my daily carry bag to the office and back. I'm pretty sure the case is plastic because of how it's worn through. Aside from vanity- cable and drive still works flawlessly!   Recently I've recently upgraded the 5400rpm drive in my 2011 Macbook Pro to a 500gb SSD. And my work 2013 macbook has a stock 500gb SSD. I simply don't have room for my Lightroom photo library so I keep it all on this TB G-Drive (backed up regularly of course). When working through 12-20mp files in lightroom I experience no delays. If I import a very large batch of files from SD card --> Lightroom --> this drive it takes longer to write than it does to the internal SSD but that's expected.  ---------  Pros: + Thunderbolt! + 7200rpm HD + Comes with thunderbolt and usb 3.0 cable + Doesn't run hot + No bulky annoying power supply (hey it's been a really long time since I bought an external HD)  Cons: - Cost - Would be more cost effective to go with a USB 3.0 drive  The long version:  Out of the box I was impressed with the look and feel. Amazon is stating that the enclosure is stainless steel but I could've sworn it was just a really nice plastic, especially in comparison to my Macbook. It's still nice and looks a million times better than that orange lacie bumper drive thing. It mimics the older non retina MacBook pros in thickness and the LED light takes cues from the macbook as well. It comes with the thunderbolt cable which I learned afterwards is really expensive when bought alone.  The first thing I did was format the drive and moved a 114 GB folder over to free up some space. OSX doesn't tell you the exact rate of transfer in mb/s and I was surprised to see that this folder was going to take more than an hour to copy over. Thunderbolt is advertised at 10gb/s transfer rate! Well I completely oversaw the fact that with a spinning hard drive you are limited to the disk read/write speed. In the real world thunderbolt has an advantage over USB 3.0 when it comes to Raid or SSD setups. With 5400/7200 rpm drives you are much better off saving some money and going with a USB 3.0 drive- granted you have USB 3.0 on your computer. I have the earliest Macbook pro with thunderbolt and only USB 2.0 so this drive is a good choice for me.  For the money this is currently the best 1 TB thunderbolt/USB 3.0 drive for the money because of the 7200 rpm drive. Right now all of the competition is using a much slower 5400 rpm drive at this price point. While transferring a lot of files back and forth and testing it, it did get warm to the touch but nothing out of the ordinary and certainly not burning hot like some are reporting for other thunderbolt external drives.  So how fast is it? It took a little more than an hour to transfer that 114 GB folder. It's late, I don't feel like crunching numbers so I did a quick test to get a better grasp on how fast that is. I put about a bunch of large photoshop, illustrator and jpegs into a folder (totaling 3.5 GB) and transferring that from one partition to another on the stock 5400 rpm drive in my macbook took about 3 min 49 seconds. Transferring that same folder to the G-Drive took 1 min 27 seconds! Definitely breathes some life into my machine and I can't wait to move all of my adobe files and pictures over and work directly off of the G-Drive.  This is still an initial review and I'll update as I work more with it.  EDIT: Ok to quickly clarify and add some things I missed last night. It's a pretty quiet drive, there is no fan but you can still here the disk spinning like any other platter drive. Also, I picked up the box and noticed that G Technology clearly states on the box, in orange, "transfer speeds up to 136mb/s" which is about as fast as a 7200 rpm drive will go. Quickand rough calculation in my head and I seem to get just below that. Compared to other 5400 based thunderbolt drives that have transfer speeds of around ~70-80 mb/s. Kudos to G for not trying to milk the regular "10gb/s transfer rate!" thunderbolt marketing claims that some other manufacturers are abusing.
output: Initial Impression: currently the best thunderbolt drive for the money

Got my second one today, well I shuld say they shipped something that looks like a tablet and I received it today. The box it came in is the same as the product I got last time, but the tablet inside was 7\\" diagonal, and had a 5\\" screen and one home button. The back was silver, instead of white, and the inside of the box was dirty and oily. How that happens I'm not sure. Also the tablet looked like it was flipped face down and dragged across concrete or sanded or something. The entire face was scratched and scuffed.The back had huge cracks and chunks taken out of it. This does not seem shipping related. It seems they shipped me used garbage. TO TOP IT OFF! There is a quality control sticker on the side, it says QC17. Did the quality control check to see the item had mass or something? AND ON TOP OF THAT! It didn't charge, and it didn't even turn on. I can't say anything else about it other than what I got TWICE was garbage. Thanks for Amazon return policy.

JUlY 10,2012
Opened the box:
The back of the tablet was opened, like it wasn't closed all the way during assembly. I pushed it back together and went on to enjoy my new tablet. It booted up, had 4.0 installed and a koi fish background. It was very impressive and responsive off the bat. I installed a lot of apps that I have on my phone, and played some games. After a while I tried to watch a movie and the sound stopped working. The volume was all the way up, but nothing came out through headphones or the speaker. I decided I'd play with it later in frustration and hoped I had just messed with a setting to do that or something. I plug it into the wall, and then it shuts off. Not the normal way, but just goes black. Now it won't turn on at all, and to top it off the back popped off again like it's the wrong size or something. It just won't close in one spot. This one is obviously defective and I contacted the shipper for a new one as a replacement. Now I see that the tablet is being sold by someone else so we'll see how this works out...
output: Got one after the other. BOth broken, one DOA

I researched other drives heavily before settling on this one. It's a replacement for my MacBook Pro's dead Superdrive.

First of all, I read in these reviews that a lot of people's Superdrives have died. Minus 10 points to Apple.

Secondly, I read a lot of things in these reviews that made me worry, so here's my experience:

I paid $35 which was awesome. I loved the high star rating of this device on Amazon, but I was wary that some or a lot of the reviews might be fake. The negative reviews were VERY negative (one star). I took a chance and so far it looks great.

I am running Mac OS 10.6.8. I plugged the drive in and my computer instantly recognized it and loaded a DVD I put in it, then when I asked it to burn a DVD from the Disk Utility, I thought I would have a problem, but no. It instantly ejected the drive door and asked me if I wanted to burn in that drive, without me even telling it anything.

I had heard a lot about the Nero software and how it was only a short free trial, but I didn't open the Nero software. I didn't need to. So all of that has me very happy.

Also, it does not have a power cable, which I like.

It DOES take up 2 USB ports, which is a little annoying, but I don't really care. I have hard drives that do the same thing, so I'm used to it.

Someone on here complained that it's light and it moves around the desktop but so far its weight does not surprise me. It's no lighter than I would have expected.

I can't speak to its reliability yet because I've only had it for about 20 minutes. If it breaks down I will come back on here and change this review. If it had broken down, you wouldn't be reading this.

I recently bought this drive as a replacement for an older 500gb USB 2.0 version of the drive which has been great. However, with the new drive, I noticed when it was plugged into my computer, my internet would become unusable. It took me a long while to figure out that the interference was caused by frequencies being emitted from the new g-drive mini external drive, they were jamming my computers wifi. This is a known problem with USB 3.0 and wifi and bluetooth. I found that if I more the drive far enough away from my computer it seems to not interfere but that means I had to buy a longer cable and I can't set the drive near the back of my mac book. Also its important to note that my internet connection is disrupted whether I use the USB 3.0 connect or the firewire connection on the new drive. for more info just search USB 3.0 and wifi.

This is straight from Apple's website:
\\"I sometimes have difficulty with Wi-Fi or Bluetooth devices when USB 3 devices are attached to my computer. What could be wrong?

Some USB 3 devices, hard drives in particular, can generate radio frequency interference that can cause Wi-Fi and Bluetooth devices operating in the 2.4GHz band to have issues communicating with your computer. Do not place hard drives or other USB devices behind the rear of your Mac near at the hinge of your screen. The antennas for Wi-Fi and Bluetooth are located there, and USB 3 devices placed there may interfere with your wireless connections. See this white paper for more information.\\"

from:
[...]
output: I like this company and the drives, but beware of USB 3.0 if can disrupt wifi and bluetooth

Simply said - this is a really nice dock... I particularly like how the tablet can double as a Digital Picture Frame (looks super elegant in the living room) and through the use of really cool aps like Accuweather and cassandra - or even chumby - it can work as a digital clock - weather station or current events notifier - it offeres to viewing angles (didn't see this noted anywhere online) by sliding the back foot up and down against the slot - it just changes the pitch the display sits at...

Seriously - very nice...

three things hold me back from giving it 5 stars

1) Sony really missed the boat regarding giving this dock a little extra functionality - seriously though - a HDMI out port would have been dandy - not everything is DLNA certified - hell, I can't even throw my videos to my Bravia Link Blue-Ray system - so HDMI would have been a great add-on to get through the doc.

2) Would be nice if you could flip which way the cord comes out of the unit when it's attached - given the right angle nature of the power cord that would have been useful to flip it...

3) for the price they should have included a power adapter - especially since the damn tablet requires their proprietary adapter and can't be charged over USB (if they had - I'd by a 2nd stand so I could have one by the bed on the night stand and one in the living room by the entertainment center - hell I could even consider a 3rd in the kitchen but I'm not in to buying 2 more power supplies at these prices - one of those things that unless money is no object to you - just is an expensive proposition but would be sweet if it wasn't cost prohibitive)

~Chris
output: A Really Nice Compliment for your Sony Tablet

UPDATE 4 March 5,2014 : Amazon denied my request to return product to the reseller. So I'm stuck with a useless device. Buy only from Amazon directly. Look at product description carefully and never buy from a re seller. The A to Z guarantee is useless in this instance.

UPDATE 3 March 2, 2014 : Stopped receiving internet several times in past 6 weeks. Had to reset to factory default each time and re-configure. It takes several re configuring attempts before it will receive internet. Workes great when working. Quit again this week. Tired of messing with this thing, did not want to contact Hawking's useless support and tried to return it. Found out that I had inadvertently purchased it from an Amazon reseller - antoline. I had clicked the product description on my \\"Your Order\\" page from the previous two repeater purchase/returns and was directed to a page from where I ordered this third Hawking repeater. It was not from Amazon and antoline would not take it back, responding that I had exceeded the 30 day return window. Contacted Amazon and they are trying to remedy with their A to Z guarantee. I'm pretty confident that Amazon will take care of this. Stay tuned.

UPDATE 2: Before returning to Amazon, I rebooted repeater went through setup and it worked! Worked for about 3 weeks then lost internet again. Rebooted/setup several times without success. Waited 5 days and rebooted/setup - it received internet! I'm thinking that something changes in the repeater or WiFi hot spot after several weeks and the repeater needs a reboot and setup. Still a hassle. The Hawking USB HAWNU1 adapter never needs this kind of attention. But I need this repeater in order to receive wifi on several computers. No other manufacturer offers a similar device (that accepts an external receiving antenna) so I am stuck with rebooting/setup every couple weeks. If someone knows of a similar product, I sure would like to hear about it

UPDATE: The adapter I had working quit after about 3 weeks. Powers on, but no internet. Rebooted several times no success. Sent that back and ordered another one which worked great after setup. Worked great for about three weeks and it quit receiving internet too. Reset/rebooted it a couple times but would not receive internet. I foolishly called Hawking tech support and they had me go through the reboot without success. I will not order another one. I'll stick to the Hawking USB adapter, which has been working well.

AMAZON HAS BEEN GREAT with my return & refund of theses devices. They probably should stop selling these repeaters - it's got to be costing them money on the shipping back and forth.

Instances.input: It is light weight and easy to carry around because it fits inside my bag perfectly! So far it is everything I expected it to be.

This keyboard is very good looking, but it won't type like a mac keyboard at all. Don't keep your hope up.

Typing on this keyboard is not fluid at all. When you type on this keyboard, more force is required than is really necessary to register a hit. The spacebar is the worst as often it will either not register at all, or register a second late, resulting int his orthis. When you first get this keyboard, you will have to spend a lot of time replacing letters that didn't hit when you type. I suppose you could get used toit, but if you are a fast typer, get a better keyboard.

The keys are not comfortable at all to type on. They are very slippery (especially the spacebar key) and feel like extremely cheap plastic.

If you are in a market for keyboard, it is better for you to go to the store and physically try out the keyboard to see if you will like it. If you really must order from amazon, order the Logitech Keyboard K120. That keyboard will feel more like a normal keyboard you would use at work or school.
output: Be careful, not as good as it seems

Instances.input:
I picked up the black case since I wanted something basic to keep my Kindle safe when I take it with me everywhere, but after about a week of use I noticed 2 things that bugged me a bit! So the smaller issue I've found is that you can't read on a metal surface. Rather, you can, but folding the cover across the back and setting it down causes the Kindle to go back into the sleep screen and you have to manually wake it. Not a big deal, but a little annoying if you pick it up and put it down a lot.

The bigger problem I found was that this protective case actually damages my kindle!! The little silver magnetic clasp clamps onto the leather front, but they never bothered filing the edges of the closure. This has begun creating little scratches on the right side of my kindle. It is only on the black frame surrounding the screen, but it really bothers me that the device meant to protect my Kindle is slowly damaging it! For now I've gone ahead and covered my Kindle with a piece of tape so that takes the scratches instead, but I'm going to take a metal file to it and hope that does the trick.

With all of that said, I love the rest of it! It's a sturdy case and the texture provides a great grip for holding it. Overall, a great design minus the scuffing :)

I ordered this memory to upgrade my office computer from 2GB to 4GB of RAM because I was hitting my 2GB ceiling for too often.  I only have 2 slots available, so I needed two 2GB DDR2 PC2-8500 (240 PIN) modules.  I also wanted 1066MHz for better performance, which was a bit difficult to find, but having purchased memory on Amazon.com in the past (mostly Crucial or Kensington), I searched and found this kit by Komputerbay.  I had never heard of the company, but the price was great, and this kit was exactly what I was looking for.  The Heatspreaders are another excellent feature that give me peace of mind as well because they help increase the longevity of the memory by more efficiently dissipating the heat.  I work in IT so I have installed a lot of RAM in my day, and I put a lot of demands on my computer.  I also work on our website constantly which requires graphic design and web design software (mostly Adobe CS4).  I installed the new memory as soon as it arrived (shipping was very fast too), and my computer performance has been excellent ever since!  :-)  I will definitely purchase more memory from Komputerbay in the future, and I would highly recommend Komputerbay to anyone looking for an affordable way to upgrade their RAM.  As far as I am concerned Komputerbay's quality and performance are just as good as any other \\"name brand\\" memory, without the \\"name brand\\" price! :-)

My installation is a departure from most applications.  I wanted to convert a glass china cabinet into a multiple use AV equipment and display case.  Since it wouldn't have served my purpose to leave the cabinet door open, I resorted to modifying it to provide adequate ventilation so as to avoid overheating of my sensitive electronic equipment, which throws off a good deal of heat.  The cabinet has an elevated \\"floor\\" about 4 inches off the carpet, so I cut oval holes large enough to accommodate grommets that I also purchased from Amazon, through which I ran the cabling from behind the cabinet and into the interior from below.  That solved two issues; how to get the cabling inside and, importantly, how to provide a source of cool air as the cabinet was exhausted.  The cabinet top has both a finished \\"ceiling,\\" with a small \\"attic\\" or air space above, and then is covered with a \\"roof\\" - that's 2 separate layers.  I took the roof off and cut two rectangular holes in the ceiling to accommodate 2 oak louvers that I stained to match the finish of the cabinet interior, so the interior looks very professional.  Some people have remarked that it looks like it was factory made that way.  Now to the installation of the case fans; I fabricated a new roof out of 3/16-inch mahogany veneer in which I cut two (2) holes to accommodate the 2 Antec Big Boy case fans, positioning them so they exhaust upward into the room, running the wiring up to the top side.  I sealed the edges of the case fans to the roof and the roof to the top of the cabinet by applying some caulking to ensure that air would be pulled from below, rather than leaking into the attic and then immediately exhausted.  I had a variable voltage transformer with a in-line controller that I Used as a power supply, directly wiring in the fans on the 12v side and added a 120v AC cord to the other.  That completed the installation.  I can vary the speed of the fans and, unless I turn them up to maximum rpms, it's very difficult to hear them running.  They do a great job of creating a negative pressure inside the cabinet that effectively draws cool air from below to keep my electronic equipment cool.  I'm very pleased with how well the project worked out and extremely happy with the amount of cooling it provides.  I'd recommend this fan to anyone who wants a high flow at minimal noise levels.ult to hear them running.  They do a great job of creating a negative pressure inside the cabinet that effectively draws cool air from below to keep my electronic equipment cool.  I'm very pleased with how well the project worked out and extremely happy with the amount of cooling it provides.  I'd recommend this fan to anyone who wants a high flow at minimal noise levels.

I have used the Cruzer for several months now with now problems whatsoever. It has incredible durability, very fast download/upload speeds (assuming you're using it with USB 2.0) and is a very compact size (pinkie finger). I for one actually like the blue light because it reminds me that I need to remove the Cruzer when it's not in use. The USB 2.0 format makes it super compatible with just about any modern computer and the memory size is great for basic documents, pictures and music files. I carry it on my key chain so the only annoying thing is when I need my keys but also need the Cruzer in the computer. Thus you have to remover the Cruzer via Windows which takes about 5-10 seconds after a few clicks of the mouse--very simple but slightly bothersome because of my needs. Also, it's easy to love the protective cap when the Cruzer is in use so keep track of it!

I would recommend purchasing one with more memory (512 or even 1gb) since prices are dropping and deals abound around the internet. But if you are looking for an entry level 256mb portable memory card with USB 2.0 capabilities, this is a great option.

By the way I have a Kingston Data Traveler 256mb and I like the Cruzer Mini much better because the Cruzer is so much smaller and the cap is easier to remove! I highly recommend!
output: Great product and prices keep dropping
