Before I get too long with my review, the value and the quality of this product is purely fantastic.  Also, note how I only have been using this for few days.  This review is based on that time frame.  It seems promising anyhow.  Over all, I used to use a Wacom (no screen) tablet, and it was a great product.  The problem was that I never got over the awkwardness of not actually drawing directly on the surface.  As you can see, the market price of screened tablet is quite expensive so to begin with, so I was about to give up on screened tablet till I came across this product.  After using this for hours I only found some minor flaws, but over all it is an excellent pentablet!  Let me get across the flaws first.    First of all, there are no grips on the pen.  This could noticeably hurt your fingers within few hours. Not a tough problem to solve however.  Secondly, there seems to be a slight lag between the movement of the pen and the response of the screen.  When you're rapidly moving your pen to cover a broad area with a paint tool, you might notice how the lag causes less surface area to be covered.  Third and finally, for lefties, you may accidentally press the button when you're drawing causing the screen to zoom in or out, due to its layout.  I tried vertically inverting the image through settings, but due to the lighting placement of the tablet, it completely whites out the screen.  Not a big problem though, just need to learn to not rest your hand on the buttons.  Now the good stuff.  The pressure sensitivity might take time to get used to, but once you do so, it responds with quality.  Also, the fact that it functions as an extended desktop works well when you're dealing with a long-term drawing.  You get to play some distraction in the main monitor...  The color is quite true to what shows up on the computer's main monitor.  May be a little darker? Not to a level that shows issue to me.  The complete portability of this product helps too.  It's very light, compact enough, and does not require an AC adaptor... BIG plus to the last part.    And of course, the obvious.  THE PRICE.  The price is amazing for what you get.  I don't think I would be overstating if I said this product offers you high quality digitizer tablet while maintaining 1/3 (or less) of the price to its competitor.  Now this, should be the new standard for this market.  Honestly.  Finally, just for those who have been using other tablets before hand and is thinking about purchasing this.    The installation might get slightly confusing.  It took me awhile to realize how my pre-existing tablet driver was prohibiting the installation of this new tablet driver...I couldn't set up many minor details of this hardware till I noticed that.  Over all, the value beats its flaws by miles.  Five stars.    Just for your information, I used this tablet on a 2011 MBP 13\\", boot camp.  (Note: Compatibility with OSX seems a little questionable at the moment.)
output: Few things to knit pick, but otherwise...

Alienware m17x r2 laptop with an ATI Mobility Radeon HD 5870 graphics card. I use two external monitors plus the laptop monitor for a total of three monitors. One external monitor is using the HDMI port. One external monitor on the Display Port using this wonderful adapter. Resolution is great. On an old Dell E207WFP monitor I'm getting 1680 X 1050. I've been using this great adapter for one month with no issues. Plug it in and go.

After unpacking the product, I read the instructions to first charge the keyboard for at least 6 hours before first use. I used the supplied micro USB to my Laptop, which was plugged in and charging. There is no wall charger - just USB.

Cover:
I wish it had a little more tactile grip feel, or slightly more texture to it. The cover fit perfect on my iPad 3. All ports and areas accessible, and iPad Apple logo was visible when removed from stand. The iPad 3 charged with no blocking or issues. Removing it from the iPad was easy and the directions were very clear. Press and hold two spots, and it snaps back off.

Sliding Bracket:
The cover attachment took some practice to attach, but it was secure and had 360 degrees of motion. The slide of the bracket allowed for many adjustable potions both vertical and horizontal. You need to note that the iPad needs to rest on the keyboard at different angles. It just can't tilt and hold its position off the keyboard, as it will not balance correctly. If you do open all the way - it needs to be supported which I was able to do when commuting across my lap. Not perfect, but other cases I have tried can't do this. The release switch slides the bracket out, and it can simply be pushed back in without using the release switch. This is both good and bad depending on how you use the case. For some, they might not want the slide to push back in if holding in a lap.

Keyboard:
The Bluetooth key board connected as my other devices with no issues. Battery life presented no concerns as compare with my other devices. The hot keys at top, responded with iPad 3 settings. Typing was as expected on a smaller key board, and one would expect to not type full time on this. It will never replace the comfort a full size key board. The spacebar cut-out opening for the thumb could be a little larger for me. 8 rubber bumpers around the outside of the keyboard protect the iPad when closed. It does need some forceto open, as it tends to feel very stiff. I like the fact that I know it will stay closed and protected in my bag. 4 rubber feet prevent from sliding on smooth surfaces. They worked well on my desk. There are bright colored LED's display Charge, Cap, and Bluetooth Status in the center front of the keyboard. I found them very easy to see and monitor. The charging micro USB port is located on the right side, near the center -so it felt like it did not interfere even when charging while typing.

Summary: No small compact keyboard case is perfect. For me, this had some product options and operation that out weighed the ones it did not have.

Pro's - Very flexible positioning - 360 degrees (horizontal and vertical)
Light weight and very small
Clam detaches for iPad free use - along with still being very slim when detached.
Compatible with multiple iPad generations

Con's - Slippery plastic inexpensive feel/touch - (this was the biggest for me........)
Key board spacebar needs more thumb area cut-out in channel.
Lock key directly over delete key
output: The product Good features out weighs the bad ones (for me)

Instances.input: I used this to charge my blue-tooth keyboard.  Worked as expected.

I ordered this up specifically as I needed an external drive in order to load some programs onto a new HP mini-notebook - I did not, and do not, expect the notebook to be my primary computer, so I was not concerned with getting something top-flight, as I might be otherwise. I actually was going to get a cheap, drive only unit, but went with this for three bucks more simply because I could burn with it if need be - but there was no expectation of technical dazzle here, and within that expectation this was just fine for my needs.     The unit was not exactly as pictured above. It is actually a TEAC, or at least the one I received was. The mini runs XP, and the unit was recognized and installed immediately. I needed to install printer software, and the unit worked perfectly well for this. Just for grins I tried to burn a music CD, and that worked fine too, though it was slow, about 15 minutes for an Ipod playlist burn. Burning doc files was reasonably fast.    If you are looking for an external drive/burner to use as a primary piece of equipment, or to replace a broken one in a current machine that you intend to keep a while, you might want to spend a bit more money and get some more bells and whistles. I doubt this unit is going to take a lot of heavy use for a long time. But if your need is simply to have a little back up, or as was the case with me, something to use to just load some data into a machine with no drive, this should be just the ticket. For the price I was very happy, and I was very happy with the service - it arrived in three days. For what it is, this is a good buy.
Awesome sound and quality and quick shipping
Its light weight, love the color and yes I would recommend it to a friend, I am thinking of getting another color

Instances.input:
Would work on my computer only after messing with the display settings constantly and/or restarting projector or computer. I don't believe the fault is entirely the adapter. It seems certain computer and projectors do not play well with convertors. I have a Lenovo yoga 2 pro and Epson projector. Like I said, it will work only after making adjustments upon every time the adapter was used. I gave the adapter to my assistant at work and it works well on his yoga 1 with the same projector. Go figure. Seems to be somewhat of a crap shoot whether it will work or not.

I ended up buying a new HDMI projector. An expensive option but now I don't have to spend 10-15 minutes prior to a presentation messing with the adapter and hoping it will work.

Lastly, for all future reviewers I think it would help a great deal to post what computer and display you are using. This should help people figure out if it may work for them or not.
output: Works well only on certain model computers and projectors.

Instances.input: This case looks great and works great. I wanted something cute, and I got it. I love that the iPad turns on when you open the case. Got it for a great price, and I'm so happy I found it!

Bought this and a 750 Gb version about the same time and used them flawlesslessly on my Sony Vaio laptop.  I then moved them to my emachines PC and they froze my computer up and the drives became corrupted.  I could reformat (yay, hours of work gone), and get it to work again with my Sony laptop.  I tried it on a Toshiba laptop...same problem with the emachines PC....froze up, drive became corrupted, had to be reformatted.  This all take place with repeated returns to Seagate and hours on the phone with their tech support as well before i finally realized it was a compatability issue with 2 of my 4 computers.  I am now using these as backup storage/archiving only with my Dell PC, on which I have had no problems like with the Sony Vaio.  So it appears to be a 50% success/failure rate for me.  The Dell has Vista and the other three had Windows XP, so the OS doesn't seem to be the culprit.  Have had other seagates up to 500 Gb capacity previously purchased that are working to this day, but I have switched over to Western Digital after this mess.  Seagate techs were very helpful, but ultimately a LOT of my time was wasted on the phone, and sending HDs back and forth to Seagate for repairs that apparently didn't work.  The one fix I haven't tried yet is to disable the orange pulsing access light--supposedly this fixes the problem in some cases, but I have given up at this point and will just use it with the Dell...it may be that the size of the drive is too much for the two computers to handle...and I also did try partitioning them to see if that would help, but it did not.  Talking with people at an electronics store, I was told that they got a lot of complaints about the Seagates...as others have said, when they work, the work great.  And I must say I am impressed with the 5-year warranty these things have, but I am thinking that may put Seagate out of business!
output: This and the 750 Gb won't work on 2 of 4 computers

I have had a Kindle Fire HD for 6 months and had another tablet before it and never thought I would need a keyboard. I bought apps that supposedly let you write with your finger or a stylus and then it translates to typed words. They work, but they are clumsy and take too long. When I saw this case/keyboard combo at this price, I thought I would give it a try and am very glad I did. The case fits perfectly and is attractive. It is padded enough to protect the kindle and the keyboard but not too much to make it bulky. The keyboard synced with the Kindle Fire quickly and easily. I watched the video put up by the distributor and it made it simple. I now use the Kindle to not only read email, but to answer it, which I didn't do before very much. This keyboard is not a full sized keyboard, but is more than adequate for typing emails and documents. I love using it for URLs, searches and filling out web forms. It is just so much quicker than the touch screen.

I am very satisfied with the quality of workmanship. The product does not feel light and cheap and it looks good. It arrived on time (Amazon Prime ROCKS!)and the seller even followed up by email to make sure I received the product and that I was satisfied. This is a professional seller with good CRM skills. It is nice to business with people who do the job so well and offer quality products at great prices.

I highly recommend this seller and this product.

Instances.input: My son lives in Japan. I bought this product for him because he likes to play video games to pass the time while in flight between Japan and the US (10 - 12 hours). When he came to the US for the Christmas holidays, he flew on a 777, plugged the laptop into the Inverter and fitted the Inverter into the seat's power source. After 40 minutes the laptop stopped because the battery had been drained of power. Flying back to Japan, he again flew on a 777, again used the Inverter, and again the laptop stopped after about 40 minutes. Again, the battery had no power. It's unfortunate that the product doesn't do what you claim, it would have helped to pass the time on the long flights.

The first thing you do after you put this ram in your computer is run multiple memory tests (memtest86+ for example). UBCD (ultimate boot CD) has it. All the people who post the glowing reviews should have done this right away.

I was building a new system and wanted 32 GB of ram it it. I ordered 4 chips (2 packs of 2). At least one chip was bad according to memtest86+. Amazon to the rescue. I sent that set back and reordered another set. They tested fine. Five month later no issues so far.

I don't think the actual 9-9-9-24 matched up on the test if I remember correctly, but I didn't care. So far no lockups, random reboots, etc.

I think a lot of the reviews of this product are fake...

if you run memtest let it run multiple times. You will loose a day of system use based on this testing, but it is well worth it.
output: Cheap, but I used it.  Test, Test, test....

I've been using this external drive for a little more than a month now, and haven't had any problems yet.  The transfer speed is pretty fast!!! My PC has two internal disks that are striped, so read performance isn't hindered as much there.  Now I just need to wait & see how this drive does on the longevity side.      NOTE:  My 64-bit Windows 7 machine already had a driver installed that worked with the supplied PCIe adapter card, so the driver installation (from MyBook 3.0 CD) failed with a cryptic error message.  Eventually I realized that it was failing because it was sort of conflicting with the existing driver.  I would like to see better error handling (better error messages presented to customers), but since it works great despite this software shortcoming, I don't want to ding the product itself.

I have absolutely fallen in love with these headphones. They are a moderate weight and quite comfortable as well as have a great sound quality with deep bass and clear treble. These head phones are perfect for anyone whether you are just looking for great sound quality or you are a passionate gamer.

What makes these headphones so great for gaming is the way the mic is positioned. With its rotating attachment and flexible neck it is easy to maneuver into whatever position is best for you and it is stiff enough that it will stay where you have adjusted it to as well. The mic quality is also crystal clear and my friends even commented on how much clearer I sounded than with my previous set. Also most important for any gaming is sound quality. These headphones clearly pick up even the smallest of sounds and you can clearly hear the direction and intensity of an approaching player in a game such as a First Person Shooter.

If I did have one negative thing to say about them it is that, although they are a comfortable soft design, they are moderately heavy and might take a bit of time to get used to for extended gaming or listening.

I think one of the best attributes of these headphones is the convenient sound control capabilities on the cord that makes life much easier and no longer do I have to reach up to adjust my speakers or exit out of the game. The added bonus of the mute switch for the mic is nice as well and I like that I can clip this to my shirt or belt for easy access.

Honestly I would compare these favorably to my Bose speakers in terms of sound quality. But, I think my favorite part is that I can put these on full blast and even someone sitting right next to me won't be disturbed.

Instances.input:
I purchased this when the included software with my Samsung 840 Pro failed to clone my drive (it would do a little, slow down then hang permanently). I was upgrading from a too-small SSD. With the Apricorn unit the transfer process went flawlessly and it transferred about 200GB of data in 25 minutes or so over a USB 3.0 connection.

There was some difficulty in getting the new drive to boot. A little fooling around in the POST setup to reset the new drive to be the first hard drive got it to boot fine (it came up as the second). This might be more nuts-and-bolts than many users would be comfortable with.

The resulting drive does not appear however to be a true clone. When I opened Outlook, it did not find/recognize the internal cache file and started synchronizing everything again with the server (5GB of data to download). There have been other small indications--when I opened the Amazon web page, it no longer recognized and logged me in. I immediately checked Lightroom, as the loss of the catalog file would be a real problem, but that was fine. I assume that the software makes some selections of what it moves to speed up the process, or the problem may lie elsewhere, but be aware that cloning in my case did not result in a completely continuous experience. No insuperable problems, but a little unsettling (what else is not there?).
output: Good product, but not really a clone-maker

I work doing graphics production, identity, print and designed ad feed for social media. Do casual gaming and video editing.

Here are a short list of the real world improvements I have seen so far:

WORK: My workflow had been dramatically improved, handling files was never this easy, exporting a large banner for large printing is a breeze. Exporting a full magazine for pre-press from Adobe InDesign takes so little time. It is a wonder.

GAMING: Maps load in no time, Battlefield 3, Left for Dead 2, Team Fortress 2, this is what I have been playing lately and map loading times are a joke, you know how convenient is to have that first spawn, well you have it.

A little advice, I have 1T hard drive installed too, this is my main back up drive, what I do is that whenever I am developing a graphics project I save everything on a folder on my desktop, open files and add files from there (to make real use of the SSD) when I am done I simply move that folder to my back up drive.

If you are considering buying an SSD then you need one, you will be glad you got this great piece of hardware.

Instances.input:
THINGS TO NOTE:
-You need to reference the Skinomi website and their video VERY carefully.
-Set aside AT LEAST 2 hours before applying this skin on a clean dust-free work area, ESPECIALLY if you're a first timer.
-The skin will probably look bad when you're done. It won't start to look good until after a week has passed. As long as you don't have big bubbles, the little bubbles will go away.

The only experience I've had with applying electronic skins was with easy apply static screen protectors; nothing as intense as this skin is. I was very nervous having to spray liquid onto my hands and my 3DS to apply this skin protector, but I'm here to tell you you'll be fine! When I was done, I thought my applying job was okay, but I was disappointed in myself as there were a couple of bubbles here and there. But lo and behold, they started to fade as time passed! The screen doesn't even look like it has a protector on it, unlike other screens I've seen with protectors.

If you've never put on a skin protector, but have a careful disposition, I'm sure you'll be fine with this product. You'll be proud of yourself when you're done!
output: I was able to put this skin on as a first timer, but I was very careful as well.

I purchased this enclosure because I already own an IDE enclosure that looks almost exactly the same as this one.  In my haste, I purchased this not realizing it is essentially a cheap knock-off of the one I own.  Beware.    I have had no problems transferring data using this enclosure with an SATA hard disk.  However, I will refrain from buying another one of these enclosures due to the poor construction of the case and poor design of the power cable.  The enclosure is equipped to connect to both IDE and SATA disks, but there is barely enough room inside the enclosure for the SATA power cable.  I had to literally crumple the cord into the case to get the top closed.  Normally this would not bother me, except the SATA cord is very thick and acts like a spring when it's curled up inside that tiny space in the shape of an 'S'.  The SATA cord offers so much resistance that I had to force the top of the enclosure shut and hold it down tightly to fit the screws.    Also, the power cable runs an irritatingly short distance from the transformer to the plug for the enclosure.  The large block of a transformer is much closer to the enclosure side of the cable than the outlet plug side of the cable, which forces me to rest the transformer on my desktop next to the enclosure.  I see this as not only an eyesore, but also a safety issue for the enclosure, and perhaps the enclosed hard disk as well.  If the heavy transformer were pushed off the edge of the desk, it could take the enclosure with it, introducing a risk of shock damage to the hard disk.    On the positive side, this enclosure does securely support the hard disk with four small screws.  Not all enclosures have that feature.    I'd like to test the IDE interface, but I'm afraid of putting unnecessary strain on the enclosure.
output: Works well, but case is poorly designed

I'll keep it whenever I do end up buying me another computer... I'd spend $150, but I wouldn't spend $200+. It does have good qualities.. But the first week I got it, it seemed to have a random sound effect. I'd be listening to a video, and it would randomly mute. Easy fix is that I just close out the pages and restart what I was doing.
Also, when it gets a little too hot (for lack of paying attention) it will shut down immediately. Typically, there is some sort of warning on such. And, yes... it's my fault. I need to get a cooling pad, and a desk would be a good idea. But the warnings of overheating are nice.
You can't use Java, so that stinks.
Sometimes the mouse locks up really bad. As soon as I restart it, it will work fine.
So far, the battery is the best I've ever used.
Overall, it's a good computer. Especially if it's just for casual use. I work on the computer, and am constantly listening to music... So it runs a lot. I'm glad I didn't spend $200+. The most I've paid for a laptop was $700, and that was by far the best computer I've ever had. So, I would never pay more than what I paid for this one. But I do like it.
It's a good thing it stands well in a horizontal position because it is heavy and hard to hold.  So when in bed I can just prop it on chest to read.

You get what you pay for. This laptop, refurbished by a qualified HP refurbisher is a replacement for the original laptop ordered. Unfortunately the same problems exist where the new Windows 7 does not completely integrate with the functions available on laptops from 7-10 years ago. So not everything works, and now after having it for a few months the sound system has a short in it, causing the mixer to go off and the program pop up a warning sign in front of what you are doing on the screen...that kind of thing. But for the price, I still have a laptop, warranteed for a year.

Strike that, it took a crap just after I wrote this review. The seller never responded other than two emails asking me what my problem was...so return was not possible. Good thing I had a square trade warranty on it. I no longer do refurbished or Microsoft!

Amazon deserves an F for keeping things accurate on description of products. They have 10 year old comments
about products that have improved and have nothing to do with the comments.
I was furious with them recently for not being accurate on The Sopranos box set. They didn't give a damn
that one set had 33 discs,soundtracks etc from series before 2009,ands the other boxed different,cheaper,smaller,no soundtracks,etc.

Instances.input: I have had the $69 dollar Kindle for over a year and was absolutely delighted with it and recommended it to many people. I ordered the Paperwhite on Oct. 8 2012 and received it shortly after Nov. 1. The lighted screen is great and easier on my old eyes, BUT - all the features I raved about on my first Kindle were replaced with imitations of other books. The list of books I had purchased is replaced by dim, minute copies of the book cover, as are new books offered for sale. Only 6 books per page so looking is time-consuming. The almost instant appearance of new books ordered is not present with the paperwhite - sometimes it is half an hour, some-times much longer, and it is not shown at the top or first so I can check to see if it has arrived. The touch screen is tempermental, sometimes skipping many pages, sometimes not reversing - sometimes just ignoring my request. Amazon took an almost perfect product and created something much inferior. I especially miss a simple typed list of books like the old one had. I intend to return it if Amazon will accept it.

Apple's latest update to their aluminum PowerBook series warrants a close look by current PowerBook users and anyone on the fence. The 17\\" screen is stunning, even keeping in mind that other makers have copied the idea (Apple's overall presentation simply outclasses the copycats' efforts), and the design and construction are first class.
I purchased the new 17\\" PowerBook to replace the previous 15\\" model. The increase in processor speed is noticeable, and I love the new trackpad which incorporates vertical and horizontal scrolling simply by touching the pad with two fingers instead of one. It is immediately easy to use--no extra buttons to manipulate or odd procedures to learn. The screen seems brighter than the previous one, and the new keyboard backlighting is beautiful.
I also like the fact that, besides increasing the base amount of memory, Apple now ships the machines with one memory slot open. That is, a standard 512MB machine has one 512MB strip on board, with one slot open. I simply took the \\"extra\\" 512MB strip out of my previous machine and put it in the new one, giving me a full 1GB of memory (upgradable to 2GB for those planning missions beyond the galaxy or whatever).
Buyers of the new 17\\" PowerBook should also check out the Apple/Brenthaven shoulder bag and backpack. I opted for the backpack this time. It is beautifully crafted; easily worth the slight additional cost over the standard fare, especially since the computer sleeve is made specifically for this computer.
In sum, this is not an \\"intermediate\\" tweak; it is a serious upgrade of an already-great product.

If Samsung wants to convince someone who never owned a tablet to buy one, or someone who has been using iPad and wanted to upgrade, this tablet comes as close to the better choice as ever been. While I think it is hard for a long-time iOS user to switch to Android, the Samsung Galxy Tab S could be the one to switch or additional tablet device you want to get.

I will not attempt to evaluate Android 4.4 here, as there are more qualified people who can do that. If you are used to iOS operating system it is unlikely that you will switch platform because of the latest Android. If you are used to Android in your phones or other Android tablets, congratulation! You now have a tablet device choice that is far superior in term of physical features and technology than any currently in the market. The iPad Mini Retina (which I own) is in the same price range but doesn't even come close.

This tablet is a joy to use. Watching a high definition video on this tablet is a whole new amazing experience. Colors are richer and pictures are so sharp you could not believe it can get to that level. Playing the same video side by side with the iPad Mini retina or iPad 3 and you could tell the differences. The iPad 3 used to have the best screen in all tablets, but no longer. Next to Galaxy S, you would think it is almost dull and boring. I have heard of AMOLED , now I am totally convinced this is the new standard for tablet devices. Playing a video is as easy as clicking on the video file to play it after setting the default player the first time.

The Galaxy Tab S comes with only 16GB or 32 GB, but you can add an additional of 128GB of storage via a microSD slot on the side. There is not many 128GB microSD card available and still expensive, but with 64GB card, you could get to 80GB of total storage. Total cost: $440 versus $600 for a 64GB iPad mini retina and $699 for iPad Air. Adding a 128GB microSD card (around $120) is still cheaper than a 64GB version of either above iPads.

My Nexus 7 is only $220 but hardly belong in the same league. Nexus 7 has no rear camera, no storage expansion option and drained the battery so fast I have to charge it twice a day! A Nexus on full charge, leave in idle, would be dead in about 2 days. So on battery consumption, the Galaxy Tab S has about the same performance as the iPad's .

The camera app in the Galaxy Tab S is far superior to one on the iPad. There are several modes to chose from, most interesting is Dual Camera. You could imprint the image of the front camera to one taken by rear camera! How cool is that?? Image quality is about the same, but of course they look gorgeous on another level when viewing on the Galaxy Tab S.

The Galaxy Tab S is thin and light. So thin that I constantly worry that I would drop it. There is no cover/case for it yet and I hope the future cases have cut-outs for the tablet's stereo speakers. They are located on the side of the tablet, I constantly cover them with my fingers!

I am sure Apple will come up with something clever, hopefully in the same price range to stay competitive. Right now, this table is the reigning king of all tablets due to it price range, features and most importantly, it gorgeous screen.

7/1/14 update: WiFi performance on the Galaxy Tab S is superb; I streamed the same Nextflix movie to the Galaxy and iPad's side by side and the Galaxy really shined. While the iPads continued to buffer and finally gave up and displayed the movie in standard resolution, the Galaxy played the movie in HD with no hick-ups. I guess I could run a speedtest to have better data,but based on this I am not sure I need anymore proof. If you use this tablet mainly for surfing the web, watching streamed movies or playing videos, this tablet is the one to get!!rsion of either above iPads.

My Nexus 7 is only $220 but hardly belong in the same league. Nexus 7 has no rear camera, no storage expansion option and drained the battery so fast I have to charge it twice a day! A Nexus on full charge, leave in idle, would be dead in about 2 days. So on battery consumption, the Galaxy Tab S has about the same performance as the iPad's .

The camera app in the Galaxy Tab S is far superior to one on the iPad. There are several modes to chose from, most interesting is Dual Camera. You could imprint the image of the front camera to one taken by rear camera! How cool is that?? Image quality is about the same, but of course they look gorgeous on another level when viewing on the Galaxy Tab S.

I bought this for a Linux HTPC build. This works great at HD video playback, never had any issues with video playback, artifacts, scan lines, tears, etc. In addition it can even play some basic games, like Source Engine based games. FPS on medium settings generally stay at or around 30fps (occasional dip). This is my first personal APU build and I was fairly impressed with this little guy, it did better then most cheap (<100$) video cards would've done. When it came to compiling (I use Gentoo) it kept up pretty well as well. In single threaded compiling against against a 4.7ghz 1100t it was about 10% slower. Of course you throw 4 parallel jobs at it and you're looking at least 25% slower. This card DOES get hot though. And by hot - I don't know why they included that crappy - not even piped heatsink with it. I threw on the heatsink with the heat pipes that came with my 1100t and it dropped the temps a good 10°c (to about 40°c) at idle, 15-20° at load (about 70°c). It overclocks okay, I played around with it on my Asus motherboard and was able to squeeze about 200mhz more out of it without bumping up the cpuv or temps that much. Unfortunately since I have a really small console case in an entertainment center heat is a concern. Perhaps if I work out a small corsair water cooling system in there I could squeeze some more speed out of it. All in all, for the price and what it is designed to do - I am very happy with this purchase.

A specific situation occurred at our office where we needed to provide a computer to an outside auditor as a "look only" device. Basically, they would come in our office, sit down at this computer and open Excel to look at a few spreadsheets we had preloaded. Management wanted a computer that could not leave, nor could the auditor easily take the spreadsheets with them.

To protect our serial port, we also purchased the Mobile Edge MEALK1 Securicable Key Lock from Amazon.

Let me say up front that these are not LOCKS, but BLOCKERS, as they are so named. Once they are inserted, they CAN be removed with two small screwdrivers. It takes a little patience, but it can be done. The "key" is really only to facilitate you removing the bits from the USB ports. You can install them with your fingers, simply by pushing them into the USB ports. I recommend you use your fingernail to really make sure they are in as far as they can go. This might make it a little harder for someone to remove without the key, but not impossible.

The blocker installer key and four included bits seem to be made from quality components, and we are happy with our purchase.

The unit worked well prior to my update to Mountain Lion (10.8) and it fits in nicely with my other Twelve South gear. I have the [[ASIN:B0084JFM20 Twelve South 12-1215 HoverBar Version 2 Adjustable Arm for iPad 2 and iPad 3]], [[ASIN:B002LARBZE Twelve South (12-0902) BackPack]] and [[ASIN:B004L9M0AO Twelve South (12-1101) MagicWand Connects Magic Track Pad to Wireless Keyboard]], which all work as advertised and make this product not working as advertised under 10.8 a little harder to swallow. I understand that Twelve South is a hardware and design company, but with only one software-dependent offering, I expect it work with the newest OS, especially given the clientele. I am using this product with an early 2011 MBP (2.2 quad, 16gb, 256 SSD, 6750M) connected to an Apple Thunderbolt Display . After the update, the sound prefane doesn't maintain settings to combine with 'Display Audio' and comes across muddled, as I would imagine the audio source is stuck between 'Built-In Audio' and 'Display Audio'. I would have rated the product a 4 or 5 prior to my experience with Mountain Lion (10.8), as it was low profile and delivered what was expected.

I have spoken with Twelve South customer service and received beta drivers and a few generic troubleshooting tips (e.g. using the uninstallation program and reinstalling the package fresh, connecting/reconnecting the audio source, booting with [[ASIN:B005G2R0AU Twelve South (12-1109) BassJump 2]] connected or connecting after OS has loaded) over the course of several months, but to no avail. After months of it not working, it's back in the original box, presumably waiting to be given to a friend or family member who is uninterested or incapable of updating to 10.8. I will look around Amazon for another space-saving audio option for my desk.
output: Worked Well Prior To Mountain Lion Update

First off, Amazon's 2 day shipping was great. My order actually came a day early.     I trust the MacAlly name and have several of their enclosures, including 2 of these. The cases are sturdy and appear well-made. They have two rubber decorative strips that prevent slippage on your desk. And MacAlly generously provides 3 cables - SATA, USB2, and FireWire. They also include a little plastic stand that lets you position the case vertically. Very nice.    Here are some other details about this drive, the good and not so good:    1) You have to unscrew the case to open it and insert your drive (of course). Unfortunately whoever screwed the case together fastened the screws really really tight. I have had to return more than one MacAlly enclosure because I couldn't get the screws off!      2) Once the enclosure is open, you attach 4 cushioned screws to the side of your drive. These fit neatly into a metal rim in the case and provide some shock absorption for your drive - a very nice touch.     3) There are two cables you attach to connectors on your SATA drive. The connectors themselves slide easily into their sockets on the drive. However they are on cables attached to the innards of the enclosure and IMHO very poorly placed. To attach each cable, you need to twist it upside down. One of the cables is very stiff. It makes it tricky to place into the sockets. It also stresses the cable and makes it rise up rigidly. Then to close the case, you have to press really hard to squish the cable down, all the while wondering if you are damaging the cable or other components. Most enclosures, MacAlly or not, have a small space to work in. This one puts a lot of cable in a small small space.
output: Good enclosure, why oh why do they place the cables upside down?

Instances.input:
Top of the line SSD that I purchased after researching all other options for a gaming computer HD. If you don't know it yet, many popular PC games are going to a live-on demand process, which means that the game engine is stored on your HD but content that you encounter in the game world is requested from your hard drive as a result of communications with online servers. What this means is that the server is constantly requesting information from your hard drive to be displayed in the game world. In real time, this creates micro stutters and noticeable jumps and freezes as a traditional HDD spools up to read the platters. A SDD does not have this spool up issue and therefore many of the games that you are used to seeing micro stutters and jumpy graphics instead play smooth as butter. I learned this fact by careful research and then it was proven to me when I purchased and implemented this SSD. Specifically I play World of Tanks and Diablo 3, both of which are improved quite a lot with this SSD.

It comes with access to software that makes it easy to clone your existing HD. You can even migrate your entire OS to this HD and then make your computer boot from this new drive, which will allow you to turn your old HDD into a storage device! This is what I did and I'm never buying a traditional platter HDD for my OS/gaming ever again.
output: PC Gamers Should All Migrate to SSD's

This kit also came with a bottle of system prep for prepping the loop and killing anything in there before long term use, which was a nice add-on.

I had the Samsung branded cover for a year before buying this one, and it was a nice case, but there were two issues I wanted to address. First, while the Samsung cover does protect the screen, it makes it awkward to use around the house because you have to deal with the folded cover when you are walking around, and second, using the camera is nearly impossible with the cover open.

This new cover addressed both issues, and in addition, I find:

The tablet is easy to hold onto with this cover.
The corners are thick, providing extra protection in case of a corner drop.
All the holes line up very well.

The only time I switch back to my old full cover now is when I travel.

The only con is that it is difficult to remove the device from the cover in order to dock it in the keyboard. If you have a Bluetooth keyboard, that won't be an issue.
output: Great for around the house use.

Instances.input: I needed to dedicate my older laptop for the MagicJack I'd been using on my desktop, but the Ethernet port had been damaged. It just plugged in and Windows XP found its own driver for it, set itself correctly to 100Mbps and within a minute or so my old laptop was back online.  I also did not use the included CD.  It works fine without it.

Cons

Instances.input:
I upgraded from an older AMD Radeon 6850 graphics card (which was the loudest thing inside my PC) to this Gigabyte GeForce GTX 660 OC edition. The new card is significantly better than my old card -- I can see lighting and shadow details that I didn't even realize where in my games -- and it runs MUCH quieter.

The "Windforce" heatsink and dual fan design keeps the GPU cool but the card remains relatively quiet even when the fans turn on high. This lack of noise combined with exceptional gaming performance is why I love this graphics card. Sure, I can still hear the fans working when I'm pushing a game at 1080p resolution with all the detail settings maxed out, but the fans aren't so loud that i can't hear my wife or kids calling my name from outside my office (that was a problem with my old Radeon card).

Add to this the fact that the GTX 660 supports my 3D monitor (for the handful of games I might want to play in 3D) and the GTX 660 supports streaming games to the Nvidia Shield and this is simply a fantastic card.

Keep in mind this is a dual-slot card because of the large cooling block so make sure you have two open slots on your motherboard/case. Space isn't too much of an issue -- I was able to fit this card inside a typical mini-tower without any problems -- just make sure you have at least a 500w power supply and you should be golden.
output: A fantastic graphics card and one of the best deals as of Q4 2013.

I travel a lot from appointment to appointment for work and this is a whole lot lighter than lugging around a full laptop. It's a good compromise between work and pleasure. The underside of the keyboard also has a compartment that is made to be very easy for a HD installation. I would highly recommend getting an SSD if you require lots of memory space.

Overall, I have no issues with this purchase. It's perfect for work with enough keyboard typing space and light enough for lots of traveling and not feeling you're carrying a bowling ball.
output: I've taken a look at many other alternatives and ASUS T200 seems to be a good balance on price and performance

Instances.input:
Up front, I should say I got my kindle on a Black Friday sale for $100 off. At that price, I think it's one of the best purchases I've made in years. Furthermore, after getting used to it over the last six months, I think that if someone said I needed to pay an additional $100 to keep it, I would do so in a heartbeat.

I am a PhD student who reads almost exclusively from pdfs of journal articles in my discipline. My plan for the DX was that it would be both a convenient reading tool and file for the papers that pile up over years. It succeeds at both these tasks superbly. I initially tried to make do with a standard sized reading device, a Sony E-Reader, because I thought touch highlighting capabilities would be very important. For me though, the small screen meant I typically had to manually remove the margins from articles and read them in landscape mode, cutting the article into 2 or 3 sections. It doesn't seem like such a big deal, but I found I ended up printing the articles and reading them that way and the device went unused.

The DX is useless for annotating or highlighting PDFs. However, I found this wasn't as big a problem as I initially suspected. When I need to make notes now, I do it on a separate pad of paper. It turns out this doesn't really impact the experience for me.

What has surprised me, is how much I enjoy other aspects of the device. I find I read more articles on the spur of the moment, since I can usually dump them onto the kindle easily. I didn't anticipate how convenient it would be to only have to worry about making sure you have one thing with you, since it carries every article you've ever read with it. I didn't realize how convenient it would be for reading fiction, since before this I always just bought paper books. I like that I no longer think about the fact that a big hardcover fiction book is heavy, when I'm deciding whether or not to throw it in my bag, on the off-chance I have some downtime to read.

Now I'm just worried it will break one day and Amazon will have discontinued the line...
output: Surprised How Much I Like It

Kindle Touch 3G.    What to say about the Kindle Touch 3G?  Well it was everything I hoped for, and more.  I love it!  Most of the things I here people complain about are things that can be fixed simply by getting used to using a touch screen.  The Kindle itself and the touch screen simply take some time to learn how to use it.    Is the Kindle Touch slow and sluggish, is the screen dull and gray?  No!  Only if you make them that way.    Brightness  Major Tip!  A lot of people have debated the screen brightness, background brightness and the color of the background.  The answer lies not in each Kindle being a little different but in the lighting.  Simply put the brighter the lighting the better your Kindle will look.  If your one of those people who puts 40 Watt bulbs in every light socket, draws the curtains closed, snaps the blinds closed and likes it dark(you know who you are out there) then needless to say, your going to be one of those people complaining about the screen not being bright and the background not being white.    I was very worried about the screen brightness before I bought it.  But I am very very happy with it.  If you use Daylight CFL light bulbs(The white lighted ones) the Kindle looks so much better.  Put the Kindle under almost any white florescent light and the Kindle looks great.  The bright white of the florescent bulbs makes the Kindle look like the bright Kindle you see in the Amazon photos.  So the better the lighting the better the Kindle looks.  If your Kindle looks grayish or yellowish its your lack of lighting.  The Kindle looks sharp under a bright incandescent  bulb, but I will concede that the Kindle doesn't look good under the yellowish CFL lights.  Like I said, try looking at your Kindle under all different types of light and you'll see I'm right, those people who complain about the Kindle being murky are probably not using bright enough of a light.  And of course it looks fantastic when your outside on a nice sunny day.    Angle.  If you angle your Kindle vertically(not side to side) and you do it slowly you'll see that the boldness and blackness of the lettering improves greatly when you hit just the right angle.  I find that if I angle the top of the Kindle up(toward you) very slightly the lettering looks even better.    Slow or Sluggish?  No way!  *** Biggest tip of all.  Stop chicken pecking!  Sometimes when you hit the menu button or the goto button and so on, the Kindle doesn't seem to respond.  Thus the complaint that its slow and sluggish.  This is what most people seem to complain about.  Again it's you, not the Kindle.  I was watching a friend of mine use his Kindle and he was trying to bring up the menu.  I swear he looked and sounded like a chicken pecking at seed.  The harder you poke or the harder you press down the less responsive the Kindle is.  Very very very lightly touch the Kindle and it will work so much better and will be faster to respond.  If you have the experience of tapping the menu several times and nothing happens, this is normal at first.  The menu or any other on screen button options will not respond if you strike at it or poke at it or even push down with hard pressure.  Imagine if I told you the Kindle screen was wired to explode if  you put too much pressure on the screen.  Think about how lightly you would touch the screen, and that is how lightly you should touch it.  I can get any of the menu and other on screen buttons to respond quickly and instantly and with only one try.  It's NOT called the Kindle peck, or the Kindle Poke or the Kindle Push or the Kindle Press, it's the Kindle TOUCH!    I bought a small stylus and that helps a lot.  The stylus is about and inch and a half long with a rubber tip and has a loop so it can dangle from your finger.  I don't use it to turn pages because that's not necessary, but I use it for just about everything else on the Kindle and it makes Kindling so much easier.  Especially on the on screen keyboard.  Again VERY lightly touch your Kindle, you don't have to peck at it or push down.  The touch aspect takes a couple weeks to get used to.  So don't use your Kindle for a few days and write a bad review the day after your Kindle arrives.  I can't emphasize enough buy a mini stylus, it makes a big difference!  You can by a full size stylus or a mini, and they come in all sorts of colors.  The stylus I purchased can be found here -  [....]    (Take note that this stylus can plug into the headphone jack, but this is a place holder, its not intended to be in the jack while your using it, the cord is way to short for that.  The cord is just meant to loop around your index finger.)    Battery  The battery life is based on an average of 30 minutes a day as described in the Amazon description.  So for me reading about 90 minutes to 2 hours a day, the Kindle lasted about 21 days.  That's fantastic when you compare it to a cell phone(especially a smart phone)  or almost any other electronic device that's rechargeable.  Keep something important in mind, the first week or two or so that you own your Kindle, you'll be playing around with it a lot, and that causes a lot of page refreshes and that zaps the battery life.  Judge your Kindle's battery life after the second charge and after your through playing with it, and settle in to more of a reading routine.  Also remember something else, it only takes about 3 hours to recharge, so big deal!  So what about those people who whine that the battery doesn't last that long.  Well . . .   1. The only two things on the Kindle that use battery power while it's on, are the Wi-fi/3G and the page refresh.  It is not an LCD screen.  It's E-Ink.   2. So if you keep the Wi-fi/3G turned on then your Kindle will suck the battery power faster.  So turn the Wi-fi/3G off!  You only need it when your downloading or syncing or searching the Kindle store, you don't need it when your reading.  NOTE - You turn the 3G off by turning the Wi-fi off.   3. Keep the pagerefresh at it's default setting, when you change it to refresh every page you are cutting 75% of the battery life.  Yes 75%.   4.  Don't turn your Kindle off!  Put it in sleep mode unless your going to be away for more that 3 days or so. When you turn the Kindle completely off it goes into an indexing mode, and that takes battery power.  Your Kindle uses little to no power in sleep mode. This is in the user guide.    Another tip I'll give goes counter intuitive to everyone else's tip.  When turning pages DON'T SWIPE.  Just lightly touch the screen, it works so much better.  When you swipe vertically up or down it makes it jump to the next or previous chapter, this is actually very handy.  But some people say they make it jump to the next chapter by mistake when trying to swipe to turn the page.  Like I said just a light touch and the page turns, save your swipes for chapter jumps.    Page Turn  I can see that some people might like the page turn buttons on the Nook or previous Kindle's, but frankly it takes almost no effort to touch the screen with your thumb to go to the next page. (Assuming it's in your right hand.)  I do this almost with out thought.  If your holding it in your left hand you can still do this very easy, you just have to stretch your thumb out a little.  You can go page forward and back and hold the Kindle in one hand, if your holding it with your left hand and holding at the bottom left corner.  Though as I said I see why some people might miss the page turn buttons.  But frankly for me it's just and unconscious effort to turn the page.  It's not like your being asked to do one hundred one armed push-ups or something!    Ghosting?  I personally don't see the ghosting, I know two other people who have Kindles and they never see it either.  If you do have a problem with it, the only choice is to change the page refresh to every page, but as I said this will chew up the battery.  I will say that about maybe once every couple weeks I might see a very slight distortion on a page, this can be fixed with a quick 1 second touch to put the Kindle in sleep mode and then a quick 1 second touch to bring it back.  But I only have seen this 2 or 3 times in the six weeks I've owned it.    To 3G or not to 3G  I bought 3G for some long complicated reasons I won't go into.  A lot of people who bought 3G because they travel a lot seem to regret it.  You can always download books before your trip.  But I do recommend the 3G if your one of those people or you know someone who can barely turn their computer on, doesn't even know what a router or Wi-fi is. I think for those people 3G is much better.  The fact that I can't surf the internet using free 3G(except the Amazon Kindle store and Wikipedia) doesn't bother me at all, it's an e-reader not a tablet, so get over it!  You can surf the web using Wi-fi mode.  For reasons of full discloser lets explain.  Using free 3G you can surf Amazon's Kindle store down load books and apps for free.  You can surf Amazons Kindle store and Wikipedia Free.  But you can't send documents or down load audio books with free 3G  But you can do these with either  Wi-fi or the USB Cable.  You can also surf the web with the Wi-fi.  Also don't forget you can buy books on your computer and purchase them, and then on your Kindle click the Home screen - menu - snc(with the Wi-fi/3G on), and you book/app will download.  Frankly it's a lot easier doing this on the computer then surfing the Kindle store on the Kindle.  It also saves your Kindle's battery life.    Special Offers  The screen saver is an ad, but frankly the ads look ten times better than the default ugly Amazon screen saver so who cares!  A small ad about the size of your pinky sits at the bottom of the home screen, its very tiny and out of the way.  And an ad may appear on Amazons Kindle store site your surfing, but how often do you do that?  And again the ad is small.  There are NO ads while your reading.  They are so irrelevant and amount tonothing, I think it's a brilliant way to lower the cost of the device in a bad economy.  It's hard to imagine any one who isn't a stuck up elitist having a problem with the ads.  I think it's actually interesting to see what's going to pop up in the screen saver next.  I'm sorry to be rude but if your offended by a couple of minor ads then pay $30 to $40 more and quit griping.    Features  One click on a word in a book, and the dictionary pops up.  Cool!  And very handy.  X-ray.  Well this one I've had limited experience with, not all books have X-ray.  It will give a chart telling you where a character appears in a book or chapter, click on the character and it will tell you more, or take you to a wikipedia article.  In some cases it will tell you more about a thing or place or event.  I believe this feature will be expanded as publishers get used to it.  You can bookmark and better yet, have multiple bookmarks.  You can make notes, and highlight text.  And so much more.    Another tip  It's amazing how many people buy the Kindle to read, but then don't read the user guide.  Yes sometimes it's fun with electronics to not read the user guide and learn as you go, but in this case read the user guide.(Which is in Ebook form on your Kindle.)    Nitpicks.  Okay so I guess I have to find something to complain about so you'll believe this is a real review.  Bookmarking is easy, just touch the top right corner and a small dog eared bookmark appears. (You can delete the bookmark the same way.  But retrieving bookmarks could be a tad easier, though it gets easier with time. You can find a page number(if the original book had page numbers) by clicking the menu then looking at the bottom of the page.  The option to have the page numbers there all the time would be nice.  And a book should start with the cover, but not on the Kindle?  When you click to read a book the cover doesn't pop up, it would just be cool if it did.  (You can see the cover by back paging or clicking gotoand then clicking cover.)     Over all I love it!  The ability to buy a book online, click sync on the Kindle and WHAM there it is on your Kindle is just so amazing.  No spending money on gas driving around town looking for that one book, and then trying to figure out what to do with the books after you read them. I have a PC laptop with a Mini DisplayPort output. I wanted to connect my 2560x1440 monitor so I bought this cable. Initially I was worried about the issues with pin 20, but I would like to confirm that pin 20 on this cable is NOT connected to anything. I tested pin 20 with a DMM. Furthermore, according to Startech, there are only 19 active pins on this cable. My display wakes up fine after it goes to sleep. Bottomline: it works.
output: Works Fine: Pin 20 is not connected

As someone who has only Razer peripherals, and loves them more than any other brand, I found this mouse pad disappointing. There is according to the description, a side for speed, and a side for control. While you can definitely tell the difference between the sides upon actually rubbing the textures, I really cannot tell while using a Razer DeathAdder mouse. One thing about this pad however is that it is painfully loud. It makes a loud grinding sound any time you move the mouse across it, regardless of whatever side you are using, and it grinds away at the pads on the bottom of the mouse. While you can use the pad without the wrist rest, the rest itself is of disappointing quality. It is a pretty pad, and doesn't quite feel like gel, but rather rubber, and the Razer insignia printed on it is essentially a fabric sticker that rubs off after only a few hours to a day of use. There really isn't anything good to say about this pad with the exception of the fact that the Razer Synapse software has presets for mouse calibration with the Vespula in mind, making the mouse more accurate on the pad. In the end, you're better off with just a cloth pad.
output: Not really a good mouse pad.

I wanted to try liquid cooling for the first time on my sister's PC (This was one of my first builds)
I was noticing the stock cooler for the AMD Phenom II 955 was struggling to keep the CPU at 45 C' idle and going 69+ C' when gaming. The noise was so annoying that I decided to replace it.

Given that I built this PC in 2010 I said myself why not replace this with liquid cooling, from what I saw on Benchmarks from various websites the benefits were substantial to convince myself to spend $60 for this model, I needed something that can keep my CPU 30' Idle and less than 50' when gaming and quiet like the Cooler Master TPC 812 (I paid almost $80) that I use on my Main PC.

Once I installed the H55 I was impressed with its cooling capability, In idle the CPU runs from 29 to 32 C' and when running games from BF3, NFS5 and Crysis 3 the PC did not pass 43 C'

Now my disappointment was that the fan was louder than the AMD Stock fan, I was expecting this to be quieter given that this is the "quiet" edition liquid cooling. In the two floor house I could hear the PC running from the stairs.

Luckily I had an extra spare fan Corsair SP 120 quiet edition (Now this fan is quiet as the name says) to replace the one that came with the H55, and the noise level went down substantially. I knew to not put weaker fans on the liquid coolers but the temps were unchanged with the SP120. I played Crisys 3 on with this fan and the temp did not pass 45 C'

So In summary I can say liquid cooling will give you way better cooling capability vs High End Heatsinks. Now the other factor that come into play is noise. My Cooler Master TPC 812 is still quieter even though I'm using Push Pull se-tup. So if noise is a concern better to have a quieter fan available just in case.

Pros:

Excellent Cooling power 45 C' under full load
Its low Profile Grill makes it great for mid ATX Cases
Ease of Install
Water Pump takes less space and looks cool

Cons:

Noise

PC used:

AMD Phenom II 955
ASUS M4A87TD
AMD Radeon 6770 1GB
8 GB Corsair Vengeance DDR3 1600Mhz
1.5 TB WD Caviar Blackr Pump takes less space and looks cool

Cons:

Noise

1.5 TB WD Caviar Black

After dealing with the HP 1010NR and its meager 8GB hard drive I started checking out the reviews on Amazon for netbooks and was amazed by the amount of positives for this one.  I bought one and now I know why.  This is an amazing little computer.  From the much larger screen size to the addition of Bluetooth and the ample 160GB hard drive,and the wonderful battery life (i'm averaging 6.5 hours on one charge so far...) this one puts most other netbooks in the dust.  I thought long and hard between this one and the Asus HE but I have a Samsung HDTV and the T260HD Monitor and I love them both so I went with this and I am very glad I did.  One other pleasant thing was how easy this was to network when I had room to install Windows 7 on it and networked it with our main computer.  I had to input one code and it works like a dream!  I dont do tech speak so you will probably get more out of other reviews but just suffice it to say that you will love this if you spend just the little bit extra.  And oh, NEVER buy HP.  If the junk they sell isnt bad enough, their customer service is the worst in the business.  Buy Samsung, Dell or something else and enjoy life!

I've used this product for a couple of weeks now.  The battery life is good under moderate use (5-8 hours per day).  I'm able to use it for more than a week without charging.  It took a week or so to get use to the finger swipe options.  Once you get the swing of things, the touch pad begins to earn its worth.  I use several Logitech devices and they seem to never disappoint me.  The touch pad is attractive, useful wirelessly, and works extremely well with Windows 8.  One of the gotchas is that your hands would need to stay dry to take advantage of the finger swipes (however, this holds true for most touch pads).  The second gotcha is the left mouse click (for drag and drop features), you must have the touch pad on a flat service since the clicking occurs when you push down on the left corner of the touch pad  (you can actually hear the clicking when pressing).  Uneven surfaces makes it difficult to do a left mouse click because it requires "hard" pushing of the left corner of the touch pad on uneven surfaces.  Make sure to keep the touch pad on hard flat surface and this problem completely goes away.  Overall, I give this product a strong 8 (from 1 to 10).

I currently own a Link Station Pro Quad 8TB unit. I purchased it from Amazon on April 19 2011, on May 14, 2011 I had my first failure Error Code E07 which is no single lights and 7 red flashing lights in .03 second intervals. This error code means Logic Board failure. I RMA'd the unit back, and Buffalo was more than accommodating and helpful. I received my new (refurbished) unit in 7 days. Unpacked, Setup and began using the unit, all is good ok.
On July 31st I went to power up the unit and low and behold I get that damn E07 error again 7 short flashing red lights
Logic Board Failure. Once again Buffalo was more than accommodating and I received my new (refurbished) unit in 5 Business days. As before all went well and and I am in the process of loading it now.

My suggestion to anyone buying a Link-Station DONT! Save your pennies and go for the TeraStation, as it is an Enterprise class unit not a Consumer Class unit like the LinkStation. I always Opt for the Enterprise class in any hardware I purchase, but this time I just could not seem to muster up the $2,700.00 they asked, the $819.34 dollar Link Station seemed more attractive. and Besides I previously had owned an old Link-Station single drive 320 no web access, I left that damn thing on for 3 years non stop without one failure. it ran like a charm. soooo I dunno what is up here, I wish they would do a little bit of investigation into this issue and deem it a Know Issue and put it on the Recall list. It is not the fact they die, it is just a royal pain in the *ss every time I have to reload it. I have 720 Videos along with 1.8TB of Software. So it becomes a 3 week Job. Oh and to add to the reloading I can only run the server that the data is being backed up from during the cooler evening hours to avoid blowing a breaker. (It is a Dell PowerEdge 2900) One bad *ss twin Quad (8 core 2.33) 16 GB memory, Oh and the word slow down is not even in its vocabulary. The PE motors thru anything you throw at it. except hot days or having anything else running on that particular circuit. I know your probably thinking that this could be the issue with the Linkstation failure, I can assure you it is not, I have it on its own private Edison Circuit with nothing else running on it.

With that little bitch session over with I am off my soap box

Thank You all for listening and take to heart what I said about the Link station it is all too real.
if you dont believe me call buffalo and ask them about the guy with the 714-610**** telephone number and his problems. they will confirm what I am saying. I am not giving out my entire number but they do know me, my real name is Rob and i am in Long Beach CA

C-Ya

I know your probably thinking that this could be the issue with the Linkstation failure, I can assure you it is not, I have it on its own private Edison Circuit with nothing else running on it.

With that little bitch session over with I am off my soap box

Thank You all for listening and take to heart what I said about the Link station it is all too real.

The Intel Sandy Bridge line of processors is simply amazing. I have not a single complaint about them. The i5 is ideal for those who want a lot of \\"snap\\" when using MS office products (large spread sheets for example), doing some photoshop, or other tasks which might need a bit more grunt than what you get with the core i3. If you aren't playing the latest video games or doing heavy video editing, then the i5 is really ideal.

With the \\"K\\" variant, you have the option to do some overclocking to get even more performance. On a stock cooler, you can easily bump the processor speed up to 3.5+GHz without worry. In my opinion, this extra bit of flexibility is well worth the extra cost vs the standard 2500.

Since I have a Linksys Wireless N router and now need a little more distance and strength than the built-in wireless G in my computer I decided to try this, despite the cost.  My throughput is now twice my nearby wired connection, over 200k bps!  Dependable strong signal and it goes further!  I recommend purchase for those needing higher and stronger connections, especially if you already have the Linksys Wireless-N router.

Instances.input:
I had been looking for mobile storage for quite a while, specifically for offloading photos. I don't like the idea of multiple cards as I know I won't be using them too often. So that left me with the expensive photo storage devices or a cheap small laptop.

Neither are too attractive due to costs and maintenance.

Then I stumbled across the RAVPower FileHub. It is essentially a self-powered mobile NAS or file server.

So I only have to bring along the FileHub and a portable USB hard disk and I have a large easily accessible mobile storage for various files and photo storage/backup and a portable battery for charging other devices via USB.

The device can easily be accessed, via WiFi using the iOS app, to transfer files between attached storages, USB and SD card, and I have not had any problem watching movies from the portable USB hard disk.

The device is very easy to carry around. It is light weight and quite thin.

The built-in battery is rated 3,000mAh but I had not have to depend on it extensively. So I can only say that so far I am quite happy with how long it lasted.

If more power is needed, another model - WD02 is rated at 6,000mAh, has DLNA service for streaming video and has a network port for connecting the device to a network using network cable.

However, this model only support micro-SD along with a USB device. So if you need to connect to a SD card, you will need to use a converter and connect it to the USB port – which means you cannot transfer files between a SD to a USB HDD.

I reviewed this keyboard 3 1/2 years ago and trashed on it, but in all fairness I just had to return to update my review. The reason I trashed it was a defect that my unit had where it would randomly act like the hyperspace button on the old asteroids video game. The cursor would just vanish and reappear somewhere else often when you'd go to do a right click. Well that unit was smashed into a thousand pieces in anger when it clicked on the wrong thing at the wrong time, but when I had ordered it I had ordered 2 of them. The second one has lasted this entire time in my media room with almost daily use. I can't say how many times it's dropped onto the tile floor and the battery door popped off and the batteries scattered across the floor and rolled under the couch, from on top of my eliptical machine even from 6ft up! But I put it back together and it keeps on ticking. So my first unit was a disaster and my second one has been bulletproof. Over the last 3 years I've gone through 4 other competitors to replace the smashed one and I've yet to find one as good. Now I have to say this thing isn't perfect, and it's NOT for desktop use. But it's ideal for when you don't have a platform to operate a separate keyboard and mouse.

Pros: over 3 years and still going strong of nearly daily use in my media room! Form factor, combined mouse and keyboard in the perfect sized package. Compared to others, pretty darn durable. not indestructible, but very forgiving. Very long battery life. Takes alkaline, no recharging. Replace batteries every 6 months is about it. Top row of media buttons, volume, play, mute etc. Oh and the range is pretty good too. Actually have no problem with range. Probably about 30ft.

Cons: If they'd only make the trackball able to pop out for cleaning like other track ball mouses do. Eventually it gets little dust bunnies clogging up the sensors causing it to be sticky. About every 6 months I take it out to my shop and pull the screws out of the back, disassemble it and clean out the contacts. It's unavoidable really, unless you live in an intel clean room it's going to happen. One little stupid peeve is the volume buttons are backwards. Right is down and left is up. You get use to it, but ..

So I'm knocking it one * for 50% failure rate in my personal case, and for not having a pop out trackball for cleaning.

If this thing died for any reason, I'd have to order another one. I just haven't found anything as good. I have to say I've also tried the competitors with a trackpad figuring no sensors to clean, which is true, but it's way more fragile and I'm much more fluent with the trackball so despite my best efforts over 3 years to top this one, so far I can't. I'm still ticked off about the first one, but the second one is rock solid!
This has held up great for my four year old! I don't have a \\"panic\\" feeling when I see him playing with his kindle and walking at the same time because I know it's safe!
It really helps when I'm trying to do my homework. I also put my textbook on it and now I carry that around, because it's lighter.
This is a GREAT product. Highly recommended !

I have received the Netgear AC750 Dual Band WiFi Gigabit Router (R6050) free as a participant of the NETGEAR Friends and Family review program.

The setup only took a few minutes to connect the wires and then access the configuration page. To access the configuration page use the default IP address or http://www.roterlogin.net for easy access. I changed a few wireless access settings and I was able to connect using my laptop and iphone. You will have to setup different SSID names for 2.4 and 5GHz wifi bands. Strange but not a deal killer. After setup I could also use the Netgear Genie iOS app to access the AP to monitor my network and change settings.

This router has a lot of features for the price. It has great range (I could access the AP everywhere in my house), a usb 2.0 port for a non-network printer or external hard drive, has 1 WAN and 4 LAN 10/100/1000 Ethernet ports, and the ability to enable an isolated Guest Network access. The Guest Network is great because I can give my kids’ friends wireless access but know they won’t have access to my local intranet.

The performance was great with one user connected streaming video. I did not try multiple users streaming or playing online games.

The AC750 is a great middle of the road router that performed the tasks you would expect out of a unit in its class.
output: Easy setup, great features, nice value for price

Hi,
I was initially disappointed with this device as I was unaware that it would only stream video (this was my primary use) that was in the format that my ipad and iphone would play natively. This was a real pain, as I was hoping to avoid all the converting nonsense. However, I bought a cheap app off the app store called nPlayer (think it was 69p or around that) and once I added the SMB/CIFS network (which is 10.10.10.254 for verbatim mediashare devices, other devices may have a different default value)I found this app would stream ALL of my video's! MKV,AVI,MP4,DivX....the lot, perfectly, from either the SD card or a usb device (they both show up if plugged in)
This has made the device a joy to use.
I also found that for some reason, if you set up a wireless bridge, but the internet connection for this network is out of range, the mediashare device will sometimes constantly lose the connection to your device. By turning the wireless bridge feature off in these circumstances, via the settings, a constant connection is achieved (which i've found is also a bit quicker when copying files). The constant dropping of the connection to devices doesn't seem to happen when the internet bridge can connect to a strong reliable internet connection.
Hope this helps people, because when it's up and running correctly it's a device I wouldn't be without!
output: Good bit of kit once you've figured it all out.

I'm a complete technology geek. I love my iPhone and I love my Kindle 3 Keyboard. I'm a big reader. My biggest issue on the Kindle keyboard was the lack of a back light. I know, I know, e-ink and all that. Don't get me wrong, I actually prefer reading on my Kindle Keyboard even after having the Fire for a few weeks. Easier on the eyes (and battery life).  For what it's made for, the Fire is a pretty good device. I can't rate it excellent or even great because of two issues that are a big turn off for me.   The good- It's fun. Seriously, there is a lot to do on the Fire. You can read, watch tv shows and movies, play games or play on the web. It does what it says it will. It's a media hub. I have used it to check email, get on Facebook, watch shows on Netflix, play games and read mostly. It is responsive and I have had almost no bugs or issues like that. It's fast too. I love reading at night on it because I don't have to mess with a light hanging off the Kindle. I like how smooth the pages turn. Is this an \\"iPad killer\\"? No. I already have an iPhone so I have no need for a bigger version of the same device (I have never quite understood that). It's not marketed as an iPad, either. It's a much better size for portability and to hold comfortably. It's a great price. And it's Amazon, which I love!  Now my two BIG issues.   1. A complete and total lack of any way to organize your books. Seriously? My Kindle Keyboard can organize books, but the Fire doesn't? I have a lot of books on my device and I would like to keep all my books on it. I am a bit OCD about my organization and this is almost a deal breaker for me. I have seriously considered not using it because I don't like having to scroll through hundreds and hundreds of books. Use the search feature? Sure, that may work if you know what you are looking for. For me, though, when I finish a series I don't always know what I want to read next. On my old Kindle I had everything sorted by Author and as I finished a book Ideleted it. On the Fire I feel so lost in between a series that I ended up pulling all my books off via Calibre and just loading one author's books. Very frustrating. Amazon seriously needs to not only add collections, but an easy way of putting books into collections.   2. The Carousel. I mean, I actually like the carousel. Although it is a bit touchy sometimes. But the front screen should be customize-able.  I don't want every book in my library showing on my main screen. I also do not need someone to see every web page I have visited. I know I can clear history, but seriously who wants to do that every time they visit a page? I have two teens that play with my Fire from time to time and I am unable to hand it over without some concerns about privacy.   Obviously a software update would fix both of these issues. Perhaps options for the front screen selecting what you wish to show, and what you don't would be a good start.  All in all the Fire is a great device. However, if you are concerned about being able to organizing your books or privacy issues, you might want to wait and see if these issues are addressed.
output: Great device with two major (for me) issues
