The size and quality is all I expected, and more.  Have you ever bought a laptop bag that was labeled \\"for laptops up to 18 inches\\", to finally discover that your 17.5\\" laptop wouldn't fit? I have.  Now I have a 18\\"+ ASUS G74, and there are very few bags that even pretend to fit this.  I got the Everki Titan backpack today, and my laptop fits perfectly. Not only that, but I can add my smaller 17.5\\" laptop if I want...  Alternatively, I can also fit the bigger laptop, a tablet and my DSLR + telephoto lens + tripod.  And in either configuration, there is room to spare for power supplies, battery chargers, external hard drives, and a change of clothes if I need to use it as a carry-on bag... Which I can, because it fits well within the allowed dimensions in airplanes bins.  The build quality is also excellent: large zips (so they will not get stuck), sturdy materials, extra strappings to make sure you can carry that extra weight easily. The inside is well designed (I counted some 15 pockets of all sizes, but I may have missed some), and generously padded.  The only quips I have so far are very minor: I would have liked a few larger pockets (most of them are only large enough to put a power supply in -- the brick size kind I have for my laptop), and well... aesthetically, it's not bad (mostly because the all-black exterior is discreet), but definitely looks industrial. Then again, I didn't buy this backpack for its looks.
output: Giant bag for giant laptops, plus all your stuff.

Thank you for contacting Targus customer support.

Unfortunately, we have identified some issues with a few different models of the new Targus iPad 3rd Generation cases. To assist you further, I will need you to provide me with a copy of the receipt for proof of purchase of this case either emailed or faxed to us. We are anticipating having these manufacturered and shipped out within the next 6-8 weeks.

I truly appreciate your patience and cooperation in this matter and I anticipate hearing back from you soon for further resolution.

Thank you for the update. I have forwarded your replacement request to our warehouse for placement of this order. You may feel free to keep the case you have and to use this to the best of your ability. We are anticipating have the redesigned cases available for shipment to you within the next 6-8 weeks.

UPDATE: I have been able to utilize the array as long as I connect it to a powered USB3 hub ... strange, since the array is self-powered, also, the fan has now completely failed, I will need to search for a replacement to install. upon close examination, the fan is only mm from the interface board, not sure if the fan is just there to keep the interface board cool, not much room for good air flow, I might consider modifying the chassis in order to mount a more reliable fan. I did notice, as the unit heated up, i would begin to notice intermittent connectivity between my computer and the array.  If you want a USB3 enclosure, THIS is NOT the enclosure you want. This RAID Array works fine when connected to a USB2 port (recognition by the computer, file transfer R/W) but when connected to the USB3 port of my computer (MSI GT70 laptop) the enclosure is not recognized by the computer, mounting and un-mounting repeatedly till I remove the enclosure from the USB3 port. I have looked for firmware updates for both my laptop as well as the enclosure, the laptop is working fine with other USB3 hard drives I have. Though I do not have another device to confirm the issue with the Dyconn enclosure, I still recommend you find another manufacturer if you want a USB3 enclosure, If you're fine with the enclosure running USB2, then it will do what you need.  An amendment to this review is the fan, I have already gone through 2 of these units already, and the fan is beginning to fail again with a sound similar to something that is unbalanced. I will most likely keep this unit and replace the fan myself, as it does work as a decent usb2 storage device. But AGAIN if you have any serious needs for a USB3 storage array, spend the extra money, it will do you well in the end.
output: Does not work properly with USB3 connection

I've had the TEW-659BRV for about 2 weeks now. It has a nice feature set, but every day it drops connections and loses computers on the LAN. I have to reboot the router to recover. Some kind of a routing problem I would guess. It seemed to be a little more frequent if I used the multiple SSID and DHCP reservation features. I bought this router because the Cisco RV-120 was poorly reviewed, but I don't think this one is any better. It is on it's original firmware however, so maybe there's hope in the future.

The static IP/DHCP reservation setting was a little strange in that it wouldn't let you set static IP's outside the DHCP range of addresses. You can work around that by temporarily widening the DHCP address range, reserving the static IP's, and then restoring the normal DHCP range.

The firewall can't be turned off as far as I can tell. That might have been nice since this is now just a standalone VPN server and wireless AP for me now. Only on my second day of that duty, but so far so good. I have created a PPTP VPN link from a Windows 7 computer to the router with no problems. However, I have no Internet through the VPN when this router's WAN is not connected.

It wants to run the setup Wizard every time you log in to the router. One or two extra clicks to get to something useful.

All pretty good, except it needs that reboot pretty frequently. I look forward to a firmware update. Until then, I have a Linksys E3200 as my Internet gateway, and it hasn't had any problems other than no VPN server.

This wireless mouse requires Windows 7 and a WIN7 certified WiFi network adaptor.  I have Windows 7 Starter on my Asus netbook.  As far as the network adaptor, I didn't have a clue about that, but apparently it's there.  The mouse works on Wi-Fi, and does not tie up a USB port.  I connected up my external disk drive to the Asus, popped in the mini-disk, and closed the drive.  The software loaded quickly.  Following the pictorial instructions included, I pulled the tab from the mouse battery case, turned the switch to \\"On\\" and I had a functional mouse.  No problems whatsoever.  This is the first wireless mouse I've ever used.  It's pretty big and oddly shaped, but not uncomfortable to use.  It has a touch scroll where a wheel would be.  Right now, I have to say I prefer a wheel to the touch scroll, but it might be I just have to get used to it.  The packaging says that the \\"Innovative touch scroll adjusts to the speed of your finger to get you there fast.\\"  Well, maybe with a bit more practice that will be true.    The mouse has six buttons, allowing you to create shortcuts.  The box also claims \\"precision laser tracking\\" that works on almost any surface, except possibly glass.  Battery life of nine months is claimed.  As noted above, batteries were already installed, and had to be activated by pulling the tab.  I didn't open the case to see what kind of batteries they were (and it didn't say anywhere on the packaging that I could find) but the on-line write-up says the mouse uses two standard AA batteries.  One drawback to a wireless mouse is the need to remember to turn it off when not in use.  I'm not sure the advantages of having a wireless device make up for this mild nuisance, for me anyway.  But the mouse itself is fine, and worked for me practically right out of the box.
Perfect Transaction.  Will buy again!!!!

Instances.input:
I have held off for many years buying a Kindle mainly because I love books, the tactile sensation of having a book and being able to display them on bookshelves. I decided to go ahead and get one because I had lost most of my books when I had to move and could not bring them with. I felt that with the copious amount of books that I have bought in the past and having no intention of stopping that behavior, it would be best for me to get all of the books I previously owned on a Kindle. This should negate the worry of needing to replace my library should something untoward happen again. I will still purchase certain books in print, but far fewer than before and likely duplicated on my Kindle as well.
Thus far I have been nothing but pleased with my purchase. The display is clear and bright, with no issues whether I am reading in the dark before bed or waiting for the bus on a sunny day. All of the books I have downloaded so far have done so quickly to the point of being almost instantaneous. The ability to change the size of the font I could see as being particularly useful for people with poor eyesight, which I will undoubtedly have later in life since I read in the dark. I am particularly a fan of the built in dictionary that allows you to highlight a word while reading just by touching the word and have the definition come up in a pop-up window. This saves me some time as I like to look up any words I am unfamiliar with. Additionally, I enjoy the ability to highlight passages while I am reading and then be able to access all of my highlighted passages in one location. When I read something I find particularly insightful or beautiful I always mean to write it down or memorize it for later use. The highlight feature makes this process much more convenient.
I am very pleased with my Kindle and would recommend it to anyone who was interested. My one complaint is a small one and has nothing to do with the quality of the product. Rather it is a complaint on thechoice of model I have. I would like to be able to view the covers of my book in color to better appreciate the artwork. I chose the paperwhite model without realizing how much I would want that after the fact. Always has to be some complaint though, I guess. Mine is due to my own lack of foresight, at least.
Broke instantly.  I would not recommend backing-up data you care about on this.  I plan on buying a Seagate when I can afford another portable HDD.  I should have read The Wirecutter sooner :\ .

One corner has some of the pink chipping away, but after a year and with my own personal fidgetting and picking at it when I play games or read, that makes sense. All in all this is a great product that's really lasted for me, and I'm so glad that this was the one I ended up choosing over something else. A great investment, and a cute one at that.
output: Long lasting and cute to boot

Instances.input:
I just picked this up today and can't say enough about my initial reaction. I have a three-year-old AOC flat panel monitor that is now serving as my second display. Looking at the two side-by-side, you see a remarkable difference.

Sharp, bright, huge, almost intimidating. If you can get your hands on one of these, I think you'll feel the extra money you'll pay over a 21\\" is money well spent.

Notable features include:
- 90 degree rotation (your monitor can be portrait or landscape)
- picture in picture
- 16:10 aspect ratio
- 1920 X 1200 resolution (make sure your video card supports it)
- HD-ready!
- VGA, dual component, S-Video and composite
- DVI-D with HCDP input
- 4-port USB (2.0) hub

There's an available option for a speaker bar along the bottom. The monitor adjusts very easily. Raising and lowering it is aided by a spring system. The entire monitor is actually very light (~15 pounds)

I'm very happy with this purchase.
output: A monitor to be excited about

Instances.input: I wouldn't normally write a review on a keyboard, but I LOVE this keyboard!! I've checked out quite a few over the last 10 years and finally found this one. It has the soft feel to the keys that I've always wanted, it's much more quiet than any other keyboard I've used, and I really do like the surface as well. The letters are printed under the keys so wearing away will never be a problem. Also, the keys light up immediately and with the lightest touch. I've read that some people have had problems with the battery life, but I've not experienced any problems yet. I've only had this item for a few weeks, but I've yet to charge it and it has been going strong.  Some people don't like the feel and look of the keys. I think someone even said that they felt like chicklets, but I love them.   Great keyboard, and one that has made writing much more enjoyable for me.

This D-Link wireless router was easy to connect to for configuration but it took a visit to the D-Link site to figure out how to secure my network as the configuration utility was not intuitive.

My two PCs use the G-122 USB key to connect to the network. These work like a dream with Vista once you can find the driver at the D-Link site. Vista sorts out all the configuration for you. Also works well with Windows 2000 but you have to configure the USB key using a utility, which is not that intuitive to use - again a visit to the D-link support site is required to figure out how to set up a security. G-122 didn't work on my Windows ME PC when the network was secured but did work when it was unsecured.

Had to change my router to channel 11 to avoid interference from my 2.4GHz Panasonic cordless phone.

Altogether a pretty good product for D-Link that makes it easy to set up your own wireless network.
output: D-Link make it pretty easy to get a wireless network up-and-running

So when I decided to get an iPad Mini, I researched TPU cases before I bought the Mini.

This TPU case fits the Mini perfectly, and has the grippy quality I appreciate.

The only negative is that it has sharp mold-lines right where my fingers go. My iPhone 4 and 5 cases don't have them there- they managed to put the mold lines where they don't annoy.

INITIAL REVIEW: This case fits well (assuming that you are ordering the right product, just check, it's not that hard). It's easy to put on, and possible, though not easy to get off (which is kind of the point). It has a nice feel to it and leaves all ports open as designed. I only have two minor reasons for giving it 4 instead of 5 stars. one, there was a slight blemish, sort of like a thin spot, in the coating. You can't really see it when it's on the computer, and I bought it to make it grippier/easier to handle, so I decided I was fine with it. The second is that if you use your MacBook a lot so that your wrists/arms rest on the front edge of the case, this added case has two little 1/2\\" clips along that edge, about 1\\" from either side of the trackpad, that leave lines in my skin and are pretty uncomfortable for me. However, I do have sensitive skin, and my sessions of using this without an external keyboard or in an uncomfortable position are limited to trips and a couple other occasional circumstances. Still, I think it is something to consider for many users.

UPDATE: After a few-to-several months (depending on how much you carry your MBP around) the corners will start to chip. The left corner of the monitor is now actually pretty rough and snags on fabric. Overall it's still making it less slippery, but, put this money toward a higher quality product and pass on this one. Downgraded from 4 to 2 stars.
output: Economical Case with Nice Feel; Doesn't Last

I drug my feet about buying an iPad for a year. Well, I actually bought an iPad retina a year ago and took it back because I was disappointed in how heavy and clunky the unit was. The new changes to the iPad Air makes it soooo much better, and I love it. I checked out the 10" Samsung and decided it just wasn't enough, and I actually bought the Samsung Tab 7" last fall, but neither of them hold a candle to an iPad for speed and sharpness. The first headset's microphone did not work. Amazon sent a replacement headset while arranging for UPS pickup of my the defective headset. It was worth the wait.
Dragon Naturally Speaking includes a headset with the program. Without noise cancellation the microphone needs a very quiet room as well as the microphone volume set as loud as possible. The free headset is difficult for long term wear.
The Sennheiser PC 31-II more than fulfills the dictation role. Noise cancelling microphone's sensitivity aids my dictation to be picked up at a normal volume in a room with a television on. Sound quality excels for open on-ear ear pads at this price. Music, games, and video are crystal with unexpectedly great responsiveness from full bass to thrilling high range. As others have mentioned, the PC 31-II light comfortable fit allows one to forget the headset is being worn.
I'm quite pleased with the headset for dictation, playing games or listening music. For the price range, the Sennheiser PC 31-II is hard to beat.
KEVIN aka "DocPayne"
output: Quick Replacement was worth the wait.

This is an excellent little trackball if you know what you're doing. As with any trackball, you will need to clean it every now and again, but that's really easy to do. Just pick it up and tap it against your hand and the ball pops right out - no need to twist or unlock anything like in previous models. Just wipe the contact points with a q-tip or a bit of tissue (or even your finger is better than nothing) to wipe off the gunk. It still works fine even with the build-up (no skipping or bouncing) it just takes a little more effort to move the ball. Sometimes it's hard to even notice when the gunk has built up.   I've been using one of these for 6 years, now, since my previous one (which was not optical) wore out. Although that one is still going strong I'm picking up a second one to use with my laptop. I like to use the trackball for gaming and photo manipulation since for me a trackball gives better speed, accuracy, and precision than a standard optical mouse. If you're a fan of trackballs this is a good one to have.

The only con I can say is that the locking mechanism for the case when in stand configuration seems a little kludgy, but the stand holds well under the weight and does not slide.

I needed something to read a 3.5 or 2.5 inch sata drive. It is great for this and doesn't require screws as the drives just drop down into the cradle and is ready to plug into a usb port. It was great to be able to clone a crive that was bad and transfer it a new drive. Really sweet.

Instances.input:
I just got my Kindle about an hour ago and the first thing I did while it charged was put the skin on! It is very easy to put on and avoid bubbles. If you have a bubble, just lift up the decal sheet and apply it again a bit slower, applying pressure with your nail or finger. It is also very easy to take off should I decide to change it. The only reason that I gave it four stars is because it does not come with a screen protector. I am very pleased with this product over all, and I love all the design options. All it needs to get that five stars is an actual screen protector sheet.

Pros:
* Punctuation marks are on their normal keys, and mostly where you would expect them
* Both shift keys are easily accessible and where you expect them to be
* Powered by two AAA batteries with other reviewers reporting long battery life; a low-battery LED is present
* Able to be used on one's lap with only one's legs as a surface
* Compact profile when folded
* Solid construction
* No awkward, odd sizing on some keys on either side of the \\"folding keyboard break\\" in the middle of the keyboard (left to right)

Cons:
* Top row of numbers and their punctuation marks are positioned about a key's width to the right of where they are on a normal keyboard
* Backspace key is hard to locate at first without looking (located just above the large Enter key and just below the \\"Connect\\" button)
* \\"Pipe\\" and backslash symbols (| and \) key does not work on iPhone 4S
* No Caps Lock indicator LED

After a long, detailed search for the right foldable, Bluetooth keyboard for my iPhone, I ended up choosing the Perixx PERIBOARD-806 ALU Folding Bluetooth Keyboard. What are the things I really like about it?

First of all, this keyboard is NOT beset with the problem that a number of others in this category suffer from: putting punctuation marks either on other keys than they are normally found, or in other places on the keyboard than normal, or, worst case...BOTH. It sounds like a simple thing, but in addition to adjusting to a smaller keyboard in some cases, also having to adjust to your most-needed punctuation keys being out of whack is a problem I don't need. With the 806, this problem doesn't come up.

Also, I have to keep up with recharging enough gear in my life, so the fact that it runs (A LONG TIME according to some other reviewers) off two AAA batteries is a real plus. In addition, there is an LED that will warn you when the battery is getting low.

Is it \\"lappable\\" (i.e., can you spread it out on your lap with no surface underneath it)? Contrary to some other reviewers who said \\"No\\", I found it to work fine when spread out on my legs. I do tend to use a stiff, flat surface for comfort though (the cardboard surface of an 8.5x11\\" binder positioned in landscape mode works fine).

The 806 has a compact profile when folded (5 7/8 x 4 x 5/8\\" dimensions). I personally want the keyboard to be as compact as possible when folded up while still meeting my other requirements. This keyboard fits the bill nicely. Also, it is built solidly (some parts and hinges are made out of aluminum). WARNING: Don't think of it as near indestructible though. Unfortunately, mine dropped to a tile floor from about waist high and a small piece of plastic broke off, preventing the folding mechanism from working as smoothly as it did when intact. I am, however, still able to use the keyboard fully and without problem...just a bit of a hassle when re-folding.

Finally, whereas some unfolded folding keyboards have a bizarre placement and size of some of the keys in the middle (going left to right) of the keyboard to allow for the folding mechanism, when you look straight down on the 806 from above when unfolded, it looks pretty much just like your normal desktop or laptop keyboard. This is a really big plus since you don't have to get used to odd, middle-of-the-keyboard key placement and spacing.

OKAY, SO THAT'S THE GOOD. WHAT'S THE BAD (OR AT LEAST THE NOT SO GOOD)?

Although the row of numbered keys above the top row of letters has all of the keys (and their shifted punctuation marks) where you would expect them sequentially (in a row from left to right), they are placed just about a key's width to the right of where your fingers would normally reach to if you are a touch typist. This has the effect of causing the mis-typing of those numbers or punctuation marks until you've spent a LOT of time on the keyboard. Also on this same row, the Backspace key is small enough to be hard to locate from your touch typing position...at first. I would note however, that having used the keyboard a lot by now, I find that I have been able to largely adjust to this issue and it's not so big a deal as it was in the first days and weeks of use.

Here's one that could be a deal killer if you plan on using this keyboard for entering some network addressing characters, or performing some operating system commands on your iPhone. The \\"pipe\\" (|) symbol and the backslash (\) key DOES NOT WORK when paired with my iPhone 4S and iOS version 6.1.3 (10B329). I have paired the keyboard with my MacBook Pro and this key works just fine. Also, it works fine when paired with a Samsung Galaxy III. So whether this is a problem with all iOS devices, I do not know as I have no way to test on an iPod Touch or an iPad. I alerted the keyboard maker (Perixx) to this situation and they told me to check the same key on other devices to see if it might be the key itself or just one or more devices on which it won't work while working on others. I did, and reported my findings. I then asked them to get back with me after presenting these findings to their engineers so I could have their feedback before writing this review. I did not hear back on this request after allowing several weeks.

Finally, a small thing but one that should be mentioned. There is no LED to let you know when the keyboard is in the Caps Lock state. Not a big deal, but one that is a bit annoying I must confess.

BUT WHAT ABOUT THOSE \\"IT'S JUST TOO SMALL/CRAMPED AND I WISH I HADN'T BOUGHT IT\\" REVIEWS?

When I was searching for just the right keyboard, these were the reviews that worried me most. Fortunately, I can report that at least for me, the tightness of the key sizing and arrangement on the 806 IS something to which one can become accustomed. As long as I put my brain in \\"tighten up your touch typing home row resting and reach positions\\" mode, I find that I can type almost as well as I can on a normal sized keyboard. It does require a little bit of extra brain power though. But \\"What about MY hands?\\" you may ask. So I will finish this review by giving you some hard numbers that might help you make your decision.

When I took a ruler and set it on my Apple, wired external keyboard with keypad's \\"home row\\" (ASDF, etc.) and measured the horizontal distance from the left-to-right middle of the \\"A\\" key, to the left-to-right middle of the Apostrophe/Double Quote key, I got the following: 7.5 inches. When I made the same measurement on the PERIBOARD-806, I got the following: 6.5 inches. Okay, so that's the keyboard's dimensions but how big are my hands? If I hold my left hand flat with palm down, and squeeze from my pinky finger on the left to my index finger on my right when looking down on my hand from above, from the left edge of my pinky's fingernail to the right edge of my index finger's fingernail is exactly 2.5 inches. So how does this apply to you? I would say that if you hold one of your hands in the manner described above, take the same measurement I described, and the distance is greater than 2.5 inches, then this keyboard's layout would *probably* be too small for comfortable, efficient use since my own hand size is probably right on the upper limit for a good match for the 806. Also, if you would be using this keyboard for heavy number entry, I would say you had better think hard about using ANY keyboard that doesn't have a dedicated keypad.

So as for me, though it requires resetting my brain just a little and tightening up my touch typing stance, I have found the 806 to more than meet my needs and be a really good fit for portable, non-charging-hassle, durable use.
output: VERY Good for the Right Hands

For starters, I am a avid reader and have been so since I was in elementary school. I read several books a month and have so for the past 20 + years.

I got this on a Friday and was highly disappointed and by that night I had decided to pack it back up and return it on Monday. But I picked it up again Saturday and read some more...then by Sunday night I started to appreciate it more, especially things such as the dictionary when you point to a word which was an awesome surprise. Every time I pick it up I like it a little bit more than before and once I finish my stack of books on my night stand I am not sure I will buy many more hard copy books which is a surreal thought for me.

And here is some random thoughts...

Battery life is simply outstanding.

Its easy to load pdf's and doc's onto the Kindle.

Navigating around the Kindle and organizing your collections is a breeze.

Less distractions than reading a book. You easily get immersed into what you're reading.

Books are so cheap! I have books from .99 to 10.00...how great is that?

Books take a few seconds to download.

Sync to last page read is awesome.

Incredibly easy on the eyes. My eye strain has been greatly reduced versus reading a true book so I tend to read more. And I think the bags under my eyes are starting to go away a bit.

Now here is a few minor complaints/constructive criticisms.

When searching the amazon store on a Kindle I wish it was easier to do searches by author name.

I wish the page forward buttons were bigger or had a different texture on them so I would never have to look for the button which happens once a reading session.

You are at the mercy of how a PDF was created when viewing a PDF file which makes some PDF's fairly unreadable. However from what I have seen this seems to only be a problem with older PDF's.

My suggestions for those considering a Kindle.

You don't need 3G unless you travel a lot and will be buying a lot of books while traveling. Wi-Fi is perfectly fine if your Kindle is at home most of the time. Having the internet on drains the battery so the only time you need it connected is when a book is downloading. So basically your kindle will only be connected for a handful of minutes a month. It's is incredibly simply to turn the connection on/off.

You don't need an anti scratch cover in my opinion. The screen is tough and why ruin the text? You do however need a slip cover for the unit itself to protect against dust or whatever. I got a \\"[[ASIN:B003NE5UWI BUILT Neoprene Kindle Sleeve (Fits 6\\" Display, Latest Generation Kindle) Black]] sleeve which is great.

Any questions ask away in the comment section and I will be glad to answer.

EDIT FOR UPDATE 07/15/11. For what it's worth which probably isn't much since I am sure this review will be buried. But I have been using this for over two months now. I have bought a ton of books and between free independent books and sales the kindle has paid for itself in my estimation.traveling. Wi-Fi is perfectly fine if your Kindle is at home most of the time. Having the internet on drains the battery so the only time you need it connected is when a book is downloading. So basically your kindle will only be connected for a handful of minutes a month. It's is incredibly simply to turn the connection on/off. You don't need an anti scratch cover in my opinion. The screen is tough and why ruin the text? You do however need a slip cover for the unit itself to protect against dust or whatever. I got a \\"[[ASIN:B003NE5UWI BUILT Neoprene Kindle Sleeve (Fits 6\\" Display, Latest Generation Kindle) Black]] sleeve which is great. Any questions ask away in the comment section and I will be glad to answer. EDIT FOR UPDATE 07/15/11. For what it's worth which probably isn't much since I am sure this review will be buried. But I have been using this for over two months now. I have bought a ton of books and between free independent books and sales the kindle has paid for itself in my estimation.

Even with help room assistance, I made it listen or talk on the PC, not at the same time and not TV or phone. The instructions were inadequate, forcing me to spend a half-day muddling through the hookup. I had to return the first one  because it had no instructions at all. I didn't know the USB bug was to be removed from inside the left earpiece. I had bought it for use with the media player and the voice recorder. Even with resetting manually between sound and mic applications, I could not play music in chat rooms while the mic was in service. I keep it for listening only.
output: Headset apparently Not Compatible With "Stereo Mix"

I thought I loved my Kindle Fire when I first received it.  I couldn't believe when I went looking for the \\"text-to-speech\\" feature that is on the regular Kindle, I found it wasn't available on the Kindle Fire.  If the Kindle Fire is an upgrade from the Kindle, why wouldn't this feature be included.  Used to love to order books before that had the text-to-speech enabling feature so that I could (if I wanted to) listen to the book in my car, my headset, my radio, etc.  Hope they come up with a 'fix\\" for this soon as I know I am VERY disappointed, as well as others I have talked with.

I got a Kindle for my birthday this year (actually, I got a check for my birthday, and I spent most of it on a Kindle), and I love it!    I am definitely a book addict, and my bookshelves are mostly full. I'm also someone who likes to take more than one book with me when I go somewhere because I never know which one I might need/want. The Kindle helps me with both of these; I can buy more books without needing more bookshelves, and I can carry literally dozens of \\"books\\" with me without a problem.    I've had my eye on the Kindle for as long as they've been available. One of the reasons I hesitated to buy one was that it didn't seem like many books I needed/wanted were available for it. Well, the selection has gotten better, and many of the books I look for actually are available in Kindle editions (including many of the professional books I need).     Since I've been known to be an \\"impulse buyer\\" when it comes to books, it doesn't hurt that not everything I look for is available in this format--I've decided that unless it's a book that I'm required to buy for some reason, I won't get it if it's not available in a Kindle edition!    The other really really cool thing about having a Kindle is the \\"instant gratification\\"--I can decide to buy a book, order it, and get it immediately, rather than having to wait for it to be shipped to me. This has come in handy more than once already...I'm getting spoiled :-)    Yes, as other reviewers have mentioned, you have to be careful how you hold it, or you'll move forward or back a page without meaning to. Also, I'm still getting used to not being able to just flip through a book to find the next chapter, etc.--the electronic format isn't quite as comfortable for me in this respect. I know there are lots of handy Kindle features that I haven't explored yet, though, so I'm sure there are ways to get around things like this. I also like being able to \\"highlight\\" and \\"unhighlight\\" at will (without feeling guilty for marking up a book). There are also sometimes errors in the Kindle editions of books that weren't in the originals--so far, just a minor annoyance.    As other reviewers have mentioned, the [[ASIN:B000HGGA24 Case Logic HDC-1 Medium EVA External Hard Drive Case (Black)]] works very well for carrying the Kindle and accessories. I also bought the [[ASIN:B001EVVYQS MiniSuit Silicone Skin Case for Amazon Kindle with Adjustable Stand (Black)]]. It works OK, although you have to be careful how you set up the stand so that it doesn't fall over (the part of the case that has the stand attached is not stiff, so it doesn't stay still).    So, anyway, go ahead...take the plunge...buy a Kindle!
output: Hooray! I don't have to buy more bookshelves!

I have an ongoing need for extended battery power operations when I am traveling internationally. These flights are no less then 11 hours and some can be up to 15 hours.
My Apple 13” MacBook Air laptop computer has a great battery life. Usually about 8 hours (in the real world) but even that falls short of my needs. After extensive research, I selected this battery because they are the ONLY one who include the magsafe & magsafe2 connectors needed to plug into my computer. They offer the maximum amount of battery power without exceeding the TSA international limit of 100 Wh. This battery just makes it at 98 Wh.
TESTING: I depleted my laptop battery down to 6% . Then I plugged in the BIXNET battery to see what it can really do on a full charge.
The results were; it fully recharged my laptop internal battery in 2 hours and at the same time provided playing mp4 movies for 4 hours, all at the same time.
NOTE: The battery charging instructions in the box were not accurate as to how this recharge function happens. On my battery and charger, the power brick always remains glowing with a red LED. Regardless of the charge in the battery. While the charge is being accepted, the 4 bars do build to show that the charge is growing. BUT IT IS IMPORTANT TO REALLY WATCH THE LITTLE BATTERY ICON FLASHING IN THE LED BATTERY WINDOW. After showing all 4 bars, the icon is STILL flashing. That indicates that the battery has NOT YET topped off. Let it remain charging until the battery icon STOPS flashing. Then you know your battery is FULLY CHARGED
CONCLUSION: What more could you ask for extending the operation of a full laptop computer. I highly recommend this product for anyone who needs the extended laptop life on battery power.
Well done BIXPower.

We have more than a dozen of these monitors at work and I have two on my desk and one at home. The monitors arrive with an enclosed calibration sheet. Apparently they are factory calibrated now. Because I work on media I needed a color accurate monitor that could also double as a day to day working display for coding, presentations and documents. Out of the box these monitors required less calibration work than any LCD monitor or TV that I've used in the past five years. I saw none of the pink or green tinge referred to in other reviews. Nor was there any noticeable graduation of color tint from one side to another. In fact side by side the monitors appear perfectly matched and even.

The color from these monitors is very neutral, which is to say quite accurate. While they are not 'reference' quality they don't fall far short of the mark. For the price they are a good deal. You should be aware that IPS is known for accuracy and range of colors. The display is not LED backlit, because LED's do not allow the full range of colors you get from older monitors. This was a deliberate choice and the correct one. If you want to go green and simply don't care about color accuracy or vertical viewing angle, get something like the Dell G2410H.

Watching bluray disks on this monitor is also a very satisfying experience - be warned that the color neutrality does not make this display as flashy as a TV or TN monitor, but what you get in return is accuracy. At home I do some moderate gaming so I watch out for latency, especially the whole-screen refresh which is always much worse than the stated response times. This is a 6mS display and I've seen it switch whole screen refresh in about 20-25mS. While this may not seem good, it is in fact considerably better than average. Anytime you see a claim of 2mS switching time, be aware it is like saying an amplifier produces 200W of \\"music power\\" where in fact it manages maybe 25W RMS at best. So gaming is very satisfactory although not a reason to buy this class of monitor.

In terms of performance, the processor behind these displays seems faster than almost anything else I've seen. The OSD is easy to use and better thought out than my 2408WFP displays. I like that the OSD puts the function graphics right next to the corresponding buttons (so for example you get a tic mark against the button used to accept a setting).

The connections for the monitor include 2 DVI, 1 display port and an hdmi port. As usual the hdmi input stops edid/hdcp support when you switch away to another DVI input. This is annoying for various reasons, but most people won't care.

I particularly loathe TN displays due to their poor color accuracy and ridiculous vertical viewing angles. So 100% of my monitors at home and work are either PVA or IPS types. I have eight at home, including HP and Samsung. I still think that Dell peaked with the 2408 but this IPS display is a worthy successor and for the price point a good deal. I would assume if you are looking here it's because you want an exceptional monitor rather than the high street vanilla variety. If so, you should be very happy with this monitor. It is not far short of perfect.

Dell has fallen from grace in recent years, in no small part due to a deteriorating web site and fierce competition. Dell's website is undermined by lack of consistency, poor navigation, stupid base configurations and a pricing structure that is undermined when you find you can buy a pre-configured machine through a retail outlet at a cheaper price than you can build the equivalent machine online. Their product lines are also poorly differentiated from their competitor's machines. But their monitors are second to none. I ordered two identical DDR2 DIMM's. For some reason they sent them as two separate shipments on two successive days. The first one arrived and did not work in two different AMD motherboards. The computer would not post at all. The next DIMM came the following day and it did work. It showed no errors on Memtest 5.01 after 10 passes. But it did cause problems booting Windows 10 preview (endless boot loop), but I am hoping that I can still use the DIMM. Reinspecting the first failed DIMM, I noticed that the plastic tray had an extra barcoded label slapped on that the second one didn't. I suspect it was a returned DIMM that had failed previously and that the company was sending it back out, hoping it would work for a different customer.

So overall I had a 50% defective rate and the working DIMM has some issues as well. Therefore I'm giving this two stars. The price was certainly a great deal for 4 Gb DDR2. I just wish they had both worked.
output: The price was certainly a great deal for 4 Gb DDR2

I researched for days before deciding on this laptop.    Battery life: 10/10  +/-3 hours in High Performance Mode (GeForce G210M graphics)  6+ hours in Entertainment Mode (intergrated Intel Graphics)  8+ hours in Battery Saving Mode (intergrated Intel Graphics)  And the laptop is smart enough to stop charging as soon as it gets to 100% charge. This way it wont overcharge and damage the battery.    Graphics: 10/10  Prior to testing Portal, I toggled to the GeForce 210 graphics card. Portal plays very well at 720p at maximum settings with AA off. Very impressive for a laptop that is 3.94lbs (yes i weighed it). 98% of the time I'm not playing games, so it nice to be able to save battery until you want to play games.    Build: 10/10  I bought this because I'm a college student. I needed something powerful and light. The discrete graphics card is perfect for games. It's made with alimunum and feels very sturdy.    Features: 9/10  Think of the 9/10 as a good thing. So first off the hardware: it's got a webcam, microphone, VGA out, and HDMI out. It doesn't have a DVD-ROM, but that was a tradeoff.  If you want the DVD-ROM built-in, buy the UL80-A1, but be warned, the UL80-A1 is heavier, more cheaply built and cost about the same. I just bought an external DVD-ROM.  The sound card has the ability to record in Stereo Mix, this was a HUGE plus for me. Stereo Mix record allows you to record streaming audio at any point.  The BOIS does mild overclocking and OS virtualization (like running XP inside Windows 7). And you can set it to enable USB bootability.  The ONLY reason I gave \\"Features\\" a 9/10 was because the wifi card isn't recognized in Backtrack 3, which is like Linux for network hackers. But... 99.5% of people probably won't be using for Backtrack 3. BTW it still works for BT3, but I just had to buy a separate network card.    Bottom line, it's sturdy, light-weight, very long battery life, and option for high gaming performance.  It can record Stereo Mix, has good BIOS options, and all the peripheral connections necessary.  I installed an 80GB Intel X-25 SSD. It was an extra $200, but it now boots into Windows in 30 seconds (instead of 1 min. 45 sec.) and is very quick and responsive. Now I have a spare 500GB hard drive.    So cruise for hot spots, surf the internet anywhere, do your homework anywhere, and play games anywhere. The battery will last you all day!    10/10 !

I've used Adesso keyboards for many years with my Apple laptops. Except for having to remember that the \\"Alt\\" and \\"Command\\" keys are switched, there's no issue using this Windows keyboard with a Mac.

In the past, my Adesso keyboards have started to fail after 3 years - not the best track record but okay. But I really like their trackpad implementation - you can use your finger to scroll horizontally and vertically.

Most important is the design of the keys. They feel firm but not too hard. They're quiet and well placed. The number one advantage over the Microsoft keyboard is the double spacebar - one for each thumb. The MS keyboard only has one space bar which you have to hit right in the middle otherwise it won't trigger. That means you have to keep stretching your thumb towards the center of the keyboard to ensure you trigger the spacebar - not very ergonomic. The two spacebars on the Adesso fit right under my thumbs and are very comfortable to use.

Kudos to Adesso and shame on Microsoft.

Just like Wireless N and Wireless G, I get different strength on different devices and locations in my house, but with the faster rate, being slow means running at Wireless G or wireless N speeds...

For the most part this router is overkill for me. I'm limited by my Internet provider with their residential gateway to use this router as mostly an access point. But it does that job very well. Setup of these devices are getting easier, but the advanced features are getting less clear. I'd really like to see wizards or clear in depth documentatoin on the advanced features...
output: very fast.. even when its slow.

Instances.input: The Lexar 16GB UDMA CompactFlash (300x) is a super fast, large capacity card. Depending on the size of the RAW, JPEG or TIFF file generated by the camera, 16GB media can either hold a lot or an enormous number of images, it allows shooting up to 3,000 frames per card. If you have a UDMA capable camera and you are missing shots because your buffer isn't emptying fast enough, this is definitely a card for you. If you are getting impatient waiting for your photos to download from the CF card to your computer, again, this card will serve you well.
output: Lexar is always a good choice !

First I have to say that the price point on this case / bluetooth folio case is unbelievable and truly a great deal! There are many other cases out there that cost much more and are simply not as nice.

This keyboard case comes nicely packaged, with clear instructions. I had this paired with my Ipad Air in under 30 seconds, no hassles or issues at all! I noticed other people said they had problems keeping it paired with their ipad... however, I did not have any issues with this at all... it stayed paired and never lost connection for me. The battery life is great... and it recharges fairly quickly.

This folio keyboard really makes you feel like you have a mini-laptop! When my ipad air is installed in the case it does not feel like it adds bulk like some cases, its very slim and lightweight and the exterior has a very smooth finish.

The keyboard keys are very responsive and have a nice feel to them and use the standard QWERTY layout. As with any keyboard of this size I tend to initially have trouble getting use to it being so small, so it takes some time for my hands to adjust to typing with a small keyboard, but this is to be expected on any case you use like this... its simply not going to be a full laptop or desktop keyboard size... but once I got use to it ... I was able to type with my normal accuracy. This keyboard has great shortcut keys like brightness and volume adjustments which is very convenient.

The best part about this case is the way you can adjust your screen while its installed in this case... you can slide out the top section and tilt your ipad air screen at a great easily viewable angle and with the 360 degree turning feature your can easily and smoothly turn the ipad so its either horizontal or vertical depending on your preferences.

A Few Minor Suggestions:

I wish the outside of the case had some texture so it was not so smooth (maybe a rubbered texture inlay?). I like the velvety feel of it but I would just like to feel I had a better grip when I pick it up, I just get worried because the ipad is an expensive devise and I do not want to drop it. 

I would like it if I could remove my Ipad Air more easily, I had a difficult time getting it out of the case when I just wanted to play a game... I got very nervous because I did not want to break my ipad. A good option would be if the ipad could detach from the keyboard so it was not necessary for me to try to remove the ipad from the case. 
Lastly, I wish there was a thin layer of protection between the case and my ipad and a removable thin sheet of a soft microfiber to put between the keyboard and ipad glass when you close it.feel of it but I would just like to feel I had a better grip when I pick it up, I just get worried because the ipad is an expensive devise and I do not want to drop it. 

I would like it if I could remove my Ipad Air more easily, I had a difficult time getting it out of the case when I just wanted to play a game... I got very nervous because I did not want to break my ipad. A good option would be if the ipad could detach from the keyboard so it was not necessary for me to try to remove the ipad from the case. 
Lastly, I wish there was a thin layer of protection between the case and my ipad and a removable thin sheet of a soft microfiber to put between the keyboard and ipad glass when you close it.

This is the best case out there right now for my needs.    My requirements are that it must    1. Support portrait in addition to landscape  2. Stably support both modes at approx 45 degrees   3. Must support the sleep/wake feature  4. Be as thin and light as possible     Compared to the Targus 360 (which does not support sleep/wake), this case is thinner and lighter.  The ipad can be stood up at \\"unlimited\\" angles from ~55-75 deg (realistically) due to the big non-slip surface.      Compare that to the Targus which only has 2 notches.  However, I set the ipad at the lowest angle (~55 deg) most of the time.    I like the magnetic latch used to help keep the cover closed as opposed to the strap on the Targus because it's easier to use.    Now for the cons:  - I wish the angle would go lower to about 45 deg but b/c the viewing angle of the ipad is so good, this doesn't matter as much.  - There should be more coverage on all sides of the ipad. Right now, the ipad is held in place at 4 corners. The fit has been secure and stable so far though.  - There was a slight odor at first.  I'm airing it out and the odor seems to have mostly dissipated.  - At $60, it's $10 more than what I wanted to pay for a case in general.  - The word \\"Joy\\" on the latch makes the case look cheap.  The word shouldn't have been as prominent.    Overall though I do think it's the best case out there and strongly recommend it.

I'm a college student and I take my MacBook Pro EVERYWHERE. I bought a clear Speck case for my laptop but it made it really bulky and really heavy. I have been using Zagg products for years for my iPod and iPhone. So I decided to buy one for my MacBook Pro. I was a little reluctant at first because the application of the invisible shield takes a lot of time and patience. Applying the invisible shield gives you a really good grip on your laptop when you are carrying it. It's clear, and weightless.

When I applied the invisible shield, I started with the sides first since they were little pieces and that gave me practice.

---TIPS FOR APPLICATION---

1) Get a slightly damp paper towel and clean you MacBook Pro first (make sure your hands are clean too!)

2) Spray your fingers with the solution given and then peel off the invisible shield for the sides (HIGHLY RECOMMENDED because the top and bottom pieces are way difficult, the sides will give you some practice)

3) Spray the invisible shield after you've peeled it off the paper, apply to laptop have a damp paper towel and run it over the invisible shield after you applied it to the laptop so it can absorb and solution that might get into your laptop. Use the squeegee to remove any air bubbles. Repeat steps for other side.

I applied the bottom of the shield after I did the sides and what you want to do is DO NOT PEEL THE WHOLE THING OFF THE PAPER. Peel off about 1/4 of the shield then spray the solution on it and apply it on the laptop. Straighten it if necessary.

Slowly peel off the rest of the shield and spray the shield as you peel it from the paper. Once you apply the whole thing, use the squeegee if necessary to remove air bubbles.
After you are done, I highly recommend that you should leave the invisible shield on to dry overnight and DO NOT USE THE LAPTOP because it takes a while for it to stick to the surface. Using the laptop might shift the invisible shield while it is drying. Just repeat the same steps from the application of the bottom for the top part of your laptop. And let it dry overnight as well.

My review/comparison between Skinomi and TechArmor screen protectors:

Having never installed a screen protector on any of my devices, I decided to spend a little extra and buy different ones from a couple of the top rated manufacturers on Amazon. Skinomi and TechArmor. Since I had no idea what I would like, I tried two different TechArmor protectors for my tablet (one HD clear and one with the matte anti-fingerprint, anti-glare), and bought a Skinomi TechSkin for my phone.

Phone installation was first and was pretty straight forward. I was glad to have read some reviews, and knew in advance that immediately after installation the screen doesn't look that good. Since it's a wet application, it really does take a full 12 hours before it's all clear and smoothed out. But, the screen has a nice feel to it and the clarity and sharpness is excellent.

Next was the installation of TechArmor (matte finish) protector on my Nexus 7 tablet. This protector is by far the best choice for being fingerprint resistant, but the clarity of text and images was diminished enough that I opted not to use it at all. The installation of the HD clear version of the TechArmor protector followed. Image and text clarity are perfect but it really provides no resistance to fingerprints at all. The feel of it was also a little too grippy for my preference.

During the days of this experiment, I was using my phone with the Skinomi TechSkin, and liking it more everyday. The choice was really simple. Skinomi TechSkins somehow have found a way to provide perfect clarity for text and images while being VERY resistant to fingerprints. You will still wipe off your screen from time to time, but I'd say this protector reduces the problem with fingerprints by 70%. Naturally, I bought the same TechSkin for my Nexus 7 tablet.

The wet application is a little more difficult in general and especially on a larger screen. I totally screwed it up and ruined my Skinomi TechSkin for the tablet. Knowing it was my own fault, I had little doubts that I would have to buy another if I wanted it. Nevertheless, I emailed Skinomi support about what happened. To my surprise (and delight), they only asked for a copy of my order, a picture of the ruined protector and the code that comes with the documentation in the box. With that, they actually sent me a free replacement! If that's not excellent customer service, I don't know what is....

Before attempting the second installation of the same protector on my tablet, I watched the youtube video they tell you about in the instructions and noticed that I wasn't using nearly enough spray. This really solved all my problems. If you have enough spray on the protector, it's fairly easy to get it perfectly into place. Otherwise, it's nearly impossible. That's the only advice I'd give - watch the video and see how much they use and do the same. You'll have no issues.

I now have Skinomi TechSkins on my phone and tablet and couldn't be happier. With the money I spent in this little experiment, take my advice and just by yourself the Skinomi. You'll be glad you did.
output: After trying a few, I found what I think is the best protector.

Instances.input:
The Kindle Fire HD 7 can easily be inserted into this case and the polyurethane case will hold it securely. This stand is primarily focused on providing a hands-free landscape viewing with a quick flip of the cover. There are two silicone 3/4” silicone strips beneath the case that will keep it from slipping. You can put it in portrait position, but this is not a folio and there’s virtually no support.

The edges of the shell are beveled, a feature that I feel makes it easier to hold. This slim case is set up with the sleep / wake function, a feature is like in any device that offers it. I would have like to see something added, perhaps a bit of silicone, to the reverse side to give it a no-slip grip. Make sure before you order than you know those dimensions.

Dimensions of the Kindle Fire HD 7

► Height: 7.60” (191 mm)

► Width: 5.39” (119 mm)

► Depth: 0.41” (11 mm)

The polyurethane is not padded, but it’s quite solid, durable, and the fit is tight as it should be. This feature also make it difficult to remove the Kindle as the edges are so inflexible. The inside, including the shell, is lined with a gray microfiber. The case offers up easy access to all ports and buttons. The hinge can fold right around to the back so if you want to hold your Kindle in portrait mode to read, it’s very handy to do so.

I do like this “slim” version, but do prefer the Nupro that has the elasticized closure band. If you are an on-the-go person, you may wish to consider that particular style. This Nupro polyurethane slim case for the Kindle Fire HD 7 is very attractive and also quite functional. I have the purple and find it a particularly appealing, soothing color.
output: This Nupro neoprene case for the Kindle Fire HD 7 is very functional, but could use a bit of improvement ...

I got this mouse at Fry's.  Pairing the Hype Bluetooth Curve with my Lenovo ThinkPad T420s is extremely simple.  It took a minute and required no passcode. The adapter does what it says and what I needed it to do. It takes power from a 4 pin female and transfers it to two male SATA connectors. The length between the 4 pin and each SATA is long enough to go most places you'd want it to.

I did have two gripes about this connector:
- The wires come out of the top of the SATA, not in through the sides. In my particular configuration (connecting two hard drives in a modified Dell XPS), this made it somewhat hard to close the case since the wires were near the top.

- The wires are not stick together on the two series of 5 wires. This makes things a little messier than is necessary and makes it a little harder to route cables.

Minor gripes. Other than that, good product and did what I needed it to do.
output: Does what it says, but could be better

This mouse has been replaced by the M95, and the primary difference is that the side/thumb buttons are slightly lighter to press.

The software is bad, but it is functional, and you can make it work. I would like the ability to do \\"shift-modifiers\\", for example, when I press one of the side buttons and scroll the mousewheel, I want to be able to scroll through tabs by firing a Ctrl-Tab every time I scroll the mousewheel down. I've implemented this separately using an autohotkey script. Building this into the software would give users an entire new dimension of goodness.

My mouse wheel stopped working properly after about a year of use, mousewheel-down would trigger multiple times when I scrolled in either direction. These mice have a two year warranty. I emailed Corsair about it and they suggested an RMA, I mailed off my mouse and they replaced it with an M95 straight away. I'm very happy with their warranty service, and it gives me confidence in buying Corsair products in the future.

My old mouse had an issue with the right mouse button, if I hit it from a weird angle it wouldn't always click properly, but during gaming sessions this never happened to me and the new (not yet grimy) mouse doesn't have this issue. Five stars.

Update: Down to just two stars. The new mouse has an identical issue with the mousewheel-down triggering. It appears to develop when dust or whatever gets in the mouse, I tried hitting it with canned air of course, but that doesn't help. I won't be purchasing another mouse from Corsair due to this issue, but once again, their customer service was great.

Instances.input: I have an older dual core Vostro 1520 which I absolutely love - got it on a price mistake from the manufacturer so I've stuck with it and it's been a great computer workhorse over the years. I was really upset when the battery finally gave out on it and was forced to carry a charger everywhere I went. So I started on a quest to find a battery replacement all over the internet - I literally tried as many as two (2) dozen batteries - all upwards of $30+ to only be disappointed with my choice as the computer was unable to recognize the battery, or identify it as counterfeit or fake - the battery indicator would flash orange/blue designating non-compliance to the computer, or, upon start-up the computer would identify the battery as not compliance and "not chargeable". I read the reviews for this LB1 High Performance battery and thought I'd give it a try. I do have Windows 7 Ultimate loaded on my Vostro 1520 and am aware that there is a process by which you integrate the battery to the computer when replacing the current battery. I received this LB1 battery and thought I would just "plug and play" - the results? Instant integration without problems on my Vostro! Wow, great resuts, and, for the price, I could purchase as many as three (3) of these batteries for the price I paid for the other ones I tried...great replacement - have had for a few weeks now without any issue - thanks LB1!!!
output: Surprised as a GREAT Battery Replacement - No Integration Issues - Vostro 1520

Instances.input: Just bought these and they are perfect for use with a notebook.    Shielded, space saving and much better than most speakers i've  used with a notebook.    The sound is very warm and crystal clear, just what you'd expect  from a well known audio company.    You can get room filling sound and decent bass with a few tweaks.    I hooked them up to a Targus mini-usb 2.0 hub   (though i have 3 usb ports in the back of my pc)   and the notebook headphone jack.   Peeled apart the wire a few inches to reach both.      Right clicked on the speaker icon in the taskbar, selected  \\"adjust audio properties\\", added PC speaker to the usual array  of volume controls. Set all including pc speakers to max   except system volume which i set to 3/4    Then in audio properties under speaker settings, clicked on advanced  and chose desktop speakers from the dropdown menu instead of the default  laptop stereo.   (and though they get the sound from the headphone out jack, selecting  headphones is only for... well, headphones)    Running three sets of volume controls:  With the system volume at 3/4, the volume knob on the right speaker set  to half, your final volume will depend on the volume control of whatever  video or audio player you are using both on and offline.  You can play around with your volume settings to your own satisfaction.    Since system volume comes in loud, i don't bother to turn the speakers  on with the on-off switch on the back of the right speaker until i'm actually going to use them to listen to a film, video or mp3, etc or browse through these kinds of sites.  Till then, there is no sound since they are plugged into the headphone jack.    I haven't heard any start-up, shut-down or any other system sounds and have not missed them, there is almost always some visual effect associated  with those.    The sound at youtube and various video sites etc is not a substitute for expensive high end speakers but is very good for listening to music and movie soundtracks at decent volumes and good fidelity with none of the harsh muffled sound you usually get with outboard pc speakers.  And no distortion unless you run the sound up to absolute max.    You won't get deep bass, frequency is 180Hz-20KHz, but frankly i don't want deep bass rattling and thumping my notebook and its hard drive and optical drive with the speakers only 3 inches away.    As a bonus, the stereo separation is outstanding on these.    For the price i think these are the best notebook speakers around :)

I used this caddy to put an extra hard drive in my Dell Latitude 6520. It works great -- I mounted the drive, inserted the caddy, and instantly had SATA access to my drive. It has embedded set screws that mount into the hard drive to keep it securely in place.

A couple minor cons:
(1) There is NO BEZEL on the outside of the unit to make it form up with the curved outside of the laptop. This doesn't really bother me, but it might annoy most people.

(2) There is no handle or mechanism to hold the caddy in the laptop chassis similar to the push-to-eject handle on the DVD unit. This means (a) you will not be able to pull the drive caddy out, and (b) there's nothing stopping it from falling out if you give the laptop a good jolt while it was vertical. I solved this problem by dismounting the push-to-eject handle from the DVD unit and attaching it to the new caddy. This has a locking mechanism in it to keep the hard drive locked in and allows me to pull it out. It also leaves the DVD with a small gap that I can grab with my finger to pull the drive out. Problem solved.
output: Good, inexpensive way to add second hard drive to Dell Latitude E6520

Instances.input: I have been using this switch for over a year and it does exactly what I purchased it for. Allows me to use two computers with one monitor. I have different Operating systems on the two computers and with just a key stroke I can swap between computers.

Just like every other review for this SSD, and any other name brand SSD, the increase in speeds in fantastic. From Windows Experience Score 6.4 to 7.9 (max) in December 2013. Incredible shutdown speed, and restart speed. You might miss the login/logo screen, its that fast. Today's SSD's are reliable, and will outlast normal hard drives. Today's SSD's have been put through equivalent stress tests of over 20 gig a day for 20+ years and they have not worn out. Their failure is more likely a result of a mechanical problem, of which a normal hard disk drives are far more susceptible to.

To be honest, the difference in speed between this SSD, and other competitors is something that would be difficult for a human to discern. What is the practical 50 mb/s difference in speed, when you are comparing against other 400-500 mb/s ssd's? Maybe half a second on start-up?

What makes this SSD from Samsung a great buy, is the included software, whether or not you have the desktop kit, that is included. You get migration software, and a SD set-up and monitoring software. This software exceeds the software provided by Intel for their SSD, and other manufacturers sometimes does not include any software, or provides for download a limited use software.

If you are building a system, check out computer cases with built in 2.5 drive bays, and cases with built-in SSD mounts like [[ASIN:B006TVQTHW Antec Three Hundred Two Gaming Case, Black]]. This case has two mounting platforms just for SSD's, one behind the motherboard, and the other on the floor of the case (SSDs will not require cooling). This setup does not use any of the bays. I purchased this case, and like it, but have not reviewed it yet.

The Samsung Magician Software provides a user interface for the following tasks, which as as simple as clicking through. This software makes the Samsung SSD the best buy, when compared to similarly priced SSD's, or even similar capacity SSD's.

PERFORMANCE BENCHMARKING. Benchmark the SSD, and keep a history of benchmarks. Compare them in graphs. Not just this SSD, but any of the drives in your system.

PERFORMANCE OPTIMIZATION. Optimize Performance if your current OS does not use TRIM

FIRMWARE UPDATES

OS OPTIMIZATION. Optimize Windows. Easily choose three profiles; Maximum Performance, Maximum Capacity, or Maximum Reliability, and the Samsung Magician software will automatically make the associated settings on the SSD and in Windows. You can also make your own customized profile.

OVER PROVISIONING. SSD need over-provisioning to maintain performance and reliability. Some SSD's like Kingston will not need Over Provisioning, but will require that you have unused space for the benefits of Over Provisioning. The Samsung Magician Software give you a recommended amount, and will unallocate the space for you.

SECURE ERASE, if you ever needed to secure erase the SSD. I'll be honest, I don't use it, but I believe that SSD's have a difference procedure than disc drives.

RAPID MODE. Samsung has a mode that can accelerate the SSD even more. But I have read that this acceleration can only be used in certain circumstances. It will require a gig of space to be enabled

DATA SECURITY: Data security can be enabled.

This is an endurance test of Samsung 840 SSDs. And, it is a conservative test. [...].

Instances.input:
Initial Review: I purchased this for an HP Slimline 5000 series computer. I just installed it and so far it is working well and is surprisingly quiet. However, I must note for anyone considering purchasing this PSU that it is not an exact replacement for the OEM PSU. The dimensions are exactly the same as the OEM PSU, but the connectors are different. The OEM PSU has a 1 x 24 pin, 1 x 4 pin, and 2 x Sata (one per chain) that is all. This PSU has 1 x 24 pin, 1 x 4 pin, 2 x 4 pin Molex (on the same chain), and 2 x Sata (on the same chain). The problem with this setup is that there is not enough length between sata connectors as there are 2 connectors on one chain. Since both the HD and DVDrom use sata power, I needed to use a molex to sata converter to ensure I had power to both.

I will update this review if I encounter any performance issues.
output: 300W TFX Power Supply - HP Slimline S5000 Replacement

Instances.input:
I just got this monitor, so these are my initial impressions. The picture quality is solid and I'm pleased with this purchase. I love Samsung monitors, including this one. An awesome feature on this one is the ability to rotate it 90 degrees, but for some silly reason, you can't do so with the base this monitor comes with. You will need to find some other way to mount this monitor in order to take advantage of this feature.

There were several other things that were a little silly:
- The base feels a bit flimsy and took me a while to figure out how to assemble. The diagrams were not particularly helpful, but after 15 or so minutes it finally came together. (Go ahead and laugh. I probably deserve it!)
- The buttons used to adjust the picture settings are conveniently located on the front of the monitor. This is a pleasant change from Samsung's usual habit of placing them out of sight on the side of my other monitors. However, the buttons take a significant amount of force to press, and the entire monitor moves when you do. This makes for a very unsatisfying experience when adjusting brightness, etc. I find myself using my other hand to steady the monitor when making adjustments.
- The power and video cables are on the short side (I'm guessing 6 feet). I couldn't put the monitor where I wanted it and ended up having to rearrange my desk to make it work out of the box.

All of that aside, I would recommend this monitor overall. It is visually appealing and I'm very happy to give it a place on my desk, especially given the price and the fact that it's 1920 x 1200.
output: Controls are a little goofy, but overall is worth the money

I have been on the technology freak, power user, Software Engineer for industry for over 25 years and After a lot of research on an affordable Diskless NAS, this came on top.

It has the perfect price point for the hardware inside. You get pretty much all you will get for a more expensive NAS like a Netgear or a Seagate but better.

PERFORMANCE
80+ MB/s

CPU
1.2 GHZ Dual Issue Arm

MEMORY
512 MB DDR3

INTERNAL HARD DRIVES
Number of Bays: 4 Empty Bays
Drive Interface: SATA 6 Gbps
Supported RAID: 0/1/5/10/JBOD (Individual Disks)
RAID only supported when 2 or more HDDs are inserted

LAN INTERFACE
Number of Ports: 1
Data Transfer Rates: 10/100/1000 Mbps
Supported Protocols: TCP/IP
Network File Services: CIFS/SMB, AFP, HTTP/HTTPS, FTP/FTPS
Connector Type: RJ-45

USB INTERFACE
Standard Compliance: USB 3.0 / 2.0
Connector Type: A type
Number of Ports: 2 x USB 3.0, 1 x USB 2.0
Data Transfer Rates: 5 Gbps (USB 3.0), 480 Mbps (USB 2.0)

Work as expected :-)

NOTE: Keep in mind that read and write performance can be affected by many factors, but mainly if you use cheap Hard Drives. For NAS drives I recommend you get at least Western Digital RED series drives.

http://www.amazon.com/WD-Red-NAS-Hard-Drive/dp/B008JJLW4M/ref=sr_1_1?s=electronics&ie=UTF8&qid=1417757476&sr=1-1&keywords=western+digital+red
output: Best 4 Bay Diskless NAS out there at the moment at this price point.

I purchased these speakers 2 years ago on a college student's budget, and they have served me very well. I use them for everything from music to movies and games.

I have worked as a theater sound designer and am currently with a home audio company; I'm not an expert by any means, but I do like good audio. These speakers may have a few flaws, but I would say, for the price - $50 a that time - you would be hard pressed to find a better setup.

This product is just awful.   I bought it to replace a broken charger and not even one month later this one is broken too.  The piece that plugs into the laptop just broke off.  It looks like was made very cheaply.

If you're like me you're always swapping out your laptop's hard drive for something faster or larger or both. What you end up having is a bunch of old, very usable drives sitting around doing nothing when you could be using them to store your music or photos or keeping your system backed up.

This little device lets you slip any 2.5-inch drive inside and make it an external USB drive. I love the fact that this case does not require any tools to put it together or take it apart. It is truly a snap to use as the top slips easily off and the drive easily connects or disconnects from the port inside the case.

The case utilizes USB 3.0 speeds which give quite a boost over USB 2.0. In a very unscientific test I loaded up a SSD in the case and copied over a large video file over both USB 3.0 and USB 2.0 ports. On the USB 3.0 ports I averaged about 105 MB/s and over the USB 2.0 ports I averaged about 37 MB/s.

The USB cable provides the power for the drive so there is no need for an external power cable so that is nice. If you're using some non-powered hubs I'm guessing the unit might not operate but it worked perfectly in both of my powered USB hubs.

The case comes with a small USB 3.0 cable and has worked with other USB 3.0 cables I've tested.

Overall this is a well built and easy to operate enclosure for any 2.5-inch drive. Highly recommended.

Sample provided for review.
output: Well Built External Enclosure Delivers On USB 3.0 Speeds

This travel wireless was impressive because it 'just worked', 'out of the box'. Flip it over, the unit's wireless name and password are printed on the bottom. You do not need a computer to set it up.

Having said that, you do need to purchase a short ethernet cable to go along with this item.

I give this 4 starts because there are two places where it could be easily improved.
(1) The power cable is bulky. It would be nice if it had those flip-out pegs so that it was more compact to travel.
(2) A built in 6\\" ethernet cord would also be nice.
(3) Given that the power cable is bulky and you need to have an ethernet cord, the carrying case that comes with this is too small.

Having said these critiques, I would definitely buy this item again.

Overall this tablet is a solid 3 star performer with a balance of strengths and weaknesses. Lets start with what I like. It has a strong Internet connection thanks to its dual antennas I assume. All I know is that there are certain spots in my house where my phone and laptop don't catch my wireless signal and the kindle does so that's a strong point for me. Good app selection and integration with amazon products and services. The screen is as bright and vivid as any tablet out there, it is solidly built and just the right size in my opinion. Speakers are above average and battery life is pretty decent as well. Here are some of the cons. First, no dual cameras and while it has the basic functionality of an iPad its just not arranged the same way, it's just not as intuitive or customizable as an iPad or other android tablet especially with regards to the home screen. The carousel is nice but I'm so used to my iPhone and iPad layout it just doesn't work for me although I'm sure there's an app for that. The ipad layout just makes everything faster and streamlined. It shouldnt take more than one step to get to the internet, or your favorite apps, etc. One really annoying thing is the ads on the startup screen. If you're gonna try and lower the price by forcing ads on us and not including a basic USB dc charger that literally costs you 39 cents then i think the price should be even lower than what it is. Overall a nice attempt, like I said, some good, some not so good. 3 stars overall.

This thing can be do everything. NAS? Done. SAN? Done. FTP, FTPS, SFTP? Of course. Thin provisioning? Not a problem. Data replication? ..as if you had to ask.

This is an amazing all-in-one unit that is currently only being used for block-level iSCSI connections. Performance easily saturates 1Gbps connections, so we're going to bond the channels shortly (which it supports wonderfully).

If you need some storage for development vmware environments, this has the grunt to get it done. It's also awesome as an FTP/FTPS/SFTP server as well as just a great unit to throw your backups on to. The price is amazing for what you get, and I can't think of any downsides. Pair it with some WD RE4 drives and what it FLY.
