Instances.input:
This is an odd little product that seems to have a very limited audience. Too bad because for that it's an expensive toy. For the most part, it duplicates what an iPhone or iPad can already do. The manufacturer seems to play up the capability of using it for two-camera shoots. Like I said, the market is pretty specialized.

There are a few good semi-technical reviews on this so I won't just repeat them verbatim, but rather add a few observations of my own.

It's nice that the hard case turns into a little monopod and that it can actually be used on a real standard tripod. It's not nice that the camera swivels on a little magnet attached to the case ... but it's far to easy to bump it and knock the camera off. It doesn't appear to be capable of withstanding a few falls to a hard surface like pavement.

The little light is nice but you better be very close to your subject, otherwise it's just not bright enough. It's nice that it's wireless but I wouldn't think of it as a sport cam. And the camera itself is surprisingly heavy for what it is.

There were a few reviews bemoaning the fact that the camera is useless with a PC or Android product. To be fair, that fact is stated clearly so if someone does not have a compatible product, they shouldn't buy this cam. That being said, I think Logitech is living in an unrealistic world by making this thing 100% incompatible with anything but Mac products ... virtually all hardware is multi-platform anymore and in the real world by far the highest percentage of people own multi-brands. I can see (for technical reasons) why functionality might be limited, but it makes no sense to not even be able to plug the USB into a PC and use it as a webcam. And WiFi is WiFi ... the signal should be receivable by ANY product that can pick up a WiFi signal. People want to carry smaller and LESS stuff with them, not larger and MORE stuff. The logic of making it 100% incompatible makes as much sense is not being able to use tires made for a Chevy on a Ford.being able to use tires made for a Chevy on a Ford.

I was a little careless when applying this screen protector and noticed, after 8 hours, that I had left some small bubbles under the skin (by this time it was too late to squeegee them out). After 24 hours all had disappeared but one -- right in the center of the screen, it was the largest of the bubbles that had been left behind and I thought I had ruined my new tablet. I put the tablet down and didn't get back to it for a few days but when I did I was extremely surprised, the bubble had disappeared and I was left with an amazingly clear view of my new tablet's screen.

I would recommend watching the application video and take your time, you will not be disappointed in the end results!

Case Logic is a strong brand in the \\"case\\" market and continues to provide quality products with this attache. The iPad case is extremely sturdy, well-built, and provides enough room and pockets for all a commuter or travelers basic needs.     It easily fits the iPad and iPad2. The case contains two primary pockets: the slimmer 'back' pocket is for the iPad itself, and the larger 'front' pocket contains banded knit netting to hold your iPad peripherals. The marketing materials promote that the larger of the netting pockets holds a portable keyboard and is configured to act as the actual workspace for the keyboard with attached iPad. The netted pockets are large and flexible enough to hold an iPad charger, cord as well as keys, work ID badge or any other commuting carry-arounds.    The bag is small which is both good and bad. It's light, fits comfortably over the shoulder with the extended shoulder strap, and has two smaller handles if the carrier prefers. The nylon case is strong and should protect all items during the course of normal wear, tear and banging around. The inside is also well-padded.    I commute about an hour to and from work each day. I'll easily be able to bring back and forth my iPad, a book, and additional basics. I'll need a larger bag when I need to schlep my laptop. This iPad bag is a little bulky to fit into my larger commuting backpack. It'll fit, but it'll add bulk.    It's made to serve as a stand alone carry-around bag for your iPad and essentials. In that context, it's perfect.
output: The Perfect Carry-Along iPad Case for Travelers and Commuters

I am a trackball fan from way back since I was first introduced to them by my physical therapist after having a shoulder operation that made moving my arm next to impossible. I find moving a mouse around a desk both clumsy and unnatural and just don't understand how people can accept them. This is my third trackball from Logitech and it is by far the best one I have had.(I gave the old ones to friends or family who are now converts to the trackball way!) It took a little while to get used to having the ball on the left side as opposed to the standard center position, but once I got used to using my thumb, things really flew. Set up was snap and the documentation was great. The design is very comfortable and the buttons and scroll wheel fall easily to hand. It has operated flawlessly for the year+ that I have owned it and I have only had to change the battery once in that time. The cordless feature works great and is a real boon to me because of my cluttered desk. Its RF signal does not interfere with my other IR controlled equipment(i.e. stereo and cordless keyboard). My only quibbles with this trackball (and the reason I gave it 4 stars instead of 5) is that it needs a greater range and they need to use ball bearings in the ball seat like their other trackballs. Right now I have to have the reciever within a foot or so of the trackball to work consistantly and it would be much more convenient if I could stick it someplace out of the way. Using ball bearings instead of the current nylon mounts in the ball seat would give the ball the super smooth action that their other trackballs have had and that I'm used to. In the end, I would certainly recommend this to anyone looking to make their computing a more pleasurable experience, but be warned...trackballs can be addictive!

Instances.input:
I'm not a huge fan of wireless devices in general. I don't like replacing batteries and don't like the potential for interference.

With that said, generally I've been quite surprisingly satisfied with the Logitech diNovo Keyboard for Notebooks. First, I have to say I am a fan of the elegant and simple design. It's relatively rectangular, but the edges are curved in a nice, subtle way. The angle of the keyboard is nice, in my experience, and the black/brushed aluminum look is appealing to me. I also don't like the touchpads that tend to get integrated into wireless keyboards--I prefer a full mouse (if a small one) to go on the side of my keyboard.

More importantly than that, the keyboard's functionality is nice. I like the responsiveness of the keys. They are rounded in a way that feels good to the touch, and they have a good amount of springiness and resistance to the keystroke. I've had little input lag or error, except when typing from an excessively far distance--most normal constraints would be fine for this device.

I can't say I use this keyboard everyday, but I do wish battery life was a bit better. I couldn't give a great estimate, but part of the reason I find myself wanting more is because even after periods of little to no use, sometimes I find the batteries die quickly. However this could also be attributed to using my rechargeable batteries, which may not exactly be new.

Finally, one nice touch, for me, is the inclusion of the side numpad. It's not something I absolutely need, but I enjoy having it. Using a laptop, the numpad gives additional options. Using a desktop, it replicates functionality better as a result of the numpad. I don't make a habit of using the media/app keys, but they function as advertised and I haven't had any trouble with them.

With all that said, if the only issue is replacing some rechargeable AAA batteries now and then, it's a pretty solid device, in my opinion. The battery issue isn't a huge one--I still get plenty of life out of it. I just always find myself wishing for a LITTLE BIT more. I can't say what consistent use as a primary keyboard would do to the battery life, but I expect it would be sufficient enough.

Overall, a really great wireless device. I'm very happy with my purchase, even long after the initial purchase. I haven't found any other keyboards that match simplicity, style, and functionality with the diNovo for Notebooks.plenty of life out of it. I just always find myself wishing for a LITTLE BIT more. I can't say what consistent use as a primary keyboard would do to the battery life, but I expect it would be sufficient enough. Overall, a really great wireless device. I'm very happy with my purchase, even long after the initial purchase. I haven't found any other keyboards that match simplicity, style, and functionality with the diNovo for Notebooks.

Upon receiving this product I was a little apprehensive right when I took the case out of the box. I was unsure as to the cover over the volume buttons, home button, etc. and the screen protector. However, after using the case for more than a week, I was more than convinced of its versatility. The covers over the various buttons are extremely user friendly and do not inhibit the use of your iPad. The screen protector is also very responsive. For someone who uses an iPhone without a case or cover, the screen protector was hardly noticeable. The unit is very well put together. The case is strong and the keyboard feels like a regular laptop keyboard. My favorite feature is the ability to detach the entire iPad from the keyboard. This allows the user to use the iPad on its own, and allows for much more freedom. The case allows for many different angles, either in landscape or portrait mode. Further, the case "locks into" portrait or landscape method so it does not swivel back and forth. Overall, this case goes along way into converting the iPad into lite laptop, while maintaining the iPad's utility by allowing detachment from the keyboard.

This is definitely fast enough for the Canon SD camera I use with it. The pictures transfer over to the card very fast and it holds a ton of images at 8GB. I've used Sandisk, Kingston, and all the higher end \\"models\\", but this Class 6 ranks right up there with all the others - at a fraction of the cost.

Gotta say, - I`m totally underwhelmed by this thing.
I bought this to increase my wifi range and because I had an increasing number of wifi enabled items in the house - PC`s (3) printer, 2 androids, kindle, ipad, ipod touch etc, etc.
I DJ over the internet and was attrracted to the QOS settings that (on paper) would allocate best bandwidth to the broadcast stream.
On the old BT router , I had NO problems with streaming despite the lack of any QOS.
With this router, - I have to turn off EVERY SINGLE wifi enabled item, turn OFF the QOS, and drop my bitrate from a normal setting of 320bps right down to 64bps in order to stay connected to the server at all.
EVEN THEN, it still buffers like crazy and intermittently disconnects. (and thats even through a WIRED connection (ethernet)) - the wifi won`t even stay connected.
(yes , its configured correctly).

That`s just Pants IMO.

Its going back tomorrow and I won`t be getting another one.

BTW - I reconnected the BT hub - and its just fine.

Edit:- was persuaded to swap it for another, testing now with Cat 6 cables thrown in from seller. will update when I have soak tested it for a while.

I'm at a total loss...because Amazon claims the list price is $29.00, and that their price of $13.22 saves you $15.74

But. That's. Just. Wrong.

Directly from Apple, this handy adapter is only $9.99, certainly NOT 3 times that like the $29 Amazon claims.

Ugh. The situation is both confounding and disappointing.

The product, possibly the cheapest Android ICS 7\\" tablet on the market at <$100, performs as expected. If you want to watch Netflix movies or read web pages or play silly Android games on a screen larger than a cell phone but smaller than an iPad, it is excellent. It is not a communications-oriented device, it is a media player. When purchased, the lack of cameras was a given. The lack of a video cable (it is advertised to have 1080P video output, right on the box), and a charge (power) indicator LED are serious faults that are not mentioned by most reviewers. A possible use for it is to entertain children less than 9 yrs old who don't need such things. For anyone else, there are FAR better 7\\" Android tablets for a bit more money.

But, I still love this!

I just bought the CD-ROM to minimize using my CD-RW drive for daily use, and installed on my DELL Dimension 4100 Pentium III 800MHZ.
My first impression was that this thing was little bit noisy...
Things looked just fine until I tried all different kinda of CDs in different format. The drive reads pretty much all the CDs such as regular audio CD, DirectCD(for CD-RW)... etc, but, does not read some of my kids games like Rugrats Activity game and CD-R format CD while my writiable CD drive(Sony CD-RW CRX140E)reads them just fine.
First, I thought it might not have the right driver, so there I was searching and searching web site after another, but could not find the "right" driver since it does not exist. Digital Research themselves say there is no need for any driver unless you are using DOS or Windows3.1. And MS says it is compatible with my OS which is Windows Me.
After a while, I found the little label on the box list of all the supported CD formats... And there it was. CD-R was not in the list. And I still don't know why my kids game can not be read from this thing.
These are the format they claim it supports. CD-ROM XA, CD-DA, CD-I/MPEG, Photo-CD, Karaoke CD, CD-Movie, I-TRAX CD, CD-RW, and CD Plus.(This was shock to me first since I didn't know there are all these different formats available out there).
Overall, I think the CD-ROM is pretty okay, but does not fit my need. I will have to decide which one to refund; the game or the CD-ROM, but my kid love the Rugrat game...

Update: I have changed my star rating due to the fact that returning the item was completely painless and Amazon covered the return shipping. Because I lost no money (maybe a little time) it is not fair to blast a product that has many great features, just not the one I needed. That being said, HooToo customer service was more than adequate and I appreciate solid customer service very much.
End of update

First off, I'm no tech at network setup. I have performed the task lots of times, successfully, and I am aware of what a WAN port is vs. a LAN port. However, and this may be where my lack of knowledge is a problem, I truly don't understand how you can advertise as having LAN features without a single LAN port. In my hope that \\"Lan features\\" meant LAN features, I assumed that, like other routers I have had, the one Ethernet port could serve as a WAN or a LAN depending on one's need. I have searched amazon reviews through and through, searched the rest of the Web and even re-read the very limited \\"pamphlet\\" or \\"sad excuse for a manual\\" more times than I care to admit. Still, no dice. I am returning this immediately for a wifi router that actually has LAN features.

I should add, that if I am incorrect in believing the one WAN port cannot be turned into a LAN port, then HooToo has made zero effort to explain how that is done.

In case anyone is wondering what I was going to use this for, I own a Behringer X32 Digital Mixer that has the option to connect a wireless router (one with actual LAN features btw) directly to the mixer via cat5 to then be controlled wirelessly by an iPad or iPhone. If you have any sort of similar need, this supposed \\"LAN featured wifi router\\" is lacking a very crucial component.....a flipping LAN port!
output: LAN features without a LAN port?  (At least not a LAN port for my needs)

I bought this for our 32GB 8.9" HDX to provide some protection to the glass. My son destroyed the glass on our iPad 3, so this was an absolute must for the Kindle. I wanted to buy a ballistic glass protector, but unfortunately wasn't able to find one for the HDX. After reading all the positive reviews, and the"self healing" ability, I decided to give this product a shot. I figured for the price it was worth taking a chance. Overall, I think this is a very nice product.

My ArmorSuit MilitaryShield arrived before my Kindle, so I was able to check it out before I committed. It was well packaged...no chance of receiving it damaged; thank you very much for that since that is not always the case with orders purchased from Amazon.

ArmorSuit MilitaryShield was rolled onto a self adhesive backing. It came with a cleaning cloth, a plastic squeegee, cleaning/application solution, and most importantly instructions. The instructions were printed on a large paper. The instructions were well written and easy to understand. For the mechanically or technically challenged, the instructions even direct you to their YouTube page to show you a detailed installation of this shield.

When my Kindle came in, I immediately installed the shield. Here is my experience:

The most important part of this installation is to clean your hands and your Kindle. You cannot get good results without doing this. It's that simple. Having prior experience installing window tint professionally made this installation familiar.

After cleaning my hands and the Kindle, I liberally sprayed my hands and protector with the solution. Once both are wet, I began installing the film from left to right, squeegeeing as I went. It's important that you keep the film close to the glass as possible when installing and squeegee when you apply to glass.

Once that's done, you may or may not have bubbles. If you do, then saturate thefilm with spray and squeegee outwards. As you get to the edges, use the included cleaning cloth to absorb the liquid from under the film. Do this until all bubbles are removed. It's extremely important that you keep the film wet during this process, or you chance scratching film. If you find any creases on your film, remove film and start again making sure you keep the film wet.

Once you are done getting the bubbles out place your Kindle on a flat surface for up to 48 hours to dry. During this drying period, the imperfections will go away. Here is where I made a mistake. After a few hours I took a look at it, and it looked like crap! So I removed the film and reinstalled. If you do this, you will most likely run out of solution. If you do, you can use a high quality cleaner you would use to clean your glasses. I reinstalled the film and it went on good again. I checked on it a few hours later, and it still looked terrible! It looked as if there was dust or dirt under the film. This time, I let it sit for the recommended 48 hours and wow! The imperfections completely disappeared!

The glass looks really good. I'm not sure if I lost any resolution with this film, but it looks fine to me. My brother was over on Christmas and was playing with my Kindle and didn't even notice there was any film on the screen, which is great since he hates these protectors.

I do agree that it is difficult to tell that there is film on my Kindle. But if you start looking at the screen at different angles, you can see the imperfections in the film itself, not the installation. These imperfections resemble scratches, but they aren't. Because of this, I question if this actually "self heals" like advertised. As for fingerprints, it doesn't appear to really make a difference. But that's fine by me, since that is not why I bought this.

I am on the fence regarding the feel of the film. It me feels weird to me. It's probably just me regarding the feel. Regarding screen sensitivity, I do no notice any loss due to using this protector.

Unless I see a high quality ballistic glass for an affordable price, I would certainly use this again. The price is very fair for what they are providing. They were a pleasure doing business with. And they followed up to make certain I was happy with my purchase.
output: Very nice for the price, but not perfect

Instances.input: I recently upgraded my Kindle reader from my Paper White First Generation, to the new Voyage #G. I had decide to do this after reading the specs for the new better lighting and especially more important for me, the 300 pip  page resolution. I was not disappointed as I find both features help me read better with less eyestrain than I had before. The Processor is much faster and the response to menu tap commands is may times faster them my old device. My old Paper White may have been getting older anyhow or I have to many titles stored on the device for the processor to work. ?  I definitely love the weight reduction- a very big difference that you feel as you compare both in your hands. At first I was skeptical about the new cover design which I did buy (the Amazon leather cover for Voyage). But I realized much later on that flipping the cover up over the top makes holding and reading the Kindle much more comfortable than on the older cover for Paper White. I recommend the leather cover. It really nice and soft.

I hardly ever write reviews but I am so upset with how things have gone with this Kindle I felt like I had to. I got my first one in December and it worked perfectly for about two months and then all of a sudden the battery started dying literally within hours of charging it. I tried turning off the wi-fi, updating the software etc and the problem persisted. It also would freeze almost daily which is annoying. So I called customers service, the first person I spoke to said he didn't know what was wrong with it and would call me back. I never heard from him again, although he did email me a survey after not solving my issue to ask me how he did?! I tried calling again later on and the next person sent me a new Kindle in the mail and I returned the old one. It took me an entire evening of messing around with the new one to get it to set up. This included it freezing repeatedly, not recognizing any wifi networks and then randomly all of a sudden recognizing them but not accepting my password but then after 20 minutes on the phone with technical support it suddenly decided to accept my password followed by freezing and having to restart it.

All in all, it's a great ereader if you can actually get it to work. I still had faith in it when the first one I got didn't work figuring it was a fluke. When I got my second one and that didn't work either I'm starting to think that this is a piece of junk and you should probably avoid it.
output: Gone through two in less than a year and neither one worked

Instances.input: as posted

I needed this because the mountable devices in our office are full-size, and we wanted to mount to a wall. Most wall-mount racks aren't deep enough to support full-size gear, and are just meant for shallow/low-profile devices (and despite a device's stated dimensions, you'll usually need even more depth to accommodate the power plug in the back of most).

Luckily I found this, after much searching, which supports everything we have. Our largest devices are a 48-port D-Link switch and a 48-port Netgear switch, which fit with the rack adjusted to its maximum depth.

I was impressed with the quality. It's a very sturdy, solid rack (and heavy); even though it's adjustable, which had me a little doubtful when I ordered. But after 6 months, with plenty of wire manipulation, it shows no signs of weakness, and stands there like a rock.

This model (RK812WALLOA) has an adjustable depth (RK812WALLO is the non-adjustable version). The adjustment isn't simple, though -- it's meant to be done one time at installation, requiring complete removal of 8 bolts. The rack is still completely sturdy even when fully extended.

Installation is fairly painless, but a bit more time-consuming than I anticipated. You'll want a second person to help. The thing is heavy, and chances are you'll need to mark/drill holes; even once that's done, you'll want to have one person hold it up while the other screws it in.

- Beware this doesn't come with hardware to mount it to the wall. I used drywall screws with plastic anchors, and that seems to have worked out well.

- This also doesn't come with enough nuts if, for example, you're planning to fill up the rack with 1U devices. It actually only comes with enough nuts to mount 2 or 3 devices (I was disappointed to find this out, as the specs don't mention the number of included nuts). I ordered [[ASIN:B00009XT0G StarTech.com 50 Pack M5 Cage Nuts for Server Rack Cabinets CABCAGENUTS]] since we needed to mount more than that.

In the end I'm more than satisfied. It's a quality product.needed to mount more than that.

In the end I'm more than satisfied. It's a quality product.

Instances.input:
The LAP PRO universal tablet stand doesn't work very well with my Kindle Fire HD 8.9\\" Wi-Fi tablet. The stand consists of a very firm, 18-inch wide, cylindrical pillow with a soft handle that doubles as a sort of tray for the tablet. Because there is no frame to hold the tablet securely, the tablet must be set carefully into the handle-tray, and then the tablet simply leans against the pillow for support. However, the tablet is very easily dislodged from the tray, even when the stand is sitting on a flat tabletop.

Out of the box, the LAP PRO holds the 8.9\\" Kindle Fire HD tablet at a near-vertical angle that is uncomfortable for viewing or for using a stylus on the touch screen. There is a sheet packed with the pillow that says: \\"Your LAP PRO has come slightly over filled intentionally, which may interfere with some functions. This will change in time. This is to ensure it will perform properly and last longer after it breaks in. The fabric will stretch and the beans settle from use.\\" However, this is not really a beanbag stand. The pillow is filled with something that feels like medium-fine sand (not beans). Also, the pillow is too firm to accommodate its shape to an uneven surface the way a beanbag does.

To adjust the tablet viewing angle, you must reshape the pillow--it isn't enough to simply roll the pillow forward or backwards. Because the pillow is so firm, you must exert some effort in reshaping. It is easier to adjust the pillow shape and the viewing angle if you unzip the zipper that runs alongside the handle-tray, but then the pillow kind of flops around. (The zipper is there to open and close a compartment that is probably intended to hold your tablet, because the LAP PRO is also supposed to be a \\"caddy\\".)

If I needed a travel pillow (another of the LAP PRO's advertised uses) or a tablet caddy, I might end up liking the LAP PRO. However, because the stand is too large for convenient tabletop use, is hard to adjust, doesn't hold the tablet securely, and needs break-in time, I rate it at 2 stars (\\"I don't like it\\" on the official Amazon scale).

EDITED 11/18/12: After hearing from the seller, Renegade Concepts, I believe that I may have received an overfilled LAP PRO. (Renegade Concepts offered to replace my unit.) If my LAP PRO had been less firm out of the box, I would have rated it at 3 stars (\\"It's OK\\").just, doesn't hold the tablet securely, and needs break-in time, I rate it at 2 stars (\\"I don't like it\\" on the official Amazon scale).

EDITED 11/18/12: After hearing from the seller, Renegade Concepts, I believe that I may have received an overfilled LAP PRO. (Renegade Concepts offered to replace my unit.) If my LAP PRO had been less firm out of the box, I would have rated it at 3 stars (\\"It's OK\\").
output: A Pillow, Not Really an Adjustable Tablet Stand

I went from 300 watts to 700 watts because I am going to be getting a beefy video card. My main concern was the noise level for this power supply since the wattage is obviously being bumped up 400 watts. Install was easy and when it fired up, it was as quiet as the 300 watt power supply, maybe even quieter! Beyond happy and will highly recommend this power supply to others!

EDIT - Going on 6 weeks and still quiet.

TIP FOR THOSE WHO SAY THIS CARD IS LOUD: Make sure you have the power supply fan pointed to the vents going OUTSIDE the case. If the psu is mounted at the top, point it up. If it's bottom mounted, point it down. Regardless, your case should have a vent area at the top or bottom that gives the psu fan capability to intake air...if that's blocked, you bet it's going to get loud and it will get loud quick! The fan should NOT be pointed into the case because it will compete with other fans and suck in heat. Just an FYI

This is the third Republic of gamers laptop i owned, and i gotta say ASUS is the best, i've never have any problem with their products. I update my laptop every 1 year and half or so, by that i mean i sell my current laptop and buy the lastest i can affort. I can tell the other 2 laptops from asus i sold still working perfectly not a single issue. Some people may think im an ASUS fanboy but i do some research before buying if i can find a laptop with better hardware for a lower price i might go with another brand. For example i see a lenovo with the same specs for about $1000, i bought this one for $1200 mainly because i know its a trusted brand and the cooling system is very good and very very silent.

With this babe you can play the most recent games at decent settings here some examples of some games i tested:

No Vsyng or AA in any of the games above.

Dota 2 1080p max settings = 40-65 fps
Medal of honor Warfighter 1080p max settings = 27-33 fps
MaxPayne 3 1080p max settings = 35-40 fps
Far Cry 3 1080p custom settings everything on max except shadows on medium and posfxquality off = 26-34 fps

As long as i get 28 fps+ im happy.
For the record i have my gtx 660m OC @ +100, +300. Max temp i've ever reach 81°.

In my case i dont like 17\\" laptops and my budged was $1200. So this laptop suite my needs. If you want a high end laptop, dont mind the size and have the money, go with alienware or clevo. Get a laptop with GTX 675M or GTX 680M (a beast).

I will update this review later because i have a lot more to test.

I needed to replace an old D-Link DIR-615 that I've had for while.  I was having more and more issues (such as connection consistency, wireless signal, etc, that could not be resolved) and finally decided to replace it with the DIR-825.  Several of the new features including the ability to setup a guest wireless are awesome.  In general I was having a much better experience with this router.  Unfortunately, the 2.4 wireless signal was worse than the old router, and the 5Ghz is a complete joke.  I would get zero to one bar of signal on the 5Ghz wireless in the next room, literally 10 feet from the router.  If I have to be in the same room as the router I might as well just run a cable to the device.  I returned the router and purchased the D-Link DIR-655.  The DIR-655 is probably the best wireless router I've owned.  I personally would recommend getting the DIR-655 over the DIR-825 any day.

I have a home recording studio that's been in need of some upgrades, so when I saw the TABRM086, I got a brilliant idea. When I'm reading scripts, I find that using my Surface RT tablet is much easier than trying to read from the regular monitor, and I could not for the life of me find an easy way to keep it near eye level. Sure, I can hold the Surface in my hand, but for long scripts, that just isn't feasible. I needed something to hold my tablet for me!

The TABRM086 couldn't be any more perfect as a tablet holder for my particular situation. Setup only took a few minutes. The only hitch was that I had to adjust the width of the c-clamp. If your mounting area isn't particularly thick, make sure to have a Phillips screwdriver ready, like I did! As for putting everything together, it really couldn't have been much easier: Choose the right size arms on the spring-loaded tablet holder [4 short ones, if you're using a Surface RT, like me], clamp the mount, adjust the arm, attach the holder, insert tablet. The arm is EXACTLY the right length for where I put it. I had concerns that the clamp might slide down while I was recording, but it's been holding strong for a few sessions now and hasn't budged a bit! Now doing silly voices is a much more comfortable experience!

So, in summary: If you're in need of a tablet c-clamp style mount, this is a great choice!
output: Perfect mount for my home recording studio!

Instances.input:
First off, I can't say anything about the ability of this device to protect against surges b/c I haven't done any tests on it. However, if you believe the specs (and it seems like the Tripp Lite ones are more honest and thorough than most other brands), it provides a good deal of protection for a surge protector/suppressor in this price range.

I chose this particular model because of the many positive reviews on other models. My first and only experience with Tripp Lite was back in 2000. The surge protector worked well and provided a good user experience in that it's fairly easy to push the plugs in and pull them out and has 3 useful indicator lights. Also, the plastic has a good feel to it. I'm still using it today. I'm glad to see the reviews for Tripp Lite's other products are generally good. Also, if you spend as much time as I did, the positive reviews seem to be based more off of substance/experience than just subjective guesses.

Well, my next step was to look up the specs. The Tripp Lite website was very thorough. At one point, I was down to three Belkin surge protectors and 3 Tripp Lite ones. The Tripp LIte website had all the technical info I was looking for while the Belkin website was lacking in specification details. Go read up on what's important when looking to buy a surge protector (e.g., energy absorption; clamping voltage; response time, etc.) and you'll care more about the specs. Amazon's product descriptions lack these details and that's okay, but it's not okay for the mfr's website to lack this detail. So, I decided to go with the Tripp LIte products. Oh, Tripp Lite keeps advertising the # of transformers. It does matter b/c in some other brands/models, some plugs are disabled and will not allow for use of all the plugs. Read some of the bad reviews on the other products if you don't believe me.

Now it's time to choose the model I want. Originally, I was going to go with the Tripp Lite TLP810SAT's sister product that comes with an ethernet line connector instead of the coaxial connector. However, once I figured out that I'll never use ethernet surge suppression b/c this is for residential use and that I have FiOS, which uses a coaxial cable connection, I decided to go with this model. Also, don't be misled that all coaxial cable connections are the same. Only one set of coaxial cable connections on this surge protector is specifically designed for high bandwidth broadband use (see the Tripp Lite website and compare the specs for different models). If I only had cable internet, I wouldn't have cared so much, but because I have a FiOS connection, I decided not to take the chance. Also, for a few dollars more than the other version, I don't see any reason to pass up on this model. Finally, if I did end up having FiOS and some other connection that requires a coaxial cable, I'm all set. So, I rather pay a little more for this model than the other model that has an ethernet connection that I'll never use.

Now for the negative. The packaging had a little wrinkling in it, while the box it shipped in was okay. Also, there's no way to tell if this thing is new or used b/c the packaging is not sealed. One or two of the plug covers were in the open position as well. It's annoying that I don't know for sure if I received a brand new product, but it does have a lifetime warranty, so it's not really a big concern. Overall, I'm fine with this product.

UPDATE JAN 2012: I'm not sure when the change happened, but Tripp Lite's website now says that both sets of coaxial plugs are now \\"2 Sets 2.2GHz gold coax jacks\\" and \\"2 line (2.2 GHz Bandwidth)\\". It's implied in the Amazon manufacturer description as well. Looks like they either upgraded the other set of coax jacks or found out that it is good enough to meet the 2.2 GHz bandwidth advertisement. Note that in the version I bought, one set of coaxial plugs is labeled \\"DSS Protection\\" while the other set is \\"Cable/Antenna Protection\\". Note that I bought my first one of these in mid-2009 and a second one in April 2010. Both are still working well and so is the other Tripp Lite model I bought in 2000.e in mid-2009 and a second one in April 2010. Both are still working well and so is the other Tripp Lite model I bought in 2000.
output: Plugs and Features are What Made Me Buy This

Instances.input:
I bought this drive to replace the Windows install drive in my laptop that had two 500gb mechanical drives. I'm extremely happy with this purchase for a few reasons:

Installation was easy.
It bolts in like any other harddrive. My biggest problem was that the two harddrive bays in my laptop were unlabeled and I had to take a gamble on which one actually contained my install of windows. That's not Intel's fault, but it was the biggest problem with installing this drive. It came with a molex to sata power converter, a sata cable, a 2.5 to 3.5 converter tray, and all the screws I might have needed in desktop or laptop.

Migration was easy.
The Intel migration tools are nice and simple. All I had to do was install the tool and tell it to migrate. It even automagically found my new SSD as the destination and my windows install as the source. It restarted the computer into the transfer utility and did it all the appropriate moving and resizing to put my 500gb Windows 7 installation on the 180gb SSD. After that I had to change the boot priority of the drives to make my laptop boot to the SSD instead of my old mechanical one.

The drive is crazy fast.
The speed of this drive is just silly. My computer boots and finishes loading all programs so fast that everything is loaded before my wifi adapter can connect to my network. This means I have the first world problem that Steam completely loads before there is internet connectivity and complains that it is offline. Copying files from one location to another on the drive happens at speeds so fast I don't feel the need to benchmark it. Booting up my laptop takes about 15 seconds because of my bios wait time and shutting down takes about two seconds.

Head parking sounds traded for an odd sound after standby.
I have noticed that my laptop makes a high pitched sound when coming out of standby. It lasts about three seconds and goes away. I think there's something that thesoundcard might be picking up from the drive. It's not too bad and only happens right after standby so I'm O.K. with it. I'm happy to trade the frequent sound of the mechanical drives parking their heads for a short sound that only happens after standby.

As an overall review I will say that Intel SSD drives will probably go into any new machine I build and recommendations I make to other people regarding builds.

This is a \\"cheap access point\\", in all possible interpretations of the phrase. Sure it's very inexpensive, but it has its quirks. None that can't be overcome, of course.
#1 - Setup
The physical installation is a snap. Plug in the cables and you're done. Installing and configuring with the USB configuration program was easy. But then you have to switch to the SNMP configuration tool if you want to use any of the more useful features like MAC authentication. Only problem: you need to assign it an IP address, which is hard for those of us that use public IP addresses, since you either waste a public IP or set up a private IP on a different mask and alias the configuring computer's interface to communicate with the private netmask. It's manageable for someone that does networking for a living, but certainly not for a typical consumer.
#2 - Signal Strength and Latency
I don't think this is as strong as most AP's. I can AdHoc between two cards across my apartment complex, but I only get very weak intermittent signals using the AP from the same location. While playing games such as WarCraft 3 over the WLAN, I often times get timeouts and lag, for something that only averages 20ms in ping times even if the cards are in good range with 80-90% signal.
#3 - SNMP
For a product that claims to be SNMP manageable, it certainly isn't SNMP compliant. It uses its own proprietary SNMP OID's and can't be used with typical management programs. On the good side, there's a Perl filter online for those interested in running MRTG for bandwidth usage graphs over this AP. VERY useful.
Overall, I would recommend this AP as it is very cheap and still useful for all my needs.

This modem works with time warner cable in NYC/manhattan. It's not on their approved device list - I called and they said they can't activate it because it's not supported but I begged the level 3 folks to push through the form and they did.

I called last Thursday and they said it would take 72 hours. Then I called on Wednesday (6 days later) and they said it would be another 48 hours. Then I called on Friday and they said it'd be another 24 hours... 5 minutes after I got off the phone with them the old modem stopped working and the new one started working. It should be noted that each of those 3 calls was over 45 minutes - virtually all on hold.
output: Works with Time warner in NYC!

Instances.input: I bought this as an inexpensive NAS option for backups for my parents' desktop and notebooks last Christmas and have had a frustrating experience trying to support it ever since, only recently discovering that the lack of NTFS support was the root of the problem.    The drive can be formatted with NTFS and used solely over the USB link, but network connectivity requires that the drive be formatted FAT32.  For those not technically inclined, FAT32 was introduced with Windows 98 and, although XP supports the filesystem, NTFS was brought to the home user with Windows XP Home Edition way back in 2001.  The main limitations of FAT32 compared to NTFS are the lack of security (FAT32 keeps no record of who or what owns a particular file), and it is incapable of handling individual files larger than 4 GiB, which normally wouldn't be a problem unless you were handling DVD images or, say, computer backups.    The last firmware released by Iomega for the drive introduces a non-standard kludge for manipulating files larger than 4 GiB over the network:  files are broken up on the actual drive, as visible through USB, but they are presented as single files over the LAN.  However, non-standard means exactly that, and there is no reason for any standards-compliant application (such as most backup software) to expect to be able to write anything larger than 4 GiB to the drive when it sees it is formatted with FAT32.      The upshot?  I tried Windows Live OneCare, which seems to work fine until the backup pool for a particular computer reaches the 4 GiB limit, at which point OneCare will be \\"unable to detect\\" the drive until you erase the existing backups and start over.  NTBACKUP (installable from the Windows XP Home Edition CD and included in the installation of Windows XP Professional) will back up directly to the drive until the result runs up against the 4 GiB barrier and start giving you write errors.  And most damningly, the drive cannot be used as backup media for Windows Vista's Backup and Restore at all:  without an NTFS drive, that program will generate errors attempting to ask for the password to an NTFS account that does not exist.      The one program I have not yet tried is the software included with this drive, but I haven't for a very good reason:  only one license is included.  Why one would want a hard drive with an ethernet port when one only needs to backup a single machine is beyond me.  And even if I did only need one computer backed up, I would use the USB port instead, formatting the drive with NTFS.    To sum up, NTFS can only be accessed via USB, the maximum filesize cludge in the latest firmware all but eliminates the use of the USB port when the drive is FAT32, and the included software is meaningless in a networked environment.  And I know of no technical reason why Iomega hasn't implemented NTFS through a firmware patch; the platter itself doesn't care and the Linux-based firmware should be more than capable.  The lack of standards compliance and plain-old common sense on Iomega's part here has turned me off of their company for the foreseeable future.      Personally, the real kicker is that I previously purchased a Western Digital MyBookWorld for my own needs, and wanted to avoid the bundled Mionet software, the unexplained calls back to their servers even when Mionet isn't used, and the collection of .TMP files that keep showing up in the root directory, when I shopped for a similar product for my parents.  WD may not do FTP, but at least it does NTFS.
output: Lack of NTFS renders useless as NAS

Instances.input: I was looking for a protective case for my surface pro, and found it here. I absolutely love the holder for the stylus pen and the case's ability to change the angle for screen viewing. It is definitely a "must have" accessory for this computer system.

Instances.input:
This case for iPad is fantastic for several reasons:
1. Nice quality leather that doesn't look scuffed up after limited use.
2. Magnets work perfectly to put iPad into sleep mode when case is closed.
3. Allows 2 viewing angles with notches that are deep enough to hold the iPad in place, unlike other cases.
4. Ability to rotate from landscape to portrait orientation (and stand up for viewing!) makes this case more functional.
5. Has an elastic strap for holding it closed.
6. The iPad snaps in securely and easily, without having a border that covers the edge of the iPad.

Highly recommend, its perfect.
output: Perfect. High Quality. Ability to rotate makes it so functional!

Instances.input: I've had my Kindle 3 (wifi) for a month now and love it.  Being the proud owner of an original Kindle and the purchaser of over 600 books for my Kindle, I clung to my Kindle 1 until enticed to the Kindle 3 by the wifi option (3G NEVER worked out here on the farm).  I am impressed with the new clarity of the script against the screen and with the lightness of the Kindle.  I'm also impressed with the Amazon service since my first Kindle3 had a defect and these guys got me a new one by overnight express...    One little complaint - I keep pressing the \\"back\\" button rather than the 5-way mouse....thought I'd get used to it, but hasn't happened.  Couldn't the 5-way mouse be the very bottom item? Also...wish the battery could be owner-replaced as in Kindle 1. (I guess that makes 2 little complaints)    Love the battery life and the dual USB/AC charger.  Love the graphite color - my Kindle 1 was the absolute dirtiest white when I laid it to rest.  Also love the Kindle for PC feature...    Keep the Kindle pure AMazon - don't turn it into a playtoy trying to meet everyone's wishes.  You're good at what you do, Kindle - keep it up.
output: Original Kindle Owner - Love my Kindle 3
